The constant traffic is from the near-by bus station where peope are always coming and going, often passing by my shop.  I am married with a two year old daughter, and with my income from the business I can provide good nourishment and medical care for my family.

My business is informal because I do not have my own store, but I do pay my taxes to the town, so I am able to keep my informal spot near the general market in Danli.  I sell cosmetics, chains, flowers, gifts, and other Ã­tems.  I also go directly to Tabacco Companies where most of the employees are women and would be interested in my products.  My wife and I run this business together, together we staff the booth, do the administrative details, and make decisions about what products we will invest in.

This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Sarah is married with 6 children and she is the bread winner. Her last born is disabled and attends special school which is expensive.

She started her business with USD 7.and has since expanded it by ploughing back part of her income. She has attended various business trainings offered by WEEC and this has enabled her to manage her small business.

This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Margaret is a single lady with two children. She has educated them up to secondary school. Though they have not gotten formal jobs. She has assisted them get into the Jua Kali (informal) sector where they work as Mechanics.

Margaret has been in the Jua Kali sector for the last 15 years. Her experience has made her to be very keen in studying the market trends. She therefore engages in goods that are on high demand. Currently she is engaged in selling Pishori rice. She takes her orders from retail shops, households, festivities like weddings. She joined WEEC programme in 2005. She got a loan of USD 139 and bought more stock. She paid her loan in 10 months.

This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Sarah has been involved in community Work both in her local church as a Sunday school teacher and also at village level as a youth counselor. This has enabled her to know many parents in the area.

Her business idea stemmed from the plight of many working parents who have had problems getting house girls who are honest. She therefore decided to start a day care centre. She Charges USD 7 per child per month. The income she gets from her work is enough to pay the room she has rented and also cater for the household expenses. In 2004 She took a loan of USD 139 that enabled her to go for a nursery school course. The course was to prepare her for her new business. In year 2005 She took another loan of USD 139 that enabled her set her business.

This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Loyce is a widow with 3 children and 5 dependants. She is a trained nursery school teacher. Through her training she has learnt to be disciplined and committed to her work. She is involved in church activities as a deacon and also the Chairlady of the womenâ€™s guild in the church.

Her preference of real estate (rental rooms) is because it does not take a lot of her time. She started her small project of 6 semi permanent rooms. From her rental income and loans she was able to put up 12 permanent rooms. She does not use her loans in any other way other than in her said project. To date she has 78 rental rooms. Her business has enabled her to bring up her family and also pay school fees for the five children who had previously dropped out of school for lack of school fees.

This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Naomi is a single mother with 5 children and 2 dependants. Naomi is an active member in the community. She is the Coordinator of the umoja road village. She is a leader of the Nambala Women group that has a project of grinding mill.

By joining the women groups in Ongata Rongai Naomi was able to attend short business skills courses. She has experience in different businesses from which she was able to raise capital buy a plot and developed it with rental houses due to high demand. She has 6 semi permanent houses and two are due for completion. She took a loan from WEEC of USD 139 in 2005 and laid the foundation of the two rooms.

This business is a member of the Kadisi Wisdom Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Jacinta is 43 years old, married with 4 children. She is involved in community work where she takes care of destitute children in the locality by giving free education in her private school.

Jacinta is a dairy farmer in Ongata Rongai. Currently, she has one dairy cow which earns her USD. 100 per month. This has been a reduction due to the prolonged dry season in that area. Under normal climatic conditions, she is able to raise 3 dairy cows and these can give her USD.456 per month. This enables her to take care of her family.

Iâ€™m an itinerant bread salesman.  Twice a week I go to Tegucigalpa and buy my bread supply for the week directly from the bakeries.  Upon returning to my community I travel in my car throughout my neighbouring villages selling the bread. Iâ€™ve had my business for three years and in this time my clientele has increased significantly, particularly with small grocers. At the moment I do not have enough capital to cover the demand that I have.

Iâ€™ve been selling medicines itinerantly in neighbouring communities for the past year.   This business generates earnings that I use to provide for my family. I also sell low quality wood that I buy from sawmills. This wood is used as a substitute for electricity by the people the in my residence.

My family and I serve food for a living.  I have a diner where I serve traditional food.  Throughout time I have attracted many clients to my establishment.   Many people visit my business each day because it is located in front of a bus terminal. At this moment the demand for food is very high that is why I need larger credits to cover the costs of serving more clients.

I provide transportation for people travelling from the city of El Paraiso to Las Manos in the border between Nicaragua and Honduras.  Iâ€™ve been doing this for the past seven years.  I make the journey on a daily basis, so I need to take my van to the mechanic for a check up and restore the seats in order to improve the security and comfort of my passengers.

Iâ€™ve had my business for the past 5 years, I take photos in special events, frame photos and diplomas, sell film and cameras as well as well as car batteries.  My business has grown parallel with my improved experience and my knowledge of camera repairs. I also fix cameras but only on few occasions. I only have basic repair equipment and would need greater financing in order to improve my shop and my services.

For the past 4 years Iâ€™ve dedicated myself to the sale of clothing and shoes for children, women and men. I sell my products to various offices in this city.  I already have a set clientele and I get paid every 15 days or upon delivery. I also sell from my residence with the help of my kids.  This business generates some earnings that allow me to better provide for my household.

My name is Santos Casco and I make and sell delicious nacatamelas, one of our typical foods.  In the last months my business has grown since I have received many more orders.  My business clients say that the flavour of my nacatamales is unique which is made better by my kind, charming customer service.  I also sell my nacatamales to my neighbours.

I bake and sell bread (rosquillas and quesadillas) and receive orders from my clients, housewives or owners of small grocery shops. I have done this for the past three years and with the help of one of my sons Iâ€™ve managed to grow significantly.  My demand is now so large that I need to buy more ingredients.

My name is Dirminda Sorto, I am the owner of a mill that grinds corn for household production and consumption of tortillas. Iâ€™ve had my mill for the past 13 years, and since itâ€™s the only mill in my community I have a lot of clients, therefore it has deteriorated.  The mill is one of the primary income sources of my family. I would like a credit in order to buy an electric mill and be able to continue with my business. Also, during school session, I sell candy to the students in my community and at the entrance of the school.

I am the owner of a small grocery shop that sells basic staples and other popular products such as milk, bread, lard, soda, candies amongst others. Iâ€™ve had my business for the past two years and itâ€™s the only shop in my community. Because of this I have a high demand and I need to restock with products that will be easily sold. I use the earnings from my store in order to keep my children in primary and secondary school.

I am the owner of a carpentry shop that builds beds, doors, wardrobes, dinning tables, chairs amongst others. I have lots of clients and most of my work is done by order.  I get paid 50% when we sign the contract and 50% when I hand them the final product, which makes it harder for me to sell furniture to other clients. This area has lots of demand for the elaboration of furniture and wood therefore I decided to work with PRISMA.

Iâ€™ve had my shop for the past seven years. Iâ€™ve managed to administer it and increase my number of clients.  It is my only source of income so I take care of my sales. I am a single mother of two. One of my sons is in school and the other is two years old. I think if I invest more capital in restocking my store Iâ€™ll get more earnings

My name is Angelina LÃ³pez and I sell accessories for sewing;  I also tailor clothing for women.  Iâ€™ve been tailoring for the past fifteen years and selling the accessories for the past two. I need the credit in order to buy the necessary cloth to make school uniforms.

I've had my business for two years.  Before my salon I worked for a private company and when I retired I invested the money in my own business. At the moment Iâ€™m working towards getting more clients and in order to do so I need to get good quality products to satisfy them.  The earnings of the salon help me with my family.

Both my husband and myself run the business.  We both keep the store that generates income that covers the expenses of my family. My business is one of the largest in my community and once in a while visitors ask me to cook for them, which provides some extra earnings.

I sell popular medicines for headache, diarrhea, fleas, stomach aches amongst others.  I sell my product in neighbouring communities. My wife and my two sons sell the medicine from my house. Iâ€™ve had this business for the past two years.  My wife also sells products from catalogues. The main source of income in my household is the medicines.

For the past 5 years Iâ€™ve had my store. I have a lot of clients because of the great diversity of products that I offer.  Iâ€™m located at the exit of the city and because of this I get a lot of business from the people travelling to the surrounding villages.  They buy their weekly provisions in my store. One way in which Iâ€™ve increased my sales is by allowing customers to pay every 15 days rather than on a weekly basis.

I own two car that I use as a taxis to provide tranportation in the city of Danily.  I work from 6:00 am â€“ 7:30 pm therefore I have to give maintenance to both my cars. I need to keep using at least one in order to retian my daily earnings.  I also need to change  the tires in the other.  In my family we are four, two kids, my wife and myself.  I mainly use the income for our everyday life.

I sell clothing and shoes for children, men and women.  My business is in  one of the main streets of Danili.  Iâ€™ve had my stand for the past two years and my sales are good given that my main clients are people from other communities that visit Danili.

This business is a member of the Melody Mothers group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lucy is a widow with one dependant. Despite being a widow she is very active.

Lucy grows and sells vegetables and poultry farming on a small plot. She started her farming business with a loan of USD 280. She sells her vegetable products to the neighbors and the nearby markets. Due to the prolonged dry spells, the demand for her products has increased since she is among the few using irrigation method of farming.

For poultry, she gets orders from hotels in Nairobi though due to lack of enough capital she is not able to meet the demand from her clients.

This business is a member of the Melody Mothers group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Mary Kunyua is married with 3 dependants. She is involved in community work and takes care of the orphans in her locality.

Mary sales fresh milk from her own cows and also buys from farmers in the same area. She distributes it to hotels in Nairobi. The income from her business is basically used in expansion of her business and feeding the orphans. Lack of a permanent stall for her business has been a major challenge since new customers canâ€™t locate her.

Elizabeth is single and an active member of Kandisi Wisdom Women Group. She has been a member of Women Fighting Aids in Kenya (WOFAK) since 2003.She trains the youth in HIV/AIDS related matter to minimize the spread of this scourge.

She has a small retail shop where he sells phone accessories, and operates a payphone. As a trainer with WOFAK, she is given an allowance of USD.4 per day 3 days a week. Late last year, she had her business in Nairobi unfortunately; thieves broke into her shop and cleaned it.

Ruth is the Chairlady of Kandisi Wisdom Womenâ€™s Group. She is married with 4 children.

She is in the business of screen printing with the husband. They have been able to buy a plot of land on which their permanent house is and can afford to send their children to school. Currently, her business is housed in her residence and intends to rent a shop in the town centre to increase her clientele.

Teresia is married with 6 dependants. She is a very active lady and a treasurer of Ole Roimen Women Group.

Teresia is the sole supplier of Furniture in her locality. She gets orders from the schools and residents since she does quality work. Though she is not able to meet the demand of her clients on time due to limited capital and lack of wood curving machine. \r\nIn addition to the furniture business, she sells vegetables and milk from her zero grazed cows. Her income from farming is steady throughout the year.

Nelly is married with 5 dependants. She takes care of the whole family, the husband has a poor paying job.

Nelly sells used clothes and her stock is USD 100.She does not have a permanent stall as it is expensive to own one for the time being. Her business is not enough to cater for her family basic needs and education.

Marcos is a single father who owns a small store that sells chickens and other meats. He averages about 16 hours of work a day and depends on his family to take care of his daughter. With the money received from the loan Marcos plans to increase his inventory so that he can diversify his products and buy in bulk at lower prices. He plans to use the increased income to provide better health care, education and clothing for his daughter.

Walter is originally from ManabÃ­ but has lived in Guayaquil for 15 years. He owns a small store where he sells groceries and other food items. He learned the business from his parents who provide some support for him but cannot give him credit. His wife also helps out at the store, but in order to grow he needs a source of capital other than the loan sharks. With the credit he plans to increase and diversify his inventory. Currently his profits average about two dollars a day.

Don Melecio is a tailor who produces menâ€™s suits and other clothing. He has 6 children who he cares for all by himself because of a wife that abandoned the family. His dream is to support his children so that they may receive a college education that will help them make a better life from themselves. Although he has over 25 years of experience the lack of capital does not allow him to produce at higher quantities. He is terrified of the loan sharks but is confident he can handle the loans.

Luz owns a store that sells school, office and party supplies. She is a single mother of one child who is currently still in school. She mainly sells notebooks, pens and party items for children and adults. The loans will help Luz purchase increased volume of products in times when demand is high such as carnival, Christmas and other holidays. She has over 25 years of experience in this business.

Vicente owns a shop in his house where he sells shoes and other sports equipments. He and his wife manage the store while taking care of their only son. He is in need of capital in order to be able to access better and more attractive styles for his client base. He will use the capital to try out different vendors of apparel and purchase products at higher quantities.

Rogelio owns his business on the outskirts of Guayaquil, but his neighborhood has many people that are potential clients. He has 3 children and a wife who helps out in their store whenever necessary. Rogelio has 5 years of experience in the business but needs capital in order to buy from wholesalers at cheaper prices. He also states that he will use new capital to invest in products that are in high demand at his store but he cannot currently afford. Rogelio says loan sharks charge above 20% interest and he cannot afford to repay those loans.

IsaÃ­as owns a store where he sells items of first necessity such as food and hygienic products. He is 46 years old and has 4 children. His business is well placed in a corner and is accredited by the government but IsaÃ­as does not have access to credit. With increased capital he plans to add variety and volume to his inventory in order to increase sales and profits. He also seeks to add an employee who may be able to help him in his sotre. He wants to use the money he makesto provide a better education for his four children.

Francisco is 48 years old and owns a shop for veterinary and agricultural products. He provides foods and medicines for domestic and farm animals in the neighborhood. He has over 25 years of experience in this business and is seeking loans in order to acquire better quality and higher quantity of products so that he may serve his clients better. He comments that the only access to credit he has charges 10% to 20% monthly interest and is way beyond what he can afford. He hope he can use profits made from his business in order to provide a better living for his two children who he cares for by himself.

Carmen has lived in Guayaquil for over twenty years where she owns a small grocery store. She is a widow with three children that she cares for by herself. She lives in a remote area of Guayaquil but she knows her business well as she has over 13 years of experience. With the loan she will be able to purchase products in bulk and lower costs.

Martha owns a small stand that sells chickens to the public. She learned the business from her parents and has been in this line of work for over 15 years. Although she earns money from this business and her husband has a humble but stable salary they are often short of money and do not have enough to invest in her business. With the loan money Martha plans to invest in more products and better tools. Currently she begins work at 6 a.m. and usually dedicates 16 hours a day to her business.

My business consists of the reparation of parts for agricultural vehicles and machinery, lathes and everything related to lathes. I have 8 years of experience and regular clients that supply parts from various shops in the community and from surrounding communities. I need this loan to complete the purchase of a lathe machine now that I enough have jobs and with a single machine it is difficult to complete all the orders quickly. The parts will also be useful for increasing sales.

For 5 years my business has sold clothing and shoes for women, men and children, distributing the merchandise door-to-door among my neighbors and friends that prefer to do business with me at the moment because I offer them affordable prices with methods of payment. I also have clients who are teachers and factory workers and I visit some villages around Danli. Maintaining good clients and administration has generated a good income for me, but I need the loan to improve my business and cover the costs of labor.

My business sells electronics such as: TVs, irons, video recorders, microwaves, etc. I use the money to help pay for the education of my family and to improve the conditions of the business so that there is always an assortment of products. My business relies/benefits from a good location and regular clients that come to me for their purchases. I need the loan to offer more products that are requested by clients.

I have had my business for 12 years, maintaining good clientele and management. My best clients are students, lawyers and some offices. The money I have made through my business has helped me to improve the business and cover family expenses.

My name is Karla Aguilar and I have a business selling clothing, shoes, and cosmetics door-to-door and by request for 5 years. I visit government offices, private companies, my largest buyers being teachers in urban and rural schools and employees of different institutions. I am requesting this loan in order to buy school clothes to increase my sales. With this money I can pay family and educational expenses.

For 4 years my business has sold paper and office supplies. I decided to become independent and run my own business in order to cover family expenses. I have a good location and the preference of clients who can find a complete assortment of paper and supplies. For this school year I want to sell more school supplies and for this I need the loan to provide a complete assortment.

I have had my business for 10 years and I am dedicated to repairing electronics Duch as TVs, stoves, DVD players, toasters, and others. I have good clients that provide me with work. Currently I have 2 helpers in my shop. The gains are considerable as they help me to have my business and maintain my home.

I have been selling assorted second-hand clothing for 17 years. In this area there are many similar businesses but the important thing is to have a greater variety of clothing than the competition and that it be of higher quality. Thanks to the profits from my business I can look after the health and education of my children.

Angel is a 29-year-old resident of Sliven, Bulgaria. Angel is a member of the Roma minority, also referred to as gypsies. He lives in the Roma neighborhood in a small, 2-room house without running water with his mother and brother.

For the past 15 years, Angel has worked in a bike shop in the center of Sliven tuning and repairing bikes. This year, Angel wants to start his own bike repair shop in the Roma neighborhood, "Nedeshda". Bikes play an important role for transport for members of the Roma community for two key reasons: 1) very few Roma own functioning vehicles and 2) public transport does not serve the Nedeshda. As such, the Roma without donkeys predominately get around by riding their bikes and walking.

The focus of Angel's business will be fixing punctured tires and tubes, broken chains and petals. The seed capital provided by this loan will be enough to cover the equipment he needs (welding tools, wrenches, screwdrivers, saws, hammers and a number of bike-specific tools), inventory (rubber, spare parts) and the modest renovation he needs to perform on the part of his house where he will have this shop (shown in photo).

Monica A. is a very active member of Life in Africa who came to Kampala as a result of the war in Northern Uganda.

Monica's husband was seriously wounded by rebels before they came to Kampala. He survived his wounds but has been left permanently disabled and unable to do physical work. Monica made ends meet making paper beads from glue and recycled paper, and working in a stone quarry next to the Internally Displaced camp in the outskirts of Kampala where they live.

In August of 2005 Monica joined Life in Africa and now earns a good living making solidarity bracelets that raise global awareness of the situation in Northern Uganda. She employs others to work at her place in the quarry, and finally has enough income to maintain her family's basic needs. She now has enough income to service a small loan of shs. 800,000 ($475), with which she plans help her husband participate in supporting the family again.

They have a small room at their residence which Monica and her husband plan on turning into a food shop. Her husband will run the shop while Monica continues to work.

Below is her budget; Sugar 3 bags @ 70,000/= 210,000/=
Maize flour 3 bags @ 50,000/= 100,000/=
Peanuts 1 bags @ 150,000/= 150,000/=
Soap 2 boxes@ 15,000/= 30,000/=
Cooking Oil 1 j/can@ 30,000/= 30,000/=
Simsim 1 bag @ 150,000/= 150,000/=
Weighing Scale 1 pc @ 70,000/= 70,000/=
Transport 50,000/=
Contingencies 10,000/=

Based on her current income, she will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. Monica has desig-nated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu, her wartorn home.

Ocola J. is 52 years old and is married with 5 children. He is Acholi and is one of the many thousands of people who were forced to flee their homes in the North because of the war that has been going on for the last 20 years. His family lives in an Internally Displaced People's camp in the outskirts of Kampala called the Acholi Quarter. Six months ago J. joined Life in Africa and has been an active member ever since. He started as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project but his hard work and determination quickly earned him a promotion to a sanding processor.

He has acquired a piece of land from the King of Buganda who has sympathy for the people of Acholi and who has set aside free land for them. Knowing that the people of the Acholi quarter have to go long distances to look for water, he has a plan to install a water tap on his land. The current water sellers who bring water in to this hilltop area are charging five shillings per litre for water which makes it very hard for the people to purchase water for their needs. With a water tap installed on his land, J. will be able to purchase water for only one shilling per litre and he plans on selling this water for a reduced rate of 3 shillings per litre to his community.

Not only will this provide a steady income for his family needs, but it will also offer a valuable service to his community at a more affordable price than they can currently get. This will insure that he has a secure source of buyers for his water, and it is likely to have a great impact on those living in the Acholi quarters.

To accomplish this project, J. is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475). He es-timates that once he acquires this loan it will take approximately one week to have the water tap installed. Below is his budget:

16 metal pipes @ 12000= each =192000=
connection fee to national water=300000=
labor charges & other expenses =200000=
building of small house so that the tap can be locked to avoid theft =100000=
The whole total is 792000=.

Based on his current income, J. will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. J. loves music and dance, and has designated the community impact portion of the interest he pays to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery program.

Grace A. is a mother of four children and has been an active member of Life in Africa for the last four years. Five years ago she was faced with the problem of earning enough money to support herself and her children. As with many women in her situation, she turned to something she knew to try and earn money. She happened to know how to make good peanut butter and so she started her small business. Her main goal was to be self reliant and to serve her customers well while earning an income to support her children.

In the beginning she used the age old method of grinding the nuts using a mortar and pestle. This method worked but it was a very slow process and she found she was not able to make the peanut butter fast enough to earn adequate money. To remedy this, she carefully planned and saved to purchase a processing machine. This enabled her to process enough to meet the de-mands of her customers and her business grew.

But her good business sense tells her that she can do more. She now has the capability of pro-ducing large quantities but still must produce smaller batches because she has no way of storing it until it is sold. This will require the purchase of a refrigerator which will allow her to always have a supply on hand and will also enable her to increase her number of customers. To accomplish this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us. This amount will purchase a refrigerator, additional packing materials needed and the necessary capital to expand her production. Below is her budget:

800,000/= LOAN BUDGET
FRIDGE 400,000=
PACKING MATERIALS 200,000=
ADDITIONAL CAPITAL 200,000=
TOTAL 800,000=

Based on her current income, Grace will be able to repay the loan in 6 months. She has desig-nated 1/4 of the interest she pays on this loan to support educational opportunities for Life in Af-rica member children.

Zarina A. is a widow with three children. When her husband died unexpectedly she had just given birth to the third child and she was left with the sole responsibility of providing for herself and her children. This is no easy task for a woman in Uganda but Zarina was determined and remarkably managed to obtain a job as a housekeeper in Kampala. It was through this job that she was introduced to Life in Africa and she has been an active member for the last five years.

Zarina saw value in building rental properties as a way to provide for her children's education. She managed to secure several loans through Life in Africa and built a solid housing unit in a poor section of Kampala. She has several tenants living in her property now and she was able to responsibly pay back all her loans. She earns an income from this property of shs. 200,000 ($111) each month. But the house is not yet plastered. She wants to finish the outside properly now to ensure that her tenants have quality housing for their families and to insure the value and durability of her investment.

Zarina is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475) to complete the plastering of the property. Her budget is listed below.

20 bags of cement @ 17000= 340000=
sand 80000=
labor 300000=
transport 50000=
other expenses 30000=
Total 800000=

Based on her current income, Zarina will be able to pay off this loan in 4 months. She has desig-nated 1/4 of the interest she pays to support craft skills development workshops at Life in Africa, which she enjoys taking part in.

Peter has just been promoted to Foreman at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. His hope is to eventually return to University for further studies, but in Peterâ€™s family itâ€™s become urgent that he starts to think about finding a wife â€“ two of his younger brothers have serious girlfriends they would like to marry, but it is against custom for them to marry before their older brothers do. With his recent promotion, Peter also believes itâ€™s time he started to think seriously about his future, and a wife is definitely part of the plan.

In Uganda, however, marriage is not a day long event but a long process that begins at the point Peter finds himself now. Since itâ€™s taboo for any girl Peter brings home to enter his fatherâ€™s house, the first thing that must happen is that Peter builds a house of his own on his fatherâ€™s land in Tororo (Eastern Uganda). Peter has been saving for this purpose and would like a loan of shs. 800,000 ($475) to add to what he has saved and complete the house quickly.

Peter is an extremely sincere, hardworking and capable young man, and very popular with the Life in Africa members - who are all now wondering who his choice of bride will be!

Below is Peterâ€™s budget:
Cement 20 Bags @ 17000 = 52000
Sand 2 Trips @ 30000 = 60000
Doors 4 @ 50000 = 200000
Windows 4 @ 15000 = 60000
Nails 4kg @ 4000 = 16000

Based on his current income, Peter will be able to repay this loan in 8 months. He has designated a portion of the interest he pays on the loan to support Life in Africaâ€™s Internet4change Program.

Nighty A. is one of the most active Life in Africa member from the displaced Acholi quarter in the ouskirts of Kampala. In addition to working in a stone quarry, she also now earns a part time income making solidarity bracelets to increase awareness of the war in her home of Northern Uganda.

Nighty's husband has deserted her but she has struggled for the welfare of her family. She has managed singlehandedly to send all her children back to school and has also managed to save a little bit for further development.

With this savings she has acquired a small piece of land at the acholi quarters , where she now plans to build a two roomed house that will create more space for the children.

Below is her budget in full:
Bricks 5,000/= @ 60/= 300,000/=
Cement 10 bags @18,000/= 180,000/=
Iron sheets 20 pcs @10,000/= 200,000/=
Timbers 20 pcs @ 5,000/= 100,000/=
Transport 20,000/=v Total 800,000/=

Based on her current income, Nighty will be able to repy this loan in 12 months. She has desig-nated a 1/4 of the interest she pays on this loan to support educational opportunities for Life in Af-rica member children.

Teopista joined Life in Africa in February of 2005. Since then she has been a very active member and has become a leader at the WE Center. She is a single mother raising three children and she always works very hard to provide for them and to keep them in school. As they get older, the school fees increase and she is looking for a way to insure that she will be able to pay all the fees so they can complete their education. She does not think that being a single mother should be a barrier to her children's education.

Even with all the demands for their needs, she has managed to save enough money to acquire a plot of land. She plans to build a house on this land that she will rent out. The income from this rental property will be specifically used for her children's education. Housing is in high demand so this will be a sound investment.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475) to assist her in starting the first phase of her project. She has savings that she will add to this loan to purchase the necessary materials to lay the foundation and build part of the walls.

Her total project budget is shs. 3,252,000/=
With the 800,000/= that Teopista is asking to borrow for the first phase, she plans to buy:
Bricks 7,000 @ 60/= 420,000/=
Cement 20 bags @ 18,000/= 360,000/=
Transport 20,000/=
TOTAL 780,000/=

Based on her current income, Teopista will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. She has des-ignated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change training program.

Monica is an awesome lady. She is a widowed mother of three beautiful children. She joined Life in Africa in 2003 and is now the WE Center Manager. She is loved and respected by all who work with her.

5 years ago, Monica's husband died of injuries he suffered in a trucking accident. After he died, his family came and claimed all his property, including their family home, leaving Monica and her children left on the street to start life over from scratch. This sort of thing happens far too often in Uganda and there was nothing legal that Monica could do. When she found her way to Life in Af-rica she was destitute, but realized that she could learn new skills that might improve her situation.

Monica learned quickly and worked hard. She is now the Manager of the Life in Africa WE Center and earns a steady income. Her children are all in school and their lives have greatly improved. But they still have no home to call their own, and this is a painful memory for the whole family. Monica feels it's important to give her children a home that no one can take away from them or evict them from.

She has sold some property her family owned in her village and has managed to buy a plot of land in Kireka on the outskirts of Kampala. Here she plans to build a solid family home. She has carefully planned and the project will be completed in three years using money she saves from her salary and a series of loans. The total budget for the house she wishes to build is shs. 13,000,000 ($7220).

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs 800,000 ($475) for the first phase. This will build the foundation of the house. Once this loan is repaid, she will start on the next phase and continue until the house is built. The loan she is requesting will enable her to buy: hard core stones, bricks, sand, and cement, all for laying the foundation of the house.

Based on her current income, Monica can repay this loan in 12 months. She has designated 1/4 of the interest she pays on her loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change training program.

My name is Tulio Morales, my business is the making and selling of cement blocks.  My operation is located on my property where I live, near the town of La Entrada a Copn.  We live in an area where there are a lot of cement shops like mine.  Right now, I have several good orders from people that live in neighboring townships, people who have their own construction businesses.  Peolple come to me for my good quality and fair price.  I have four children of school age, so I work hard to have a good businesss.

My name is Dionicia B., and I have been selling furniture out of my home for ten years.  I buy my inventory in Honduras comercial center, the city of San Pedro Sula.  My store was nothing when it started, now it is the biggest furniture store in my area, I have very good clients and people know me.  I have three children of school age and I know I have to keep my business prosperous in order to provide an educated life for my family.

This business is a member of Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Joyce attended WEECâ€™s livestock programme training and later was given a livestock loan. She has managed to pay it back. Meanwhile, she has been saving small money with the group and this has made her qualify for yet another loan.

Traditionally, she is a Masai and these are cattle keepers. She joined the group five years ago and has been saving with the group for all this time. She attended livestock training and thereafter was given a loan of USD.300. She bought three steers which she later sold and a profit of USD.150. Currently, she is raising four steers hopefully they will be sold in two months time. There is ready market for them in Nairobi and nearby towns.

Patricia received her first loan from WEEC of USD.300 in 2001. She bought two steers and started her business of making handicraft at home, selling them in Isinya. She then received a loan of USD.600 and bought 4 more steers. To date, she has over 20 steers. She able to pay her children school fees and meet all family requirements. The demand for steers is very high because this area was hit by prolonged drought which forced some cattle keepers to relocate.

Joyce is married with 3 children. She was educated up to primary school level. She was later trained on livestock management. This enabled her to work on improving the cattle for marketing. She is also a devoted member of catholic church.

Instead of keeping large herds of cattle, Joyce has turned to purchasing of good quality steers and rearing them for 6 months using modern improved methods. She later market the steers at Enkirgirri market at USD 205. Currently Joyce has only 3 steers out of 5 as two died out of prolonged drought.

Rebecca K. is a hard working mother of eight; four boys and four girls. She has been an acitve member of Life in Africa since March of 2005. She works as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project which now provides her with a steady income. She also runs a stall at a local market in Kampala from which she also receives some money. Together these two jobs allow her to maintain her large family.

Rebecca is very passionate about educating her children. She says, "They should have the education I never had." But school fees for eight children is very challenging. She is looking for ways to add to her income to insure that this challenge can be met.

Rebecca's church owns some land with clay on it that it makes available to church members for making bricks. Rebecca has already seen one of her daughters do quite well in this business. She is thus seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 500,000 ($280) to fund the start-up of her own brick business.

This investment will create 2 jobs for others who will make the bricks, and she plans on using this business to finance the building of some tenant houses on her property. These she will rent out to further add to her income so that the necessary school fees for her children will be paid.

Below is her budget.

Firewood -- 25,000/=
Transport -- 10,000/=
Labour -- 435,000/=
Total -- 500,000/=

According to Rebecca's current income, she hopes to be able to repay this loan in 10 months. She has designated the impact portion of the interest she pays to support Life in Africa's Integrated Education Program for Adults, where she is currently learning English.

Rebecca's online journal can be found here.

This business is a member of the Queen Esther Women`s Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Muthoni is married, lives in Ole Roimen and the secretary to the group. She was retrenched from one of the insurance companies in Nairobi some time back. There after, she decided to start her own businesses.

She used her small savings to start up a shop at Ole Roimen. With support from the husband and a loan from WEEC, she built one rental room and the rest is history. As the demand for rental houses increased, she sought support from WEEC again. Due to good loan repayments of the previous loans, she was given another loan of USD 600 which she used to construct additional rental houses.

This business is situated in Sambour Village, Dangkar Commune, Dangkar District, just outside of Phnom Penh

Hak S. is living and working with her husband and 4 children in the suburbs of Phnom Penh city. Her business is to cook and sell food to the workers around the the nearby factories. Each member of the family is involved in this activity: Hak S. gets up at 1am and goes to the fish and seafood market, and then comes back home and start cooking rice, shrimp, fish, soups, dry and fried vegetables. Her husband brings their children to the factories on their motorbike for 9am, which is the morning break for sewing factory worker and they start selling. At home, Hak S. is still cooking to provide fresh food to the worker for their afternoon break at 3:30pm.

This loan of $700 will allow S. and her family to improve their living condition by repairing their house. They will buy materials and perform the reparation by themselves, in addition to their casual workload. Sometimes does Hak S. feel very tired, I want to start another business, she said, but she does not know what she should do.

This is the first time Hak S. takes a loan with CREDIT but her neighbors are old clients and introduce her to CREDIT staff.

This business is located in Thnot Chum Village, Boengtumpun Commune, Min Chey District just outside of Phnom Penh City.

Kem P. is living with her husband, four children and mother-in-law in a small, two storeys wooden house. Their main activity consists in growing and harvesting water spinach in the nearby fields. The household production is brought to the market in a motorbike cart they have to rent every day, and sold in the market for human and animal consumption.

With the $700 she will receive from CREDIT, Kem P. want to buy the motorbike cart for $120 to save the money of the daily rent. She is also planning to increase her crops through renting one more hectare of land, which is worth $200 yearly. P. will have to purchase more seeds, for $1.25 per 10 square meters, and she knows she will have to work harder with her husband but they expect to increase their annual income over the next few years.

P. is not satisfied with this business: they can barely earn their living with it, she said. Her plan is to spare enough money to open a stand in the market, and sell her neighbors production. In that case, her husband could become a moto-taxi.

This business is located in Poum Kmey, Dangkar District, Dangkar Commune, outside of Phnom Penh City

Keo S. is married and has 5 children. She lives with her husband in Phnom Penh nearby suburbs and they run their business together at home, with the help of one of their sons and one additional employee. The four of them manage to produce two big music instruments every month, out of the yellow wood provided by the partner who markets their production. Each piece is bought for $60 by the shopkeeper, so that this activity generates a monthly income of $120.

With a loan of $1500, Keo S. will acquire a wood carving machine, worth $250, and a motor, worth about $100, to increase the volume and the quality of her production. She will also purchase her own stock of yellow wood, $50 per piece, and other materials required in her activity. This will allow her to substantially increase the income of her family, as these music instruments are usually sold $200 in Phnom Penh markets. We want to expand this business, S. said, because we love doing it. S. has chosen a 12 months loan term and CREDIT loan officer will visit her monthly for repayment collection.

Thnot Chum Village, Boengtumpun Commune, Min Chey District outside of Phnom Penh City

Khen Samuon is married and lives with her husband and 4 children, 3 boys and 1 daughter, in a small wooden house in Phnom Penh suburbs. She has been working in sewing factories for 7 years, while her husband is self-employed as a moto taxi. Ken Samuon is not very confident about her future but her desire is to support her son to succeed in life.

With the $1000 she requested from CREDIT, Samuon wants to allow her elder son to open a motorbike workshop in Phnom Penh City. She is borrowing for buying the tools, materials and spare parts required for such a business. The family as already found a place for rent for about $60 monthly and the owner has accepted to let them use the premises for free for a one month test period. Khen Samuon and her husband are willing to pay the first monthly installments with their own salaries but they are eventually expecting a daily income of 20,000 Riels, about $5, from the workshop, which will be enough to cover the interest and the reimbursement of the loan and generate a substantial income.

This business is located in Au Bekam, Dangkar District, outside of Phnom Penh City

Part Sithaot is a nurse; she acts as a medical assistant for the families in the neighborhood. Most of the time, she is living alone with her four children as her husband is a soldier. She moved from Battambang to Phnom Penh 6 years ago to follow her elder son who was starting with the University.

With the $1600 she requested from CREDIT, Part Sithaot will be able to enlarge her house. She has already bought the material but needs this money to hire people to perform the operations. Sithaot will not have any problem to find her labor force among the unemployed youth of her community. It will cost her around $1.25 per day per worker.

With this loan, Sithaot is also planning to open a furniture workshop. She will rent a place, purchase tools and raw materials and employ permanently at least two skilled workers.

Part Sithaot is confident about repaying her loan. It is the second time I borrow from CREDIT, she said, and so far, I have never been late.

Florence is married with four children. She has been in the group for 4 years. Currently she is the group treasurer. She is a treasurer of Revelations women group and another self help group. They buy household utensils for members and distribute amongst themselves.\r\n

\r\nFlorence keeps dairy cows and sells milk at Landless and Thika town. She has also a retail shop in Gatundu-Makongeni area. Due to high demand of milk, she would like to increase supply by buying more milk from vendors as well as buying another dairy cow.

Milly N. has been an active member of LiA since october 2004, Milly joined with her skills as an artisan making mats and table mats from used straws which have been sold in the LiA gallery, bazaars and hawking them around by her children.

Milly was doing all this to increase on her family income but still there is alot she and her husband can't accomplish with the meagre incomes they get . Their family has expanded; when Milly joined LiA she had four children but now she has given birth to two more.

With her own income now that she is working at the new WE Center across the road from her home, Milly is finding herself newly empowered as a mother and a wife. She has decided that the house they live in is simply too small for 6 children. Her plan is to help the husband to enlarge their house so that they can have enough room to accommodate their big family they have now. She wants to add a bedroom and a living room to their one room they have been staying in.

To achieve this she needs a loan of Ushs. 800,000 and her budget is as follows:

  • Bricks 4000 @ Ushs.60 = 240,000
  • Iron Sheets 24pcs @Ushs. 11,000 = 264,000
  • Bags of Cement 10Pkts @Ushs.18500 = 185,000
  • Timber @Ushs. 60,000
  • Transport @Ushs. 40,000
  • Water @ Ushs.11,000

Total Ushs. 800,000

Milly's husband is a builder and he is ready to do the expansion of the house.

Milly has a surplus of Ushs.260,000 on her monthly expenses to enable her repay her loan in a period of 6 months at a rate of Ushs.147,335. She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she pays on this loan to support new lighting for the WE Center Member Gallery.

Edith N. is a lively and active member of Life in Africa. She is currently working in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project. She is educated and holds a Bachelor's Degree in Development studies but, since finishing her University studies, she has been unable to find a job. She supported herself by doing odd jobs and managed to earn enough money to open a small retail shop.

This shop is in a very good location and is lucrative because there are few other shops in the village. The people would have to walk very long distances to find the products she plans on offering. By bringing these products closer to them she will be guaranteed a large and solid customer base. This will not only provide more income for her but will also serve her community. For this reason she wishes to grow and expand her shop.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to purchase the stock needed to expand her existing shop.

Below is her budget:

  • Sugar 2 bags @70,000/=
  • Rice 1 bag @70,000/=
  • Batteries 2 boxes @ 5,500/=
  • Cooking oil 1 jerry can @ 20,000/=
  • fridge 1 Unit @ 300,000/=
  • Soap 2 boxes @ 10,000/=
  • Maize flour 1 bag @ 12,000/=
  • Salt 2 cartons @ 10,000/=
  • Paraffin 1 jerry can @ 26,000/=
  • Match boxes 1 carton @ 7,500/=
  • Baking Powder 1 box @ 48,000/=
  • Geisha 1 box @ 8,000/=
  • Millet flour 1 Bag @10,000/=
  • contingencies 32,000/=

Total------------------ 800,000/=

She will be paying 102,890/= per month for 10 months in order to completely service the loan properly. Edith has designated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support the Internet4Change team at Life in Africa, where she is an Agent in training.

Okidi B. is an active member of Life in Africa working as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. He lives with his wife and three children in the IDP camp known as the Acholi quarter.

He, like thousands of other Acholis, was forced to flee their homes due to the war in the north. Initially at the camp, he earned what little he could at the stone quarry but he found this inadequate since he could not provide enough food, medicine or schooling for his children. Working at LiA has greatly improved his life and now he is able to provide these basics for his family. But he is a business man at heart. He owned a shop in the north and was forced to leave it but his mind still thinks in terms of business.

He has been able to negotiate a busness deal with a local secondary school to provide them with flour each term (three times per year). He will travel to the rural area to buy the flour and then return with it to the school. He will be able to make a profit of 200,000 each term. He will continue with his work at LiA since this business will only require his attention 3 times per year.

He is seeking a loan in the amount of 700,000 to make the initial puchase of flour. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is his budget:

15 bags of maize flour @ 30000/ = 450000/=

Transport 200000/=

Misllenoius 50000/=

Total 700000/=

The nature of his busines gives him time to proceed with his job because he has go and buy once then supplies to school direct. This means he can do it himself just those 3 times and no need for rent. According to his current income, he will be able to pay the loan in 12 installments, and will almost double the loan amount during that period. Okidi has designated the community impact portion of the interest he pays to support the Life in Africa Talent Discovery team.

This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lydia is married and has four children. She is the Chairlady of welfare in the same group. She is also a of mothers union member where she is a church treasurer. She has been in the group for the last four years.

Currently she has two dairy cows. Has been keeping around 500 chicken a business she started in 2004 using the first loan of USD.300 from WEEC. She sells eggs to local market and Nairobi. The demand is high and would like to increase the number of chicken to at least 1000.She is able to provide for her family all the basic necessities.

Kilama G. has been an active member of Life in Africa for the last six months. He works as a bracelet maker for the Invisible Children Bracelet Project.

He lives with his wife and children in the Acholi quarters. He has been there for five years ,and he came from Pader district he has six children. Before coming to LiA, he worked in the stone quarry with his wife and had a very difficult time supporting his family. His wife still works at the quarry while he works at liA. Together, their incomes now support the family and their lives have improved. However, housing is very poor in the Acholi quarter.

He has acquired a plot of land from the King of Buganda who has sympathy for the people of Acholi. On this land he plans to build a two room house for his family. For this he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 10 months, and he will be paying 94,000/= per month.

  • 3000 BRICKS @ 60----------180,000/
  • 2 TRIPS OF SAND @ 30000------60,000/
  • 12 BAGS OF CEMENT @ 18000------216,000/
  • TIMBER (4X2) 8 PIECES @3000------24,000/
  • (3x4) 5 '' @500--------25,000/
  • 14 IRON SHEETS @ 10,000 --------------140,000/
  • TRANSPORT----------------------------------33,000/
  • LABOUR------------------------------------------110,000/
  • NAILS 4 INCHES 3KGS @ 1,500/-------6,000/
  • NAILS 6 INCHES1KGS @ 2,000/------2,000/
  • ROOFING NAILS 2KGS @ 2,300/-----3,400/
TOTAL-------------------------------------------800,000/

Kilama will be paying 94,000/= per month in a period of ten months and he saves Ushs 101500/ on his account. He has dedicated 25% of the interest he will pay on this loan to supporting the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu.

Joyce M. is a Patchwork and Embroidery designer specializing in wall hangings of flowers, animals, birds, and persons. She joined Life in Africa 2 years ago and she has since then been a very active member of the WE Center. She has passed on her skills to some of the members of the Center and she is actually the best person one would ever want to work with.

She has developed a good reputation with many International families living in Kampala and they have become customers. She has a stall near her home where she hangs and displays her work but she also does many hangings by special order for her customers. She is now in a good position to expand her business since the demand for her products is now more than what she can produce herself.. And in doing this she will be able to offer jobs to one or two other LiA members to assist her in the production process.

To fund this expansion Joyce is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us. This will purchase enough materials to complete 100 wall hangings. These will be sold from her stall, at bazaars and at exhibitions as well as to her current client base. With the addition of some hired help, she will be able to complete the 100 hangings in four months.

Below is her budget of what she needs to buy.

  • Item/ Quantity/ Cost/ Total
  • Poly Viscose. White 30 Metres x 4000 = 120000
  • Poly Viscose. Cream 30 Metres x 4000 =120000
  • Poly Viscose. Army Color 30 Metres x 4000 =120000
  • Cotton White 90 Metres x 1500 =135000
  • Cotton Cream 90 Metres x 1500 =135000
  • Cotton Brown 90 Metres x 1500 =135000
  • Cotton Green 10 Metres x 150 =15000
  • Transport 20000

Total 800000

According to Joyce's current income, she will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change Team, who need more computers so they can better help Joyce to sell some of her patchworks online.

Read more about Joyce at http://joyceM..blogspot.com/

Robert O., was born in northern town of Kitgum in 1979 and has lived there until the war was unbearable when he moved to Kampala in 2002.His father was among those killed by the rebels, when he was just ten years old and watching this happened it was impossible for him to continue living in that situation thus the decision to look for safer place, this then was then when he came to Kampala.

While in Kampala Robert now as an adult married with 1 child started learning building skills this was through giving a hand to the mason. This could not earn him enough money so, he decided to join the rest at the stone quarry, a job he did until the news of the bracket project by life in Africa knocked on his door.

This gave him a lot of uplift in his earning that during the few months of working with them, he managed to acquire a small plot that he now wished to develop into a family house.

He therefore seeks a loan of 500,000/= which he will pay back in 12 mouths at 50,415 @

Budget

  • Bricks 1500 x 60/= - 90,000/=
  • Cement 5bags x 18,000/= - 90,000/=
  • Iron sheets 15 x 10,000/= = 150,000/=
  • Roofing poles 10 x 3000/= - 30,000/=
  • Sand 1 trip x 6,000/= - 60,000/=
  • Doors and window frames – 40,000/=
  • Transport – 30,000/=
  • Contingency – 10,000/=

Total ----------- 500,000/=


Since he already has building skills, Robert will be doing his work himself so no labour cost. After this Robert plans to get a bigger land where he will build rental houses that will enable his children go to school. Robert has designated the community impact portion of the interest he will pay on this loan to support educational opportunities for LiA member children.

Florence A. is 32 years old and has two children, a boy and a girl. They came to Kampala when the war intensified in Northern Uganda and every body was being forced to move into the IDP Camps. She knew how hard life would be in the camps and she thought she could make a better life in the capital city of Kampala. She is a hard worker and believes in doing whatever it takes to provide for her children. She works at many things including housekeeping and running small businesses. She has had her best success in selling charcoal.

She now works in Invisible Children Bracelet Project at Life in Africa. Her sister, who also was forced to flee because of the war, lives with her and runs the charcoal business. Their lives have much improved but she realizes that the charcoal business can be much more profitable if you have the capital to stock more. For this reason, she wishes to expand her business by seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000.

With the additonal profits from the business, her salary at LiA,and the money she has already saved she plans to buy a piece of land. Here she will build a house for her family to live in and another house to rent out which will increase their income and allow them to live a better and more secure life.

Below is her budget in full:

Charcoal – 40 bags x 8,000/= -----320,000/=

Transport ----------- 160,000/=

Loading -------------- 20,000/=

Total ------------- 500,000/=

She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she will pay on the loan to support Life in Africa's Adult Education Program, where she is excited to now be learning English.

Stephen A. is an active member of Life in Africa. He is a resident of Acholi quarters (a displaced people's camp in the surburb of Kampala). At the camp, his only source of income was the stone quarry where he worked very hard to make barely enough money to exist on. Since coming to Life in Africa, his life has totally changed.

He moved to Kampala as a result of the war in Northern Uganda. There he also was forced to live in an IDP camp and conditions were very hard. He had to leave school when he couldn't raise money for his school fees and his family had a hard time even getting enough food. He now lives with his brother and part of the money he earns he sends to his family back in Gulu to pay for school fees for his younger brothers and to help the family buy food.

His plan now is to start up a used clothing business. His brother has agreed to run the business while Stephen continues his work at Life in Africa. He plans to use the additional income from this business to start saving for building a family house that will enable him to bring down his family who are still suffering in the camps in northen Uganda.

For this business, he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000.

Below are his full budget:

1- 2 bales of clothes @ 150,000/= ------ 300,000/=

2- Transport ---------- 40,000/=

3- Rent for space @ 30,000/=@month ----- 90,000/=

4- licence --------- 50,000/=

5- contingencies ---------- 20,000/=

TOTAL ------------ 500,000/=
With the income he now earns through the WE Center Kampala, Stephen will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. He has designated 25% of the interest he pays to support the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu.

Abdon O. has been an active member of Life in Africa for six months. He currently works at the WE Center as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project.

He is Acholi and his home used to be Gulu in Northern Uganda. However, in 1997 the war there became so dangerous that he was forced to flee and come to Kampala where he lives in the displaced persons camp known as the Acholi quarters. There, he and his wife worked in the quarry and barely earned enough to feed their five children much less provide such things as school fees. He now works at LiA while his wife continues at the quarry. Their combined income can now provide a much better life for the family.

But living conditions are not good in the camp and he dreams of having a home of their own. He has acquired a piece of land donated by the King of Buganda and it is his intent to build a modest two room home on it so that his children will not have to live in a rented house. To do this he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us.

Below is his break down.

He wants to buy the following materials

1: 12 iron sheets @----------------11000--------132,000/

2: 12 bags of cement @--------------18500-----201,000/

3: 3000 bricks @ 60-----------------------------180,000/

4:13 pieces of timber for roofing

(3x4)- 3000----24,000/

(4x2)-----5000-------------------20,000/

5: 2 trips of sand @----------60000----------------120,000/

6: transporting materials to the site-------------- 40,000/

7: Labour-------------------------------------------83,000/

TOTAL: 800,000/

According to his current income, he will be able to repay this loan in 12months and he will be paying 80,665 per month. O. has designated the community impact portion of the interest he will pay to support the Transport for Life in Africa team, which is currently trying to raise money for a LiA community owned vehicle that can help transport workers to the WE Center.

Edidah is a wonderful woman and is a very active member of Life in Africa. She is the sole breadwinner for seven children. She is very talented in the art of handicrafts and earns her living by making and selling beautiful basket, bracelets, shopping bags and many other items.

She faces several challenges in her work. The first is that she is an asthmatic. This makes it very difficult to work during the cold and wet season. However, she does not let this fact stop her and she works hard even when she is sick. These skills, her determination and her good business sense allow her to provide the basic needs for her family. Her other challenge is providing the school fees to educate all her children. Their education has become her number one priority.

To overcome this last challenge, Edidah has devised a plan to constuct a two room house that she will rent out. She owns a plot of land located at Mutungo near Kampala and she has family there to help in the constuction of this house. This project will take about three months to complete and once it is finished, she will use the income from this property to pay the school fees that will insure the education of her children.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 500,000.

Below is her budget:

  • Cement - 12 bags 200,000/=
  • Doors - 2 pcs 90,000/=
  • Wood - 20 pcs 100,000/=
  • Labour - 85,000/=
  • Bricks ((3500in number) 24,500/=

Total 500,000/=

Loan Amount 500,000/=

Edidah will be able to repay her loan in 10 installments. She has designated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support the WE Team for developing self-sustaining project at LiA, which she currently leads.

Agnes is married with four children. She has trained on secretarial, computers and an accountant by professional. She is a CCI member.

She started her private computer college eight years ago. She is the Managing Director of the college which has 170 students. Thika is a densely populated town and most school leavers have missed vacancy in her college due to lack of enough computers and training materials. The college has employed 8 members of staff.

This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Eunice Muthoni is the current chairlady of Revelation women group. She has been the Women Coordinator of St Stephen Anglican Church of Kenya for the last five years. She is married with 5 children.

She started her small shop in 2003 after being given her first loan of USD.300 from WEEC.Landless area is a dry area and sodas and other cold drinks sale easily. The population of the area is growing very fast and at times runs out of stock of some items which is not good if you are to attain and retain customers.

This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Edith is married with 4 children. She is hardworking and a good member of PCEA church.


Edith has a banana plantation in Maragua District in central Kenya. She also grows and sells maize and beans. Edith has been in this business for the last two years. She also has a lorry for transport business. It is normally hired to carry building materials in Thika. Thika is an industrial town where construction works is at an increase. This business has built her a house and is about to be completed.

This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Grace is a pastor of Regeneration church in Thika, Kenya. Through her church ministry, she has traveled to Uganda, Tanzania, Sudan and Rwanda. She has been a member of Revelation women group for the last 4 years. She is a mother of four.

In 2005 she received a loan of USD.300 and bought a cow. To date she has two dairy cows. She also practices horticulture farming on a small scale. She sells milk, onions, and cabbages to her neighbors and in Thika town.

Jane is married with six children. She joined the group in 2003. She is an active member of the group and the local self help group.

Jane started her business of selling cereals in 2003. She was given her first loan of USD.300 by WEEC and had trained in hair dressing. Therefore, she started her own salon in Thika town. The business has grown and handles mores than 10 people a day.

"This business is a member of the Revelations Women group.
