M. Pak is living in the house were she was born, in Kandal province, not far from Phnom Penh, with her 6 children. Her husband is a moto taxi, while she is selling food to the factory workers in her neighborhood. She gets up early in the morning to cook and begins selling around ten for the first break in the factories. In the afternoon, her husband brings her to the market. Four of her children are helping her in this business and the two remaining are employed in the factories. The five of them make around $5 profit out of $25 daily sale.

For her first loan with CREDIT, she is requesting a $500 loan to buy a new motorbike for her husband. She will sell the old one, which is breaking down often and costs much in reparations.

M. Pak is a cautious person; her first concern would be to save a little money for the rainy days. She is also thinking about expanding her business with her next CREDIT loans.

C. Sokhim is one of CREDIT oldest clients. She is cooking and selling food in her neighborhood for quite a long time. She is living with her husband, her mother and four children in a house she ameliorated with her previous loans. “My living standards have been improving steadily since I borrowed for the first time with CREDIT”, she said. “I was never late in my repayments, because I want to deserve CREDIT’s trust in me.

 

C. Sokhim used to borrow small amount in Riel, Cambodia national currency, but this time she is requesting $700.

 

As she heard that a new factory was going to be opened in her village, her plan is to build a house to rent decent rooms to the workers, who will come from the provinces to work in this factory. This is a big investment but Sokhim is planning to go step by step: this first loan will be used to prepare the land before having the house built. Eventually, she is expecting a good income for her family.

Toncho graduated from the local technical college in Sliven, Bulgaria, with the U.S.-equivalent of an associate's degree in electrical repair in the mid-1980s.  He began work at a large, state-run electrical repair shop until the fall of communism in 1989.  Like many Bulgarians, he soon found himself out of work.  In early 1991, he struck out on his own and started his own electrical repair shop.  He sells spare parts and fixes a broad range of electrical devices, usually TVs, VCRs, and radios, although he sees the occasional kitchen appliance.   Toncho also sells a small selection of new and used appliances, and this loan will help him expand that part of the business.  The loan proceeds will be used to expand his shop to include a separate showroom and increase his inventory.  The Chinese industrial revolution has had a dramatic impact on the sales of low-end electrical appliances in Bulgaria, as their costs have dropped to the point where an increasing number of Bulgarians can afford them.  While DVD players remain rare (a $100 player is 2 weeks salary for most here) many families are using small credit programs to finally replace 20-year old appliances.  We think Toncho is well-positioned to address this growing market in Sliven.

In 1989, after the fall of communism in Bulgaria, Ivan began to drive a taxi.  He initially began working for another company, although several years ago was able to put together enough money for his own car and strike out on his own.  He now is a member of a cab co-op, which allows Ivan to work for himself, while having the infrastructure he would enjoy working for a larger company; the co-op provides its members with centralized dispatch, discounted repair and maintenance, and other services.   He is in need, however, at this point of a new car.  He has found a used Opel Astra for approx. $4,000, which fits his needs nicely.  This loan will fund half the cost, while he will be using his own cash for the remaining cost.  He has two children, one of whom is currently taking an auto mechanics course (which may come in handy at some point for dad…)   His wife is a seamstress and his daughter is still in school.  The S. family lives in Sliven, Bulgaria.

Bahar and his wife own a café in the Turkish quarter of Sliven, Bulgaria.  It is a modest spot, predominately offering drinks and simple foods, such as crepes, and a well-worn pool table.  The café seats up to 12 people.   In conjunction with the café, Bahar’s wife runs a business importing textiles from Turkey.  She makes the trip to Turkey monthly, bringing back predominately clothes, which she then sells in a corner of the café and a variety of local markets.  She typically makes the trip to Turkey on the night train with two of her three grown children for safety’s sake. The loan proceeds will fund two things: 1) working capital for the café and 2) inventory and transportation expenses for the clothing business.   As a historical aside, after the brutal Ottoman occupation of Bulgaria (15th century to late 19th century) the Turks who remained in Bulgaria for the most part either cloistered themselves or moved east to be again inside Ottoman lands.  10% of the Bulgarian population is of Turkish descent, and is often excluded from mainstream society due to their religion (Islam) and residual resentment many ethnic Bulgarians still feel against the Turks, nearly 150 years later.

Fana owns and runs a small grocery in one of the Roma neighborhoods in Sliven, Bulgaria.  She has had this small store for 15 years, and has built up enough of a capital base to enable her to extend credit to many of her customers in difficult times.  However, she has found herself with a surprising expense – a new refrigerator. Her current cooler has started to leak badly, and has become prohibitively expensive to operate, increasingly so as the summer approaches.  Unplugging it is not an option – yogurt is a staple of the Bulgarian diet, accounting for a significant amount of her sales year-round, and in the summer, ice cream sales become a major revenue contributor.   Fana’s daughter and husband work for her.  Her daughter typically works in the store while her husband focuses on sourcing inventory from the lowest-cost provider in the region.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

Kurte is a vocalist from the Roma minority in Bulgaria.    He began his career with a local group, the Kitka Orchestra.  He then moved around, working with the Lulugi, Melodia and now the Kozar Orchestras.     

Kurte’s dream is to record his own solo album with the songs he has written.  This money is going to be used for the costs of producing his new album.  The costs include studio time, CD pressing and licensing for the covers he will record. 

Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

Mihail had been a soccer player in Bulgaria for 10 years, before, in his own words, “things started to fall apart.”  For the past several years, he has been playing the drums in several bands in Sliven, performing at weddings and other celebrations.  While he has no formal music education, his entire family was comprised of musicians growing up, and it seems as second nature to him.  He is 30 years old and has two kids.  When not playing music or touring, Mihail and his wife operate a hamburger-like stand in the Roma section of town.   Every summer for the past several years, Mihail and his wife have gone to the Black Sea coast for work.  Last summer, Mihail began to play with “Southern Nights” orchestra in Sunny Beach.  While Mihail plays, his wife does hair braiding and styling on the street for tourists.    This loan will be used to finance the upfront costs for this summer’s work; travel expenses, instrument tuning and the purchase of this year’s uniform.  The loan duration is 1 year, although we expect the preponderance of the loan to be repaid in a shorter time frame.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

Metodi is a 54-year old piano player living in Sliven, Bulgaria.  He is a member of the Roma minority, and works as a keyboardist in a Roma band.  He began playing music as a child, tapping anything that would make a good percussion beat.  He attended a government-run music high school in on the west coast of Bulgaria in Burgas and then in a military academy in Plovdiv, where his training focused on classical music.  He began working in the Bulgarian Army Band where he played the accordion and other instruments as needed.   Since the massive military cuts of the post-Cold War era, Metodi looks for work feverishly, both as a solo performer and in a group.  Last summer, Metodi began to play with “Southern Nights” orchestra in Sunny Beach.    Sunny Beach is a new tourist destination for western Europeans on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast.  This loan will be used to finance the upfront costs for this summer’s work; travel expenses, instrument tuning and the purchase of this year’s uniform.  The loan duration is 1 year, although we expect the preponderance of the loan to be repaid in a shorter time frame.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

Alexander is a musical jack-of-all-trades.  Having studied at an institution in Bulgaria, Musical Academy “Tschakovsky” in Sofia, he plays all sorts of wind instruments – Trombone, Clarinet, Trumpet, etc. – as the situation requires, in addition to the piano and accordion.    Upon graduating, he worked as an Army musician for 28 years.  Once he reached the mandatory retirement age, Alexander joined the Karandila Orchestra, a Roma group based in Sliven, Bulgaria, which plays weddings and tours as often as they can.  One of the most unfortunate aspects of the transition from communism to capitalism is the lack of savings of the eldery, coupled with the low support from the state.  For those currently in the 65-85 age bracket, their entire working years was during communism.  During that time there was little money to be saved, but there was little perceived need; the government would take care of them.  As that paradigm has shifted dramatically, many of those who have "retired" have returned to the workforce to supplement the $50 the government gives them monthly.           This loan will be used to finance the upfront costs for this summer’s work; travel expenses, instrument tuning and the purchase of this year’s uniform.  The loan duration is 1 year, although we expect the preponderance of the loan to be repaid in a shorter time frame.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

I am 26 years old, married with three children. I have been selling vegetables in Mukuyu Market for the last four years. As i worked, i faced different challeges in raising enough money to support my family. Also, the little that i saved, it could not last long.I joined a women group which assisted me to save some money with it, which later would be lent to some one. I have used three small loans from this group, the first one was USD.60, then,USD 165 and USD 225. I paid all these loans promptly and i hope to get another to push me forward. I have been able to send my children to school and look forward to a better life.

<font size="2">I am a young lady aged 26, married with two children. My business is at Mukuyu market in Muranga District, Kenya. I have been in this business for over four years and for all this time it has been growing steadily. My current stock is about USD.325 and need to be boosted to increase the rate of return. By stocking new clothes, i will be in a position of pulling more customers because of having a variety which ar</font><font size="2">e of high quality and </font><font size="2">pocket friendly. I have been using loans from the group but because of not being enough to cover all members, i have opted this funding. I had an opportunity of using three loans and paid them back. </font>

Beatrice is 47 years married with six children.  She is a nutritionist in the village where she lives.  She educates other members within the community of the importance of growing and eating vegetables for a healthy living.

 She started her business in 2003, grows and sells vegetables. Her main customers come from Muranga town who sell the vegetables as far as the city Nairobi. She is assured of the market because of the high quality of her vegetables. She has been receiving loans from the group but the group is unable to handle the demand because of her demand for a bigger loan.

I am 42 years old, married with three children. I am the treasurer of a self help group called Konguini Thayu Women Group. Our major activity is savings and credit done by all members of the group.I have been the treasurer of this group since 2003.

I started my business in 1998 and have been able to construct a small shop and bought a dairy cow. Having a big space and on a strategic position at the centre of town coupled with the demand for soft drinks in this part of town, i believe it will be a good venture. This will bring in more income which wilgive me the opportunity to give my children better education and improve my standard of living.

I have been a chairperson for a self help group called Kaganda Magdalene Mothers for three years. I am married and have five children.

I started my business in 1987 and it is always improving. I sell a variety of household commodities at Kaganda shopping centre in Muranga, Kenya. I have been able to look after my family as well as educating my children.

Also, i have been able to repay four small loans which I received from my group.

I have been a secretary of Konguini Thayu Women Group for the last three years. Prior to joining the group I could not take minutes but now I have been empowered and been able to take the minutes for the group and come-up with an Agenda. I am married and have three children

I have been selling cereals as a business in a small town called Mukuyu in Central Kenya. The business has been progressing very well and the profits I get I have been able to venture into buying and selling sand and stones for building.

I am married with three children and am the Chairlady of Konguini Thayu Women group. When I joined the group I did not realise that I have leadership qualities. I have managed to improve the groups activities and empowering other members of the group.

I run a restaurant and sell produce in Embu Central Market in Kenya.  I have been in this business for more than 20 years and it has enabled me educate my children and my last born in Secondary school.  My first loan was Usd.300 and the 2nd one wasUsd.600. All loans were paid promptly because of good profits from my business.

I am 46 years old and an active member of Konguini Thayu Women Group and my activity in the group is rules controller which I have held since the group was formed in 2003.  Prior to joining the group I did not know that I can enforce group rules and regulations. 

I  sell my rice in diffrent parts of Central Kenya that is in Kagio, Kangari Karatina and Embu.  I buy as a wholesaler and sell to other retailers who inturn sell to small towns and individual customers.  The group revolving fund is not swift enough to cater for all members at the same time and this calls for external funding to cover the gap.  The business currently needs support to maintain the level of stock so that I do not dissapoint my customers because the demand is very high.

I am 50 years old and married with four children and a member of the Loans committee in charge of appraising members for group loans in Kongoini Thayu Women Group

 I have been running this business with my husband since 1970.  In addition to the business,we have a dairy cow which produces 15 litres of milk per milking and this supplements our income and also been able to feed my family with the milk at the same time selling to the milk vendors.  My first loan was Usd.300 and the second one was the same and I managed to pay promptly

Denis T. is married with five children and taking care of three Orphans who live with them in their family.
He started his business by selling firewood.  He did very well in this business.
 
In 2002 he got a loan from WITEP worth $ 200 and he changed the business to selling of used cloths.
 
He got enough money and he has started a new business of selling New Cloths.
Given a loan of $ 900, he plans to expand his business by stocking New Cloths for Gents, Ladies, Children and Girls / Boys.
 
This business will fetch him enough money for refunding the loan money, meeting the basic needs of the family.
This man is of integrity and he is capable of refunding the loan money.

Ochomi N. is married with eight children.
 
He started a small business of retail shop in the village.  The business grew steadily and the stock expanded after getting a loan of $ 200 from WITEP.
 
He now wants to expand the business to meet the high demand from customers in the strategic place in village.
 
It is 15 kilometers to reach the main town of Mbale.  So people of the community refer buying essential commodities from him than going to town.
 
Given a loan of $800, he plans to expand the business to meet the stock.
 
He is man of integrity and respect who will be in position to refund the money.

Omutia M. is a married woman with nine children. She has done charcoal business for five years now.
 
She started by buying one sack and then sell it in a small groups of bundles put together at 500 shillings Uganda money.
 
She got a loan of $200 from WITEP  that enabled her to increase her stock to ten bags now.
 
Uganda is a rainy forest country where by charcoal is the major fuel for cooking both in towns and villages.
 
The demand of charcoal is very high during this period when there is too much rain. Given a loan of $800, she plans to increase the stock by hiring a lorry then can buy up to 80 sacks of charcoal.
 
This will fetch her enough money to pay for the loan money and take care of her family.
 
She is a respected woman in the community.

Grace is married woman with a five children.  This is a business oriented woman who believes in achieving her goals.
 
She started by selling produce e.g. Maize, Millet, Sorghum, Rice, Groundnuts, Pease from WITEP worth $200 that helped her to increase her stock.
 
Given a loan   of $1,000, she plans to expand her business by opening up a store in Mbale Town in order meet the middle man with her produce.  She will increase the quantity and quality of each item that, she sells.
 
This is a woman of high dignity who is able to refund the loan money without any problem.

Simon started by selling of chicken in the market. After doing this business for two years, he got some more money to venture into more paying business.  He started selling goats in the village markets.
 
He got a loan money of $200 and this expanded his business to selling cows in the local markets around.
 
He can now afford to buy up to 3 bulls of 300,000 shillings each.
Given a loan of $1000, he plans to expand his business by buying up to 15 Bulls that can fetch him enough profit to meet his basic needs and pay the loan money.
 
Uganda being a rainy country, cows have enough grass to feed on freely.
 
Simon is a respected a man in the community who is able to refund the loan money.

Wilson Hernandez is a 41-year-old native of Guayaquil who is married and has 3 children. He owns his home and rents a location for his business where he sells, repairs and refurbishes furniture. He sells all types of items, including popular outdoor pieces made with wood perfect for beach conditions. His business is located near his home in a popular business sector. He opens from 8:30 AM to 6:30 PM and counts on the help of one employee and his oldest daughter. He is in need of $575 dollars in order to buy materials (such as wood and paint) necessary for the production and refurbishment of new items.

Rosa C. is a 47 year old single mother of four children. Although only two of her children still live at home she has the responsibility of supporting one of them who is currently enrolled in a University. Her dream is to have her children attain college degrees and become professionals.

 

Her beauty salon has been established for over thirteen years. She has a dedicated group of clients but she is looking to expand her business in order to increase profits. She is interested in hiring another employee and offering new services. Therefore, she will use the capital in order to help her hire a new employee and buy products that will help her diversify her offerings.

Carmen H. is a mother of 3 and is 42 years old. Although she lives in Duran, her dental office is located in Guayaquil. She has just a little less than 20 years of experience in the field and is interested in investing in new tools that will help her be more efficient and offer better service to her clients. She currently opens at 6 AM and works diligently until 8 PM. She seems to be very responsible and highly dedicated to her work.

Jorge R. is a 30 year old married man and a father of 2. He owns a mechanic shop in an area where there is very little competition. He opens up shop at 7:30 AM and works until 4:00 PM. His clients attest that his service is good and convenient because of the location. He is in need of a $355 loan in order to purchase new tools and more materials that allow him to work efficiently and conveniently.

Boris P. is a 39 year old computer technician in Guayaquil. At his shop he repairs computers with hardware and software issues and sells computer accessories. He also helps his clients get connected online and shows them how to use the power of the Internet to their advantage. This in itself is a valuable service to the community as he is helping to bridge the technology gap and break paradigms in computer literacy.  Currently he counts on the help of two employees who all help him run his shop from 8 AM until 10 PM. He intends to use the loan to add another employee, buy accessories in bulk and buy newer tools for computer repair.

Ervin L. is 27 years old and has three children. He owns a small location where he sells ceviche, a common Ecuadorian dish made with seafood, lime, onions and tomatoes. He is near a very popular market that creates high traffic around his area and helps him sell. He has an assistant who helps him along with the mother of his children. He is in need of a loan in order to buy more seafood so that he can meet the increasing demand he is experiencing. He is also eager to add chairs and tables for his clients in order to create a more inviting dining environment.

Lourdes R. is a 46 year old mother of five, although she now only has the responsibility of her 11 year old daughter. She owns a small restaurant that serves breakfast and dinner mainly to her loyal customers who are workers in the area. She opens at 6 AM and closes at 4 PM. She is in need of this loan in order to buy food in bulk and make some minor improvements to her location.

Maria C. is 41 years old, is married and has 3 children. She owns a business where members of the community make long distance and local phone calls. This is a valuable service in her area because many people cannot afford to have their own phone lines in their home. Recently the city made her move back part of her business in order to abide by local regulations. She is in need of a loan in order to repair the floor that was damaged in order to comply with the local government. The current condition is having a significantly negative effect on her business.

Oswaldo C. is 33 years old, has three children and owns a restaurant that he opened about a year ago. He is encouraged by the progress and popularity of his venture and is seeking to invest in improvements to the location and to take advantage of buying food in bulk. The restaurant is conveniently located on a main street where he gets plenty of attention and business. He works from 8:00 AM until 10:00 PM.

Rosa P. has two children and is 35 years old. She owns a store in 
Guayaquil where she sells food in large amounts like rice, corn and sugar. The business is located in her parents home which is conveniently located on a main street. She is seeking to diversify her product offerings and buy in larger quantities for her clients. She also sells women’s clothing and perfume as a side job in order to bring in extra income for her home. She will use the loan primarily for her store in order to increase her inventory and boost sales.

Edgar P., originally from Riobamba, Ecuador, is a 39 year old salesman with two children, eight and five years old. Mr. P. is a homeowner. His business is located in a section of Guayaquil called Bastión Popular, and it has been in operation for seven years. His wife helps him with sales and administrative work from 6:00 am until 6:00 pm. Edgar is in charge of managing some customers’ weekly credit tabs, although most customers pay cash for his goods on the spot. He needs this loan money to be able to buy other products like watches, lamps, bed sheets, and other home items. Mr. P. thinks this loan will also help financially because he can receive a discount from wholesalers if he buys in bulk and pays in cash. Lastly, Edgar wants lenders to know that he is a hard-working entrepreneur.

Felipe Guterrez is a 45 year-old businessman from Manabi, Ecuador with one son. Mr. G. is a homeowner who runs a seafood restaurant in the busy market called Municipal de Bastión Popular. His clientele is mainly locals from the neighborhood. With 11 years of experience at this particular business, he and his wife who also helps run the operation work from 6:00 am until 1:00 pm. Mr. G. needs this loan to be able to buy more seafood and a display case to show off the meals of the day. Don Felipe is a persevering self-starter who loves managing his small seafood restaurant.

Diana F., who was born in Quevado, Ecuador, is a 22 year-old single woman who resides with her parents. She runs a small gift shop in the Municipal de Bastión Popular that is known for its selection of perfumes. She has been in business for 5 years. Every morning from 6:00 am until 2:00 pm Diana and her mother operate their shop. Ms. F. wants this loan to buy more products and diversify her stock. This hard-working young woman not only runs this business; she is wrapping up her studies at the University in Business Administration.

Cesar P., who was born in Chimborazo, a region in Ecuador known for its famous extinct volcano. Mr. P. is married with one son, he is a homeowner, and his forte is preparing a delicious South American soup called encebollado. His restaurant is located on one of Guayaqil’s major avenues and has been serving up Don P.’s famous recipe soup for 8 years. Before starting his own business, Cesar worked at a restaurant for 12 years. When he thought he was ready to open his own business, he used what little savings he had and rented a small storefront along a well-positioned thoroughfare in downtown Guayquil. He and his wife work hard every day from 6:00 am until 1:00 pm, and they are requesting $1035.00 to be able to buy key ingredients in bulk. For instance: oil, dressing, cola, etc… He also would like to buy some uniform utensils and dishes to serve up encebollado.

 

For more information about the history and culture of Riobamba, the largest city in the province of Chimborazo, read here.

Jane is an active member Kabuta Ladies in Action a group she joined in 2001. She is married with 2 children who go to primary and secondary School.

She started her business with her husband in 2001. The business has grown over the years to be the best in Muranga Town and this has led to the opening of another outlet on another street. On average the butchery sells 100kgs per day and at every end of month the demand is so high and this calls for attention.

Salydia has been a good member of the group since it was started in 2001. She is a single mother aged 44 years with one child who is in college.

She started by selling maize and beans in Sagana market in 1990. In 1998, she realized that people wanted meat but it was not enough in the market. She started rearing cows and goats for sale. In 2001, she borrowed USD.150 bought goats which she later sold and paid the loan back. The small profit she earned was used to pay her child’s school fees and home upkeep

Grace is the chairlady of Kabuta Ladies in action a post she has held since 2001. She is also a treasurer of her local church in Kabuta and a retired Primary school teacher.

She has been in this business for over 20 years and this gives her confidence in soliciting for more funding because she is sure and understands market trends.  The group manages a revolving fund and she has been able to pay back two loans of USD 300. Her produce is sold in muranga town as well as to middle men who take it to Nairobi because of the cheap railway transport.

Felicina is an active member both in group and her church where she is a prayer leader. She is married with nine children, four are working while other four are in college and one in secondary school.\r\n\r\nShe has been in business for more than twenty five years. She has a stall at Githma market. She has been able to educated her four children who are already working but the conditions have changed and for the business to keep running normarlly, some funding is needed.

Joyce is a widow with four children all in Primary school. She is hard working and very active in group activities.

\r\nWith the husband they started with two rooms in 2004 and in June 2005 they added two more to be four all together. She gets USD.88 every month and in addition she sells bananas, maize and vegetables.

W. is the chairlady of this group. She is a widow fortunately her last child is in college. She is also the treasurer of rural Electrification project in her area and a retired Primary school teacher.

She sells milk in Thika Town and Saba Saba town ship. She sells about 150 litres every day earning about USD.37 per day. She has created a big clientele in Thika because of being honest and maintaining the quality of her milk.

Mary is married with three children and an active member of the group and her church. She is aged 30 years.

\r\nShe has been selling handicraft and milk for one year and two years respectively. She sells 6.5 litres every day earning USD1.6 and the craft shop brings in about USD.55 per month. The business is growing day -by- day however, cash withdrawals affect it very much.

Ruth is a good member of Kahumbu Kwirera Mothers and she has been a member since the group started in January 2005. She is married with three children who are still in primary school.

\r\n\r\nShe sells milk and maize to clients in Kirigo tranding centre. The reason why she started selling maize is that; it is the staple food for the Kenyans and therefore at any time you are assured of making a sale. She borrowed a loan of USD.300 from the group and repaid it and it has pushed her to selling over 100 kgs in two days.

Robina is married with 4 children all of them in college. She is a Chairlady of a home cell in her church and a retired primary teacher.

\r\n\r\nShe has a stall at Mizizi market where she sells vegetables while carrying on her teaching profession. She says she would not have managed to educate her children to university level had it not been the income from this small business. Her husband comes in once in a while when she needs help and this has helped her very much.

Evelyn is the Treasurer of Kahumbu Kwirera Mothers. She is a hard working lady, a widow with six children all working.
\r\n\r\nShe sells milk from her two dairy cows and bananas. She sells ten litres of milk every day giving her USD.2.5. There is a ready market for milk in Maragua, as well as Thika, which calls for increase in supply.

Albert W. is a dedicated and talented young artist who joined Life in Africa in 2005. He was very excited to join since LiA offered him the opportunity to develop and use his artistic talent as well as to earn an income. He proved to be a fast learner and very quickly earned a job with the Invisible Children Bracelet project where he works as a sander.

This income is very important to him. He is just a young man but when his father died he was the oldest and it was up to him to take over the responsiblity for his mother and younger siblings. He tried at first to do this by selling his artwork. He quickly found that selling art is not like selling food or charcoal which are needed on a daily basis. Art is more of a luxury and this made their life very difficult. But he is determined to do right for his family and he came up with a plan.

His plan is to cash in on the high demand for decent housing by building three rooms to rent out. He and his brothers have worked very hard and have made 7000 bricks by hand that are now ready to be fired. He knows that once this project is complete the income will greatly improve their lives and will insure that there is sufficent money for school fees and medicine for his younger siblings. He is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 which will fire the bricks and build the house up to the beams. He will be able to repay this loan in 10 ,months.

His budget is as indicated below:

Burning Bricks --------- Ushs.150,000

Cement 10 bags --------- Ushs.190,000

Sand 2 trips --------- Ushs.160,000

 Concrete stones -------- Ushs.100,000

Tranport --------- Ushs. 60,000

Water --------- Ushs.20,000

 Labour --------- Ushs.100,000

Incidentals --------- Ushs. 20,000

Total --------- Uhs.800,000

He wants to repay this loan in 10 months and his expenses verses income is 100,000.

WE Team to Benefit: Internet4change

Joyce K. joined Life in Africa in August of 2005. She is a very happy and dedicated member who loves what is happening at LiA and all the opportunities that are made available to people just like her. She is currently working in the Invisible Children Bracelet project creating bracelets and this has greatly improved the lives of her family by providing a steady source of income.

She has a large family and this means that the needs are also large. Her younger brother lives with her and together they have come up with a good plan to increase their income. Their plan is to purchase a motorcycle which her brother will operate as a a bodaboda (for hire). Transport is very needed in Kampala and bodaboda drivers can do quite well.

The money earned from this business will help the family but Joyce also realizes that as a young man, her brother also needs to have some money of his own. They have agreed that one day a week he will keep the money as his salary which will allow him to start saving for the time when he will have his own home and life. The family has already saved 500,000 towards this project. She is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to add to this to make the purchase. She will be able to repay this loan in 8 months.

She wants to pay this loan in a period of 8 months and her income verses expenses is Ushs.190,000

She saves Ushs. 50,000 per month and remains with Ushs. 140,000.

Gilbert M. joined Life in Africa in 2005. He started as a volunteer working with visual images. His hard work and dedication has earned him a full time paid position as Visual Images Manager at the WE Center.

Gilbert has a passion for computers and he wishes to pursue a higher education majoring in computer studies. In order to accomplish this goal he has devised a plan to open a business.

This will give him the necessary funds to complete his education. The business he has chosen is a secretarial service.

He has already secured a space for this business and has one computer in place. The location of the space is near the University and services such as this are in high demand by the students which will offer a strong customer base to support the business. The services to be offered include photocopying , scanning , typing and printing , plus spiral and book binding. Eventually he is also going to venture into CD writng and music recording.

Gilbert has already saved Ushs.900,000 and he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to get the business up and running. To start this business, he is seeking a loan in the amount of Ushs.800,000. He will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

M. Rebecca is a young woman full of hope for the future. She is an active member of Life in Africa and is employed in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. In addition she also participates in many of the other activities offered by LiA and her positive attitude affects all those she comes in contact with.

She also is very responsible and has a good and generous heart. She supports her brother financially as well as two Aids orphans. These children are currently staying with relatives and even with the money she sends, they live under very poor conditions. She really wants to be able to give them a better life and longs to earn enough to provide school fees so these children can be educated.

She has a sister living in Kampala who is not able to go to school herself. Together they plan to open a second hand clothes business. Rebecca has worked in this type of business before and knows that she can make a good income once she gets it going. Her sister will help by working this business while Rebecca continues on at LiA. The business will be located at Kisasi trading center but they also plan to ocassionally shift to other locations to increase their business. She is so determined in this plan that she has already saved 150,000 towards the start up. She is seeking a loan in the amount 500,000 to add to this. Kyaziike Joan is a remarkable young woman. She is very responsible and dedicated even for her young years. She joined Life in Africa in November of 2005 and has been an active member being employed by the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She has just finished her secondary schooling and she now longs to go on to the University to complete her education.

She lives at home with her parents and she is the eldest of their four children. Her father's income in somewhat unsteady so she gladly helps financially using her salary. Her father wisely worked hard and built a two room house next to their family home. This is rented out and the income from this rental has paid the school fees for Joan so far. However, the University fees are much higher and they are looking at ways to increase their income to provide for this.

The plan is to add two more rooms to the existing house. This will double the amount of rent they will earn. Housing is in great demand in Kampala so they know they will have no problem finding tenants. The money from this rental will be used to pay the University fees for Joan's education and for her younger siblings who will follow her. Annet N. has been an active member of Life in Africa since 2005. She started as a volunteer working in the arts and crafts center and then moved to a paying job working with the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She enjoys working on this project and at LiA because it offers the workers a way out of poverty. She is a single woman living on her own without the help of her family and her salary sustains her.

She has been fortunate to be able to live with friends who agreed to help her. Out of kindness toward her they have not charged her any rent. But she knows that this cannot continue since their own situation is very unstable. While she is very grateful for their kindness, she is now looking for a way to provide housing for herself as well as to add to her income. She has realized that housing is in great demand all the time in Kampala and she has decided to invest in property for herself and to rent out for income.

The first phase of this project will be to secure a plot of land. She has found the plot she wants and she has successfully negotiated a deal with the landowner. If she can come up with the money needed by the end of June he will sell her the property. Once she has paid for the land, she will then build a house on it to live in and also apartments that she will rent out. In this way she will be able to secure her future. To succeed at this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to add to the 2,200,000 that she has managed to save herself. She will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

This is her budget: Land Aqcuisition --- 800,000/= Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: integrated Adult Education

A. Rose is an active member of Life in Africa working in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She is 34 years old, is married and has 6 children. She is Acholi and originally lived in the Pader District in Northern Uganda. It was there that the rebels attacked her village and abducted two of her children. Her children were gone for two years but were finally rescued by government troups and were returned to her in the camp she fled to in Kampala. Rose and her husband both started working in the stone quarry but they were not able to earn enough to sustain the family. When she joined LiA their lives took a turn for the better. They have more money and they have been able to save enough to build a modest home which also helps financially since they no longer have to pay rent.

Their plan now is to enlarge the stone quarry work that her husband still does. By making it their own business they will be able to hire others so her husband does not have to do all the work himself and their production will increase giving them more income. To do this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is the budget in full:-

  1. Buying stone site 200,000=

  2. Labour digging up stones 150,000=

  3. Pulling out from pit 60,000=

  4. Cracking stones 60,000=

  5. Loading onto vehicles 30,000=

    Total 500,000=

WE Team to benefit: Adult Education

Margaret is an active member of Life in Africa. She is young, dedicated and very determined to make a secure future for herself. She originally came from Western Uganda but moved to Kampala where she lives with an aunt who agreed to help her with her education by taking her in and paying the school fees. She finished her secondary schooling but going on to the University became impossible due to lack of funds. But she would not be stopped.

She found the Womens Vocational Education Center where she managed to enroll in a course to learn catering. She graduated after 2 years and is determined to use what she learned to start a business. She currently works Monday through Friday at Life in Africa and runs a small scale catering service on the weekends. She saved carefully and has been able to buy things she needed such as warmers, plates, forks, knives, and table cloths which she rents out to her customers.

Her client list has grown and now she is ready to expand her small business. This will entail the purchase of more equipment so she will be able to cater to more customers and handle larger gatherings. For this reason she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

300 plates @ 1000/ ------------300,000/

150 forks @ 1200/ -----------180,000/

150 knives @ 1000/-----------150,000/

4 big saucepans @ 40000/ -----160,000/

Transport----------------------10,000/

Totals ------------------------800,000/

WE Team to benefit: Transport 4 liA

A. Esither is an active member of Life in Africa. She lives with her family in the Acholi quarters which is a camp for displaced persons from the wartorn North. Life is very difficult in the camps and the thousands who live there have very inadequate facilities and few services available to them. As a very observant person she has studied her community to see what services she could provide.

As a result of her observations, she decided that the people living in the camp need to raise their self esteem. They need to be as smartly dressed and groomed as any other people living in Kampala. To this end she plans to open a men's saloon (barber shop). Her husband who currently toils in the rock quarry would run the business while she continues with her work at LiA.

Her plans include erecting a small room adjacent to her house where there is power available. She also will purchase a small generator so that the business can still run even with the current power crisis in Uganda. Currently there are only a few such businesses and customers have to wait a very long time to have their turn to get shaved. She will be able to service more people and can keep the prices low so they can afford it.

To complete this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/=. She will be able to repay the loan in 12 months at a rate of 41,667/= per month.

  • Machine for shaving……………...70,000/=
  • A large mirror…………………….60,000/=

  • One bench …………………………5,000/=
  • installing power....20,000/=
  • Building saloon shack…………….20,000/=
  • 4 iron sheets............. 40,000/=
  • others......................5000/=

Total = 500,000/=

B. Auma is an active member of Life in Africa. She is married and has six children. Originally she lived in Northern Uganda where there has been war for twenty years. Her father was killed in this war and soon after she came to Kampala in search of a safer place to live. Here she earned what money she could by working in the rock quarry and also by selling yellow bananas. These she carried in a basket on her head and she would walk miles each day in hopes of finding customers.

Her life was very difficult and she barely earned enough to provide food for her children much less to pay school fees. But happily, she found Life in Africa and there she now earns a good living. Life has much improved for her and her family and money is now there for rent, food and even school fees for the children.

As her life improved, she started to have hope and allowed herself to start seeing a future. She carefully saved money and has acquired a plot of land in the Acholi quarters where she lives. On this land she plans to build a two room house for her family to live in. This will not only improve their standard of living but will enable the family to save the rent money they now pay each month. With this saved money the family hopes to build a permanent house in their home land when it is safe to return. For this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. She will be able to repay this loan in one year.

She came to Kampala in 2003 when she had to flee her home in Northern Uganda because of the war. She was quite bored just sitting in the camps and so she tried working in the stone quarry to earn money. She found this work to be extremely hard physically. She still works the quarry but now hires others to do the actual labor.

She is a good business woman and knows that she can make a success of a business that offers a needed service in her community. She plans to open a salon/barber shop. The profits from this business will allow her to save so that someday she can build a permanent home and possibly another house to rent out. To do this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000. A. Pamela is an active member of Life in Africa. She is currently working in the Invisible Children Bracelet project making bracelets and she is earning a good salary for her efforts.

She live in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters where thousands who were forced to flee the war in the North have settled. She lives with her uncle but he has no work to do and so they are dependent on her income. She realizes that if there were some work for him to do their lives could be so much better and he would be happy to have work that would bring income to the household. And so she studied their situation and came up with a plan.

Groundnuts are consumed in great quantities by the Acholi. They grind these nuts and use them in sauces and nuts that are already ground are in good demand. Therefore, a local small scale business of grinding and packaging the groundnuts would be very suitable for her uncle to do. Richard O. has been an active member of Life in Africa since August of 2005. He works as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. In his spare time he works at the rock quarry and he and his wife both make paper beads and hope to someday find a market for them.

He is 36 years old and has four children. They live in the Acholi quarters which is a camp for people displaced by the war in the North. They have been their eight years arriving with nothing since they lost all their possessions when the rebels burned their home. Before joining Life in Africa, their life was horrible. They barely existed on one meal a day and had no money for things like clothes or school. His children now are amazed at how their life has changed. They now have clothes, shoes, mattresses to sleep on and they are able to eat three meals a day. But more important, the contact with other positive people and the sharing of skills and ideas have given them the courage to dream and plan for a future.

Their dream now is to have a proper house. Richard has saved enough to acquire a plot of land and he now plans to build a family home. Then with the money he saves on rent, he will save to build a second home to rent out which will add to their income and give them a more secure future. He has the skills to provide the labor himself and has already saved part of the money needed for materials. To complete this project he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is his budget in full:

1- Bricks 2000@ 60/= ------------ 120,000/=

2- Cement 6 bags @ 18,000/= -------- 108,000/=

3 - Iron sheets 20 pcs. @ 10,000/= 200,000/=

4 - Roofing poles 10 pcs. @ 3,000/= 30,000/=

5 - Transport --------------- 42,000/=

TOTAL -------------- 500,000/=

Through his savings, He will buy the sand and the fittings. He also has some building skills, so he will be responsible for the labour.

Richard's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by his community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. He has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest he will pay on this loan to support the WE Center Gulu.

B. George is an active member of Life in Africa. He works in the Invisible Children Bracelet project as a sander and he is finally earning a good income for his family. He is a humble man and is dedicated to creating a new and better life for his family. His family was forced to flee the North where the rebels are waging war and they live in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters. He has a wife and six children he is supporting and he also has a brother who lives with them.

His brother needs work to do and the additional income his brother could earn would greatly improve the life of the entire family. They have a plan to start a groundnut business which the brother can operate from their home. Groundnuts are a great favorite of the Acholi and as such are in great demand especially if they are already ground and packaged in small quantities making it affordable.

This business will be local and small scale but has the potential to grow. To start this business he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to purchase the equipment necessary. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is his break down:

1, paste miller small size @ 350,000/=

2, Small generator @ 250,000/=

3, Groundnuts 100kg @ 150,000/=

4, Renting one room with power for three months @ 25,000/= = 75,000/=

5, Transport 10,000/=

6, packaging 40,000/=

Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: self sustaining development.

S. Sok is married and father of two children. He is self employed as a moto-taxi. He came to CREDIT office to request a $500 loan and explained his plan: “I would like to buy a motorbike”, he said, “so that my wife can start her own business”. She will use the motorbike for buying and selling eggs to the local market.

S. Sok expects the motorbike to cost around $250 and his wife will use the remaining $250 as running capital for the eggs business.

He detailed the household forecasted daily income and expenses as following:

 

Moto Taxi:

25,000 taxi fare

 -8000 Petrol

=17,000 Riel ($4.12)

 

Eggs Business:

80,000 sale

-50,000 cost of eggs

-2000 petrol

=28,000 Riel ($7)

 

S. Sok is confident, but also concerned about this new business. “I am working from 3pm to 4 am while my wife will start her working days at 4am; I will hardly see her face.”

“Hopefully we will improve our standard of living and sometimes be able to build a proper house and buy a cow”, he added. His is also dreaming about his children going to the high school and the university.

L. S. Ros, a traditional medicine manufacturer and seller, is applying for his first loan from CREDIT MFI in the amount of $400.   L. S. Ros received training on making traditional medicine five years ago, and he has been making and selling medicine ever since. Currently, he is selling the medicines from his home, and he is periodically making home visits when someone calls on him. His medicines are traditional herbal medicines that he makes from a variety of plants to treat multiple illnesses. L. S. Ros’s wife assists in the production of the medicine in their home.

 

With this loan L. S. Ros plans on purchasing a motorcycle ($300) so that he may drive around with his medicines, thus expanding his business. He will spend the other $100 to purchase raw materials for the medicine production.  Currently, L. S. Ros is making about $2 a day from his traditional medicine business. L. S. Ros is hoping to improve his family’s standard of living through the growth of the business. L. S. Ros and his wife have three children who live with them in their home. Two of their children currently attend school, and L. S. Ros desires to increase their income enough to be able to send their third child to school as well.

N. K. Hing lives with her two adult sons and one daughter in Phnom Penh. She is starting an air conditioning sales and repair business to help support her family. N. K. Hing is requesting her first loan from CREDIT MFI in the amount of $1,000 to pay for the import taxes that she incurred when importing the air conditioners from the United States. The taxes totaled $2,500, but she is only requesting $1,000 for her loan. Her two sons will be working in the business, and one of them currently works for a different air condition company where he has received much training.

 

With this loan N. K. Hing plans to open her new air conditioning shop in June. She is excited about this new opportunity, and she hopes to be able to continue to invest into the business and grow to the point where she can hire other people in her community. She would also like to raise her standard of living enough to be able to build a new home for her and her family.

P. Mom is currently a moto taxi driver in Phnom Penh. He is requesting a loan of $800 in order to change his moto taxi into a tuk tuk (a passenger cart that is pulled by a motorcycle). The cart costs $700, and he will use the other $100 to cover the cost of improving his moto so that it is strong enough to pull the cart.  Currently, P. Mom makes about $2 a day as a moto taxi driver. He anticipates that with his new tuk tuk he will be able to make $10 gross income, and he will have about $4 in expenses, which means he should make about $6 a day. This will greatly increase his family’s standard of living.

 

P. Mom lives with his wife and one daughter. He has two grown children who are working in factories nearby, and one child who is studying in their original village. His wife currently sells food and fruits from their home.  P. Mom is hoping that he can increase their income enough that his wife’s business can expand into a grocery store. He would also like to make improvements on their home.

K. Sokrorn is a mother of three in Phnom Penh, who is currently selling food in front of the local factories. She is making approximately $7.50 a day from selling food. After seeing her friend successfully open a store, K. Sokrorn decided that she would like to open a grocery store. Therefore, she is applying for her first loan from CREDIT MFI in order to acquire the inventory for her store. She is requesting $500 to purchase fruits, vegetables, and other products for the store.

 

K. Sokrorn and her husband, who is a moto taxi driver, are expecting this new grocery store to help them improve the lives of their children. They would like to use the additional income they will receive from the business to build a new home and purchase cows.

Maari is married with 6 children. Maari has been greatly empowered through her active participation in various development activities. She is the coordinator of her village focal group. WEEC organized a training on Modern methods of livestock management, and she was among the participants.

In year 2004 Maari joined WEEC credit programme and was given a loan of USD 60. Her loan went to buy her first steer. To pay up her loan she started making bead ornaments for sale. This and the sale of milk enabled her to pay her loan promptly. After the fattening period, Maari sold the steers at the local market for USD 120.This enabled her to buy two Small steers. The steers are in the fattening period and will be sold in three months time.

Seenoi is married with 4 children. She went through formal education and completed primary level. She is the chairlady of Retuno focal group a group that facilitates community development issues. Seenoi too attended the training on mordern methods of livestock management. She is actively involved in the trainings undertaken to enable her community see the need to change from their traditional methods of livestock rearing that leaves them counting heavy losses during the prolonged dry spells.

Seenoi steers project was started off with USD 120 that she received from the Group revolving fund. She raised her steers very well through the training she had received. She also wanted people to learn from her the need to encompass the positive changes. After the fattening period she sold the stork however she only bought two steers because of the dry spell. With the other proceeds she paid secondary school fee for her children.

Setuka is married with six children. She joined Umoja women group and became a very active member. Due to the growing market in Isinya town for steers, She took a loan of USD 120 and bought two steers. She paid her loan from the milk proceeds. With last years prolonged drought, her family lost some of their herds. Setuka`s family now sees the need to practice the modern methods of livestock management.

Setuka sells steers in cattle markets in Isinya and now she wants to buy 3 medium sized steers. She believes that with the support she receives from her family, the trainings she gets through her group, and the favorable market she will be able to excel in her steers project.

Soyanoi is married with four children. She joined Umoja women group and became a very active member. She actively advocates for the education of the girl – child because she did not get the opportunity to go to school. She is a committee member of Inkiito primary school.

Soyanoi started her small steers’ project with money she had saved for sometime from her bead work. This was after she attended a training organized by WEEC on “THE NEED TO SAVE”. She managed to buy two small steers. She later sold the steers at USD 125.She then took a loan of USD 130 from her group, added to her sales proceeds and purchased four steers. She is currently fattening them and intends to market them when the prices are most favorable.

Eunice is married and has seven children. Her four children are in Primary and another three in secondary school. She is a trustworthy, hard working woman and this is why the group members decided to elect her as their Treasurer.

Eunice started her small business in 2001 with the help of her husband who provided start up capital. The business has been growing and at least she is able to pay school fees for her children and provide for her family’s basic necessities. She no longer waits for her husband to buy some of the household items and food.

Mary is married with three children. Two of her children are in secondary school while the other one is in primary. She finished secondary school level but could not go further because her parents wanted her to get married. She looks forward to giving her children good education which she missed because her parents did not value it so much.

Mary runs a soft drinks outlet in Olturoto Trading centre and has been running it for five years. The business is doing so well to the extent of balancing a profit of USD 65 per week. She has been able to cement her house floor and plans to build a block house if the business continues with this trend for two years

Alice is a very active member of Nyota Women Group which she joined in 2002. She is married with three children.

Alice started her small business in 2002 with assistance from her husband who gave her USD 150 to start. To date she can get USD 10 in a week which is on average good income in her standards. Her children have never missed school, they have enough food and get medical care when they are sick. She is happy to having joined her group because she has been borrowing small loans to push her in her business whenever there is a gap. The group loans she borrowed were paid back promptly because of being a hard worker and trustworthy.

Nancy is 46 years old, married with five children. She is very active in women affairs and the group decided to elect her to the post of chairlady. Nancy attended secondary education and this has helped her in directing other women.

Nancy started her business two years ago with USD 100 and it has been improving day-by- day. The business has grown to the tune of about USD 900 and continues to grow further. This business enables her to support the family in all household requirements and believes that she will be financially stable in two years to come.

Ann is 38 years and married with 3 children. Her children are all of school going age and are attending local schools. Ann is quite active in her group and due to her leadership abilities she was elected the Vice Chairlady

Ann has accessed 4 loans from her group of USD 30, USD 60, USD 90 and USD 120. She has used these loans to expand her kiosk and also start the flower farming business. She successfully repaid these loans with the proceeds from her businesses. She makes a profit of USD 75 per month from her kiosk and USD 150 per month from flower sales as she has a ready market. She has been working very closely with her husband in managing the 2 businesses.

Dorcus is married with 3 children and is 48years old. She is a nurse by profession and likes farming too. She is an open minded lady and this has enabled her to trying out other income generating activities to increase her income.

Dorcus has been a vegetable farmer for the last 5 years. She joined Revelations Women group in 2004 and started by saving USD 10 per month. In February 2005, she borrowed USD 300 and paid it. In November, she borrowed another loan of USD 300 she has repaid too. These loans helped her in educated her children and still struggling to see them through.

Freshiah is 34 years, married with 2 children. One of her children goes to primary school. Her husband assists her on the farm which has ensured that they get regular income from their activities.

She keeps dairy cows and also rears sheep for sale. She started vegetable farming 2 years ago when she joined Githunguri Abigael Mothers group where she was able to access 3 loans of USD 45, USD 75, USD 120 which she successfully repaid back. Currently she is making a profit of USD 50 from sale of vegetables. With ready market for her vegetables, she intends to grow more since she has the land and intends to buy a water pump to irrigate her vegetable farm from a river that flows near her farm. This will ensure that she has vegetables all year round to meet her client’s orders.

She is married with 5 children and is 50 years. 3 of her children have finished school while 2 are in secondary school. Her husband is a retired civil servant and currently assists her on the farm. She has been a group member for 5 years.

Grace has been a farmer all her life and therefore has experience in dairy and tea farming. A large acreage of her farm is under tea but has set aside an area where she grows fodder for her cows which are zero grazed. Grace bought her cows from tea proceeds as well as the loans she got from Our Lady of Unity women group. To date, she has successfully repaid 9 loans from her group. Her previous loan was of USD 500. She gets USD 30 per month from sale of milk and USD 220 from tea. With the loan applied for, she intends to buy a water pump so as to be able to get water from a nearby river for her cows. This has been a problem due to the steep terrain of her farm. This will enable her better manage dairy cows and get more milk for sale. She also intends to buy farm inputs-fertilizers and cattle feed.

Grace is married with 3 children and is 43 years. Her husband is employed and is currently educating 2 children in University. Due to her strong community mobilization and leadership skills, she holds many leadership positions in church and in the community. She is currently the area zonal chair lady responsible for supervising 8 groups. She has been in her group for 6 years.

Grace has one dairy cow, 600 chicken (layers) and a quarter acre of land under horticulture and 2 acres under tea. She gets USD 120 from milk, USD 1000 from sale of eggs, USD 150 from tea and USD 120 from horticulture sales .She started chicken farming early last year from a loan of USD 750 she got from her group has been able to meet her client’s orders. With the loan applied for she intends to improve on the housing of the chicken to ensure that they are sheltered from bad weather conditions and also that there is more space for additional chicken in future. Part of the loan will also be used to buy chicken feed in bulk.

Lucy is 36 years old and married with 3 children. 2 of her children are in primary school in a nearby private academy. She is also the group secretary.

Lucy started her business 3 years ago as a kiosk in Kabati town, which is quite vibrant due to being near a highway. This has however grown to the current general shop selling a variety of commodities. She was able to do this from the loans that she accessed from her group. She has received 4 loans from her group and successfully repaid them back. Her previous loan was of USD 120 was used to buy cereals for her shop to meet the huge demand that was there due to a prevailing drought in the country. She makes a profit of USD 75 per month and intends to add more stock in her business by buying a variety of goods in bulk from wholesalers so as to get a wider profit margin.

Margaret is married with 5 children and is 48years old. One of her children is waiting to join college and is currently assisting her at the farm together with her husband.

Margaret previously was used to subsistence farming-maize and beans. But she realized that this would not sustain her family and meet her family growing needs. That is when she rented a small farm and started growing French beans and cabbages. This has seen a huge transformation in her life as she is now able to make a monthly profit of USD 300 from her farming. This has enabled her send her children to school and live a decent life. The loan applied for, she intends to expand her farming by purchasing farm inputs-seeds and fertilizers so as to grow more of the cabbages and French beans. She gets orders from as far as Thika town and the buyers usually come to buy from her at the farm and therefore does not incur transport costs.

Pamela is married and has 5 children. She is a high school teacher and an active member of the Anglican Church and an official of the church council. She is the treasurer of Plains view self help group. Her 5 children are all in school and her husband is employed.

To supplement her employment income, Pamela started poultry and dairy farming in her rural home in Gatundu. She has 350 chicken (layers) and 2 dairy cows. She has employed one person at the farm but always ensures she is there when she is free and over the weekends. She sells 11 crates of eggs per day at USD 25 and 25 litres of milk at USD 5 per day. Her total income from farming every month is USD 900. Gatundu is a fast growing area and Pamela would want to increase the number of her chicken to be able to serve this readily available market better. She already has orders that she is not able to meet.

She is 50 years old, married, has 5 children, 2 of whom have completed secondary school and 1 has completed college and is looking for employment.. She is also the group secretary.

\r\nSusan has a dairy cow; also she is a horticultural farmer, banana farmer and grows maize and beans. From her farming she is able to generate USD 150 per month and also feed her family. She bought her dairy cow from a loan of USD 120 she got from her group and income from her farming. She intends to start a small business in Githunguri shopping centre which is quite vibrant to supplement her income from farming. She will be assisted by her son who has received some formal business training but is currently unemployed. She previously had a shop in Muhutini but closed it due to insecurity. She thus has the necessary experience to manage the business.

I have been working for three years selling dairy products such as small cheeses, butter, cheese, also corn, beans and firewood. In my community I am one of the only people who sell these products, which are basics for daily consumption. I hope I can increase my earnings and help my children in their education at the university level.

Loan Use: Buying butter, cheese, small hard cheeses, beans, corn and firewood.

Tengo tres años de dedicarme a la venta de lacteos como quesillo, mantequilla, queso, maiz, frijoles y leña. En mi comunidad soy una de las pocas personas que venden estos productos y que son basicos para el consumo diario. Espero poder incrementar mis ingresos y poder apoyar a mis hijos en sus estudios universitarios.

My name is Maria Socorro and I sell corn, beans and firewood. I have been working for four years in this business, which I began with my own money. In the rainy season, people look for me so they can buy firewood, because in this area, we do not have electricity. I know that with the help (loan), I will be able to better my family’s earnings.

Loan Use: Buying beans, corn and firewood.

Mi nombre es Maria Socorro y me dedico ala venta de maiz, frijoles y leña. Tengo 4 años de dedicarme a esta actividad, la que inicie con mi propio capital de trabajo. En los meses de lluvia las personas me buscan para comprar leña, ya que esta zona no tenemos luz electrica. Se que con el apoyo que me brinden podre mejorar mi ingreso familiar.

I have a small business, which is located in my house. I have been selling clothes, cosmetics, and shoes, for 15 years. My job is hard because I have to leave to go to offices to sell my products, but it is worth it, because my earnings enable me to help my children in their studies,which is especially important because one is already studying at the university.

Loan Use: Buying clothes for children and women, cosmetics, bedclothes(pajamas), curtains, sandals, and underwear.

Tengo un pequeño negocio ubicado en mi casa, vendo ropa, cosmeticos, y zapatos desde hace 15 años. El trabajo es duro porque tengo que salir a oficinas a vender mis productos, pero vale la pena ya que mis ingresos me dan la oportunidad de ayudar a mis hijos en sus estudios, logrando que 1 ya este en la universidad.

I have had a small grocery store called Oneyda, in my home for three years, I attend to the store alongside my wife. Our clients are satisfied with the attention with which we help them, and also for our quality products at low prices. Our earnings help us to pay our familial and financial obligations.

Loan Use: Buying milk, bread, eggs, cornflour, sodas, coffee, sugar and other items

Tengo una pequeña pulperia llamada Oneyda en mi casa de habitacion desde hace tres años, esta la atiendo junto a mi esposa. Nuestra clientela se siente satisfecha por la atencion que les brindamos, ademas por los productos de calidad y bajos precios. Los ingresos que percibimos por las ventas nos ayudan a cubrir nuestros compromisos familiares y financieros.

I have been working for three years in my butcher shop, selling pork, beef and chicken. My shop is located in the transportation terminal of my town. My products are good and all the people that travel here from other towns buy my meat to take home with them. Now the demand is greater because our town is growing in size. Thanks to my earnings, I can help my family with the expenses of education and food.

Loan Use: Buying pork, beef and chicken meats.

Tengo 3 años de vender carne de cerdo, res y pollo en mi carniceria zelaya, esta ubicada en la terminal de transporte de esta ciudad. Mis ventas son buenas ya que todas las personas que viajan de otras ciudades compran carne para llevar a sus hogares. Ahora la demanda que tengo es mayor ya que nuestra ciudad ha crecido en poblacion. Gracias a los ingresos que obtengo ayudo a mi familia con los gastos de estudios y alimentacion.

My name is Adelina and I have owned my shop for 5 years. It is located in one of the terminals in town, where I sell all types of ítems for basic daily consumption, along with my husband, we attend to our clients reliably and formally. Our earnings that we generate from our business help us with our familial and financial obligations.

Loan Use: Buying sugar, coffee, eggs, soap, sodas, bread and other items

Me llamo Adelina, tengo mi pulperia Kelin desde hace 5 años. Esta ubicada en una de las terminales de esta ciudad, aca vendo toda clase de producto de consumo basico familiar, junto a mi esposo atendemos a nuestra clientela que es bastante cumplidora y formal. Los ingresos que nos genera el negocio son para ayudarnos con nuestros gastos familiares y financieros.

My name is Asunción and my business is called M.’ Grocery Store. It is located near to the school Jose Trinidad Reyes, which helps me sell my products. During the night I sell sweets because there is a lot of traffic in this area and the school has three daily segments of classes. My earnings help me care for my children in their studies and in my familial expenses.

Loan Use: Buying batteries, juices, milk, churros ( a type of sweet pastry), cookies, condiments, coffee and other items.

Me llamo Asuncion, y mi negocio lleva el nombre de Pulperia M.. Esta ubicada cerca de la escuela Jose Trinidad Reyes, lo que me ayuda a vender mis productos. Por las noches vendo golosinas ya que esta zona es bastante transitada y el colegio tiene tres jornadas diarias de clases. Los ingresos me ayudan atender a mis hijos en sus estudios y gastos de familia.

I work taking photos of events and of people, also for passports and kin. I have 5 years experience and in my community, I am contracted to cover events such as reunions, parties or press events. My business is family owned and operated, but I have two young assistants who help me take photos and develop them. I like to take photos and thanks to this job, I am able to work to support my family.

Loan Use: Buying rolls of film, cameras, photographic paper and other items.

Me dedico a tomar fotografias de eventos y personas, tambien para pasaportes y carne. Tengo mas de 5 años de experiencia y en mi comunidad me contratan para cubrir eventos en reuniones, fiestas o ruedas de prensa. Mi negocio es familiar pero tengo 2 jovenes que me ayudan a tomar fotografias y revelarlas. Me gusta tomar fotos y gracias a este trabajo he podido apoyar a mi familia.

T. Sarin came to CREDIT office with his wife to request a second loan, after successfully repaying the first. After investing his first $500 to have his house connected to the electricity network, he is now applying for a $1000 loan, whose main purpose is to improve their family house. As a self employed mason, Sarin has a great experience of construction. He will use $700 for buying the materials required and perform the works by himself.

The remaining $300 will be invested in the soy bean milk business Sahin’s wife is running on her side.

Every active member of the family will contribute to the repayment. Sarin usually earns around $7 a day, while his wife can make $2 profit out of $25 soy bean milk sales. Their eldest daughter is 26 and employed in a sewing factory and her $80 monthly salary might also help. Their two youngest sons are still going to school.

“Since we started borrowing from CREDIT, our standard of living improved”, they said. ‘We would like our children to study at the University, if possible abroad”, they added.

Kaeiv Navy is married and father of children. He is working at the National Assembly of Cambodia, as a support staff.

He applied for a $500 loan for his wife to open a grocery shop. She used to run a similar business but the family sold it a few years ago, when her eldest son got married. Navy’s wife will use the money as a running capital to purchase spices and other goods to be sold in the shop. They are expecting 10,000 Riel ($2.5) profit from the shop every day, which will cover daily expenses for food.

This is the first time Navy is borrowing money. “If we are successful, we will increase the size of the business step by step with our future loans”, he said.

S. Saphean is married and mother of three young children. In addition to her casual domestic tasks, she is alS. earning her living by selling vegetables in the market at night. Her husband is a cook and enrolls for frequent weddings ceremonies. He takes care of the children at night, when Saphean is out to the market.

With the $1100 loan she requested, Saphean is planning to expand her business with a bigger stand and more diversity in her products. She hopes to increase her income from the market and would alS. like to open a small shop in front of her house to sell cane juice during the day.

M. Ban is married and father of 8 children. They are all living at the same place. His wife is growing rice in a field near their house for the family consumption, while their two eldest sons are employed in factories and their eldest daughter is waitress in a restaurant. 

M. Ban is selling watches and glasses on a mobile stand on different places such as markets and bus stations in and around Phnom Penh. For the moment, he is walking from one place to another or sometimes hiring a moto-taxi. He is selling his glasses for around 3000 Riel ($0.75) and his watches for 4000 Riel ($1).
