Jamala is a resident of Sumgayit city. She is single and 23 years old. Jamala lost both her parents during the war. She has grown up with many difficulties over the past 12 years. She started selling kitchen equipment, dishes and household appliances about four years ago. She is applying for a loan to expand her business by increasing the amount and variety of goods available for sale.

Samad is an Internally Displaced Person from the Lachin region and now resides in Beylagan. In 2003 he applied to the Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed $300 and started  his cattle breeding in his native region. He breeds cows and sells milk. Now he wants to add more cows and expand his business.

Nazile is a low income person, originally from the Masalli district of Azerbaijan.She moved to Baku and started her business in 1998. During 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch a total of $2,100. Nazile wants to borrow $1,200 to increase the variety of her trade goods.

Elshan is a 28-year-old single man living in Sumgayit city. When he started his business two years ago he sold food items, but now sells household and kitchen items. Elshan is applying for a loan to increase the variety and amount of his inventory.

Tahire is an Internally Displaced Person(IDP) from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli region. Now she lives in Beylagan Ashigly and her family is engaged in cattle breeding. She has borrowed four times from theNormicro Beylagan branch. The proceeds from these  loans were used to increase the number of livestock. Now Tahire needs $1,200 to further increase the size of her family's herd.

Rakhshanda is an Internally Displaced Person(IDP) from the occupied Agdam district since 1993. She started her own business in 1998 using her own resources. During 2005-2006 she borrowed twice from the Normicro Baku branch a total of $2,100 and has expanded her business considerably. Now she would like to borrow $1,200 to increase the variety of goods and amount of trade goods in her store.

Vugar is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Zangilan region of Azerbaijan. He is 34 years old and is married with three children. Vugar started his dental business eight years ago. The business is developing well and he is currently applying for a loan to buy dental equipment in order to increase the quality of service.

Khuraman is the resident of Sumgayit town. She is 23 years old and now lives with her family in Sumgait city. She began her business 3 years ago, when she was 20 years old. In the beginning of hers business she sold bags. Khuraman has been renting the shoe shop, but she wants to borrow $1,200 to open her own shop and to increase range of goods for sale.

Nazila is 57, married,and has 4 children.She lives in  Khaladj village, Salyan region.  
She has her own poultry farm in the backyard of her house and she checks and attends the animals daily. 
Every day Nazila goes to the market and stores to offer her products. She has had her business for 15 years ago and it allows her to support her family.
Having borrowed $500 she bought 100 chickens. 
Now she needs a loan of $800 to buy 200 chickens.

Nazima is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993 and started her own business in 1996. During 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch a total of $2,400. Nazima wants to borrow an additional $1,200 to expand the variety of trade goods in her shop.

Miri is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied Lachin region and now lives in Beylagan. After facing many hardships, he started the business of breeding and selling cattle. In order to accomplish this, Miri borrowed $400 from the Normicro Beylagan branch. Now he wants to increase the number of cows and to build a bigger shed.

He is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli. Logman with his family settled in Sumgait city. He is 42. He is married, has 3 children. In the beginning of his business he sold glass and mirror in his own car. Having borrowed a loan amount of $600, he repaired his car, has bought the funitures from furniture plants and was sold in estates. The second loan $1000 he spent to built the small furniture store. \r\nNow Logman needs a loan amount of $1200 to expand his business area. He plans to open his own furniture salon.

Narmina is a low-income person, originally from the Shamakhi district of Azerbaijan. She now lives in Baku. She started her clothing business in 1999 with her own money. During 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch and used the process to expand her business considerably. Now Narmina would like to borrow an additional $1,200 to further develop her business in order to cover her family's expenses.

Elnara is a resident of Sumgayit. She is 29 years old and lives with her family and her five-year-old child in Sumgayit city. She rents a shop where she sells food products. Her business is quite new, having started it one year ago. Elnara is applying for a loan to increase the variety of goods in her store as well as to purchase scales for use in her shop.

Mahbuba is a low income person from Baku. She is married and has children. She started her own profitable business in 1997. In 2005-2006 she borrowed two times a total of $1,500 from the Normicro Baku branch. Now she would like to borrow an additional $1,200 to expand her inventory.

Shukur is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied Lachin region of Azerbaijan.  He now lives in Sumgait city. Shukur is 26 years old and been in the clothing business for 4 years.  He supports his family from this occupation. \r\nNow he needs a loan amount of $1,200 to open his own clothes store.

Tamasha is a hard working low-income woman. She initially established her tea-shop with a small amount of money.  Using the income from her small business and borrowing two times, a total of $2,200 from the Normicro Baku branch, Tamasha not only expanded her tea-shop business but also opened a new trading business. Now she needs $1,200 to expand her trading business and enhance her tea-shop facilities.

Ali is a resident of Sumgayit city. Ali is 29 years old and has been in the business of selling clothes and other apparel items for the past year and a half. Ali supports his family with this business. He needs a loan to purchase more inventory in order to expand his business.

Magsud is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from Armenian-occupied Lachin district of Azerbaijan since 1993. In 1998 he started his business with his own meager resources. In 2005-2006 he borrowed two times from Normicro in the total amount of $2,000 and expanded his agricutural goods selling business considerably. Now he wants to borrow an additional $1,100 to expand his business further.

Elchin is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied Agdam region of Azerbaijan. He now lives in Sumgayit city. Elchin is 23 years old.  He has been in the business of selling clothing, bags, and other apparel products for the past five years. He is applying for a loan to increase his inventory.

Tabib is a Internally Displaced Person, originally from Tartar district of Azerbaijan. He now lives in  Lokbatan. He started his business in 1998. In 2005-2006 he borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch - total of $2,200.  He  would like to borrow $1,100 to increase his business more.

This single man was born in 1979 in Khaladj village, Salyan region .
4 years ago Nukhbala decided to start a small grocery store. This business does not provide him with income to cover household expenses.

Nukhbala needs a loan of $800 to expand the area of his store.

Ramil is a resident of Sumgayit city. He is 29 years old and married with one child. He began his business one year ago selling household items. Ramil is applying for a loan to expand his business by purchasing more inventory.

Ofelya lives in Beylagan. She borrowed $500 from  the Normicro Beylagan and started her business of sheep raising and sales. Now he wants a new loan in the amount of $1,100 to increase the size of her herd.

Felly started his business in 1988. He operates an open-air shop. His beginning business capital was USD 108. He began with a stock of 50 pairs of shoes, but stopped the business in 2000 due to the political and economical instability in Kinshasa. 

Felly decided to resume his shoe business in 2004 and was informed by his friend about Hope’s loan program. He agreed to sign a loan contract with Hope. With his first Hope loan he stabilized his business by adding more pairs of shoes and diverse items such as boxes of batteries, small radios, shoe polish, padlocks, and other goods. Today, Felly has a stock of about 70 pairs of shoes. 

Felly has noticed that there is demand in his neighbourhood for women’s shoes also. With a loan of $600, Felly plans to diversify his business by adding women’s shoes and clothing. His long term plan is to move from an open-air shop to a shop indoors.

Khalida is originally from Republic of Georgia; she has lived in Lokbatan since 1990. In 1995 she opened her family business with her own resources. In 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch a total of $2,850 and has expanded her business considerably. Now she plans to borrow an additional $1,200 to expand her business further. Her husband is pictured here.

Alik is a resident of Sumgayit city. He is 25 years old and is not married. Alik is engaged in buying used cars, repairing them and re-selling them in a special car market. He has been doing this for almost three years. Alik applies to Normicro for his first loan with the purpose of increasing his working capital in order to develop his business further.

Maleyka is from the capital, Baku. She is married and has children. She started her business in 1995. In 2005-2006 she borrowed two times a total of $1,300 from Normicro. Now she plans to borrow an additional $800 to expand her business.

This 37-year-old man lives in Khaladj village,Salyan region. He is married and has a child.

Ahadaga breeds calves in a private farm shed. He has been in this business for 4 years. With this business he meets the demands of his family. Through his business he has gained a great deal of knowledge and skills to expand his business.
Now he needs a loan of $800 to buy 4 calves.

Sovkat is originally from the Lerik district, in the Southern region of Azerbaijan. She is a low-income person, who is married, and has children. She opened her business in 1999 with her own money. In 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from Normicro in the total amount of $1,400 and expanded her business. Now she wants to borrow an additional $1,000 to increase the variety of her inventory.

Tofig lives in Beylagan. He has been a client of the Normicro Beylagan branch since 2002, when he started his own business after getting his first loan in amount of $600. Subsequent loans in amount of $800 and $1,000 were used for the same purpose. Now he is in need of another loan to increase the size of his herd.

Godelive began her business in 1980. She sells corn, flour, beans, rice, palm oil and other goods at her shop. Since receiving her first HOPE loan in 2004, Godelive has more than tripled her working capital. She has begun to save regularly and invests money back into her business. \r\n\r\nGodelive has recognized that there is a need for more suppliers connecting wholesalers to the retailers who sell the goods she sells. With a $1,000 loan, Godelive will build on the credibility she has developed in her community and become the supplier for goods coming from the wholesalers for her neighbourhood.

Aide is originally from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. In 1997 she started her clothing business. In 2005-2006 she borrowed two times in the total amount of $1,400 from the Normicro Baku branch and expanded her business. Now she wants to borrow $1,000 to expand her inventory.

Shola is a very kind, friendly and hard-working person. She has had her business for 5 years and it allows her to support her family.
Shola was born in 1969 in Khaladj village,Salyan region. She is married and has 2 children.
She supplies milk in the village at the nearby markets.
With this business she provides income and also provides milk for her family.
Now she needs a loan of $1000 to buy a milk cow.

Fatma is originally from Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan.\r\nIn 1998 she started her clothes trading business. In 2005-2006 she borrowed twice in the total amount of $1,400 from the Normicro Baku branch and expanded her business.\r\nNow she wants to borrow $1,000 to expand her business.

Hajibaba is an Internally Displaced Person from the Kalbajar region and now lives in Ashigli in the Beylagan region. In 2003 he applied to the Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed his first loan in amount of $300. He bought sheep for this loan and started to trade them. He used subsequent loans in amount of $500 and $800 for the same purpose. He needs a new loan to expand the business more.

Latafat is an Internally Displaced Person, originally from the Beylagan district of Azerbaijan. She moved to Baku in 1990. In 1999 she opened her salon. In 2005-2006 she borrowed 2 times in the total amount of from the Normicro Baku branch and expanded her business. Now she wants to borrow $1,000 to expand her business for the third time.

Ismayil is a 57-year-old well known welder in Yenikand village, Salyan region . He is married and has 4 children. He has been in this business for 10 years.\r\nHe needs a loan of $1200 to buy welding apparatus to satisfy his clientele. Ismayil is an honest and respectful man.

Rovshan is an Internally Displaced Person originally from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. In 2000 he started his own business. In 2005 he borrowed $500 from the Normicro Baku branch and expanded his business. Now he wants to borrow $700 to expand his business again.

Namig is originally from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. In 1995 he started his shop with a small amount of money. In 2006 he borrowed $1,650 from the Normicro Baku branch and expanded his business, Now he wants to borrow $1,200 to expand his business further.
Qabil H. owns an Auto Painting shop in the town of Khachmaz located in the Northeastern part of Azerbaijan. Qabil is looking for funding so that he can invest in a new paint sprayer.

Eyvaz H. owns an upholstery shop in the town of Khachmaz located in the Northeastern part of Azerbaijan. Eyvaz wants to invest in new hardware that will enable him to perform complex work more efficiently.

Auntie Pat, as she is called by her customers, sells necklaces, earrings, body and hair pomades, artificial hair and so on. She lives in a community where women dominate and so daily demands for goods by individuals is very high. She is seeking a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to purchase more goods to meet her customers' demand.

Mehr Afroz is 52 years old and lives in a household of 10 in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Mehr Afroz took a 1st cycle loan for her oldest son who has a fuel and gas shop in the market.

Mehr Afroz is an uneducated woman, but she knows tailoring and embroidery well. Because of low family income she took a loan for her son to buy more fuel, gas and wood for his shop. If all goes well, she hopes to take a 2nd cycle loan for herself so she can start a tailoring business.

Amina was born in 1955. She lives in a household of 6 in district 3 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Amina took a 1st cycle loan so she could buy more materials for her medicines shop.

Her medicines shop is in a clinic near her house and here she sells medicine according to the doctors' prescription. She is very happy to be a good nurse for her people.

Amina works in medicine 7 days of the week to help people and empower her family financially as well.

Jamela was born in 1984. She lives in a  household of 5 in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Jamela took a 1st cycle loan for her husband Gulboden, who has property dealer shop in a large city.

Jamela is an educated women who teaches 3rd class grade in a school near her house, but because of financial problems she took a loan for her husband so that he can buy furniture and other materials for his shop. Right now, Jamela and her husband are very happy that she is able to cover the family financially.

M. Sarwar was born in 1962. He lives in a household of 6 in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan.\r\n\r\nM. Sarwar has a shop in the market selling fabrics. He already passed the 1st, 2nd and 3rd cycle loan with positive repayment and now he is continuing with a 4th cycle loan. He has 6 years' experience in his current business. At the start of his business his shop had less fabrics, but after taking a loan through AFSG he bought lots more. Right now he is able to buy all kinds of fabrics and sell them in the bazaar. Through this process he is able to cover himself and his family financially.

Qand Agha is 32 years old and lives with his 4 children in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Qand Agha has a clothes shop in the market where he sells jeans, scarfs, jumpers, coats, t-shirts and trousers.

Qand Agha took a 4th cycle loan to buy those materials that he doesn’t already have in his shop. At the start of his business he didn't have too many customers because of less materials, so he faced lots of financial and family-related problems.

Right now with buying lots of materials for his shop, he is able to cover the expenses of both the shop and his family.

A good day's feed is the motto behind Vitoria’s barbeque stand at Moamoa, which operates on a 4-day basis every week.  Financial assistance offered to her by SPBD helped set up the business. The initial $450 loan was used to buy meat (chicken, sausages, turkey tails) and taro for her stall.  Her husband also contributes financially to their family as he earns $100 fortnightly as a bus driver.  SPBD development programs and training assisted this family with knowledge, not only in financial assistance, but also with Victoria’s savings plan as she saves $10 each day from her business operation and $25 for her family’s basic needs.

Tanumia of Maagiagi is an active member of one of the 162 village solidarity groups organized by SPBD. She is a fisherwoman.  With help from her husband, she manages their small fish stand. Monetary assistance from SPBD helped her to fish on Wednesdays and Saturdays. Their sales proved to be worthwhile as they earn $50 each day from selling their fish to the villagers. The income helped pay for school for their 2 smaller children, as well as and family and church obligations. By improving their fishing gear and nets, Tanumia hopes to earn more from her fishing enterprise.

Rohane was born in 1969 and lives in a household of 17 in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Rohane lost his left hand during the war and has had lots of financial problems since.

He decided to start a small business in the bazaar to solve his family problems. To start off with he bought socks and hats, then he took loans through AFSG to increase his business and buy more hats, socks and t-shirts, but because there are so many family members  this could not fulfill the family's financial needs. Therefore, he and his two brothers also have a second business that trades in the same products.

He hopes that by selling the products, slowly, he can improve his family's financial situation.

Tailelei runs a shop and delivers home-made chips (banana, taro). The shop is open 7 days a week and if it’s a good week the shop earns 200 tala (US$70). After making her loan payments and purchasing goods for her for her canteen, she has her real earning of 120 tala (US$40) weekly. Hard work and willingness to overcome problems and learning from past mistakes has made Talalelei’s business a fruitful one as the years go by.

Suifou, with financial assistance from SPBD, was able to put her sewing talents into commercial practice. The money helped her to buy the tools she needed like the sewing machine, thread, and all her sewing supplies. She is happy with the progress of her sewing shop as it makes her confident that she is able to provide for her family’s needs, especially in paying for her children’s education and other family commitments. "If you are looking for a seamstress, try Suifou’s Sewing Shop that provides you with all of the family's clothing at affordable rates," she would exhort her customers.

Sera and her husband share a talent for screen printing. They are raising 4 school-aged children, and are both employed. Her goal is for her children to get a good education that will benefit them in the long run. Sera was prompted to join the SPBD programme by the family's lack of money and other means of support. She decided to put her talent to good use with the help of her husband. Sera used her first loan to purchase plain materials, mostly lava (sarongs), screen-printed them, and sold them to individual shops. Because of the unique styles and beautiful colours, Sera’s business is booming - new orders are constantly being placed by her customers. She is now able to put her children through school and support her family financially. Sera is also looking to possibly expand her business by hiring 2 workers. And if she manages to save some extra money, Sera plans to expand her shop and even export her products to overseas markets. Currently, money is still a constraint, and she still has a long way to go. However, with the help of SPBD, Sera has already achieved her goal of being able to put her children through school.

Sara makes a living by making meat buns and selling them in her village. This small business operates 3 days a week (Tue/Wed/Thu). She prepares ninety meat buns daily, and sells them for 1 tala (US$0.30) each. After covering all of her expenses, Sara makes a weekly profit of 150 tala (US$50), and is happy to be able to support her family. She believes that others, too, can achieve their goals if they have faith in what they do, and in people and organizations whose help they seek.

The SPBD’s outreach program has proven successful for Puao S., a business woman and one of the best known tailors in her village. Puao specializes in sewing puletasi, muumuu (dress) and men’s shirts. She also makes beautiful and unique elei prints for individuals and organizations like the Samoa Tourism Authority. Puao also receives requests from overseas clients, which acts as another stepping stone in expanding her business and providing more income for Puao and her family. She hopes to soon be able to make more money than the current 250 tala (US$80) weekly profit.

Peka operates a small grocery store where she sells foodstuffs, toiletries, etc. Peka has 3 children to support, two of which are already working and one helps her out in running the business. Compared to the time when Peka had just opened her grocery store, the financial burden has gradually lessened. Her shop is open 7 days a week, catering for the public for 15 hours straight. Peka's goal has been to improve her standard of living and to provide good education and access to proper health care for her children. With SPBD's assistance, she has achieved her goals. However, Peka continues to work hard in order to motivate not only her family, but also other less fortune and helpless unemployed women. Her good business sense and determination have made her successful, and currently Peka is able to make a weekly profit of 200 tala (USD$30). She plans to further expand her business, most probably by creating a supermarket that would offer a greater variety of goods than what she is supplying and selling now. Peka hopes to become financially independent and continue to be a great role model to the women who are unemployed and willing to improve their families' living standards. In particular, Peka offers them support and help in complying with the SPBD policies.

Peata has joined the SPBD programme and has just been given a loan of 300 tala (US$100) to start a pork cake business. She is unemployed, married, and has 6 children. Her husband does not have a permanent job, and is not able to earn enough money to support their family. Peata's biggest worry has been the school fees for her 4 children attending school and other basic needs for her family. She opted for starting the business, because cakes are cheap to make, and because the business would not much interfere with her busy schedule as a full time mother. In addition, pork cakes are a favourite among the locals, especially children. To start out, Peata bought flour and meat, and now makes about 40 buns daily, 7 days a week. She sells the cakes to school children during the week and to other village people during the weekends. Occasionally, Peata's husband delivers the cakes to nearby shops.  She earns up to  280 tala (US$90) a week, and is now able to cover the family's basic needs in addition to paying her children’s school fees. Peata is even able to save some of the money to eventually increase the amount of cakes she supplies. In addition, she still manages to make loan payments on time, so that she can move up to the next loan level. Her determination to improve her family’s standard of living is making her work harder and learn to save with the help of SPBD's savings programme.

Fasialofa’s business is making German Buns (fried dough with coconut shavings in the middle) which she delivers to village schools and shops. With 6 children to look after (3 attending school,1 who works and 2 others still at home), Fasialofa has to work extra hard to help her husband who's the breadwinner of the family. Her husband’s earnings don't cover their expenses, so Fasialofa makes and sells German buns to help satisfy their daily necessities. She makes a profit of 120 tala (US$ 40) per week after all expenses. Now she’s able to budget and still save some in case of emergencies. She‘s looking at expanding her business into a bakery. Hopefully one day she will be financially independent and able to manage things on her own.

Marina is married with three children. She runs a small business selling shoes and boots for men and women in one of the busiest city markets. Marina has been self-employed for 10 years and the business is now the sole means of support for her family. Her husband actively helps her by traveling to remote wholesale centers to purchase inventory. Marina is a determined hard-worker. She has experienced many challenges in her life. Her younger daughter had a spine fracture and was temporarily paralyzed. Fortunately, she recovered fully and is now doing well. Challenges have only strengthened Marina’s character. Her determination and strong will to succeed have helped to keep her business stable and sustainable and have promoted its expansion. Marina has received and paid back 10 different loans from “Nadiya Ukraine”. Presently, she has about $3,000 of working capital. Her monthly net profit amounts to $500. Marina would like to get a loan for $1,000 that will allow her to purchase 100 pairs of footwear for the spring season. She is planning to buy leather shoes for men and women that always sell well in the spring. Income from the sale of these shoes will be put towards some family expenses. Marina would like to invest generated profits into her eldest daughter’s hairdressing business – making her entrepreneurial dreams come true. She believes that her first priority as a mother and successful business owner is to help her daughter find her business focus, set a good strategy and see her own startup succeed.

Марина – одружена, в неї троє дітей. Вона займається бізнесом з продажу чоловічого та жіночого взуття та чобіт. Працює вона на одному з найбільших місцевих ринків. Марина займається цим бізнесом вже 10 років, торгівля є єдиним джерелом прибутку для родини. Її чоловік активно допомагає з бізнесом, їздить на оптові бази, де закупає товар за помірними цінами для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі. Марина – наполеглива та працьовита. Вона пройшла багато випробувань. Декілька років тому її дочка отримала перелом хребта, деякий час залишалася паралізованою. На щастя, вона повністю одужала і зараз почуває себе чудово. Випробування тільки загартували характер Марини. Її наполегливість та сила волі допомогли їй зберегти стабільність бізнесу та сприяли його розвитку. Марина отримала та вчасно сплатила усі 10 позик від „Надії України”. Зараз в товар в неї вкладено приблизно 3000 доларів. Чистий місячний прибуток складає 500 доларів. Марина хотіла б отримати позику в 1000 доларів, яка дозволить їй закупити 100 пар взуття напередодні весни. Вона планує придбати шкіряне чоловіче та жіноче взуття, яке завжди користується попитом. Марина планує витратити прибуток від продажу взуття на потреби родини. Вона хотіла б вкласти отриманий прибуток в бізнес своєї старшої доньки, яка тримає власну перукарню. Фінансова підтримка допоможе їй втілити в життя мрії доньки. Вона вважає, що найголовніше для неї, як матері та успішного підприємця – допомогти донці знайти власну нішу в бізнесі, розробити стратегію та відкрити власну справу.

Ivan runs a small business, selling food products in Melitopol’s busy central market. He is married with two children. After school he was not able find a good paying job so he decided to go into business for himself. He has now been self-employed in grocery sales for 10 years and is the sole breadwinner for his family. Ivan is very determined and serious about his business. These characteristics have helped him promptly repay 5 loans from “Nadiya Ukraine”. Maintaining a reasonable pricing policy and client-friendly service have always been priorities in Ivan’s work and have ensured the success of his business. Presently, he has about $2,000 of working capital and a monthly net profit of $700. Ivan is asking for a loan of $500 to increase his assortment of food products. He is hoping to use the extra financial support to stock up on more groceries, such as dairy products, mayonnaise, coffee, tea, and canned vegetables. The loan will not only be beneficial for Ivan’s business as it will promote its expansion, but it will also help him meet his household expenses and set aside some savings for future needs.

Іван – власник бізнесу з продажу товарів харчування на центральному ринку міста Мелітополь. Він – одружений, має двох дітей. Після школи Іван не міг знайти гарно оплачувану роботу. Отже, він вирішив зайнятися власним бізнесом. Іван працює в сфері продовольчих товарів вже 10 років. Його бізнес – єдине джерело прибутку для родини. Іван – дуже цілеспрямований та серйозний. Ці якості допомогли йому вчасно сплатити усі 5 позик, які він отримав від „Надії України”. Розумна цінова політика та ввічливе обслуговування завжди були важливими в роботі Івана та забезпечили успіх його бізнесу. Зараз, в товарі в нього приблизно 2000 доларів, щомісячний прибуток складає 700 доларів. Іван просить про позику в 500 доларів для того, щоб розширити асортимент продовольчих товарів. Він сподівається використати додаткову фінансову підтримку для того, щоб закупити більше товарів харчування, а саме, молочних продуктів, майонезу, кави, чаю та консервованих овочів. Позика не тільки сприятиме розвитку бізнесу Івана, але й допоможе йому задовольнити усі потреби його родини та заощадити кошти на інші потреби.

Yuryi is married and has two grown children. He runs a small business selling curtain fabric which is the only source of income for his family. Yuryi has been in this business for 13 years. He owns a pavilion in the local market and rents retail space in one of the local malls. His wife is actively involved, helping him with sales. Yuryi is a very dynamic person and his experience in this field is exemplary. He first became a client of “Nadiya Ukraine” in 2002 and has promptly repaid every loan he has received. In that time his business has seen considerable growth. Yuryi has been able to open a new vending kiosk in a local mall, and hire an employee to help him with sales. Currently, his business does about $3,000 in monthly gross revenue. Yuryi is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase 8 rolls of curtain fabric which cost between $50 and $500 per roll. He is able to purchase assorted types of curtain fabrics at wholesale prices for further retail sale. He is also planning to hire a second salesperson soon which will provide a stable source of income for one more family in the community. Yuryi believes that this loan will help boost his economic activity and allow him to generate more profits. It will not only help him grow his business, but will also provide better a quality of life for he, his wife, and his employees.

Юрій – одружений, в нього двоє дорослих дітей. Він займається бізнесом з продажу гардинно-тюлевих тканин, який є єдиним джерелом прибутку для його родини. Юрій займається цим бізнесом вже 13 років. Він – власник павільйону на одному з місцевих ринків, а також він орендує торгівельне приміщення в одному з місцевих універмагів. Дружина Юрія активно допомагає йому з торгівлею. Юрій – дуже динамічна людина, його багатий досвід роботи вартий наслідування. Він став клієнтом „Надії України” в 2002 році, вчасно сплатив усі позики. Завдяки фінансовій підтримці його бізнес значно розширився. Юрій зміг орендувати приміщення в одному з місцевих універмагів, взяв на роботу ще одного реалізатора. Зараз місячний валовий прибуток Юрія складає приблизно 3000 доларів. Юрій просить про позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб придбати 8 рулонів гардинно-тюлевих тканин, кожен з яких коштує приблизно 50 - 500 доларів. Він хоче закупити різноманітні тканини оптом для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі. Він також планує взяти на роботу ще одного реалізатора, що забезпечить стабільний прибуток для ще однієї родини. Юрій вважає, що позика сприятиме покращенню його економічного становища та допоможе йому отримати додаткові кошти. Фінансова підтримка не тільки сприятиме росту його бізнесу, але й забезпечить кращий рівень життя для нього, його дружини та співробітників.

Nina is married with a grown son. She supports the essential needs of her household by running a small business selling tea and coffee in a busy city market. Currently, Nina has over $3,000 of working capital in her business and her monthly net profit amounts to $1,000. Nina is very patient and polite. Her commitment to good business and her natural friendliness attract many potential clients. A variety of quality teas and coffees also makes her kiosk a popular stop for passing customers. Not long ago Nina faced big challenges due to the reconstruction of the local market where she had a kiosk. However, these difficulties didn’t stop her. On the contrary, Nina continued to work hard investing her time and efforts in the growth of her business. Today she owns two kiosks and her business is continuously expanding. Nina is requesting a loan of $1,200 to help open a new kiosk in the market and to allow her to purchase additional tea and coffee from wholesalers where she can get a good price. This loan will help to significantly boost Nina’s revenue and grow her business, further improving the quality of life for her and her family.

Ніна – одружена, в неї дорослий син. Забезпечувати основні потреби родини їй допомагає власний бізнес з продажу чаю та кави. Ніна працює на одному з місцевих ринків. Зараз загальна сума в товарі у неї складає більше 3000 доларів. Розмір чистого прибутку досягає 1000 доларів. Ніна – дуже терпляча та ввічлива. Її відданість власній справі та природна привітність приваблюють багато потенційних покупців. Розмаїття якісного чаю та кави притягують увагу перехожих на ринку. Нещодавно Ніна стикнулася з певними труднощами, пов’язаними з реконструкцією місцевого ринку, де був розташований її кіоск. Однак, ці випробування не зупинили її. Навпаки, Ніна продовжувала наполегливо працювати, вкладаючи час та гроші в розвиток власного бізнесу. Зараз вона володіє двома кіосками, її бізнес поступово зростає. Ніна просить про позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб відкрити новий кіоск на ринку. Вона планує закупити додаткову партію чаю та кави оптом за помірними цінами. Позика значно підвищить прибутки Ніни та сприятиме подальшому розвитку її бізнесу, що, в свою чергу, якісно покращить життя її родини.

Fuad is the resident of Beylagan region. He decided to establish his own business and in 2005 he applied to Normicro Beylagan branch. He borrowed his first loan in amount of $700,  and opened an internet cafe. First he put billiard tables and now he is in need of another loan to buy two computers and run Internet.

Ramiz was born in 1952 in Yenikand village, Salyan region. He is married and has 4 children. He has been running this business for 5 years.\r\nHe enjoys looking after fruit trees. He plans to create a new orchard.\r\nHe requests a loan of $1000 to buy fertilizer and seedlings. He wants to increase the variety of fruit trees.

Shakir likes animals. All in Khaladj village know him and buy sheep from him.
He needs a loan of $1000 to buy pedigree ewes.
He is 48, married, has 2 children. This man is 
very optimistic about the future of his business.

Jane Wangari, aged 50 years, is recently widowed, having lost her husband in January 2007. She has two children and two grand-children, who all depend on her, because her children are only able to get casual jobs once in a while. Jane sells cooked foods, within the Kiambiu slums, including beans, black beans and githeri, a mixture of maize and beans boiled together.

Jane previously had an embroidery business which collapsed after one of her sons was involved in a road accident, where she spent all she had including business money on his medical expenses. This son eventually died, leaving Jane and her other children absolutely poor. Jane had previously borrowed some money from one of the big Micro-finance institutions in Kenya, to enable her to run this business. Due to the medical problem in the family, she was unable to continue with the loan repayments, hence could not borrow again, since she was now viewed as a risky client.  

Jane started off her current business in early 2006, after she borrowed a tin of beans from a businessman, who allowed her to cook and sell the beans, then later make the payments for the borrowed tin of beans.  From the same proceeds, she managed to buy her first tin of beans, which she continued to cook, hence setting up the business. Jane is now a member of the Vumilia group of Action Now Kenya, in the Kiambiu slums, where she has so far accessed two levels of loans, of Usd. 57 and Usd. 85, both of which she used to increase her stock, and which she has since repaid successfully. 

Currently Jane has only one sufuria (cooking pot) of her own, while the other two she has are borrowed, and the owner has actually been asking her to return them. Jane therefore seeks to buy two sufurias of a bigger size than what she is currently using, together with two jikos (cooking stoves) big enough for the pots she will buy. The biggest benefit to Jane will be that she will be able to return the borrowed pots, and also acquire bigger pots that will enable her to make more food, as is required by her customers. She also intends to introduce the sale of boiled green maize (corn) and green grams, which her customers have been requesting her to make.

As part of goodwill, Jane reserves the bean stock she gets from the boiled beans and githeri, to give to some of the women within the Kiambiu slums, who are too poor to buy food. They use this stock to make a stew for the family meal, hence their children don’t have to sleep hungry as long as Jane is there. 

A loan of $75 which will be given to her in kind (i.e ANK will purchase the two pots and cooking stoves for her), will assist her not only to achieve her objective of preparing more food, but will also enable her to have more stock to serve to more people in need. The repayment period for this loan will be between 4 – 8 months.

Ibadulla has run this business for 4 years.His neighbors know him and buy milk, butter and cheese from him. He has a steady stream of customers and places to exhibit his animals. Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy a milk cow and to improve the butter and cheese he produces.

“Virgen del Rosario” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project which provides its credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and, as a very mountainous area ranging 2,000 – 5,000 meters above sea level, has many limitations such as the cold, the difficulty to grow crops, and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “Virgen del Rosario” is located at approximately 2,500 meters above sea level in the community of Huanchuy, in the district of Chincho, province of Angaraes. The small town of Huanchuy is located at the border of the Cachi River and used to be an old colonial hacienda. Although the village politically belongs to the region of Huancavelica, all business is done with Ayacucho, the biggest city nearby. Most members of the group have never even been to the capital of their region!

The main activities of the population are related to agriculture. The valley of Huanchuy has an excellent climate because of the relatively low altituD. and the availability of water throughout the year. The climate makes it possible to grow a great variety of products like tara and black corn and many fruits and vegetables like avocado, pacay, tuna (prickly pear cactus fruit), sugarcane, carrots, and lettuce. In higher altitudes, the population also grows potatoes. From the tuna cactus comes another product: cochinilla, a small parasite (insect) that is used for its powerful coloring for cosmetics (locals used it to paint their faces or lips in traditional festivals). Besides cultivating all of the mentioned products, most people dedicate their time to raising small animals like guinea pigs, chicken, ducks and rabbits; and bigger animals as cows and bulls.

Currently the bank is starting its first loan cycle with 12 female borrowers and a total loan of 3,400 soles (about 1,225 US$). The loans range from 200 up to 600 soles. As the group is just starting its first cycle, the group was not able to save. But all agree to save in the future for reinvestment in their businesses or maybe to buy a community sewing machine. The expectations of the members of the new village bank incluD. receiving trainings on “marketing” (how to improve their business) and learning how to weave and stitch cloths. Besides that, they think the village bank will be an excellent way to share ideas and experiences.

One of the members of the community bank is Nancy. Nancy will receive a loan of 600 soles and runs a small grocery store in the community. With her loan, she will increase her merchandise, buying more soft drinks, beers, sweets, fruits and other groceries. Nancy´s dream for the future is to have her own sewing business. With FINCA Peru, she wants to learn to save so that she can improve her business and help her father.

Maura tells another story. She sells vegetables at local weekly markets, going from one to the other. But her main market is the one in Secclla. With her 600 soles loan, she will buy more vegetables like carrots, black potato, celery and onions. Part of what she sells comes from her own small terrain, but she also buys vegetables from other members of the community. Now that she will be working with FINCA Peru, she hopes to save more and to work more responsibly to be able to pay for her loan. She will use her savings to reinvest in her business.

Jesula is a 32-year-old woman who lives with her husband and five children in the community of L. Alcarrizzos, located on the outskirts of the capital of Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic. She has run a small fantasia for several years now (a fantasia is a small store that sells women’s fashion items ranging from sandals to shirts to hair accessories).

She has asked for this loan so that she can improve the variety of merchandise she is able to offer her customers. Specifically, she says she would like to start offering more hair accessories and a selection of bracelets and earrings that are popular with teenagers in the area. Her loan officer has worked with her to teach her that offering products that nobody else offers in her community will give her a competitive edge, and consequently help increase her sales and profits.

Jesula says her goal is to open and own her own store in the next five years—that way she can make it as big as she wants and not have to worry about paying rent anymore. She hopes that she can help her children attend one of the local universities in the capital so that they will have more opportunities than she has had, and she hopes to help her husband improve their home.

On behalf of Jesula and everyone here at Esperanza International, we thank you for supporting her dreams and goals!

Luciana is a 31-year-old woman who lives in the suburb of Los Alcarrizzos on the outskirts of the capital of Santo Domingo.

She has a small business selling used and new shoes to her community members and is asking for this loan so that she can have the money available to buy a larger quantity of shoes and, as a result, both sell more shoes and make more money. In her community people are very poor, and so the demand for used shoes is high; but when people can, they always prefer to have new shoes so she likes to be able to offer both.

With the money she is able to generate from this loan, she hopes that her little business will continue to grow, attracting and retaining new customers. She hopes that the extra income will also help her go back to school and finish her high school education. One day she dreams of having her own home and her own vehicle so that she can travel around more easily and be able to visit her family and friends more often.

On behalf of Luciana and everyone here at Esperanza International, we thank you for supporting her dreams and goals!

Bung T., age 51, is a widow and resided in Phnom Penh for many years where one of her children, who is married, work as garment factory worker with a salary $80 a month. Another child is a student. After Bung T.’s husband passed, she work very hard to supplement the household. She harvests crops and does farming for one of the villagers. On average, she makes about $4 per day.\r\n\r\nBecause of the difficulty of meeting daily expenses, Mrs. Bung T. is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her son-in-law so he can start a motor-taxi so he can better contribute to the family's support. She will  use the remainder of the loan to purchase wood to repair house. Her house in leaks in the rainy season. She hopes to save enough money so her child can attend the university.

Kim S., age 45, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She and her husband, Chea Chup, work together collecting fruit crops and faming whenever somebody hires them. Normally they earn a combined $4 per day. One of their children is married and lives away from home, one child is a garment-factory worker with a salary $90 a month, another child is a motorbike mechanic, and the last one is a student\r\n\r\nThe motorbike mechanic makes more money to help with the family's daily expenses, so Mrs. Kim S. is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase more mechanic's tools and to rent a small shop for that business. She will also use some of the money to purchase cane from the farmland and resell it in the market. She believes that the loan will help her family out of the poverty, and she would like to express deeply thank to all lenders from her heart.

Heng Sovy, 37-years-old, has resided in Phnom Penh for many years with her family. She has two children, one a student and another too young to attend school. She has a small business selling snow cones on the street near the school. Snow cones are one of the favorite foods among young children, because it tastes sweet and cool. Normally she makes about $5 per day. Her husband, Ly Kim L., age 38, has a business renting musical instrument to other people in the village. He earns most from Jan to May, the dry season. Most people get married during the dry season. He earns less during the rainy season. On average, he earns $7 a day.\r\n\r\nHe is requesting a loan to purchase more musical instruments. This will allow him to arrange big parties and weddings for people and earn more from his business. (Heng Sovy is pictured because her husband is not available.)

Heng N., age 56, is a widow and works as a weaver in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. People in Cambodia, especially women, like wearing silk dresses made by hand. A silk dress is very expensive, and people wear these dresses when they attend weddings or big ceremonies related to Khmer traditions. Depending on how good the decoration and silk is, a dress can cost more than $50 . Some weavers spend up to 10 days completing one dress. Heng has has one younger sister who is also a widow, and one daughter who is married and works as a garment worker earning $80 a month.\r\n\r\nTo make more money to support the family, Heng is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a wooden boat so she can fish in the rainy season. She will also purchase piglets to raise for sell. This extra income will be very beneficial to her family well-being.

Phan S., a 48-years-old, has four children and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. One of her children is a garment worker, another is a chef in a small nearby restaurant, and the other two are students. She works as a weaver and normally earns around $3 per day. Her husband is a rice and corn farmer growing. He also raises animals. Normally he earns a combined $5 a day from selling crops and animals. 

This couple would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for their child to ride to school.
This will  reduce the cost they spend every on motor-taxis, so the family can have more money for other necessities.

Pong T. is 45-year olds and has resided in Phnom Penh where her two children are employed by garment factories and earn $85 each a month. She has two other children who are students, and two that are married and live away from home. Mrs. Pong T. owns a plot of farmland for growing rice, and normally she makes about $2.50. Her husband, Mr. Kut Kan, 57, is a construction worker and he goes from village to village building houses. He also averages $2.50 a day.\r\n \r\nBecause the price of rice is going up, Mrs Pong T. would like to purchase more land for growing rice. She will also need fertilizer. She hopes to save enough money to send her children to university.

H. Mubaro is 34 years old. She is married with three children. Her husband and daughter help her with the business. Mubaro is a market vendor. She is selling different kinds of foodstuff such as peas, wheat, buckwheat and pods in the central local market. Mubaro is very friendly and polite, which allows her to have many clientele. In 5 years the business has turned into a successful one, generating stable income for this family.

\r\nThis year is very important for Mubaro, as her daughter shall graduate from school and is going to enter the University. Being a loving mother, Mubaro wants to support her daughter. In order to be able to do so, she is planning to expand her business and wants to increase the working capital for purchasing the foodstuffs for selling. With the generated income, Mubaro plans to spend for paying the fee for education of her daughter. With this purpose Mubaro requests $600 for the term of 12 months. Mubaro is counting on your help and thanks everyone for supporting her. Your support will really help her. Be an important part of the growth of Mubaro’s business!

I. Azam is 53 years old. He is married with two children. Azam provides taxi services with his car. He has been in this business for about 2 years. The current business is the main source of income for his family as his wife is a housekeeper and his children are studying at the university. Azam is working hard, and he gets up early and goes to bed late at night. The business is successful and generates stable income for the family but not enough for making the completely overhaul  of his car. Now Azam is planning to completely overhaul  his car in order it to be in working and to serve his clients in time. Today Azam requests $600 for the term of 12 months. He is planning to purchase spare parts for his car. He thanks all for supporting him and promises to manage the loan with accuracy, on time.

M. Manzurat is 39 years old. She is married with two children. Her husband is a taxi driver. In order to help her husband in supporting the family, Manzurat has been running her own business. Manzurat is a market vendor. She sells different kinds of macaroni in the central local market. Her daughter helps her with the business. As a rule, she purchases the goods for selling from the local factories.

\r\nManzurat is very friendly and polite, which allows her to have good clientele. In 8 years the business has become a successful one, generating stable income for this family. Considering the constant competition in the market, Manzurat is trying to diversify the range of goods. With this purpose she requests $600.00 for the term of 9 months. Manzurat thanks all supporting her and promises to be accurate in loan management.

Khayala H. is single. She is a 26-year-old Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town who has settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporarily on the front line in the Fuzuli region. \r\nKhayala has raised sheep and has been in this business for 5 years. Now she needs a loan of $975 to buy 15 lambs to improve her business.

M. Farogat is 40 years old. She is married. She is the loving mother of four children. Her husband is an entrepreneur. In order to help her husband in supporting the family, Farogat has been running her own business for five years. She has her own tailoring shop. Currently there are four sewers working in the shop. Farogat’s tailoring shop is specialized in sewing clothing for women of European style as well as of the national style. As any mother does, she works hard to make her children happy and to give them a good education.

\r\nToday Farogat is planning to expand her business and to hire two more sewers. So she requests $600 for the term of 6 months. She shall spend it on a new sewing machine produced in Japan. This is the first loan for Farogat ,and she promises to pay it in a timely manner. She would like to thank everyone for supporting her.

Aida (her husband is pictured) is a 41-year-old woman and the mother of 3 children. She is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan and has settled in the Fuzuli region in Kurdmahmudlu village. She works very hard with her husband for the success of their children.\r\n

\r\nThey have run their dairy business for 10 years. By improving their business, they will be able to provide their family with better living conditions. Now they need a loan of $975 to buy a cow.

Muwanga N. is the chairperson of Mabira Development Group, a group that has been together for 10 years. She has a retail shop business selling soda, juice and mineral water in Najjembe, located in the middle of Mabira forest on the Kampala - Jinja road. It is also a common place for selling roasted meat, chicken, yellow bananas and gonja to passengers in moving vehicles. She employs a total of five boys and girls to do the running around with cold water and juice to passengers in the stopping vehicles. The profits they make are shared with her as their daily wage; meaning the more they sell, the more they earn. Muwanga is a married woman with eight children of whom four are still in school. She takes care of one of her sick sister’s children, paying for school fees in a boarding section, plus one grandchild not yet in school.

Muwanga needs a loan to buy more soda, mineral water and juice for her shop. Her dream is to own a much bigger shop with more soda, mineral water and juice plus other goods like sugar, tea leaves and other foodstuffs to accompany her drinks.

Muwanga will share this loan with the members of her group. The group is really thankful to Kiva for giving them this opportunity.

Mrs. Seak L. is the mother of six school-aged children and lives with her husband in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, where she works growing rice, vegetables and some kinds of fruits on her plot of land. She picks her produce in the morning and sells it in the market in the afternoon. She has been doing this for over ten years. 

Her husband, 53, is employed as a high school teacher making about $4/day. Their combined salaries barely cover her family’s expenses (food, and her children’s education).
Mrs. Seak L. is requesting a loan form CREDIT MFI to purchase more seeds, fertilizer so she can grow more produce, and to purchase gasoline for her family’s needs.

Masitula N. owns a small boutique in Najjembe trading centre that sells new clothes for men, women and children. She has had her shop for one year and she has been a member of the Mabira development group for 10 years. In the shop, she is helped by her sister especially during the holidays and she pays her school fees as a reward. She is proud of her business and would like to keep it and restock it to the brim. She is a married woman with three children, all in school, and she takes care of three of her in-laws. Her husband works as a manager in a company.\r\n

\r\nMasitula needs a loan to help with buying more clothes for her boutique.

N. Sofia has a retail shop in Najjembe trading centre that sells new clothes for men, women and children. She has had her shop for one-and-a-half years now. She is also a proud member of Mabira development group taking loans of various amounts and repaying them on time. She is married with four children between the ages of 4 to 14 years with no-one else to cater for except her parents in the village.\r\n

\r\nShe would like a loan to help her buy more clothes for her shop. Her dream is to see the shop grow to selling other goods like shoes, handbags and many clothes of different makes.

Nail A. has run his General Store  for 5 years. This 26-year-old man is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory Fuzuli town, settled in the Fuzuli region, Alkhanli village. Nail is single. Now he needs a loan of $975 to buy goods to improve his business and get more income.

Srey SaR., 28-yeas old, has already repaid her first loan. She is requesting a second loan so she can continue improving her standard of living. She has two small children and is a garment factory worker. She is very impressed and amazed at how her first loan impacted her family. She used the loan to purchase a concrete mixer for her husband, a construction foreman. This increase her husbands productivity and increased their income. This second loan will be used to buy more construction equipment that will further increase her husband's productivity and profits.

Varziyar I. has been in the livestock  business for ten years. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region in Kurdmahmudlu village. \r\nVarziyar is 45 years old and married with three children. Now she needs a loan of $975 to buy six sheep.

Asif  A. was born in 1955. He started his business ten years ago. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region in the village of Kurdmahmudlu.  He is married and has 3 children. Now he needs a loan of $975 to buy goods to improve his business.

Mrs. Kin C. is a grocer and a farmer in the Prey Rongeang Village of Kampong Speu Province. Mrs. Kin C. is a 37-year-old married woman with two children, both of whom are enrolled in school. Her husband, Mr. Thy Kong (pictured on the left), is a farmer and a construction worker in the village. Previously, Mrs. Kin C. obtained a loan from AMK to buy fertilizers for her field and pigs for breeding purposes. Last year, her youngest child contracted typhoid, so Mrs. Kin C. incurred $75 of expenses to cure that disease. Recently, the same child fell ill again, and Mrs. Kin C. will surely need to spend additional money on unforeseen expenses.

\r\nDespite her two business activities, she is unable to support her family in a meaningful way. Thus, she is seeking to start another husbandry business. Unfortunately, Mrs. Kin C. does not have enough money to attain this goal, so she is seeking a loan to buy cows and pigs for breeding.

Mrs. Mom C. lives in the Srey Praseur Village of Kampong Speu Province, where she works as a farmer. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is studying at state school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband (pictured on the left) is a farmer and laborer who can generate a small amount of income to support their family.

\r\nAlthough her family members are engaged in different business activities, they still do not generate enough money to allow them to live in good conditions. In particular, the family would like to build a new house to replace their old house. Thus, Mrs. Mom C. is requesting a loan to supplement her income in order to build a new house for her family.

Mrs. Sophal K. is a farmer in the Beng Village of Kampong Speu Province. She is a 39-year-old mother of four children: one child attends state school, another child stays at home to assist her in the field, and the other two children are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Von Yon (pictured on the left), is a farmer and a teacher.

\r\nAs a result, the family lives in poor conditions because all of the family members have small business activities and, on the whole, they are not able to generate much income. Additionally, they live in an old house, and they do not even have enough money to build a toilet. Therefore, Mrs. Sophal K. is seeking a loan to enable them to build a toilet for her family.

Farkhad K. is  married and has 3 children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan,Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in  Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs . He has repaired vehicles and cars for four years. Now  he needs a loan of $975 to buy necessary materials for repairing  vehicles and cars  to improve his business.

Asha M., is 52 years old and is a widow. She has seven children between the ages of 38 and 12. Asha provides for her home by running a small butcher shop, where she works from 7am to 6pm daily. She started this business three years ago and now makes a monthly profit of about $135 from her sales.\r\n

Asha hopes for a loan to open another small butcher shop. She will share this loan with her loan group called Serena, which has 23 members. In the picture, Asha is in the second row, second from the right in the pink scarf.

Mary A., a married woman with 3 children, travels to a distant town to buy food supplies like maize in large quantities to sell to her customers in smaller quantities. Business is going very well, but the cost of transportation is a major problem. Mary is asking for a loan to reduce the burden of transportation cost on her limited capital. This would allow her to buy more food per trip.

A 26-year-old woman, Lay S., is married with one small child. She works as a garment factory worker. Her husband is self-employed as a carpenter making wooden tables, chairs which he sells. She and her husband can collectively make about $6 each day. She is requesting a loan to purchase more tools for her husband's carpentry business. This will increase his productivity and their income.

Mrs. Keun P. is a grocer and a farmer in the Trapaing Lompeak Village of Kampong Speu Province. Mrs. Keun P. is a 31-year-old mother of two children, one of whom is attending school while the other is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Soeur Sok (pictured on the right), is a farmer and a bed-maker in the local village, and he makes barely enough income to support their family.

\r\nRecently, her grocery business activity has improved, and thus Mrs. Keun P. is seeking to expand her business. Accordingly, she is requesting a loan to buy more grocery goods to sell to her customers.

Mr. Peurn P. lives in the Trapaing Lompeak Village of Cambodia, where he works as a farmer. Mr. Peurn P. is a 53-year-old married man, and he is the father of two children. One of his children is employed in a garment factory, while the other one assists with his father’s business. His wife, Mrs. Kong Khim (pictured on the left), is a rice farmer.

\r\nIn addition to his farming operation, he is also a bed-maker in the local village. Unfortunately, in this bed-making business, Mr. Peurn P. has encountered numerous difficulties as of late because he has insufficient money to buy wood to make beds to re-sell for a profit, so he is requsting a loan for that purpose.

Mrs. Lim T. is a farmer in the Kraing Metrey Village of Kampong Speu Province. She is married with five children: one child works as a laborer, two children work in a garment factory, and the other two children study at state school and help their parents on the rice field. Last year, two of their children got in a traffic accident, so Mrs. Lim T. incurred $1,500 of expenses in order to cure them. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

\r\nIn order to improve her family’s living conditions, Mrs. Lim T. would like to start a cow breeding business, but she does not have enough money to buy cows. Thus, Mrs. Lim T. is seeking a loan for this purpose. Previously, Mrs. Lim T. obtained a loan to buy fertilizers and pigs for breeding purposes.

Mrs. Yun Y., 32, is a mother of three children and works with her husband growing rice on their piece of farmland. They have been doing this for over ten years. In order to generate more income for her entire family, Mrs. Yun Y. is requesting a loan to purchase a motor-taxi for her husband. Transport people to their destinations is a good business and will generate more income for her household.

Eunice M., age 45, is married with three children (ages 26, 18, and 12). She started a business of raising and selling chickens in 2006. She works from 8am to 6pm at this business and makes a monthly profit of about $230 from her sales. \r\n

Eunice hopes for a loan to start a new business of selling charcoal. Charcoal is needed in many homes in Dar es Salaam to cook food and purify water because the majority of Tanzanians do no own electric stoves. In the picture, Eunice is standing third from the right.\r\n

Eunice will share this loan with her loan group, Mwanza.

Grace D. owns a provision store. She is not yet married but has been focused on developing herself. Business is going very well so she wishes to increase sales to improve her income. However, Grace is running out of stock. So she is asking for a loan to buy more goods to sell in her store.

Jewelry is a precious substance to all. Ghanaians have beads carved from stones, very precious stones that every woman would want to adorn herself with. Faustina A. has been selling jewelry such as beads, necklaces, bangles and earrings for 20 years now. She has seven children, three of whom are in school.\r\n

\r\nFaustina wants to use her loan to buy more beads and other jewelry to expand her operation and to increase her income. She is a member of the group called Stewards. Members agree to guarantee loans for each other.

Cecilia is 32 years old and the mother of two children. She treks to the northern part of Ghana to buy products like beans, millet and peanuts and then retails them in her town. Frequent travel reduces her income and therefore she wants to use her loan to buy bags of gari, beans, millet and peanuts to avoid price hikes and also to reduce her travels. She is a member of the group called “Kamfo Yehowa” meaning Praise Jehovah. Members agree to support each other to repay the loan.

Veronica F. operates a restaurant where all kinds of local dishes are sold. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a driver and his income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family, so Veronica is working very hard to help with the family’s expenses.

\r\n\r\nBusiness is good and customers are increasing rapidly. Veronica wishes to improve her services to attract more customers, so she is asking for a loan to buy more food items and other ingredients for her restaurant.

Efua D. is a fishmonger. She is married and has 4 children. She buys fresh fish from the fishermen, brings it home for processing, and then later sells the fish to her customers. She wants to increase sales to meet customer demand. Therefore she is asking for a loan to buy more fish for processing and sale.

Maame K. is a widow with 11 children. Trekking the northern part of Ghana to buy maize and gari (milled cassava) has been her principal business for the past 26 years. She wants to use her loan to buy more bags of maize and gari to increase her inventory and also to avoid price hikes. She hopes to reduce her frequent travels to enable her to save some money to support her children’s education.\r\n

\r\nMaame is a member of the group called “Kamfo Yehowa” meaning Praise Jehovah. Members agree to guarantee one another's loans.

Ekua Y., a married woman with 2 children, travels to a distant town to buy food supplies like maize in large quantities to sell to her customers in smaller quantities. Business is going very well but the cost of transportation is a big problem.

\r\n\r\nSo Ekua is asking for a loan to reduce the burden of transportation cost on her limited capital. This would allow her to purchase more food supplies per trip.

Adwoa W. is 40 years old and the mother of three children. All her children are currently in school. She has been selling used clothing for the past 10 years in the local market. Adwoa wants to use her loan to buy more used clothes to expand her operation. She is a member of the group “Kamfo Yehowa” meaning Praise Jehovah. Members agree to guarantee one another to repay the loan.

Rukia A. is 34 years old and the mother of two children. Her children are currently in school. Rukia has been selling jewelry like necklaces, earrings, bangles, rings, etc. in the local market for two years now. She wants a loan to buy more jewels to increase her inventory and also to increase her income.\r\n

\r\nRukia is a member of the group called “Kamfo Yehowa” meaning Praise Jehovah. Members agree to guarantee loans for one another.

Esi M. supplies food items to her customers in the neighboring town. She travels to a distant town to buy food supplies like maize in large quantities, which she sells to her customers in smaller quantities. She is a single parent with 1 child. Business is going very well but the cost of transportation is a big problem.

\r\n\r\nShe is asking for a loan to reduce the burden of transportation cost on her limited capital, allowing her to purchase more food items per trip.

Patience A. is 38 years old and a divorced mother with two children. Her children are currently in school. She sells used clothes in the local market to make some income to take of the children. Prices of goods are going up and therefore she wants to use her loan to buy more bales of used clothes to increase both her inventory and her income to support the children’s education.\r\n

\r\nPatience is a member of the group called “Kamfo Yehowa” meaning Praise Jehovah. Members agree to guarantee one another to help with loan repayment.

Margaret D. prepares a native food called ‘kenkey’, which is made with maize. It is very popular with the natives of her area. Margaret is divorced, with 2 children. Business is going very well, so she wishes to increase production and sales.

\r\n\r\nMargaret is running out of ingredients for her food production business, so she is asking for additional capital to buy more ingredients.

Christina A. sells sandals, cloth and clothing. She is married and has 6 dependants. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family, so Christina is working very hard to help with the family’s expenses.

\r\n\r\nShe wishes to increase sales, so she is asking for a loan to buy more goods.

Cynthia O. is 28 years old. She is a single parent of one child. She is really dedicated to her work and supportive to her child. She owns and operates a clothing and cosmetic shop in the local market.

Cynthia is a proactive businesswoman who grabs opportunities when they appear. For example, she also sells mangoes, a seasonal fruit, to make additional income for her family upkeep, and right now is the mango season.

Cynthia believes she can make her business grow bigger and brighter with loan support and wants to use the loan to buy more clothing materials and assorted cosmetics to increase her stock of goods. She belongs to the community group called Nso Nyame ye (All is possible with God) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans.

Abena M. is a 60-year-old widow mother of seven children. She is a trader who trades in tomatoes, yams, onions, beans, maize, dried fish and other goods from a tabletop in the local market. Abena says her husband died several years ago and through this business she has managed to support her seven children to finish school and enter the workforce. She is, however, convinced that her business can grow better with increased capital and therefore wants the loan to buy more tubers, baskets of tomatoes, onions, bags of maize and beans to increase her stock and make bigger income to put up a decent shelter.\r\n

\r\nAbena belongs to the community group called Okamafo (Deliverer) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans.

Adjoa P., a married woman with 4 children, sells food at the market. She travels to a distant town to buy food supplies like maize in large quantities to resell to her customers in smaller quantities. Business is going very well but the cost of transportation is a big problem.

\r\n\r\nShe is asking for a loan to reduce the burden of transportation cost on her limited capital, allowing her to buy more food per trip.

David S. is sixty-two years old. He is married and has four children who are currently in school. David earns money selling various kinds of chemicals like weed killers, fertilizers, pesticides, as well as spraying machines to the local farmers. Many local farmers buy his products during the currently ongoing farming season when many crops are being planted. Therefore, David wants to take out a loan to buy increased supplies of chemicals and spraying machines to better serve the needs of his customers. He also hopes to thereby increase his income and be able to send two of his children to university this year. David is a member of the community called Nananom (Elders) Trust Group, whose members provide a form of guarantee (social collateral) to one another to enable overall higher rates of loan repayment.

Esi Antwiwaa is twenty-six years old and single. For the past five years, she has been earning income running her own seamstress shop. Esi is a specialist in various types of female clothing, including kabas, slits, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. Esi currently needs a loan of US$500, which she will use to increase her supplies of sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. The purchase will allow her to increase the total output and efficiency of the shop. Esi is a member of the community group called Nananom Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another.

Cecilia D. sells sandals and other footwear. She is married and has 3 dependants. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family, so Cecilia is working very hard to help with the family’s expenses. She wishes to increase sales, therefore she is asking for a loan to buy more goods for sale.

Aba K., a married woman with 4 children, sells maize, yam and other food items. She travels to a distant town to buy food supplies in large quantities that she then resells to her customers. Business is going very well but the cost of transportation is a big problem.

\r\n\r\nShe is asking for a loan to reduce the burden of transportation cost on her limited capital, freeing up more capital per trip to purchase food items.

Theresa G. is a thirty-nine year old widow and has four children who are all currently in school. Theresa hopes to be able to provide her children with good education despite being a single parent. She owns and operates and grocery shop in one of the busy local markets. In the shop, Theresa sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, canned foods, peanuts, evaporated milk, etc. Currently, she would like to take out a loan to buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of evaporated milk, cartons of vegetable oil, and other goods to increase her stock. Theresa belongs to the community group called Decency Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Akosua Menu is forty-three years old. She is married and has ten children, seven of whom are currently in school. Akosu owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, etc. She also sells frozen beef, chicken, fish and palm oil as a subsidiary. Akosua currently needs a loan to be able to buy more rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc. and thus expand her business. Akosua believes that with increased income she would be more capable of financing her children’s education and providing them with better opportunities than what she had. Akosua belongs to the community group called Decency Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Fata is 43 years old woman from Donje Dubrave, a small village near the town Živinice. She is married and her husband has his own car wash.  Fata has one daughter who attends secondary school. Fata will use this loan in the amount to buy a car polishing machine. Her wish is to improve work and family income.

Sabina T. is thirty-seven years old. She is divorced and has a child who is currently in senior high school. Sabina operates a clothing store in the community market. She sells male and female clothes, including jeans, shirts, skirts and tops. Sabina currently needs a loan to be able to increase her supplies of male and female clothes and thereby expand her business. With increased income, Sabina hopes to be able to finance her child’s education at a university. She is a member of a loan group called Decency Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Fahreta was born in 1986. She is from Donje Dubrave where she lives with her husband. Her husband only works occasionally . This is her first loan at the MCO. Fahreta intends to use this loan to buy goods for her small grocery store. Her wish is to increase monthly income for her family.
