Ama H. is 36. She is married and had four children but unfortunately, she lost all of them through tragic disease. However, she is consoled by the fact that there is still hope for her to make new babies. She owns and operates a little grocery shop selling items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed milk powder, etc. She deems this an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc. to increase her stock of goods available for sale.

Ama belongs to the community group called Anyidado (Hope) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Aiša was born in 1961. She is a widow. She sells curtains and material for sewing at the market. She has two children, a son who works and one daughter who attends secondary school. This is her first loan at the MCO . Aiša intends to invest this loan in purchasing additional textiles for selling in order to increase her monthly income.

Sikujua H., age 45, is a widow with a 22-year-old son. She sells food and cosmetics, a business she started five years ago. From selling cosmetics, she makes about $90 a month, and from her food sales, she makes about $9 a day. She works from 6:30am to 5pm each day.

\r\nIn the past, Sikujua has taken three loans from Tujijenge Tanzania in order to increase her inventory, buy land, and pay school fees for her son. She now hopes for a new loan to start selling soft drinks with her food. In the picture, Sikujua is squatting third from the left and is wearing the black scarf.

Afua M. is 60, married, and has four children who have all completed school and are working. She is a food vendor selling banku. Banku is prepared from milled maize, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish or soup. Afua has a lot of customers because banku is enjoyed by many Ghanaians as breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials such as maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and also firewood. She hopes to increase her income to support her children’s education.

Afua belongs to a community group called Anyidado Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Agnes N. is forty-five years old, married, and has two children, one of whom is in senior high school, while the other one is in primary school. Agnes is hard-working and dedicated, and therefore successful in her business. For the past twelve years, she has been working as a retail seller of eggs and onions, financially supporting her family. Agnes is now in need of a loan to be able to increase her supply of onions and eggs and to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. Agnes is a member of the trust group called Anyidado (Hope) Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Alberta O. is thirty years old, married, and has two children, 1 and 4 years old. Alberta earns income running her own grocery store, where she sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. She would like to expand her business further to be able to offer other items frequently demanded by her customers. Alberta is therefore asking for a loan, which she will use to buy more rice, sugar, vegetable oil, body and hair creams, and other items to increase the stock of goods in her store. Alberta belongs to the community group called Nyame kye (God’s Gift) Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Mary A. is thirty-five years old. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. Mary works very hard and with passion to be able to provide better opportunities for her children and send the eldest of them to a medical school. Mary earns income running her own grocery store in one of the busy local markets. She sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, canned foods, peanuts, evaporated milk, etc. Currently, Mary is asking for a loan, which she will use to buy more rice, sugar, evaporated milk, vegetable oil, and other goods to increase the stock in her store. Mary belongs to the community group called Nyame Kye (God’s Gift) Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Yaa A. is forty-five years old, married, and has six children. She is very resourceful and supportive of her husband, helping him finance their children’s education and provide them with opportunities in the future. Three of Yaa's children have already completed senior high school and could start studies at a university. Yaa earns a living selling cooked food - rice with stew - as well as ground nuts, beans, and yams in the community market. She currently needs a loan to buy more rice, beans, and yams to increase the stock of goods in her store. She belongs to the community group called Nyame kye Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Mercy K. is thirty-four years old. She is married and has three children - twin boys and a girl - who are all in school and doing very well. Mercy is a responsible mother and cares a lot about her children's needs and welfare. She earns a living selling used clothes to a large number of customers. However, with insufficient capital, Mercy can barely buy enough used clothing to make profit from selling it. She is therefore asking for a loan, which she will use to buy a variety of used clothes to meet the customers' needs and thus be able to increase her income to pay for her children’s education. Mercy is a member of the community group called Anyidado Nyame (God of hope) Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Adwoa Nyaneba is forty-five years old. She is married and has a child who has completed senior high school. Adwoa sells ground nuts, beans, yams and waakye - cooked rice and beans typically eaten as breakfast in the mornings with stew, macaroni and fish. Waakye is very tasty and filling, and almost all tribes in Ghana enjoy it. Adwoa currently needs a loan to buy more bags of rice, beans, and yams to increase her stock of goods. She belongs to the community group called Nyame kye Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Anastasia E. is forty-two years old. She is married and has two sons and three daughters who are currently in school. Anastasia owns and operates a grocery store, where she sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. She enjoys running her own business and is motivated to work hard, because she dreams of a better future for her children. However, Anastasia is constrained by insufficient capital. She is therefore requesting a loan to be able to buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, and other items to increase her sales and income. Anastasia is a member of a community group called Nyame kye Trust Group, whose members provide a guarantee for one another as social collateral to help access and repay loans.

Amina M. is twenty four years old. She is not married. She sells porridge and groundnuts in her neighborhood. Porridge is one of the local foods enjoyed popularly as breakfast. It is prepared from boiled milled maize or millet grains eaten with sugar, milk and bread. Because of her large customer base, she wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, and milk to increase production. She hopes to earn a good income to support her younger brother in school. She is a member of a group called Nyame Kye Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Evgeniya is a business owner from the city of Melitopol in southern Ukraine. She has a small kiosk at the central market in Melitopol where she sells a selection of women’s clothing. Evgeniya is very experienced as an entrepreneur, having been in business for over eleven years. Married with two daughters, her business has been a good source of income for her family. One of her daughters is in college and Evgeniya has been able to help with some of her educational expenses.

\r\n\r\nEvgeniya has requested a loan of 4000 Ukrainian Griven to help purchase new clothing inventory. She has a good credit history with HOPE Intl-Nadiya Ukraine and we are happy to be able to continue helping her run a successful business.

Lubov is a careful, hard-working entrepreneur who has a small business selling women’s clothing at an outdoor market in Melitopol, Ukraine. Before starting her own business Lubov had worked in a manufacturing plant. When the plant was shut down, she decided to start her own business and began selling in the market. She has been self-employed now for about ten years. Her business has done well and she currently makes about $1000 per month – a good middle wage income in Ukraine. Lubov is divorced and has two grown children.

\r\n\r\nLubov has requested a short term loan of 2500 Ukrainian Griven to buy an assortment of new inventory for her business. She has proven to be a very responsible client with Nadiya Ukraine, repaying all previous loans on-time. We are happy to have this opportunity to assist her as she works to continue operating a successful business.

Tatyana is an entrepreneur from the southern Ukrainian city of Melitopol. She sells a variety of small clothing items including socks, hosiery and hats at an outdoor market in Melitopol. Tatyana has a good place to sell in the market with lots of passing traffic and a visible location. She has had her own business for the past twelve years. Divorced, her business is a very important source of income. She has two children – a son who is married and has a family and a daughter who was just recently married. Tatyana is able to help both of her children with the income she makes.

\r\n\r\nTatyana has requested a loan of 5000 Ukrainian Griven to increase her working capital. This will allow her to purchase new inventory and continue developing her business.

Evdokiya is a small business owner from Melitopol, Ukraine. A widow, she lives with her daughter and granddaughter. Evdokiya sells women’s clothing from a little kiosk at the busy central market in Melitopol. She is an experienced entrepreneur, having been in business for about 15 years. Her typical monthly income is around $400.

\r\n\r\nEvdokiya has requested a loan of 4000 Ukrainian Griven to purchase a supply of summer clothing to sell in her kiosk. She has been a client with HOPE Intl-Nadiya Ukraine since 2002 and has developed a reputation as a responsible borrower. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist her with operating a successful business.

Galina has a small business in Melitopol, Ukraine. She sells a variety of children’s clothing from a little outdoor kiosk at the central market in Melitopol. Galina has had her business for over ten years. When she was first starting out she chose to sell a product that was a good fit for her. Divorced and living by herself, Galina would like to continue developing her business so she can improve her standard of living. She currently makes about $320 per month.

\r\n\r\nGalina has requested a loan to purchase new summer clothing inventory. She should have good sales and resulting good income during the warm summer months.

Tatyana loves children. Her children’s clothing business, which she has had for the last ten years, is a great fit for her. She sells clothing from a little kiosk at the central market in Melitopol, Ukraine. Tatyana has gained extensive experience as an entrepreneur. She respects her customers and they respect her in return. Tatyana is married and has two children who are grown. She typically makes over $500 in a given month.

\r\n\r\nWith the change in seasons, Tatyana has requested a short term loan to help purchase some summer clothing inventory. She hopes to expand her business and improve the living standards of her family.

Uliya has a business creating beautiful synthetic flower arrangements used in funerals and as gravesite decorations. These arrangements are very common in the Ukraine as a way to memorialize and honor loved ones who have passed away. Uliya has extensive experience in this business. She has been working for herself for over seven years. She is married and has two young sons. Uliya makes about $400 per month from her business.

\r\n\r\nUliya has requested a loan of 5000 Ukrainian Griven to buy materials used in making her flower arrangements. She has been a client with HOPE Intl-Nadiya Ukraine since 2004. We are happy to have another opportunity to help this hard-working entrepreneur as she works to provide a better life for her family.

Juan is the leader of this amazing group of entrepreneurs, and they are now applying for their second loan with Esperanza. Juan is 24 years old and lives with his wife, Rosa, and their newborn baby girl. He has owned a small grocery store in his community for about three years but has been able to improve and expand his business significantly since his first loan. Juan wants to work hard to provide a better future for his new daughter. On weekends he likes to take his family to the beach or just spend quiet time in their house.\r\n

\r\nThank you for your support!

Yesenia is a funny and bright-eyed woman who lives with her husband and sonin the community of Los Alcarrizzos. She runs a small business out of her home selling curtains, sheets and a cloth home accessory that is very popular in the Dominican Republic. She has requested this loan to buy a few new kinds of fabric which are new to the area, but which she knows will be a hit with existing and new customers. Because summer is beginning, when the heat is often unbearable, people want materials that are bright, beautiful, and which help block the sun from their homes, and Yesenia plans to use this loan to buy material that will fit this need perfectly.

\r\nShe hopes that this money will help her and her husband improve their lives enough so they can afford three meals a day, and so that their son has the opportunity to grow up in health and happiness. She hopes that the boy grows up to become not only a man of God, but a man who does well for he community. She herself hopes to always continue improving her life and business, and when asked what challenges she faces in her life, replied with a simple "Yo puedo," brushing off the idea that something might keep her down, and saying matter-o- factly, “I can.”

Teresa is a very intelligent and hard-working woman who lives in the town of Samana with her three children, ages five, 14, and 15. She sells fried and baked bread outsiD. of her house, and hopes to expand her business. With this loan she plans to buy flour, coconut, and sugar, which she uses to make sweet bread. In her free time she attends church and spends time with her friends. She looks forward to being able to create a better future for herself and her family, and thanks you for your support!

Leoni is a 29 year old man who lives with his wife and three children in the suburb of Los Alcarrizzos on the outskirts of the capital of Santo Domingo.  

He has a small business selling a variety of items such as motor parts, oil, gasoline and diesel by the quart, and a variety of other motor and electrical related appliances.  He has asked for this loan so that  he will be able to buy some new parts to offer his customers, instead of only being able to offer them used and repaired parts.  He hopes that with the extra income he is able to earn with this loan he will be able to save enough money he will be able to allow his children to continue going to school with enough pencils and notebooks to learn properly, and he hopes that he can finish building a strong home out of concrete blocks that will survive the strong hurricanes and tropical storms that hit them every year.

On behalf of Leoni and everyone here at Esperanza International, we thank you for supporting his dreams and goals!

Lourdes, the leader of this group, is a 35 year old woman who lives with her husband Felix, and two teenage-aged children in the community of L. Guaricanos in the Dominican Republic. Things in L. Guaricanos are often very difficult; consistent and well paying work is hard to come by, but the people live on the outskirts of the capital and as a result are forced to pay somewhat inflated prices for everything from food to school supplies, prices that most people simply cant keep up with.

Lourdes runs a small business selling dried flowers, scented candles, natural medicines and a few different chemicals to help treat skin problems. She normally sells these items to people who know about her business from her home, and will also walk the streets a few times a week. She has asked for this loan so that she can buy a new selection of candles—candles are always sin demand since the power goes out an average of two to three time each day. She would also like to expand the types of herbal medicines she is able to offer her clients.

She hopes that with the extra income this loan will help her make, she will be able to improve the lives of her children and improve the manner in which they all live. She also says she hopes to raise them with good health, and teach them what it means to make an honest living in a world where many people resort to corruption and stealing to get by. She wants to see them all happy, and she hopes that she will able to see her family continue to move forward in their lives economically and happily.

On behalf of Lourdes and everyone here at Esperanza International, we thank you for supporting his dreams and goals!

“VilL. Cotay” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project which provides its credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations as it is a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 2,000 – 5,000 meters above sea level). These limitations incluD. the cold, the difficulty of growing crops, and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “VilL. Cotay” is located at approximately 3,500 meters above sea level in the community of Cotay, in the district of Anco, province of Churcampa. The small town of Cotay is located where there once used to be an old colonial hacienda, and the people lived there to work on the hacienda. Most business is done with the city of Huancayo, the biggest city nearby and a 4-5 hour drive away. The main activities of the population are related to agriculture and incluD. growing crops like barley, wheat, corn, potato, oca, peas and beans. Most of the population also raises sheep, cattle and small animals.

The bank is starting its first loan-cycle with 11 female borrowers and a total loan of 2,400 soles (about 875 US$). The loans range from 100, 200, 300, and up to 500 soles.

The group already is in its third loan-cycle in over one year of existence. In their time with FINCA Peru, the members have worked very hard to save and to be more responsible with money and in their businesses. They want to improve the quality of their lives; they are especially motivated because they want their children to have a good education, to be professionals, and to have better opportunities. When talking about the future, these items are the most important ones.

In FINCA Perú, what the members have learned and want to continue learning is how to know and understand each other better, how to share responsibilities amongst the members, how to be better entrepreneurs, how to calculate the gains of selling their products, and how to do family planning. When asked about their savings, most are equally-minded. Savings are for improving their businesses and for their children's education or their housing when studying.

One of the members of the community bank is Doris. Doris will receive a loan of 200 soles and has a small business of buying and selling small animals. Besides that, she also sells cereals and clothes. Her business depends a lot on the time of year. Doris works to support her family, especially the education of her children. Before she did not do a lot. She was not working and depended completely on her husband. Now she runs her own little small business! She is creating her own opportunities and savings as well. Now her husband is jealous sometimes because her business is going well and she is the one earning the money for the household. Her dream is for her children to leave the community, to study to become engineers and that way give something back to the community in future, applying what they studied. (She is very sure her children will help). She has the dream of going to a place where she can run a bigger business. With her savings, she wants to improve her business.

Viviana P. D. L. C. tells another story. She started her business making clothes for children. Together with her husband, they operate some machines for making the clothes and sell them at nearby weekly markets. Another business she runs is buying and selling cereals in Huancayo. When in Huancayo she uses her time to buy more materials for her clothing business. With her 500 soles loan, she will buy more materials in Huancayo. Now that she will be working with FINCA Peru, she hopes to save more and to work more responsibly to be able to pay for her loan. She will use her savings to reinvest in her business and in the education of her children. Besides that she is thinking about buying terrain in Huancayo in the future and a car to be able to move her product. Now that she is in FINCA Perú, she has learned to care for and value herself as she learned to save.

Cipriana L. Montanéz has a small grocery store and sells shoes and clothes in the time the kids go back to school. With her 200 soles loan, she will buy more supplies for her store. Her dream for the future is to improve her small store and for her grandchildren to study. (Unfortunately her children did not have the opportunity to study). As well the family is thinking about buying a house in Huancayo where the grandchildren can live when they are studying. In FINCA Perú, she has learned that women can work as well and that they, too, can change something in their lives to improve the quality. Besides that, she has learned to value herself. She wishes her late husband could be alive to see that she is ok!

Mrs. Khiev K. R., 41, is a mother of four single children and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been working as teachers at Ta Koak High School since 1998, making collectively about $4 each day. Now the income she and her husband make is barely enough to supplement her entire family. Because of the inflation, the prices of goods like gasoline and other commodities in Cambodia are very expensive. \r\n

\r\nIn order to generate more income to cover her daily expenses, Khiev K. R. would like to run a new business making and selling dessert near the school where there are a lot of students passing by. To do this, Khiev K. R. has requested a loan to help her get started. (Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Khiev K. R. was not available).

This is Ruhullah A., a 32-year-old man. He is marred and has four children. He lives in the district of Shewa in the Ningarhar province and works as a farmer there.\r\n

\r\nHe wants to buy a lot of seed and improve his business, but he doesn’t have enough money for this purpose. He requested a loan of 40,000 Afghanis from AFSG, and he will repay the loan in 24 months.

Anwar, the wife of Mr. A. H., is a mother of two beautiful daughters. Anwar B. is a fruitseller. She lives with her big dreams in a big country called Pakistan. Anwar’s dream is to see her daughters educated and qualified in every field. Her husband is a driver and he drives three wheel vehicles called Auto-rickshaws. She successfully completed a loan from Asasah, a microfinance Institute in Pakitstan. Anwar B. applied a loan to expand her fruit business.\r\n

Anwar has been joined in her group by a few more members who are: Maqboola B. who wants a loan for her fruit business; Zahida B. who wants a loan to start her electric supplies (tube lights) business; Nasreen B. is applying for a loan to start her fruit business; and Parveen B. wants to start her cloth business.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Sughran bibi, wife of M. S., is the mother of six children. Their eldest son got his education till 9th standard, now he works in a workshop and repairs the engines of vehicles like cars, motorbikes. Their second son is doing lathe work. Their younger children help Sughran by taking care of her buffaloes. Her husband is a contractor. Sughran bibi has a clothing business which she started through her home and she sells them to neighbors. She successfully completed a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution in Pakistan. She needs a loan for her clothing business. She hopes that if she makes some profit from the loan she’ll make something for her daughter’s marriage. \r\n

Yasmeen B. needs a loan to start a shuttering business. Naziran B. wants to start an ice business. Manzoran B. needs a loan to repair her rickshaw. Razia B. needs a loan to start a cassette business.\r\nThis is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Qubra, the wife of Mr. I. is the mother of four sons and three daughters. Her husband hasa business making wooden baskets. Due to adverse circumstances her sons couldn’t get education. Qubra's first daughter is married. Her first son drives a rickshaw, the second one works in a paint shop and the last two are learning skills about lathe work. Qubra is sweeper by profession. She successfully completed a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution in Pakistan. She has now applied for a loan to buy three wheel vehicles called auto-rickshaws.\r\n

Shabana wants a loan to start a meat business. Anwar B. and Shamim B. want loans to buy rickshaws, and Rashida B. wants a loan to start her gas slender shop.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Naheed, wife of Mr.E., is the mother of five beautiful children. The eldest son is in 9th standard. The third son is in 2nd standard. Her husband works in a workshop. She is a housewife and does household work. She successfully completed a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution of Pakistan. She took a loan for her son and made a rickshaw. Her son drives a rickshaw and supports the family. Now she applies for a loan for her husband to start his welding workshop. She hopes to make a profit from this loan that she can use to better her sons' futures. \r\n

Razia B. wants a loan to buy a rickshaw. Safia B. wants a loan to start a grocery shop. Nazia B. wants a loan to buy a paint machine. Shazia B. wants a loan to buy a rickshaw.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Sajida, wife of M. Sarwar has the business of trading wheat. She has one son and one daughter. Their son is in kindergarten. Sajida and her husband are willing to educate their children because they think that through education they will be able to face every situation very independently. She successfully completed a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution. She needs a loan to invest in her wheat business, so that they get a lot of profit because this is the wheat season.\r\n

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Haleema B. needs a loan to start a fruit cart business. Bashiran B. wants a loan to make iron boxes. Maqboola B. wants to expand her cigarette shop. Naseem B. needs a loan to start a workshop.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Rehana Parveen, wife of M. H., is the mother of four sons. The eldest son is in 2nd standard. The next to him is in kindergarten. Her purpose is to give her sons education, to make them independent. Rehana’s husband is a driver by profession and drives a rickshaw. She makes embroidered clothes and sells them. She applied her loan to repair her three wheel vehicles called auto-rickshaws. She plans to buy land with the profits. \r\n

Sangeeta B. wants a loan to start a food business. Gulshan B. wants a loan to buy masonry tools. Parveen B. wants a loan to buy woods to expand her business. Sumera B. wants a loan for her lathe work. \r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Twenty-four members in the Rotaing Village will be bonded in a Village Bank, and Mrs. Sophea B. will serve as the Village Bank President. Mrs. Sophea B. is a 33-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She is a farmer, and her husband, Mr. Chantha Prum, is also a farmer in the local village.

\r\nTypically, Mrs. Sophea B. cultivates her crops twice a year. Her farming business has encountered numerous difficulties in recent months because the field on which she farms is infertile, not to mention the fact that many insects damage the vegetables she is able to grow. Moreover, just last year, Mrs. Sophea B.’s vegetables were ruined by floods during that year's rainy season, which was truly a crisis for her family from a financial standpoint. As such, and in order to solve these problems, Mrs. Sophea B. is requesting a loan to buy more fertilizers and pesticides (to kill insects) for her field.

Mr. Huy U. is the Village Bank President of twenty-six members in the Khsom Village of Kandal Province. He is a fisherman and a bicycle repairman in the village. In addition, he is married with seV. children: two of his children are employed in a garment factoR., two are fishermen, two are enrolled in state school, and the other child stays at home. His wife, Mrs. Lou Aok, is a fish-seller. Last year, Mrs. Lou Aok was diagnosed with high blood pressure, so Mr. Huy U. incurred $125 of expenses to cure her. During that time, Mr. Huy U.’s fishing business faced a severe storm, and he was unable to catch many fish to support his family.

\r\nHis fishing business has encountered mounting problems in recent months because he does not have enough money to buy fishing equipment. Accordingly, Mr. Huy U. is seeking a loan to buy such equipment to fish in the lake. Previously, Mr. Huy U. obtained a loan from Acleda Bank, which he used to buy fishing equipment.

Bushra kosar, wife of Mr. A. G., is the mother of four children. Besides her first son, the rest of them are getting an education. Bushra B. and her husband are willing to give their children education till they want. She is a successful client of Asasah, a microfinance institution of Pakistan. She invested that loan amount in her husband’s vegetable business. Now she applies for a loan again for her husband so that he is able to expand his vegetable business and earn a lot more profit. \r\n

Anayat bibi wants a loan for his cold drinks business. Naik Parveen B. wants a loan for a meat business. Shamim B. wants a loan for a vegetable business. Rehana B. wants a loan for a fruit business.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Sakina B., wife of M. Aslam, is the mother of five children: The first three sons got their education until 8th standard and started working in a bakery. Sakina’s daughter is married. The last son is in 12th standard. Sakina is a cook by profession. She use to make bakery materials and is famous in the society where she lives. She applied for a loan to expand her bakery business. She trained her sons in this business. \r\n

Farzana B., who is Sakina B.’s daughter in law, wants a loan for her husband who is a salesman. Nasreen B. wants a loan for her husband’s meat business. Kishwar sultana and ramzana B. want loans to buy rickshaws.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

A Village Bank in Khsom Village consists of twenty-nine members. Mrs. Ly C. is the Village Bank President. She is a 38-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are studying in state school. Her husband, Mr. Sopha Mao, is a farmer in the local village.

\r\nShe is a fish-seller, so she buys fish to re-sell in the village. Her business is doing well, but she would now like to expand the business. Unfortunately, Mrs. Ly C. has insufficient money to purchase more fish; thus, Mrs. Ly C. is requesting a loan for this purpose. Previously, Mrs. Ly C. obtained a loan from Amret Co., Ltd., which enabled her start her fish-selling business.

Mrs. Chanthu H. lives in the Khsom Village of Kandal Province, where she is subsistence farmer. She is a 37-year-old married woman with six children: three of her children sell clothes in the Banteay Meanchey Province (which is on the border with Thailand), one attends school, and the others stay at home. Her husband, Mr. Nhork Chhuon (pictured on the left), is a farmer and construction worker. Aside from her farming activities, Mrs. Chanthu H. also generates income from her pump, which she permits villagers to use for a fee.

\r\nRecently, Mrs. Chanthu H. has faced mounting financial problems because her field is simply infertile. Therefore, Mrs. Chanthu H. is requesting a loan to buy more fertilizer, fuel for her pump, and pesticides to kill insects.

Zahida Parveen is the widow of A. S.. He was the breadwinner of his family. He left his family all alone without any financial support. Zahida B. hasn’t enough money to change her circumstances. She has two sons and three daughters. The eldest sons completed 10th standard and are willing to get more education. The next to them is not willing to get an education. She needs a loan for her tea business. She is out of stock now and is relying on this loan. \r\n

Zahida has been joined in her group by a few other women named: Safia B., who wants a loan to expand her juice business. Rashida B. wants a loan to invest in a clinic. Sabra B. wants a loan to expand her computer business. Abida B. wants a loan for her mobile business.\r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Mrs. Phlang C. is a fish-seller in the Khsom Village of Kandal Province. Mrs. Phlang C. is married with six children: two children are employed at a garment factory, three are enrolled in school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Last year, Mrs. Phlang C. developed a heart disease, so her husband spent $500 to cure his wife. Her husband, Mr. Tha Poul (pictured on the right), is a fisherman.

\r\nMr. Tha Poul’s business has struggled as of late because he does not have sufficient equipment in order to catch fish. Therefore, in order to make his business more successful, Mrs. Phlang C. is requesting a loan to buy more fish nets, and any remaining loan proceeds would be used to fix their fishing boat.

Um R., a 37-year-old, has four children and lives with her husband in Kampong Chnang, Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur purchasing and wholesaling in a large quantity of chickens to the market vendors, making on average $23 per day in revenue. Her husband, Mr. Heng Sophon, age 39, is a motor-taxi driver and earns approximately $3 a day of profit.\r\n\r\nTo meet her customer’s demand and to earn more profits to support the family, now she is requesting for a loan from Kiva to purchase more chicken to make her end meet.

Bidhya T. lives with her husband, Tulshi Ram T., and two children in the town of Sainbu-Bhashapati in the Lalitpur region of Nepal. Tulshi works in construction, building houses for a living. They have a daughter who is in the first grade and a son in primary school.

Two years ago, Mrs. Bidhya opened a poultry farm as a way to improve her family's standard of living and so that she could send her children to good schools. Mrs. Bidhya sells her chickens in a local market, and her husband and daughter help her in this work.

Today, the demand for chickens is increasing rapidly in Nepal, and Bidhya would like to meet this demand by expanding her business. That is why she has applied for a $375 loan to buy baby chicks to raise and eventually sell.

Shagufta B., wife of M. Y., is a fruit seller. Shagufta’s husband worked in a mill but unfortunately he left the job because his elder son became ill and through treatment they came to learn that their son was suffering from cancer. He left his job and served the amount in the treatment of his son but in vain. Shagufta’s younger son started to work as a property dealer. The eldest son sells fruit. Shagufta applied for a loan for her fruit business. She plans to renovate her house from the benefit of loan. \r\n

Shagufta has been joined in her group by a few other women who are: Sarwar B., who wants a loan for her grocery shop; Azra B., who wants to start her embroidery business; and Parveen B., who wants to buy a rickshaw. \r\n

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Mr. Samey R. repairs motorcycles for a living in the Khsom Village of Kandal Province. His wife, Mrs. Vanny Mao (pictured on the right), is a fortune-teller in the local village. Mr. Samey R. is the father of four children, one of whom is attending school while the others are too young to work or study.

\r\nIn recent months, his business has faced mounting problems because he does not have enough money to afford equipment which enable him to make repairs on the motorcycles his clients bring to him for service. Thus, Mr. Samey R. is seeking a loan to buy such equipment.

Mrs. Sarswati R. lives in the town of Bagdol, in the Lalitpur region of Nepal. Most of her neighbors make a living running small businesses. Mrs. R. has a husband, Raju R., and two sons. Raju works in a restaurant, and her sons are in the 5th and 3rd grade.

Three years ago, Mrs. Sarswati R. opened a small clothing shop where she sells different types of garments. She has applied for a loan of $225 to buy more goods to sell in this shop.

Mrs. R. is determined to provide a good education to her sons, but in Nepal the cost of education is very high. That is why she is trying to save her additional income for the future education of her two sons.

Mr. Chhorn B. lives in the Rotaing Village of Kandal Province, where he works as a farmer. Mr. Chhorn B. is a 54-year-old married man with four children: two of his children are laborers, while the others are enrolled in school. His wife, Mrs. Lon Von (pictured on the left), is a subsistence farmer. Last year, Mr. Chhorn B.’s children contracted typhoid and, as a result, he had to spend $75 to cure their diseases.

\r\nUsually, he cultivates his crops twice a year. In the dry season, Mr. Chhorn B. grows vegetables; unfortunately, however, he does not have sufficient funds in order to buy nets to protect his crops from animals that come to eat his vegetables. Thus, Mr. Chhorn B. is requesting a loan to purchase such nets, and any remaining funds would be used to buy fertilizer for his field.

Mrs. Asha Rawot lives in the town of Bagdol, in the Lalitpur region of Nepal. Most people in this region run small businesses such as grocery stores, small hotels and stationery stores.

Mrs. Maharjan is a widow who lives with her two sons. Three years ago, her husband, Mr. Tilak Rawot died, giving her sole responsibility for her family . Both of her sons are in school, one in the 10th grade and the other in the 6th.

Mrs. Rawot opened a small hotel three years ago. She also runs a shop where she sells different types of Nepali food, along with tea and coffee. She has applied for a $225 loan to buy food supplies for this business.

Mrs. Ros H. is a farmer in the Popeal Khaer Village of Kandal Province. She is a 34-year-old widow with five children: one child is employed in a garment factory, another one is a fisherman, two are enrolled in school, and the youngest child is too young to work or study. Aside from her farming work, Mrs. Ros H. owns a lake where she grows lotus, which she sells for a profit.

\r\nIn order to make her harvests more plentiful and profitable, Mrs. Ros H. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support her field and lake.

Mrs. Pramila M. lives in Baghdol, Lalitpur, a town where many people run small businesses such as grocery stores, ready-made clothes shops and so on. Mrs. M. lives with her husband, Bijay M., and one daughter. Bijay is an army officer, and her daughter is in school in the 12th grade.

Two years ago, Mrs. M. opened a beauty parlor. Before doing this, she trained for six months at an institute in a nearby city.

She is seeking a loan of $150 to buy equipment for her salon. She wants to increase her income so she can provide a better education for daughter.

Mrs. Rama M. lives in the town of Thecho with her husband and their two sons. Both sons are in school, one in grade seven and the other in grade five.\r\n

\r\nMrs. Rama and her husband Mr. Surendra earn a living making statues of traditional gods and idols, and demand for their products is increasing. To meet this increased customer demand, they need to invest in their business. They have applied for a $225 loan, which they will use to buy raw materials like wax, silver and bronze.

Mrs. Rama K. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Sainbu-Bhaishapati. She owns two cows and makes a living selling milk door to door every morning and evening.

Mrs. K. lives in a single-family home with her husband, Mr. Madan K., who works in private office, and their two daughters. Her older daughter has left school and helps her mother with her business. Her younger daughter is sill in school, in grade seven.

Mrs. K. has applied for a loan of $450 to buy another cow because the demand for milk is increasing in her area.

Goma K. is married and has two children -- a daughter who is in the eighth grade and a son in the seventh. Her husband, Mr. Manohari, works at a factory in a nearby industrial area.

Goma K. owns one cow and and makes a living selling milk in her area. In Nepal pure, fresh cow’s milk is highly valued as a beverage and for its contribution to health. She carries her milk around with her in containers and sells it door to door every morning and every evening.

Goma K. lives in a growing neighborhood in which demand for milk is constantly increasing. To help meet this demand, she would like to buy another cow to increase her production. She plans to purchase a jersey cow, which produces more milk than most cows, and has applied for a $300 loan to fund the purchase.

Farzana B., wife of Mr. M., is the mother of two children. Their eldest son is in 2nd standard. The next to him is not in a school going age. Farzana’s husband is a teacher in a local school near her area. She makes embroidered clothes. She is running a stitching center and a few girls are working with her to fulfill the order of customers. She needs a loan to purchase all decorated embroidery material to fulfill the orders of customers.\r\n

Naseem B. wants a loan to start a meat business. Rukhsana B. wants a loan to start a decorated embroidery business. Naik B. wants a loan for a meat business. Abida B. wants a loan for trading cattle.\r\nThis is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

The group leader of this small group is Asunta C.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Asunta is 29 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man. She has one child who is two years old. Each week, Asunta makes approximately 25 Sudanese Pounds in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business. \r\n

\r\nAsunta is joined in her small group by Omijima M., Christhine K., Susan P., and Mary S.. Omijima M. has a business selling clothes and wants to construct a house. Christhine K. is currently operating a business selling breads and wants a loan to buy property for her work. Susan P. operates a business selling breads and wants to expand the business. Mary S. is currently in the business of brewing alcohol and is requesting a loan to carry out her business.

Mrs. Chandra Laxmi S., 40 years old, is a seamstress who works in the town of Volakhel in Patan. She opened her shop four years ago and specializes in making custom-fitted dresses and other clothing items for women, and school uniforms for both boys and girls. Before starting her business, Mrs S. took a six-month training course.

She is married to Bidya Ratna S., who earns a living making brass religious statues. She has two daughters, ages 17 and 11 years. The youngest daughter is in the seventh grade. Her older daughter just graduated and helps her mother in her shop.

Mrs. S. has applied for a loan to buy the materials she needs to make more clothing for her customers.

Mrs. Rejena N. is 31 years old and works as a seamstress in the town of Kalanki. She opened a shop three years ago, and specializes in making custom-fitted dresses that are very popular with Nepali women. Before starting her business, Mrs Nalarmi took a six-month course in tailoring at a shop near where she lives.

She plans to use her loan to buy raw materials for making dresses, and wants to use her income for self improvement and for her daughter's education. In Nepal, the cost of providing a good education is rising, and Mrs. Narkami wants to begin saving her income now so she can provide for her daughter later.

Her husband, Sudip Singh N., is a high-school and college teacher. Their daughter is three years old and attends nursery school .

Mrs. Tulshi Maiya M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur, a part of Nepal where most people are farmers. She is married and has two children. Her husband, Tulshi Ram M., is a laborer who builds houses for a living. They have two sons who are in high school. \r\n

\r\nThe family lives in poverty because her husband's income is not enough to support four people. To overcome this problem, Mrs. M. opened up a poultry farm two years ago. She now makes a living selling chickens in the local market. Because of her success, her family's conditions are slowly improving. To continue this improvement, she has applied for a loan of $150 to buy 100 baby chicks to raise on her poultry farm.

O. Kumri is 45 years old. She is married and has four children. Her husband is entrepreneur. In order to help her husband in supporting the family, Kumri has been running her own business for the last 7 years. She works in a tailoring shop. During these seven years she has gained rich work experience about tailoring. Kumri’s work is specialized, sewing clothing for women of European style as well as of the national style.

\r\nShe always dreamed of owning a business and not having to depend on anyone else. Kumri believes that someday her dream will come true and she will open her own tailoring shop. Today she is requesting a loan of $600, which she will repay over 6 months, in order to purchase a new sewing machine. With your help, this will be possible. Kumri is counting on your help. Be an important part of the growth of Kumri’s business!

Mrs. Sushila M. is 25 years old and lives in the undeveloped region of Thecho, Lalitpur with her husband and a son. Most of people in this region are farmers. Her husband, Mr. Nanda M., is 60 years old, and for the last 26 years has installed and repaired gas cookers for a living. Mrs. M. is seeking a loan to buy the goods and supples she and her husband need to continue running this business.

A. Lochin is 38 years old. He is married with four children. Lochin is a farmer. He is growing crops like tomatos, cucumbers, onions, potatos, wheat and others. He has been working the land for ten years. His wife, who is pictured in the photo, and elder son help him with the business. Each year Lochin is grows crops sufficient for family consumption and for selling. Generating stable income, Lochin is able to support his large family. Today he requests $350 for the term of 8 months. The loan shall be used for purchasing the seeds and mineral fertilizer. After gathering his yield he wants to sell it all to the locals with the lowest prices in the market. Lochin thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to be accurate with the loan payment.

Mrs. Srijana P. is 32 years old and lives in Bijeswori, a town in the Kathmandu Valley, with her husband and three children. Mrs. P.'s oldest daughter is 13 years old and in the seventh grade. Her middle child, also a girl, is 12 and in the sixth grade. Her youngest child, a son, is six and in the first grade.\r\n

\r\nLike many people in this area, she and her husband make a living running a small shop that sells various items such as snacks, gum and jewelery that are in demand among local residents. She has applied for a loan of $225, which she will use to buy more goods to sell in her shop.

K. Mirzosafar is 51 years old. He is married with four children. Mirzosafar is a farmer. He is growing crops like onions, wheat, tomatos, cucumbers, potatos and others. He has been working the land for ten years. His wife, elder sons and a daughter help him with the business. Each year Mirzosafar grows crops sufficient for family consumption and for selling. Generating stable income, Mirzosafar is able to support his large family. Today he requests $600 for the term of 9 months. The loan shall be used for purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer. Mirzosafar thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to be accurate in the loan payment.

M. Salim is 48 years old. She is widow. Salim is the loving mother of three children. Salim is a market vendor. For the last ten years she has been selling cottonseed oil in the local market. Her son helps Salim with the business. In the traditional Tajik cuisine, the majority of the meals are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil. Especially our national dish, Oshi palov, which needs much cottonseed oil in order for it to be delicious.

\r\nSo the goods that Salim is selling are of popular demand among the population. Now Salim is planning to arrange the marriage of her son. For this reason she is planning to increase her business. Now she requests $100 for the term of 6 months. The loan shall be used for purchasing cottonseed oil in order to increase the goods. Salim is counting on your help and thanks everyone for supporting her.

Y. Karim is 40 years old. He is married. He has three children. Karim is a market vendor. He is selling the brooms in the local market. As a rule, he purchases the brooms from the neighboring country Uzbekistan, from the city of Kokand. Karim has been in this business for eleven years. His wife and elder son help him with painting the brooms. Usually they paint the brooms with the red color in order to give them a good look to attract clients. Therefore his goods are in great demand.

\r\nThe business is stable and allows Karim to use the generated income for improving the living conditions of the family. He is trying to do all the best in order to make his children happy and to give them a good education. Now his elder son is going to enter the University, and that’s why he needs to expand his business and increase the working capital for purchasing the brooms. With this purpose, he requests $700 for the term of 9 months. Karim is counting on your help and thanks everyone for supporting him.

U. Jamal is 49 years old. She and her husband have raised six children. Her husband is a businessman. In order to increase their family budget, for the last six years Jamal has been selling cottonseed oil in the local market. Her son helps Jamal with the business. In the traditional Tajik cuisine, the majority of the meals are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil. So the goods that Jamal is selling are in demand.

\r\nSix years ago, Jamal started this business with a rather small amount of money, and today the business has turned into a stable one. Now Jamal is planning to cover the higher education expenses of her daughter and to arrange the marriage of her son. For this reason she is planning to increase her business. Now she requests $300 for the term of 6 months. The loan shall be used for purchasing cottonseed oil in order to increase the goods. Having proved herself as reliable, Jamal promises to repay the loan on time and thanks all supporting her.

Sergey is married and has a daughter. He sells women’s footwear at the city market in Novaya Kahovka, Ukraine. Sergey purchases all of his inventory from national shoe factories which produce good quality and durable footwear. He started this venture 4 years ago. Today his business is well known in the city for having assorted merchandise.

\r\n\r\nSergey’s venture is the only source of income for his family. He operates it as a family business based on Christian values. Sergey always sticks to principles of integrity and responsibility. We believe this loan will help him expand his business, having a positive impact on his trade profitability and helping to further improve the economic and social situation of his family.

Yuryi is married with two daughters. He’s a businessman from Novaya Kahovka where he sells women’s footwear in the city market. Yuryi is very enterprising, has vast experience working as a vendor and is full of creative ideas. A reasonable pricing policy and client-friendly service has always been priorities in his work and have helped to ensure the success of his business. Yuryi has a perfect record as a client with HOPE Intl-Nadiya Ukraine, having promptly repaid each loan he has received.

\r\n\r\nYuryi has been running his business for seven years. Currently, he has about $6000 invested in the business. His monthly income is about $300-400. Yuryi is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to increase his inventory. He believes that having this additional turnover capital will help him minimize his sales risk and provide stable financial support for his family. Moreover, it will help him get closer to his ultimate goal of purchasing a big store of his own one day.

K. Muhayo is 42 years old. She is married with four children of school age. She has been running her business for more than three years. She rents a shop at the center of the town. She is selling clothing for kids and also baby carriages, and other baby things.

\r\nAll the goods are delivered by Muhayo’s husband from a neighboring country. Muhayo and her husband are trying to purchase goods of good quality, with prices acceptable for the clients with average incomes. Being a very nice and friendly woman by her nature, Muhayo is working hard and trying to serve the clients so that they have a positive experience and want to come back.

\r\nThe business is stable, allowing her to contribute considerably to the family budget. Now Muhayo is planning to purchase baby carriages and tricycles in order to increase the range of goods for selling. With this purpose she requests $1200 for the term of 12 months. Having positive credit history, Muhayo promises to repay the current loan promptly. She grateful for everyone supporting her.

C. Ahror is 40. He’s married. He’s the father of 4 children. Her wife is Bibijamol, and she helps Ahror with farming. Ahror is working hard on the farm, and his business includes growing and selling of onions, garlic, potatoes and maize. Due to it being the beginning of the sowing season, he is planning to sow onion, garlic, potatoes and maize. That is why he wants to buy seed and mineral fertilizer. He needs a loan of $500 with the term of 8 months. After gathering his yield he wants to sell it to locals, with the low prices in the market. He is promising to be accurate with paying the loan. Ahror and his hopeful wife are counting on your help. Be an important part of Ahror’s business!

Alla is married with two children. She is from Novaya Kahovka where she sells footwear for children and teenagers in the city market. Alla is an experienced market vendor – she has been working in the trade for 12 years. Today she earns about $400-600 of net profit per month. She has about 70 different types of shoes for sale. \r\n\r\nAlla’s business is an important source of income for her family and she works hard to provide for the daily needs of her family. Alla is very energetic and cheerful. She dreams big and always tries to be optimistic in her endeavors. Alla is seeking a loan of 2500 Grivnas to expand her vending business. She is hoping to generate enough profit and savings to open a new vending facility in the near future.

Tatyana is a working mom. She runs a business selling women’s clothing at the Dneprovskyi market in Kherson, Ukraine. Tatyana started her own business 5 years ago. She is disciplined, accurate and thoughtful in planning and managing her business and is a businesswoman who can handle any challenge with natural enthusiasm and determination.

\r\n\r\nTatyana has benefited from the lending services provided by HOPE Intl-Nadiya Ukraine and has established a reputation for honesty as she has worked with our organization. She has requested a loan of 2500 Grivnas to purchase some new clothing items to sell. This loan will provide further assistance to Tatyana as she seeks to develop her business and increase her income.

Y. Ibrohim is 30 years old. He is married. He is the father of three wonderful children. Ibrohim’s children are small now, but already today he is working hard in order to ensure the best future for them. Ibrohim is a market vendor. He is selling brooms in the local market. As a rule he purchases the brooms from the neighboring country Uzbekistan and the city of Kokand.

\r\nIbrohim has been in this business for 6 years. His wife and elder daughter, who is pictured in the photo, help him with painting the brooms. Usually they paint the brooms with a red color in order to give them a good look to attract clients. Therefore the goods that is he selling are in great demand. The business is stable and allows Ibrohim to use the generated income for improving the living conditions of the family. Today he requests $700 for the term of 9 months. The loan shall be used for increasing the stock of goods. Ibrohim thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to be accurate with the loan payment.

Naveeda B., wife of Mr. M., is a mother of two sons. Both are not yet of school-going age. She needs a loan to buy a laundry shop because her husband is a washer man by profession.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Abida B. wants a loan to buy land and to buy an iron press and iron stands; Shamim B. wants a loan to expand her Pan Shop business; Safia B. wants a loan to buy a vegetable cart; Naseem B. wants a loan to improve the condition of workshop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Nallay is 35 years old and married with 5 children. The family does subsistence farming for their survival.  They grow vegetables, peanuts, and rice. Like the other group members, Sallay K. and Mariama M., Nallay cannot grow enough food to sell due to a lack of farm inputs. The group is therefore requesting a loan of Le.1,500,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizer and hire laborers.

Safia B., wife of Mr. M., lives in a small city of Pakistan named Chichawatni. She has been living in this city for the last 40 years. She has a four room brick house. She has six sons. Her first two sons are married. All of her sons are in a mature age. The second son works in a paint shop. The son next to him has a motor bike business. Her husband runs a Pan shop. She needs a loan for her husband’s business.

Safia has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Shazia B. wants a loan to expand her meat business; Suraiya B. wants a loan to buy a donkey cart; Nasreen B. wants a loan to expand her fruit business; Irshad B., wants a loan to make sacks of flour and fine flour to sell in the market and earn a profit.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Victoria is married with one daughter. She is the main breadwinner in the family. Victoria sells terrycloth robes and other clothing items at the central market in Novaya Kahovka, Ukraine. Financial problems brought out her tenacity and innovation six years ago when she decided to start her own small business. Today she has a small kiosk selling casual outerwear for women. She makes about $300-$500 of monthly net profit.  \r\n\r\nVictoria is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to sustain her business. One of the greatest joys of her work is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She has had a great history with "HOPE Intl-Nadiya Ukraine” having repaid every loan she has received. Victoria is requesting a loan 1000 Grivnas to re-supply her inventory. She is planning to purchase a variety of clothing items and expand her trade. Victoria believes that having an assortment of clothing that is practical and durable will increase her sales and offer a nice variety to her customer base.

Alice leads a group with four members. She is 48 years old and married with seven children. Their ages are 28, 26, 20, 18,15, 12, and 8 and three of them are in school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban within a slum area.

She purchases bales of secondhand clothes, which she grades and prices. The clothes are then put on display in her home or sold in the daily markets in different areas. She sells at both retail and wholesale.

She must deal with high transport costs, price fluctuations, and an environment in which floods keep clients from getting to her stall in the rains.

She is successful in being able to pay school dues, acquire medication, and contribute to the family welfare. She aspires to buy a plot of land where she can construct rooms to rent out.

Alice has successfully paid back more than five loans.

Rukhsana B., wife of A. S., was born and brought up in an area of an industrial city named Faisalabad. She has been living in Chichawatni, a small city of Pakistan, for the last 35 years. She has four daughters and three sons. The eldest son works in a garment factory. The next son to him works in a property dealing business. And the next to them is getting education in a local school.

She needs a loan for her husband to diversify the products and, in future, make her grocery shop into a store. Her husband has been in this profession for the last 35 years. She makes embroided clothes at home.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Naziran B. wants a loan to purchase the material for wooden baskets; Khadija B. wants a loan to repair her rickshaw; Jamila B. wants a loan to buy electric items; Kosar B. wants a loan to repair her rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

M. Sobirjon is 50 years old. He’s married. Sobirjon and his wife have 3 children. Sobirjon is a farmer. His wife and elder son help him with the business. He is growing such crops as wheat, onions, potatoes, tomatoes, cucumbers and others. Having worked the land for ten years, Sobirjon has gained rich experience. Each year he is growing a yield sufficient for the family consumption and for selling. The business is the main source of income and is generating a stable income. At the same time, it requires considerable funding. Now Sobirjon needs to purchase mineral fertilizer and the seeds for planting. He’s asking for a loan on the size of $600. The loan will be repaid in 9 months. Sobirjon and his family are counting on your help. Sobirjon thanks all supporting him and promises to pay the loan on time.

Farzana B., wife of M. A., lives in a 3 room brick house. Her husband is a fruit seller. He has been in this profession for the last 12 years. Farzana's husband’s monthly income is $5 to $6. She has applied for a loan to expand her husband’s fruit business.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Naseem B. wants a loan to expand her workshop; Shahnaz B. wants a loan to repair her rickshaw; Naziran B. wants a loan to buy fruits; Shazia B. wants a loan to start a wood business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Ishrat T., wife of Mr. T., lives in a small city of Pakistan named Chichawatni. She is a housewife. Her husband runs a grocery shop. Ishrat helps him in his business. She has applied for a loan for her grocery shop. She and her husband plan that if she gets the benefit of this loan, they will diversify the products and make the grocery shop into a full grocery store.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members: Azra B. wants a loan to buy a motor cycle; Sharifan B. wants a loan to buy fruits; Amiran B. wants a loan to buy a vegetable cart; Yasmeen B. wants a loan to buy cloth.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Cossy is leads a group with five members. She is a 35-year-old widow with five children, ages 17, 16, 15, 14, and 13. All of them are in school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban within a slum area.

She has had a hair salon in her home for the last 14 years. She stocks hair oils, synthetic hair, and other salon accessories for her clients to buy. Although there is a market for her business, she must deal with the challenges of price fluctuations of her stock and noisy surroundings because she resides in a slum.

Her children dropped out of school after the death of their father, but Cossy is able to care for them and has been able to send them back to school. She managed to move to a bigger house and started rearing goats in the village. She plans to invest more in her children’s education and to buy a plot of land where she can construct a house.

Cossy has successfully paid back more than four loans.

Fatmata T. is the group leader of Sinisy solidarity group. Fatmata is 40 years old and married with 5 children. The family lives on subsistence farming but cannot grow enough for the family and for commercial purposes.

When Fatmata heard about Kiva, she organized the other group members, Fanta K., Saran K., Feremusu M., and Kutha S., to access loans to increase their production. The group grows rice, peanuts, carrots, and other vegetables for consumption and for sale. Therefore the group is requesting a loan of Le.2,500,00 to purchase fertilizer and vegetable, rice, and peanut seeds, as well as for hiring labor.

C. Mehriniso is 55-year-old mother of five children. Her husband is a driver, and they both are loving parents. Mehriniso and her husband are working hard to ensure the future for their children. Mehriniso has her own business for eight years already. She started as the seller of clothing. Gradually she is becoming more involved in this business and is dreaming of opening her own trading place. Now she is selling women's clothes and shoes in the store which is located in the central local market.

\r\nMehriniso is a friendly and polite woman. She is trying to diversify the range of goods to satisfy the needs of the clients with the various levels of income. The business is stable, allowing Mehriniso to make a considerable contribution to the family budget. Her children are growing up and their expenses are increasing too. Thus she wants to develop her business. With this purpose Mehriniso requests $1000 for purchasing new summer clothes and shoes for women to sell. The loan will be repaid within 12 months. Mehriniso thanks all supporting her and promises to pay the loan in a timely manner, as she used to do with her previous loans.

N. Mayna is 57 years old. She is widow. She’s the loving mother of eight children.  \r\nMayna is a market vendor. She is selling clothes and shoes for men in the local market. Her two sons help her with the business. Mayna has been in this business for five years already. For these years, she managed to make her business stable and profitable, generating the main incomes for her family. When we wanted take her picture she was busy servicing her clients. That is why in the photo she is standing in the background and is not clearly seen and the men standing in the foreground are her clients. She is trying to satisfy the needs of any client with various tastes and income levels. She works very hard to give her dearest children good educations and to make them happy. In order to cover the higher education expenses of her daughter who is going to enter the university, Mayna is planning to increase her working capital in order to purchase new summer shoes for selling. With this purpose Mayna requests 400 $ US Dollars for the term of 4 months. She promises to repay the loan in accurate manner. Mayna and her hopeful son are counting on your help. Be important in the growth of Mayna’s business.

Betty leads a group with five members. She is 22 years old and single with one baby. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban.

She has just started selling women’s clothes, such as skirts, blouses, and trousers. Although her business has not yet picked up momentum because it is new, she has been able to increase her stock.

She plans to use this loan to continue increasing her stock and perhaps move her business to a more strategic place.

Betty is paying her first loan.

Ugul R. is 49 years old. Her husband is a driver. Together they are raising four children. Ugul sells clothes and shoes for kids in the central local market. She has been in this business for more then 10 years. \r\n

\r\nUgul's business is very stable which allows her to improve the level of living conditions of her family. With the income from her business, Ugul managed to repair her house as she is planning to arrange the marriage of her son. That’s why she needs to expand her business and increase her working capital to purchase new summer clothes and shoes for kids. Ugul requests US$600 for this purpose. She is promising to repay the loan within 12 months. She thanks everybody who is supporting her. She says that your support will really help her.

Mohamed K. is the Matiyande group leader and is also a Kiva client who has completed his payment. With the previous loan, Mohamed increased his stock and income and has invested part of the profit in farming. Like the other 3 members, Fatmata K., Kati K., and Seray M., Mohamed sells agricultural products such as peanuts, rice, beans, etc. They buy the products from the farmers and sell to retailers, thus taking the economy into the villages.

\r\nThe group is requesting a loan of Le.3,600,000 to increase their stock and reduce transportation costs and time spent on frequent traveling. Mohamed is 36 years old and married with 3 children.

Aziz S. sells cattle. He started his business in 1998 with growing the calves. Now Aziz has the large cow-shed in which he has many calves and the milk cow. He likes animals and his job very much which allows him to support his family. Aziz is 48 years old. He is married with three children. The youngest is in his last year of school. His elder son has become an adult and now helps him as well as his wife. \r\n

\r\nThe business requires a great effort to keep it successful and to generate stable income for the family. Thus, Aziz gets up every morning at five o’clock in order to feed the animals and to look after them. Today Aziz requests $1200 US for the term of 12 months. The loan is required to purchase calves and fodder for cattle. Aziz would like everyone to trust him, and he promises to be precise in the loan payment.

Teddy leads a group of four members. She is 45 years old and married with six children. Their ages are 18, 16, 14, 11, 5, and 3, and they all go to school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban and surrounded by slums.

She has been selling local brew for 15 years in Nakulabye, one of the busy suburbs of Kampala. She collects the brew from the village and sells it to residents of the nearby slums. She must deal with stiff competition.

She has been able to increase her business and contribute to the day-to-day running of her home. She would like to buy a plot of land in order to construct a house.

Teddy has successfully paid back more than five loans.

Yonbo is the group leader and a Kiva client who has completed her repayment. With her previous loan, Yonbo increased her income and was able to take care of her children. She also expanded her rice farm. Yonbo is a widow, but recently she also lost her daughter, leaving her with a day-old baby. At 47 years old, Yonbo now has the responsibility of taking care of her grandchild.

The group has 5 members, but the other 3 members went to purchase their business stock and were not available for the group photo. Like Yonbo, Saio KaM. sells palm oil, rice, soap, etc. Occasionally Yonbo and Saio purchase kenel nuts and produce palm oil. The 2 members would like to expand their businesses and are therefore requesting a loan of Le.2200000.

Alhaji is the group leader of Molako l. With their previous loans, he was able to increase his stock of rice and palm oil and has stock for the rainy season. Alhaji is very happy that with the profit he expanded his family's farm of rice and peanuts. Mariama K. and Jeneba M. are also happy that with the profits they were able to hire laborers to work in their firm while they do the business. The group is requesting a loan of Le.2900000 to expand their businesses. Alhaji is 55 years old and married with 5 children.

Harriet is leader of a group with four members. She is 27 years old and married with two children, ages five and two. One of them goes to school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban and surrounded by slums.

She has been selling local brew for two years in Kasubi, one of the busy suburbs of Kampala. She collects the brew from the village and sells it to residents of the nearby slums. She must face the problem of thieves who waylay people and rob them of money and property.

She has been able to build her business and contribute to the day-to-day running of her home. She would like to buy a plot of land in order to construct a house.

Harriet has successfully paid back more than five loans.

Hosiyat K. is 57 years old. She is married and has three children. Her husband works as an agricultural accountant. For about ten years Hosiyat has sold wheat, buckwheat, and peas in the local market. Her son helps Hosiyat run the business. Hosiyat begins her workday at 6:00 a.m. As a rule she buys the goods from the local farmers. In the market she is known for her fair prices and friendliness, and she has built a steady clientele and a steady source of income for her family.

Now it is the season and her goods are in great demand. She plans to purchase wheat, buckwheat, and peas to resell in the market. She is asking for a loan of 3400 somoni (1000 $ US Dollars) to be repaid over a term of 6 months. Hosiyat and her son are counting on your help. Be an important investor in Hosiyat’s business.

Mbalu C. is a widow with 6 children. She has been working hard to feed her children and send the 2 elder children to school. Mbalu does subsistence farming and has a small business selling agricultural products. With her previous loans from SMT, Mbalu was able to increase her stock and sell her products in Freetown wholesale, where she earned better income.

Her group members also do the same business of selling rice, palm oil, and peanuts, in addition to farming. The members, Fatmata K., Tye C., and Hellen M., use the income from the businesses to expand their families' rice and peanut farms. The members would like a loan of Le.3,900,000 to expand their businesses.

Mr. Chuks E. is 43 years and married with three children. He lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. He is a motorcycle rider. He learned his trade over four years and started riding in 2000. He needs a loan of $875.00 to buy a motorcycle. He is very grateful to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva.

Fatima B., wife of Mr. A. A., is a mother of four sisters and four sons. She has been living in this small city of Pakistan for the last 30 years. She lives in a house which is a 4 room brick house. She requires a loan for her husband to invest in her wheat business. They all have been working in this profession for the last so many years. She hopes that if she gets the benefit of this loan, she will buy washing machine and ceiling fan.
