Nusrat B. wants a loan to expand her embroidered clothes business. Rani B. wants a loan to expand her barber salon. Shamim B. and Razia B. want a loan to buy cloth.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Shumkor M. is 54 years old. He is married and has three children, one of whom is still under his care.

Shumkor has been a farmer for ten years, and in that time has gained much experience and a love for the land. He began cultivating his land through his own efforts and has gradually gotten ahead in life. He grows wheat, onions, potatoes, tomatoes, cucumbers, and other crops. Each year he grows enough for the family and sells the surplus. The business is the main source of income, but keeping it afloat requires considerable effort and outlay.

Shumkor needs fertilizer and seeds to plant. He’s asking for a loan of $600 US dollars. Shumkor hopes that with this loan he can increase the quantity and quality of his yield and earn greater pofits. The loan will be repaid in 9 months. Shumkor and his family are counting on your help. Shumkor thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to repay the loan on time.

Binta M. is 30 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She sells beans wholesale. She learned her trade on her own and started her business in 2001. She is very grateful in anticipation of her Kiva loan. She needs a loan of $875.00 to buy more bags of beans to sell.

Alpha Umaru J. buys and sells cows. He is 33 years old and the father of 2 children, and he is married. Alpha is a Kiva client who completed payment of his installments and would like to take more loans to expand his business. With his previous loan, Alpha could purchase 2 to 3 cows at a go and sell them in Freetown. He increased his income and was able to purchase a cow for the family to rear on the farm, while he continues the buying and selling.

Ibrahim also increased his stock of goats and would like to start buying and selling cows. The members are therefore requesting a loan of le.2.200,000.

Mrs. Magdalene I. is 51 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She sells kerosene, a trade she learned from a friend. She started her business in 2004. She is requesting a loan of $875.00 to enable her buy more kerosene to sell.

Allah Rakhi, wife of M.I., is a 30 year old lady. She has three sons and one daughter. The youngest two kids are in kindergarten. She needs a loan to buy a rubbing machine which she will use for the cleaning of wood. Her daily income is $6 to $7 a day. Her husband has been in this profession for the last 20 years. Her husband will expand the business if he gets more profit. Allah Rakhi is a housewife, and does household chores.

Sughran B. wants a loan to start fruit business. Anwari B. wants a loan to expand her sugarcane business. Zeenat B. wants a loan to expand her workshop. Sabiha B. wants a loan to start a grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Razia B., wife of M.S., has been living in Chichawatni for the last 30 years. She lives in a two story house. She has six sons. She needs a loan for her son who has just completed the Electrician course, and is willing to start his own shop. Razia B. wants to invest the loan amount in her son’s shop where he performs his skills.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few other women: Naseem B. wants a loan to start a workshop; Zakia B. wants a loan to buy a donkey cart; Mahfooz B. wants a loan to start a fruit business; Bashiran B. wants a loan to buy a van on installments.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Razia B., wife of M.S., lives in a 2 room brick house. She has three daughters and one son. One daughter is in 8th standard, the second daughter is in 5th standard. Her son is in 2nd standard. Her husband has run a grocery shop for the last 6 years. His daily income is $6 to $7. She has applied for a loan for her husband’s grocery shop business.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few other members: Shamim B. wants a loan to start a wood business; Razia B. wants a loan to start a fruit business; Rani B. wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw; Rubina B. wants a loan to start a grocery business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Mrs. Bosede I. is 50 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She sells women's bags. She learned her trade from her sister and has been in business since 1996. She is requesting a loan of $700.00 to buy more bags to sell. She thanks you.

Riaz, wife of M.S., has lived in the small city of Chichawatni for the last 30 years. She lives in a 3 room mud house. Her husband has run a grocery shop for the last 2 years. She has applied for a loan for her husband’s grocery shop.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Rubina B. wants a loan to start a decor shop; Irshad B. wants a loan to buy wood to sell; Naseem B. wants a loan to expand her furniture business; Sardaran B. wants a loan to buy a fruit car.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Sabina is leader of a group with four members. She is 30 years old and divorced with three children aged 15, 12, and 8 years. All of them go to school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban and surrounded by slums.

She washes, dyes, and plaits hair. She has been providing these services for seven years in Lusaze, one of the suburbs of Kampala. Her clients are residents of the nearby slums.

She faces stiff competition, which forces her to charge low fees, and sometimes she inadvertently buys fake materials, which causes her to lose money. Another challenge is the seasonality of her market. The months of January, February, July, August, and September are slow for her business because her clients pay school dues in these months.

She acquired a plot of land in Lusaze with the loan she got from MCDT and is looking after her family. She would like to construct a house in the near future.

Sabina has successfully paid back five loans.

Šefika is a 47 years old woman from Ribnica, a small village near the town of Zavidovići. Her huband is working as a woodsman.  Šefika is currently doing vegetable greenhouse production and she also has a few cows. She sells milk to the dairy and milk products at the village. They have 5 children. This is her first loan at MCO WWI.  Šefika intends to use this loan to expand the greenhouse and to expand the vegetable assortment that she sells. By doing this she will improve standard of life for her family.

Saidu is a Kiva client who has completed his loan repayment. With the loan, Saidu has become one of the major sellers of fuel (diesel, petrol, and kerosene) in Fadugu village and is providing a service to the community. He used part of the profit to expand the family farm and the business.

Abubakar and Peter sell agricultural products and would like to expand their businesses. The group is therefore requesting a loan of Le.2,900,000.

Doris A. is 40 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She sells timber wood at the intermediary stage, such as planks and plywood. She learned her trade over a year and then started her business in 1996. She has been an LAPO member since 2003. She needs a loan of $450.00 to buy more wood to sell.

Agnes A. is 32, married, and has two children, aged 7 and 5. She owns and operates a little grocery shop selling items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, frozen beef, chicken, and fish. She wants to use the loan to buy more rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc. to expand her business. She believes that with increased income, she would be better able to provide a decent accommodation for her family.

Agnes belongs to the community group called Determination Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Beauty O. is 57 years old and married with three children. She operates a provision store in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She learned her trade by herself. She said, “I want to use this Kiva loan to buy more provisions for sales, most especially those things my customers demand more. I thank LAPO Microfinance and Kiva for their assistance.”

Hasiba was born in 1969.  She is married and  lives with her husband and two children in Ribnica, a small village near the town Zavidovići. Her husband works at the market and has his own stall.  They are also doing farming and earning additional income by doing it. This is Hasibas first loan at MCO in the amount of $825. Hasiba will use the funds to buy chickens. Her wish is to improve the living standard of her family.

Comfort A., 50, divorced mother of one daughter, is really dedicated to her work and supportive of her child. By her own effort and hard work, Comfort has supported her daughter to finish senior high school. She owns and operates a clothing and cosmetics shop in the local market. She also repairs torn and old clothes as a part-time job.

Comfort believes she can make her business grow bigger and brighter with loan support. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing and assorted cosmetics to increase her stock of goods. She belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade (Wait upon the Lord) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan.

Mrs. Victoria A. is 30 years old and married with five children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She sells timber wood that is at the intermediary stage, such as planks and flat boards. She learned her trade over 6 months and then started her business in 1996. She needs a loan of $450.00 to buy more wood to sell.

Christiana A., 38, is married with 3 children who are currently schooling. She is a food vendor and sells fufu. Fufu is prepared from cassava and plantain, cooked and pounded together and eaten with different kinds of soup. It is a very popular traditional food among the Ashanti tribe of Ghanaian society. It is enjoyed as breakfast, lunch, and/or supper.

Christiana wants to use this loan to buy more raw materials such as plantains, cassava, meat, fish, vegetables, and also firewood. She hopes to increase her income to support her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade (Wait upon the Lord) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Teopista is leader of a group with four members. She is 58 years old and a single mother with six children. Their ages range from 40 to 25. She is looking after two school-age grandchildren. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban.

She has a small retail outlet for basic commodities, soft drinks, and groceries and must pay a high rental fee for the house in which she sleeps and does the business. Although she has been able to support her family, she would like to increase her stock and income.

Teopista has successfully paid back five loans.

Ama D., 42, widowed mother of 4 children, works very hard with the passion to provide brighter future opportunities for her children. Two of her children are in junior high school and the other two are in primary school. She owns and operates a small grocery in the neighborhood market with items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, gari, groundnuts, peanuts, evaporated milk, etc. displayed on top of a table. She also sells piped water to her neighbors who do not have direct access to water.

Ama wants to use this loan to buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of evaporated milk, cartons of vegetable oil, etc. to expand her stock. She belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade (Wait upon the Lord) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Victoria I. is 48 years old and married with four children. She lives and works in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She learned to sell used clothes, bags, and shoes over 15 months and then started her business in 2004. She needs a loan of $1200.00 to buy more goods to sell.

Amadu J. is a cow trader who has been running his business for more than 4 years. He buys and sells cows. With his previous loan from Kiva, he increased the number of cows by 2 and has a small calf for the family to rear.

Unlike Amadu, Ibrahim is a butcher in Fadugu village but at a very micro scale. He normally buys 1 cow at a time. The group has 5 members, but the other 3 were away and the team managed only to meet Amadu and Ibrahim. They are requesting a loan of Le.2,000,000. to increase their flocks.

Azuma S., 65, widowed mother of 8 children, sells tomatoes, groundnuts, maize, millet, and yams. Azuma says her husband died several years ago but through this business, she has managed to help 5 of her children finish school; they are currently working. She is, however, convinced that her business can grow better with increased capital and therefore wants this loan to buy more baskets of tomatoes, groundnuts, bags of maize and yams to increase her stock and make a bigger income to finance the education of her last three children.

Azuma belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Habiba S., 62, widowed mother of 9 children, lost her husband 3 years ago through protracted illness. She has since been the sole breadwinner of the family. By dint of hard work and perseverance, she has two of her children at university, and the rest are in senior and junior high school. She sells smoked fish, eggplant, peppers, and tomatoes in one of the neighborhood markets. Many homes enjoy her fish because it has got good taste and the price is moderate.

Habiba wants to use this loan to buy assorted fish, eggplant, peppers, and onions to make increased sales and income to support her children’s education and businesses. She belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

Mohamed K. is 52 years old and married with 5 children. He has been running his business of buying and selling cows for a long time. As a good SMYT client, he was recommended for Kiva loans and obtained his first Kiva loan 8 months ago. With the loan, he increased the number of animals in his flocks and earned a good profit.

Isata sells agricultural products such as rice, palm oil, and beans, and she would like to expand her business. They are therefore requesting a loan of Le.2,200,000.

Mr. Joseph U. is 38 years old and married with five children. He sells cooked food in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. He learned his business from his mother and then started his restaurant in 2004. He needs a loan of $1200.00 to buy more food to cook and sell.

Sajida B., wife of A. S., has been living in a the city of Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 30 years. She is a mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. All her children are currently attending school. Her husband is a trader while Sajida is a teacher. She gives stitching and embroidery classes to her neighbors on a monthly basis. She would like apply for a loan to expand her husband’s wheat business again. Previously, she successfully completed her first loan that she borrowed from Asasah, a microfinance institute of Pakistan. With her first loan, she bought wheat and earned sufficient profit to buy two sewing machines.\r\n

\r\nHer loan group includes: Razia B., who wants to start a grocery shop; Bushra B., who wants to expand her grocery shop business; Irshad B., who wants to repair her rickshaw; and Kosar B. who wants to buy seasonal wheat. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Nasreen J., wife of Mr. J., has been living in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 15 years. She lives in a three room brick house with her three daughters and two sons. For the last 15 years, her husband has been running a poultry farm. She would like to apply for a loan to invest in her husband’s poultry farm business.\r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Parveen B., who wants to expand her food business; Irshad B. wants to make carpets; Karam B., who wants to repair her rickshaw; Razia B. wants to purchase and sell medicine. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Rukhsana Y., wife of Mr. Y., lives in a four room brick house with her six daughters and two sons. She would like to apply for a loan to help her son, Bawar, who is an auto-rickshaw driver. Bawar wants to buy his own rickshaw so that he can able to earn a greater income. \r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Khursheed B., who wants to buy a food shop to sell samosas, a very famous Punjabi food; Suraiya B., who wants to buy and sell medicine; Kalsoom B., who wants to repair her auto-rickshaw; and Zeenat B., who wants to start a grocery shop. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Zubaida M. N., wife of M. N., has four sons. Her three sons received education up to fifth grade and her eldest son has completed ninth grade. Her husband is a barber and she would like to apply for a loan to buy her own barber shop. \r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Rafia B., who wants to expand her pharmaceutical business; Shagufta B., who wants to expand her furniture business; and Rubina B., who wants to start a grocery shop. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Parveen F. M., wife of F. M., has six children: one daughter and five sons. Previously, she successfully started her own sweetmeat business, from a loan that she received from Asasah, a microfinance institute of Pakistan. She would now like a loan to buy and expand the sweetmeat shop. \r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Razia B., who wants to repair a rickshaw; Razia B., who wants to start a tea business; Zubaida B., who wants to expand her electronics business; and Kubran B., who wants to expand her food business. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Rano K. H., wife of K. H., lives in the city of Vehari, Pakistan. She is a mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her eldest son makes plastic shoes and she would like to apply for a loan to invest in the opening of her son's shoe business. She hopes that if she get a good profit from her investiment, she will be able to admit her last son into a good school. \r\n

\r\nHer group members include: Khalida B., who wants to start a grocery shop; Saba Bibi, who wants to repair her rickshaw; Kaneez B., who wants to buy cotton for her business; and Kalsoom B., who wants to expand her grocery business. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Mrs. Roseline U. is 44 years old and married with two children. She lives in Benin City in Edo state in Nigeria. She sells all kinds of drinks. She learned her trade from her Aunty and started her business in 2003. She needs a loan of $600.00 to buy more drinks to sell. She says she is grateful to Kiva.

Parveen Z., wife of Mr. Z., lives in the city of Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband is a gardener by profession, who also sells plants. They have an adopted girl who is five years old. Parveen stitches clothes at home for her nearby customers. She would like a loan to expand her husband’s business by purchasing more plants. If she makes a profit from her investment, she will renovate her house and buy some cattle.\r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Azra B., who wants to purchase and sell medicine; Kaneez B., who wants to repaire a tractor; Sardaran B., who wants to start a grocery shop; and Fatima B., who wants to start her tailoring business. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible

Grace is leader of a group of four members. She is 45 years old and married with five children aged between 28 and 11 years. Three of them are in school. The community she resides and works in is an urban slum in a low-lying area that is vulnerable to floods.

She has been selling dried fish, bananas, cassava, potatoes, and other foods for the last 19 years. When she goes to the seaside to collect the fish, she must deal with the high transport costs to and from the shore and spending nights in the cold.

She has been able to help support her family and she would like to invest more in her children’s education.

Grace has successfully paid back more than 15 loans.

Blessing W. is 25 years old and single. She sells drinks wholesale and has been in business since 2004. She live in Benin City in Edo state in Nigeria. She needs a loan for $700.00 to buy more drinks to sell. She says, "Thank you!" to Kiva lenders.

David M. S. is the group leader and cattle rearer.  Umu J. and Unisa A. K. are subsistence farmers and traders.  They grow rice, peanuts and beans. At the same time, they purchase the crops from other farmers.  With their previous loans, they increased their stocks and made good income which they invested in expanding the family farms and meeting their children's educational expenses.  The members would like to continue expanding their businesses and are therefore requesting a loan of 3,500,000 SLL.  David, the group leader, is 48 years old and married with 5 children.

Maryam A. S., wife of A. S., is a mother of eight children: seven sons and one daughter. Three of her children are married. One of her sons is tailor, while another is a shoe maker. Her husband is a gardener by profession, but his income remains insufficient to provide a good education for their children. She would like to apply for a loan to buy some plants for her husband's business and to help her son expand his work in tailoring.\r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Pathani B., who wants to invest her husband's goldsmith business; Suraiya B., who wants to expand her electronics shop; Shahnaz B., who wants to buy a rickshaw; and Sardaran B., who wants to start a vegetables business. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Miss Stella I. is single and 28 years old. She lives in Benin City in Edo state in Nigeria. She sells provisions, a trade she learned for a year before starting her business in 2005. She is requesting a loan of $450.00 to enable her to buy more provisions to sell. She says, “Thank you!” to Kiva lenders.

Sughran W., wife of Mr. W., has a six-year-old daughter. Her daughter is in kindergarten. Her husband is a laborer and she makes decorative embroidered clothes. She would like a loan for her husband who would like to start his own business of shuttering. From the money she is able to save, she will start a grocery shop in her home.\r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Ramzana Bibi, who wants to buy a fruit cart; Shahnaz B. who wants to start a vegetable business; and Jamila Bibi who wants to start shuttering business. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Rose is leader of a group of four members. She is 40 years old and married with four children aged between 22 and 12 years. All of them are in school. The community she resides and works in is an urban slum in a low-lying area that is vulnerable to floods.

She has been selling bananas (matooke) for 10 years. Presently, she works from under a tree after buying the produce from vendors who distribute it from trucks. She faces challenges of unstable prices, stiff competition, and the hazards of the weather.

She has been able to contribute to the running of her home and she would like to buy a plot of land and construct a house.

Rose has successfully paid back four loans.

Shafqat Rafique A., wife of R. A., is a mother of four children. Her husband is a milkman while she makes decorative embroidered clothes. She needs a loan to buy a garment shop. She plans to expand her garment business if she earns profit from this loan.\r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Naseem B., who wants to expand her grocery shop and Fatima B. who wants to invest her her embroidery business. This loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Busola A. is a 31 years old and married. She lives in Benin City in Edo State in Nigeria. She is a fashion designer who learned her skill over two years and started her business in 2007. She is requesting a loan of $450.00 to buy more tailoring materials.

Mrs. Uwi O. is 44 years old and married with a child. She lives in Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She sells a local gin known as Ogogoro, which she has been selling since 2005. She is requsting a loan of $450.00 to buy more Ogogoro to sell.

Mrs. Doris O. is 44 years old and married with two children. She lives in Benin City in the Edo State in Nigeria. She sells drinks, a trade she learned from her mother. She started her business in 1992 and her shop is very busy with customers. She is requesting a loan of $875.00 to buy more drink to sell.

Rose is leader of a group with four members. She is single, 25 years old, and without children. The community she resides and works in is an urban area that includes a large slum.

She purchases bales of old clothes, which she sells at retail and wholesale very early in the morning. There is a market for her goods, but her main challenges are the unstable prices and high rental fees.

She is able to look after herself without having to depend on someone. She would like to increase her stock and build herself a house with the anticipated increased income.

Rose has successfully paid back more than three loans.

Loi is leader of a group of four members. She is 63 years old and married with six children aged between 40 and 20 years. Two are still in school. She has been able to educate her children to university level. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban.

She has been making and selling samosas, cassava, pancakes, and chapattis for the last 24 years in school canteens and the surrounding areas. There is always a market for her products. Because of the high prices of the ingredients she uses, she would like to use this loan to buy materials for her business.

Loi has successfully paid back more than 15 loans.

Saramatu D., 65, wife and mother of 6 children, is a food vendor selling gari (milled and roasted cassava), beans, and fried plantains, popularly known as ‘red red’. This is a popular local meal enjoyed by many Ghanaians, especially students, because of its affordability. It is tasty and satisfying and very nutritious, too, because of the protein content from the beans. Saramatu also sells groundnuts, beans, and yams at the community market. She wants to use the loan to buy ingredients such as bags of gari, beans, bunches of plantains, and palm oil to increase her production and make good income.

Out of this business, Saramatu has been able to support five children to finish school, with only one currently in school. She belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade (Wait upon the Lord) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

“Las Rosas D. Anco” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project which provides its credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 2,000 – 5,000 meters above sea level). These limitations incluD. the cold, the difficulty to grow crops, and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “Las Rosas D. Anco”, is located at approximately 2,300 meters above sea level in the community of Anco, in the district with the same name, province of Churcampa. Anco is located at the border of the Mantaro river and is one of the lowest places in the department of Huancavelica. Due to its relatively low altituD., the area has a warm, almost tropical climate. The warm climate and the vicinity of the river make the area very suitable for growing fruits like oranges, lemons, avocado, papaya and mango. Besides the fruits, most of the people dedicate their time raising guinea-pigs and chicken. They also produce alfalfa, the crop that makes the diet of the guinea-pigs. The town of Anco is situated on the main road between 2 prominent Andes cities: Ayacucho and Huancayo. Business is done with both cities, and also people stopping on the road use the variety of services in town.

Currently the bank is starting its first loan cycle with 10 female borrowers and a total loan of 4,800 soles (about 1,750 US$). The loans range from 200, 300, 400, 500 and up to 600 soles. Because the bank has been formed recently, it has no history yet. The expectations working with FINCA Peru are very clear: increase business and save. For all members, the main use of the savings they will be generating now is for investing in their businesses or for the education of their children, whether to buy school uniforms, supplies, books, or even to pay the fees for entering primary or secondary school.

One of the members of the community bank is Flor D. María Q. A.. Flor will receive a loan of 600 soles and has a small business selling food in a kiosk on the main road. Besides that she also raises guinea-pigs. She almost has 200, and business is going well. Her dream for the future is to have her own restaurant, to have a guinea-pig farm with more than 1,000 small animals, and for her children to study. With her savings, she hopes to open her restaurant and maybe go to a bigger place with her husband, somewhere where there is a university where their children can study, where it will be more easy to have a better business. In FINCA Peru, she wants to learn and save more and learn to valuate herself as a person.

Doris Sara M. P. tells another story. She runs a small grocery store and has an internet cabin. Besides that, she serves meals to the employees of the district government. In the future, she wants to improve her grocery store and send her children to study at the university, so they can be professionals. She would like to improve the number of computers. With her 300 soles loan, she will increase her groceries. Now that she will be working with FINCA Peru, she hopes to save more and to work more responsibly to be able to pay for her loan. She will use her savings to reinvest in her business, increasing her internet business, install a fax machine, and open her restaurant. Now that she is in FINCA Perú, she hopes to to care for and value herself. Most women do not value themselves a lot. Fortunately now there is FINCA Perú which works only with women. She expects to receive trainings on how to improve business and how to work equally with men. (Her husband will do the cooking while she will attend the bank reunion and afterwards she will explain to him what she has learned!).

Tabita Durcal C. A. has a small business selling an elixir of 7 seeds and is running a small grocery store. Besides that she buys and sells cereals and school supplies for the children. With her 400 soles loan, she will buy more supplies for her store. Tabita has many dreams, like improving the lives of her children. When her husband left her, she thought that she would never improve her life and get out of her misery. FINCA Perú, an institution, has come to help the women of the community and help her to be reborn and run her business. With her savings she wants to buy herself her own house and not rent anymore. In FINCA Peru, in her community bank, she hopes to find a new family that will support each other.

Jamshed G. is 33 years old. He and his wife have 2 children. Jamshed’s children are small now, but he already is working hard to ensure the best future for them. Jamshed is the only breadwinner in the family and he is really hard-working.

\r\nJamshed has a shop in the central market of Istaravshan. For more than 3 years he has sold soft drinks from this location. Jamshed offers a wide range of soft drinks at attractive prices. His shop is very popular in his neighborhood and brings in a steady income. Jamshed is asking for a loan of 3200 somoni (925 $ US dollars) to expand his inventory. The loan will be repaid in 12 months.

Your support will really help him. Let’s get behind this dedicated father and help him with make his children’s dreams a reality.

Azra B., wife of Mr. M., is a mother of two children: one daughter and one son. Azra’s son is 14 years old and her daughter is 10 years old. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Her husband runs a grocery shop, and she would like to apply for a loan to expand into a bigger grocery store. \r\n

\r\nHer loan group includes: Rashida B., who wants to purchase and sell tape recorders; Bashiran B., who wants to buy horse; Sharifan B. who wants to start a milk business; and Balqees B., who wants to buy buffalo. This is loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Safia F., wife of Mr. F., is a mother of three children: two daughters and one son. Their eldest daughter, Sehar, 12 years old, is in fifth grade. Their second daughter, Maryam is 10 years old and she is in fourth grade. Their son is nine months old. Safia has a dream to see her children secure their future goals. Her husband has a motorbike rental business. Her daily income is $6 to $7. She applies would like to apply for a loan to buy a motorbike to increase the rental business. \r\n

\r\nHer loan group members include: Zubaida B., who wants to expand her bakery business; Rehana B. who wants to expand her milk business; Mafia B. who wants to expand her tape recorder business; and Noor B. who wants to expand her motorbike rental business. This is loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Elmie, age 29, is married with two kids. She is an entrepreneur in Panduma, Tukuran and is earning income from her transport service business. She started it almost 2 years ago and she earns PHP 3,000 per month. To improve the business, she borrowed 5,000 PHP from GDMPC micro credit which she just joined in 2010 to obtain rickshaw accessories and tires. Before long, Elmie hopes to expand her business.

Forty-year-old Isaac is married and has 4 children who are all in school. He works in agriculture, especially coffee-growing, to meet his family's needs as well as those of his aged parents. Coffee is a major cash crop in the area he lives. Through coffee, his father got money to educate him and his siblings, and through the same coffee, he is educating his children and has bought a small piece of land to expand his coffee plantation. He sells his coffee to processors because it is still in small quantities but his dream is to be able to process it himself at the local factory and transport it to the city. The main challenges are price fluctuations and the constant rains which do not give the coffee an opportunity to dry properly since Isaac solely depends on sunshine. High transport costs to the factory also encroach on his profits, leaving him with barely enough income to meet his costs.

Apolinario is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 2 children. \r\nApolinario is providing motorela or motorcycle services. He has had this business for 6 years. He requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to pay for maintenance.\r\nApolinario has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Apolinario hopes to improve his services.

Carolyne is a small scale farmer from Mabonde location, Kitale County in western Kenya. She has been in the farming business for ten years now and sells her maize, beans and tea to the local market. She earns additional income by baking and selling cakes to the local market.

Carolyne is thirty-five years old and married with 6 children aged between one and sixteen years old. Three of the children are currently attending school.

She has made a loan request of 31,200 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She hopes that her milk production will increase and she will be able to have enough milk for both domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help in paying school fees for her children and meeting her basic needs. She hopes that in the next five years she will have acquired three dairy cows and set up a poultry farm. Poor market prices and bad weather conditions have been her primary challenges.

Leticia Johanna, 31, is divorced and has three children.  She lives with her children in the city of Ventanas in the province of Los Ríos.  El Guasmo Communal Bank is located in the Agua Fría area of Mocache in Mocache Canton, where the people make a living in agriculture and livestock.

Leticia makes a living in agriculture growing corn.  She's requesting the loan to buy insecticide, urea, and herbicide.  With the help of the loan she'll be able to buy what she needs for her crops.  She'll make her purchases in the Mocache area.

Her dream is to be able to buy plots of land to continue planting.  In her free time she likes to clean the house.

Roger is 34 years old and married. He sells cloth. His business is well organized. He works from 7 a.m. until 8 p.m. every day of the week. He has ten years of experience in this work and employs two people to help him. Roger is the leader of the group, which is called “80704 Abahuje Umutima” in the local language, and he is the first on the left side with a paper in his hand.\n\nHe has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more cloth to re-sell. With the profits he earns, he plans to save money for his future and to pay his medical insurance.

Specioza is a thirty-eight year old married woman with five children living in Kasese, Uganda. Fourteen years ago she decided to invest in a retail shop and has since reaped tangible benefits such as the ability to pay school fees for her children and purchase land. She has many customers since her business is located on the Congo-Uganda border. Inadequate capital and price fluctuation are her major hardships while her dream is to open another outlet. Specioza intends to use the money to buy fish, palm oil, sugar, soap and clothes to sell.

This is Ma. Loida, 55, resident of Intramuros, Philippines. She is married to Bernardo, a businessman and is a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their own household. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Ma. Loida oversees operations of their pedicab transportation business. She owns seven pedicabs that carry up to four passengers each to their destination within the community. The pedicab driver then remits a boundary (daily quota) each day to her. In her business the regular customers are the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to paint the pedicabs and also for the maintenance of them. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ma. Loida dreams to be able to give her family a good life and hopes to expand her business through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

Marlina is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 

Marlina buys and sells string beans in their community. She has had this business for 16 years. She requested a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy more string beans to resell.

Marlina has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Marlina hopes to improve her business.

Manzura is a very industrious and goal-driven woman.  She's married and is raising four children.  Her husband is a taxi driver but his salary is not sufficient to meet all of the family's needs.  Manzura needs to find a source of income, so she plans to start her own business.  The children demand more comfort by the year: food, clothing, education, all cost a lot of money.  So, Manzura took a course on "Achieving Success" offered by the Businesswomen's Association and got a certificate.  Now she can really start and be successful in her own business.  She wants to buy and sell women's clothing and plans to use the income to provide her children with a good education and nutritious food.  Manzura is seeking a loan for 10,000 soms to buy startup merchandise for the new business and is awaiting your beneficence.

Segundo Reynaldo, 48, is in a common-law relationship and has 4 children. He lives with his family in Ventanas in the province of Rios. The “El Guasmo” communal bank is located in the district of Agua Fria de Mocache, in the canton of Mocache, which is known for agriculture and livestock.
Segundo Reynaldo is a farmer who sows corn. He is requesting a loan to buy insecticide, urea and herbicide. 

With the help of the loan, he can buy what is necessary for the crops. He’ll make the purchase in the district of Mocache. His dream is to buy a parcel of land. In his spare time, he enjoys going out with his family.

Aydee is well known and liked in her town. She is a great woman, and mother to Deyvis who is one year old. When she was 21 years old she was able to become independent, so that she could provide her little one with the best possible, as a result of her work and efforts. She currently lives in an adobe home, which she is renting. 

She has seven years of experience cultivating cacao and other local products, thanks to a piece of land that her parents provided her with to be able to make her own income. She admits that it is not easy work, and that it is often necessary to hire local day laborers to remove unwanted plants that compete for the nutrients that are needed by the cacao trees in order for the fruit to have optimal growth.  

She is happy with her crops because a good amount of time has passed since her plants have been afflicted by anything bad or by tropical disease that directly harm cacao plantations. However, the rainy season does affect the normal care of the crop because the plot of land is positioned on an incline.  

After all of these years of work, she has been presented with a good opportunity to buy a plot of land that will finally allow her to work towards her future plans of building her own home. This is only something to start with, since her long term goals include buying a bigger piece of property where she can start planting crops of achiote (also called annatto), turmeric and corn.

This is the first loan she has taken out through MFP. She heard about micro-loans from people in her town, who said they were very happy with the efficiency of the micro-loans; she believed their comments and wanted to become a community bank member immediately. As it is her first experience with loans, she is thankful to the other community bank members for how they have welcomed her and the motivation they share. 

With the 500 nuevos soles, she will add to the money she already had set aside for the purchase of a small plot of land for the future construction of her home.

Donaldo, 69, is a member of the “Los Humildes” (The Humble Ones) communal bank.  He’s married and has two children.  His wife is a housewife.  He’s an honest, responsible person.  He started his business 30 years ago.  He sells ice-cream or frozen treats from 8am until 3pm.  His advantage is that the product he sells is of very high quality and he sells it door to door.  The loan Donaldo is requesting is to buy caramel, sweetener and flavoring agents among other products exclusively used to make ice-cream.  With support from the loan, he will be able to offer more products to his customers.  The only problem Donaldo faces is that sales drop in winter because customers don’t buy much during that season due to the cold weather.  His goal is to have a well-established business and to have his own locale so as not to have to go out selling door to door anymore.  This is Donaldo’s 4th FAMA loan request and to date he’s made his payments punctually.

Mayra Jacqueline, 31, is a single mother of two children.  She lives with relatives and with her children who are 14 and 10 years old in Guaranda, Bolívar Province.  She’s a seamstress and is asking for the loan to buy an industrial sewing machine, fabric, thread and buttons.  With help from the loan she will buy materials needed to work in her shop.  She will make her purchases in Guaranda.  Her dream is to own a house.  She likes to dedicate her free time to her children.

Urima is 49 years old and married, with five children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro, ta'amu, and bananas, which she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for many years. Urima needs a loan to buy chemicals, a weed sprayer, bush knives, filings, and an axe for her business. She has been a member of SPBD since 2008. Urima will use the profits from her sales to support her children and her family members.

Sarah  is married with three children.  She  sells vegetables like garden eggs, peppers and tomatoes at Abura market.   She has been selling vegetables for some years now.  She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their home.   \r\n\r\nSarah will use her loan to purchase a variety of vegetables like tomatoes, garden eggs and peppers for sale. With the new profit, she wishes to mount a stall for the sale of her vegetables.

Mary Rose is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. Mary Rose has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products, and beverages. She has had this business for 6 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages. Mary Rose  has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Mary Rose hopes to improve her business for the education of her child.

Ludovichus is a 32-year-old married man. He has three children with ages ranging from 1 to 11 years old. He describes himself to be a visionary and humble man.

He operates a motorcycle with which he provides transportation services. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located within a busy town and his primary customers are businesspeople. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business.

He will use the loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to buy another motorcycle, along with some savings he had. His business goal is to expand his business within 5 years.

Ega is married and has seven children, most of whom attend school.  She is a resident of Mariakani area of Coast province, Kenya.  Ega owns a tailoring shop, which she has been doing for two years. 

Ega is requesting a loan for 21,050 KES, which she will use to purchase materials and sewing equipment such as needles, threads, etc. The extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve her family's living standard. She aspires to own a tailoring training center. 

Ega learned about Milango from an employee and joined the institution with an aim of accessing credit to improve the operations of her business. Her main challenge is bad debts.

Juliana is married to a mason and has 3 children. She sells waakye (rice and beans cooked together). She serves it with gari, macaroni, meat and fish stew. Juliana has been selling waakye for 11 years now. She uses her income to support her husband in paying their children’s school fees. Juliana needs this loan to purchase bags of rice, beans and other ingredients for the preparation of her waakye. With her new profits, Juliana will expand her business.

Ekua cooks banku and Ga kenkey for sale. She serves it with fried fish, pepper and tomato sauce in Abura. She is married and has 4 dependents. Ekua has been in this business for 4 years now. She uses her income to assist her husband in the general upkeep of their children. Her loan will be used to  purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku and kenkey for sale. She hopes to use the new profit from her expanded business to mount a better stall for the sale of her banku.

Merly is 54 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 11 children. \r\nMerly is buying and selling products from Avon like lipstick, lotions, and perfumes. She has had this business for 11 years. She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more products from Avon to re-sell.\r\nMerly has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Merly hopes to improve her business.

Luisito is from Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. He is 35 years old. Luisito is married and has one child. To make a living, Luisito owns and operates a bicycle transport service. Luisito has been engaged in his business for 5 years and earns PHP 4,000 per month for these activities. Luisito is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000, which will be used to purchase spare parts and accessories for his bicycle. In 2011, Luisito joined GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business.

Fouisto is 50 years old and lives in the town of Koboko in the Arua region of Uganda. For the past 10 years, Fouisto has been working hard to manage his small business, which sells dry food such as beans, maize flour, and nuts. 

To help expand his business, Fouisto has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more dry products such as maize flour and beans that will have to be sold, and will help Fouisto to generate greater profits and take care of his family's basic needs such as good. Fouisto hopes that in the future he will be able to increase his profits so he can better care for his family. 

Fouisto is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Fouisto who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Frodauward is 28 years old and is married with one child who is 2 years old. He runs a general store with products such as rice, beans, potatoes, sugar, and soap. The store is well organized. He works from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. every day of the week. He has three years of experience in this work and he employs one person to help him. Frodauward is the leader of the group, which is called “C80303 TUZAMURANE” in the local language, and he is pictured above in the middle with a paper in his hand.\t\t\r\n\r\nHe has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more rice, beans, potatoes, sugar, soap, etc. to re-sell. With the profits from the loan, Frodauward will reinvest in his business and renovate his house.

Pacita is 54 years old and married. She lives in Militar, Tukuran with her 5 children. She earns a living through fruit vending. She has been in this business for 2 years and earns PHP 4,000 per month from this work. Pacita has applied for a loan of PHP 5,000 with GDMPC to buy more fruit to sell. She has been a member of GDMPC since 2009. She hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Jackson is a 46-year-old married man with ten children living in Kasese, Uganda. After realizing that farming alone could not meet the day to day needs of his family he decided to set up a retail shop and also sells bananas as additional income. Like all good fathers, he dreams of educating his children through college and setting up sustainable income-generating activities for them. High license fees and inadequate capital to meet demand are his major challenges. He dreams of having a wholesale shop. Jackson is requesting money to buy sugar, cooking oil, salt, and washing and bathing soaps to sell.

Ratchel is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. \r\nRatchel has a flower garden, so she harvests and sells different kinds of flowers during harvest time. She has had this business for 8 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy fertilizers for the flower garden.\r\nRatchel has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future,Ratchel hopes to improve her business.

Concefta is only twenty four years old and already doing well in her farming business. This passionate farmer is married to Mr. Cornelius and together they have been blessed with one 3-year-old child. She has been in this business for three years now and from the look in her eyes you can tell how passionate she is about farming. Her mixed farm, which is located in the outskirts of Kitale town in western Kenya, produces milk, vegetables, eggs, and chickens which are all sold locally.\r\n\r\nConcefta (pictured with her favorite dairy cow) has made her first loan request through Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). She intends to use this loan to buy additional chickens and chicken feeds for her poultry farm. The income from the sale of eggs will boost her family's income and improve their livelihood. She plans to expand her dairy and poultry farm in the near future to increase her income. Her challenges are animal diseases and the high cost of farm inputs, which affects her production.

Mila is 55 years old and lives in the town of Arua hill in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married and has 6 children. For the past 20 years, Mila has been working hard to manage his cow business, which sells cattle. 

To help expand his business, Mila has requested a loan of 3000000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. He will use this loan to buy more cattle to sell, thereby generating greater profits that he can use to take care of his family and pay his medical bills. Mila hopes that in the future he will be able to become the richest man in town. 

Mila is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mila who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Chumvi Group consists of 15 women and five men.  They are farmers in Lugari District.  Truphosa is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 long rains season.  She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, grow enough food for her family, and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Last year, Truphosa harvested 20 bags of maize on .5 acre of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 long rains season. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock, and perhaps investing in another business. During the 2013 long rains season, each group member will receive .5 acre of agricultural inputs on credit. 

Truphosa is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Chumvi Group members. The surveillance officer, an One Acre Fund employee, is standing on the left of the photo and is not receiving a loan.

Delia is 59 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 

Delia has a shop that offers chairs for rent. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy more chairs to offer for rent.

Delia has been a member of HSPFI since 2005. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

Michael is 34 years old and lives in the town of Arua hill in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married and has 6 children, 4 of whom are currently in school. For the past 3 years, Michael has been working hard to manage his small business, which does welding. 

To help expand his business, Michael has requested a loan of 2000000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. He will use this loan to buy more metal materials to make doors and windows. This will help Michael generate greater profits and pay his children's school fees. Michael hopes that in the future he will be able to send his children to a better school. 

Michael is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Michael who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Nancy is  32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children.

Nancy  has a food/retail shop, or sari-sari store, that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She had this business for six years. She requested a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.  

Nancy has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Nancy hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

Sergio has worked for a coffee cooperative for five years although he already had experience with this crop since his family has worked growing it for many years.  Sergio and his wife, Josefina, work afternoons in their coffee farm and turn over their entire yearly harvest to the “Unión Regional de Huatusco” [coffee cooperative] because they are members of this association.  Sergio needs a loan to pay for laborers to pick coffee in the next harvest season because there is too much work to do and he can’t do it all himself with just his wife’s help.  He will repay the loan at the end of harvest.  Sergio would like to increase production and to do so he must plant new coffee plants in a few months that will start to bear fruit in three years.  At the end of harvest, Sergio would like to do some home improvements; it needs to be painted and needs some details in the bathrooms.

Noemí’s a merchant; her main activity is selling groceries.  She has more than ten years’ experience running her business.  Noemí’s a very hardworking person and has a local clientele; she’s succeeded in getting ahead by means of her business because it’s been one of her main sources of income.  Noemí has known how to win over her customers by giving them very special treatment and her store is located in a very strategic point with many passersby.  She also has a corn mill that she tends to very early.

Noemí will use the loan to buy corn, beans, rice, lard, eggs, bread, coffee, sugar, chicken, meats, canned goods, dairy products, flour, soap, toilet paper, detergent and other common use items.  With support from the loan Noemí gets she will be able to have a better business to cover household expenses and provide better quality of life for her family.  She dreams with stocking the store and to be able to save up enough to be able to do some home improvements.

Noemí is asking for a group loan with the following people: Limne whose main source of income for six years has been selling nacatamales [Nicaraguan-style tamales] and American clothing and Francia whose main source of income for the last six years has come from selling nacatamales, baked bread and donuts.

Danlí, El Paraíso, Honduras - October, 2012.

Ildephonse is 45 years old and is married with three children between 10 and 23 years old. He owns a sewing business and his business is well organized. He employs four people to help him. Ildephonse has seven years of experience in this business. He works from 7 a.m until 8 p.m every day except Sundays. \r\n\r\nIldephonse has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy more machines for his sewing business. With the profit from the loan, Ildephonse will save for his future, get more food for his family, and pay medical insurance for his family.

Mila is 62 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 14 children. \r\nMila has a store that sells yellow bananas. She has had this business for 11 years. She requested a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy more yellow bananas to re-sell.\r\nMila has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future,Mila hopes to improve her business.

Mwanasha lives with her six children in her own house. She operates a food stall. She’s been in business for two years and has gained valuable experience that makes it possible for her to make the best dishes and beverages. She has a large clientele because people know that everything she makes is top quality at affordable prices with the best service. \r\n\r\nMwanasha is very devoted to her work and what she most wants in life is to make her dreams reality. This is why she works so hard because she knows that’s the way to reach success. Demand has been increasing for some time now and she does not want to disappoint her customers so she’s decided to increase production but needs capital to invest in ingredients which is why she’s asking Yehu for a loan to buy corn and wheat flour, sugar, rice, and vegetables.

Joseline is a thirty eight year old married woman with 10 children living in Kasese, Uganda.  She is a member of the above mentioned group, where each member guarantees the other in accessing a loan.

For 14 years now, she has been selling cassava flour in markets. She began the business so as to sustain her family despite the challenges of price flactuation and inadequate capital to meet the demand.

Her dreams are of educating her children up to the university level and having a food store.  Joseline intends to use the money to buy cassava flour to sell.

Louis is 31 years old, married, and has one child. He owns a taxi van business, which he has been doing for twenty years. His business is well-organized. He works from 5:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m every day and employs one person to help him. 

Louis is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company, which he will use to buy tires and an engine to maintain his taxi van. He plans to reinvest his profits in his business and save for the future. 

Louis is the leader of the group called “C80304 TUZAMURANE” in the local language. He is pictured above with a paper in his hand.

Philip is twenty-six years old and married with two children. He is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been in the farming business for ten years now. His mixed farm produces maize, milk and beans, which are all sold locally. He is also employed as a taxi driver. \r\n\r\nPhilip has made a loan request of 62,400 KES (Kenyan shillings) in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. He plans to acquire more land that will enable him to expand his dairy farming. He faces the challenge of competition and a poor transport network that affects his income. He is optimistic that the proceeds from the sale of milk will enable him to secure a good future for his kids.

Walter, 28, is single living in his mother’s house located in the community of Paso de Vela in south Honduras.  His activity for the last two years has been selling new clothes from place to place; his customers are all his neighbors in the community.  Walter is asking for a 5,000 Lempira loan to buy new clothes like suits, t-shirts, bath sandals, fragrances, blouses, pants and shorts to earn higher profits because his sales improve during the last months of the years.  With support from this loan, Walter wants to continue investing in his business and continue growing like his fellow group members who sell tortillas and groceries; they are Hilda and Soany who also live in the village of Paso de Vela in south Honduras.  Walter’s dream is to stock a wider selection and to have his own locale and to provide better customer service.\r\n\r\nSan Lorenzo, Honduras - October, 2012.

Jhonnatan is a 21-year-old, single man living in the city of Chincha with his parents and siblings.  He’s a very kind, hardworking, enthusiastic person who has a strong wish for self-improvement.  Thanks to his efforts and his family’s support, Jhonnatan is studying Industrial Engineering.  He enjoys listening to music in his free time and occasionally his mother cooks a delicious “Carapulcra con Sopa Seca” to pamper him since this is his favorite dish.

On his own initiative and with much effort and dedication, Jhonnatan works as an assistant in a local welding shop.  He works every day starting very early in the morning and works 8 hours.  He feels good doing his work and believes he does well because of his discipline and the kind way he treats others.

Jhonnatan is very grateful to Kiva lenders because thanks to the support provided he will be able to buy course materials like textbooks, notebooks, leaflets, etc. so that he can successfully complete his coursework; he hopes to become a good professional to be able to move forward with his family that way.

Erlinda is 60 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. Erlinda has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store in which she buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products, and beverages. She had this business for 14  years. \r\n\r\nErlinda requested a loan for 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Erlinda hopes to improve her business for the education of her grandchildren.

Mrs. Uyanga is 37 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar City in Mongolia. Her husband works with her in her training course business. Her daughter Emujin, age nine, goes to primary school. 

Uyanga just started her business as a training course provider in August, 2012. She provides training courses to local business people in how to manage small and micro businesses. She is planning to promote her business, spread her message to business people in other districts and expand her business coverage. She is now requesting loan of 4,100,000 MNT to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and gas consuming car for business use. 

She is a friendly, welcoming, open-minded and responsible woman.

Isaac is 30 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom attends school.  He lives in the town of Arua hill in the Arua region of Uganda. For the past nine years, Isaac has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar, and soap. 

To help expand his business, Isaac is requesting a loan from BRAC Uganda for 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings, which he will use to buy more essential commodities such as milk, bread, sugar, and soap.  The loan will help Isaac generate greater profits, pay school fees for his child,  and buy basic needs such as food. Isaac hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business into a wholesale shop. 

Isaac is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Isaac who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Saumu started a dumpling making business approximately a year ago, motivated mainly by the great economic difficulties that her household was facing. That was when she started her business - with very little capital but with great enthusiasm. 

Thanks to her making dumplings, her husband and their four children can have a better quality of life at home and although they still have difficulties, they have more of a chance of getting over them. In addition to this business, she also sells coconuts and groundnuts from the same locale. 

The greatest difficulty Saumu has in her business is her frying pan which is small and leaking. This makes her production much more expensive and also often delays her work. Hoping to overcome this difficulty Saumu is looking for a loan in order to buy a bigger frying pan, and some ingredients like wheat flour, baking powder, and cooking oil.

Her goal is to run a hotel some time.

Isaac is 27 years old, married, and has one child.  He lives in the town of Arua hill in the Arua region of Uganda. For the past five years, Isaac has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells flour, sugar, and soap. 

To help expand his business, Isaac is requesting a loan from BRAC Uganda for 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings, which he will use to purchase essential commodities such as milk, bread, sugar, and soap.  This loan will help Isaac generate greater profits and pay for his family's medical expenses and food. Isaac hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business. 

Isaac is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Isaac who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Angela’s a housewife and owns a stationery shop; she combines these activities with growing coffee because her family has done this for generations.  Usually, she hires personnel to work her coffee crops because she doesn’t have much time left over to do the field work herself.  However, she’s always on top of everything needed there.  For the next harvest, Angela needs to buy fertilizer because she recently replanted part of the coffee grove and these plants will be ready to produce in three years and her yields will increase.  Angela lives with her husband and her granddaughter and after harvest would like to fix up an extra bedroom she has at home so she can rent it to foreign students who come to her city.

Norma’s a merchant; her main activity is selling men’s and women’s clothes, comforters, underwear.  She has more than five years’ experience running her business.  Norma’s a very hardworking person and has a local clientele.  She’s gotten ahead thanks to her business since it’s been one of her main sources of income.  She’s won over her customers thanks to the very special way she treats them.  With support from the requested loan, Norma will buy two bales of bed linens, children’s clothes, sandals, lotions and creams.  This will contribute to her having a better business to cover household expenses and have a better quality of life for her family.  Norma dreams with stocking her business and to buy more shelving to better display her wares.  

Sonia’s main source of income for the last nine years has come from her wholesale vegetable sales business and Pedro’s main source of income for the last five years has been from his business selling pigs and basic grains like corn and beans.

Danlí El Paraíso, Honduras - October, 2012

Claudia is a young 20-year-old woman who lives with her husband and her small 3-year-old child in the city of Cañete, in the district of Imperial. She loves her child and he is her reason for living. She is a very friendly, hardworking, and enthusiastic person who, together with her husband, uses all of her effort to get her family ahead. Unfortunately, Claudia was not able to study toward a professional career. Since she was very young she had to work to cover expenses, but she would have liked to have studied. 

Through her own initiative, and with a lot of effort and dedication, Claudia has worked in her little business for more than a year selling food. She sells a variety of Chinese dishes. She is a very good cook and has the help of her husband who helps with the business. Claudia works everyday, approximately 8 hours. She feels good doing her work and she believes that is going well die to her good seasoning and because she treats her customers well. 

Claudia is very grateful to the Kiva lenders because thanks to the help offered she will be able to carry out improvements to her storefront windows. She has increased her clientele and she needs to expand her store front as well as buy chairs and tables to improve it. In this way she will continue to work with great effort in to be able to achieve her greatest dream which is to have her own storefront. In the not to distant future she hopes to be able to see her little one become a great professional.

Julio, 21, is single and lives in the city of Chiclayo with his parents and siblings.  He's a very pleasant, hardworking, and enthusiastic man who has a great desire for self-improvement.  Unfortunately Juan wasn't able to study cooking as he would have liked to do.  In his free time he likes to read a little, and sometimes he cooks a delicious duck and rice to share with his family.

On his own initiative, with a lot of effort and dedication, and thanks to the support of his older brother, Julio works as a welder.  He works every day from early in the morning and can work for approximately 10 hours.  Julio also offers transportation services using his truck. He is comfortable doing his job and believes it's going well for him because of his kind treatment of his customers.

Julio is very grateful to the Kiva lenders because thanks to their help he'll be able to refurbish and maintain his truck.  This way Juan will be able to offer cargo transportation service and continue working and making the effort to get ahead and realize his big dream of having his own house.

Julito, who is married with three kids and is 33 years old, resides at Pandanan, SND, Tukuran.

Julito operates a fishing business venture to earn a living and he has been in this business for 10 years. Each month, he earns 2,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) doing this type of business.

He requested a loan of 3,000 PHP to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Julito joined GDMPC in 2011. In the future, Julito wants to save money as a reserve for future emergencies.

Ghulam Fatima is a married women who lives with her family. She sells clothes at home along with her homemaking activities, and plays a supportive role to meet the family's expenses.
   
Her husband has been a rickshaw driver for many past years, and he operates it more than 14 hours a daily to meet his family's expenses.  Due to this hard driving, he has to bear daily maintenance expenses of his vehicle because it requires proper maintenance of its engine and body, but he is unable to fund these expenses. 
 
She has applied loan from Asasah, KIVA's field partner in Pakistan, so that they can repair the rickshaw. She also comments that this facility will save on the cost of daily maintenance and time he spends on it as well.

Nazmi is 47 years old, married, and has two children who attend school. Nazmi used to work as painter. Now he is preparing to start his own planting business in a greenhouse. His wife works as a seller in a bakery. \r\n\r\nNazmi is requesting his first loan, which he will use to buy materials for planting plums and for an irrigation system. His greenhouse is at a house in the village where he lives and this loan will help him start his business soon. He will sell the plums locally. His goal is to expand further. In the future, he hopes to improve his living conditions.

Pierre is 44 years old and takes care of three relatives. He owns a business selling green bananas. He has four years of experience. His business is open every day each week from 6 a.m. until 5 p.m. except for Saturday.\r\n\r\nPierre has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to buy green bananas to resell. Through this expansion, Pierre will be able to earn more profit, which will be used to expand his food market, save for his future and reinvest in his business.

Sajida is 34 years old, married and a mother of three children.  She is a very caring mother and takes care of her family very well.  Her husband operates a livestock business while she supports him by sewing clothes.

She has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for further improvement of her clothes sewing business. With the loan investment, she will buy a new sewing machine because her current machine has become rough and needs replacement.

She is hopeful that by purchasing a new sewing machine, she will be able to fulfill larger orders on time and increase her profits.

This communal bank is called “El Progreso Unido” (United Progress) and it has 18 entrepreneurs who carry out a variety of activities among which are barber shop, street market vendor, turnover sales, bread sales, sewing, home items sales and services, among others.  All are from the city of Valparaíso.
