Estrella is a communal bank member and in the photo is seated in the first row, second from right to left, wearing brown pants and shirt with a black jacket; her hair is brows and she wears it loose.  She’s been selling fast-food for the last nine years.  She tends to her stand from Monday through Friday from 11am until 6pm with help from her daughter; she sells cheese turnovers, Napolitana turnovers [filled with ricotta and tomato], shrimp with cheese, full meals, chicken and meat hamburgers, sandwiches, soft-drinks and sweets in general.

She buys the merchandise and ingredients as needed in supermarkets, bakeries, markets and from suppliers that provide quality products at low prices which is advantageous economically.  She will use the loan to buy chicken, sausages, soft-drinks, bread, mayonnaise, oil, napkins, ham and cheese.  One of Estrella’s goals is to buy a container she can install in her business because it comes complete with floor, dishwasher and furniture to provide good customer service.

Estrella lives with her daughter who helps her sell fast-food and also lives with her one-year-old granddaughter.  Her dream is to be in good health to continue with her business where she so enjoys taking care of her customers.  She’s very happy and grateful for the opportunity Fondo Esperanza has given her because it’s allowed her to invest in her business.  She also feels very comfortable in the company of her fellow entrepreneurs in the communal bank because they share different activities and interests which has been a way for her to enjoy herself for a time.  With respect to the training offered during the meetings, she’s learned how to better manage her business.

Valparaíso is located 120 kilometers northwest of Santiago.  It’s the regional capital and seat of the national legislative branch of government.  It’s the nation’s main port and it has a variety of beautiful, picturesque sites like for example Nobel Prize laureate Pablo Neruda’s house.

Emmanuel is a physician but learned everything related to growing coffee since he was a little boy because his grandfather was in this business and he inherited some land that was used to grow coffee.  During the last harvest, Emmanuel replanted part of his land because the plants exhausted their productive cycles and needed to be replaced.  For next harvest, Emmanuel is requesting a loan because he’ll buy manure and will use part of the money to pay laborers he’s hired to pick the coffee.  After harvest, he’d like to invest in equipment for his medical office and his future goal is to continue training to become a better professional since there is much competition nowadays in the work place.

Blanca Nelly lives with her life partner in a home of their own.  She is a farmer, raises corn, and has been doing this for several years.  She has lots of experience and this helps her have better harvests.  Her farm land is located in a very agricultural zone and is close to her home.  She sells all around her area and has many steady customers because they know that she sells quality products at good prices.  She also sells clothing.  Blanca is a very hardworking and visionary woman whose secrets to getting ahead are consistency and love of labor.  She is completely sure that she will reach her goal and has wanted to expand her production for some time and wants to buy the supplies she needs.  She doesn’t have the necessary capital, so she approached INTEGRAL for a loan that will allow her to buy corn seed, fertilizer, tools, etc.  Blanca Nelly has a good payment record and is certain that she will repay the debt and give her family a better life.

The desire to get ahead is enormous for her; she lives with her mother and younger siblings.  She’s very hardworking and has been raising chicks and chickens for the last seven years to subsequently sell.  Crime is a very grave problem currently widespread in the zone where she lives which is why she hopes to get ahead by means of her work ignoring the bad influences that surround her.  \n\nAiming at taking advantage of end-of-year season when the sale of guinea hens and chickens increases, she’s asking Integral for a loan to buy larger numbers of chickens as well as feed she gives them so they’ll grow and fatten up to be sold at fair price.  She very much wants to improve her life to have a better future and set an excellent example for her siblings showing them that a better life exists away from delinquency.

With a loan of 50,000 KES, Rehema will be able to purchase second-hand clothing to sell door to door. She has been doing this business for over eight years.  Thanks to it, she has gained a lot of sales experience.

Rehema is married, and her husband is also a businessman. They have two children, both in primary school.

Rehema wants her business to expand and to sell more so that she will be able to provide quality of life to her family. Her dream is to own a boutique in the future.

This is Analyn.  She previously accessed an 8,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 12,000 PHP loan for her to buy more merchandise items like lotion, makeup, powder, undergarments, shoes, and other products to increase her product inventory. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Analyn hopes to give her children a good and quality education, and dreams of having a good life. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship co-members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

The six members of the group SIGUIDIA are essentially married women averaging 28 years of age and four children each. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Lafiabougou, a district in Sikasso City. The women are on their second loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. 
 
DIATA, the first on the right in the photo, does commerce in fruit in this group of women. She intends to use her loan to purchase some bananas, 10 baskets of papayas, 5 oranges, and 2 baskets of yams at the big market of Médine in Sikasso. She resells them for cash at the market and at home to a customer base composed of men and women. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 37,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used for day-to-day family expenses, and the other part is for her savings.

Rafael’s family has been producing coffee for several generations. Even though he wanted to become a lawyer, Rafael also wished to continue the family tradition. He currently produces approximately 10 tons of coffee per year and delivers his harvested crop to “Unión Regional de Huatusco”, an association that he joined several years ago. \r\n

\r\nFor the next harvest, Rafael needs a loan so that he can pay the coffee pickers that he has hired. In addition, he will pay the cost of transporting his coffee. The loan will be repaid at the end of the harvest. With the profits that he will earn, Rafael would like to make a few modifications to his house and complete a few details that need to be finished.

Marita is 43 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children.

Marita has a video karaoke shop that offers different kinds of songs to the costumers. She has had this business for 6 years. She requested a loan for 7,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to pay for the maintenance of her karaoke machine.

Marita has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Marita hopes to improve her business.

Edelisa, age 41, is married and has four children. She lives in Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur.

Edelisa operates a fishing business, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community to earn a living. She has been in this business for 20 years and earns 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to repair fishing boats.

Edelisa been a member of GDMPC since 2008. In the future, Edelisa wants to save money to have a reserve for future emergencies.

Epiphanie, a 28-year-old married mother of a two-year-old, has operated her well-organized retail enterprise for one year now. Working from 7 a.m. until 7 p.m. everyday, she employees one person to help her.

\r\n\r\nEpiphanie has requested a loan from Kiva lender Vision Finance Company to expand her business by buying more avocados, salt, soap, cooking oil, etc. She will reinvest the profits arising from this loan in her business and pay medical insurance for her family.

Fifty year old Stephen is a farmer from Kitale Town in Western Kenya. He is married with five children, four of whom are currently attending school. 

He has been in the farming business for 25 years now, and has two employees. His mixed farm produces milk and eggs, which are all sold locally. He also operates a power saw business in the same region. (Has a power saw which he hires out.) 

Stephen has made a loan request of 62,400 KES (Kenyan Shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help him improve the livelihood of his family. His biggest challenge in this business has been lack of enough animal feeds during the dry seasons.

Mrs. Zultsetseg is 26 years old. She lives with her husband and three children in a ger (traditional housing) in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. 

Her husband, Galbadrah, 30, works part-time in a private company as an assistant worker. Her two sons, Byambadorj and Batdorj,  ages 4 and 3, go to kindergarten, and her daughter, Battsetseg, 9 months old, stays home with Zultsetseg’s parents, who take care of the baby during the day. 

Zultsetseg has been working as a saleswoman in clothes, optical and grocery stores for years, and now she is planning to start her own business of clothes retail in the local market. Since their family now has two toddlers and one newborn, their family expenses have increased. She is asking for 1,000,000 MNT to import clothes for her newly starting clothes retail business in the local market. 

Zultsetseg is a communicative, friendly, and hardworking person.

Ama  cooks  kenkey for sale at Abura.  She is single and has one child.

 Ama  has been selling kenkey for 15 years now.  She uses her income to pay her utility and accommodation bills.  

Ama will use her loan to purchase bags of maize for the preparation of her kenkey for sale. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business

Shaheen is 32 years old, married, and has four children. She could not provide them with an education due to financial constraints.  Her husband operates a barber shop in the market and provides hair cutting and makeup services to his clients.  Shaheen supports her husband by sewing clothes for her neighboring clients.\r\n\r\nShaheen is requesting a loan from Asasah, which she will use to purchase scissors, shampoos, and other cosmetic items for her husband's barber shop.  This loan will help him improve his services and increase his profits.

Evariste is 47 years old and has four children. He also takes care of two relatives. Evariste sells meat, which he has been doing for three years. His business is well organized. He works from 7 AM until 4 PM every day and employs two people. 

Evariste is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company, which he will use to purchase more meat to sell. With the profits, he plans to save money for his future and buy his own house. 

Evariste is the leader of the group which is called "C5301 KANGUKA" in the local language and is the first row on the right.

Ms. Odette is a young Cameroonian woman, 33 years old, unmarried, and without children living in a well-known district in Doouala City. She has been in the hairstyling trade for three years, and her salon is located in the family concession. \r\n\r\nThis client would like to obtain this loan to stock up again with beauty products and hair extensions. With the profits obtained, she has the ambition to look for a new spot enabling her to become totally independent from her family.

The six members of the group BENKADI are married women averaging 38 years of age and three children each living for the most part in polygamous families in BOUGOULA VILLE, a district in Sikasso City. The women are on their ninth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. The past loans were indeed paid back.
 
ASSAN, who is second from the left in the photo, buys and sells fruit in this group of women. She intends to use her loan to purchase 10 baskets of bananas that she will resell at the big market of Sikasso City. She gets her supplies from the villages surrounding Sikasso and often from the Loulouni market. She makes her sales retail and for cash to a customer base composed of men and women at the market and at home.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 55,500 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used for paying the loan interest, and the other part is for her savings. Her ambition is to increase her sales, so as to do better in satisfying her ever-growing customer base.

The six members of the group SOUTOURA are essentially married women averaging 29 years of age and four children each. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Ouayerma I, a working-class district in Sikasso City. The women are on their 12th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. 
 
FILY, who is seated in the photo and wearing a white scarf, does commerce in plantains in this group of women. She has been in this business for about twelve years and enjoys great fame in this domain. She intends to use her loan to purchase: about 40 bunches of plantains. She gets her supplies from the big market of Médine in Sikasso on market days. She resells them for cash to a customer base composed of men and women at the big market of Sikasso City and at home. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 42,500 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used for paying the loan interest, and the other part is for her savings.

Theogene is 34 years old and is married with one child who is 5 years old. His business is well organized; he employees three people to help him. Theogene has four years of experience in this business and he works from 7:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. every day. \r\n\r\nTheogene has requested a loan from Kiva lender, Vision Finance Company, in order to expand his business by buying more spare parts to sell. With the profit from the loan, Theogene will reinvest in his business and pay his child's school fees.

Rukia is taking out a new loan to expand her vegetable selling business. She is happy that it has given her good results, which is why she has never regretted investing in it. 

Rukia used her previous loan to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables for her business. She says that it had a commendable impact both on her business and her home. 

With this new investment, she is sure to have a good income to continue providing a good and quality life for her family. She is a determined woman who, despite being a widow, has been able to send her children to school.

Ekua cooks banku and Ga kenkey for sale.  She serves it with fried fish, pepper and tomato sauce at Abura. Ekua has been into this business for seven years now.  

Her loan will be used to  purchase bags of maize and fish, which she uses in preparing her banku and kenkey for sale. 

She hopes to use the new profit from her expanded business to mount a better stall for the sale of her banku .

Ekua is married and has four children.  She is a fish monger in Abura, which she has been doing for eight years. Ekua buys fresh fish and smokes it to sell. \r\n\r\nEkua is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase large quantities of fresh fish to smoke.  She uses her income to assist her husband in paying their utility bills. With the new profits, Ekua hopes to expand her business.

Nancy is 26 years old and married with two children, aged three and six years old. She is a farmer from Kitale in western Kenya. She has been in the farming business for six years now. Her mixed farm currently produces eggs and milk which she sells to the local market. She solely relies on her income from farming to cater to the needs of her family.\r\n\r\nNancy has made her second loan request from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES in order to buy chickens. This loan will enable her to acquire additional chickens for her poultry farm which will increase her egg production and income. She plans to expand her poultry farm by acquiring at least 2,000 chickens and be the major supplier of eggs in the region. Her primary challenge in this business has been the shortage of feed for her chickens.

Benard is a married man and describes himself as ambitious. He operates a retail business where he sells charcoal. Benard has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located within a busy area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. He will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy charcoal to sell. His business goal is to expand his business within the next five years.

Fatuma is 49 years old and widowed. She is a mother to her four children, three of whom are adults, while one is still in school. Fatuma struggles to see that her last born acquires a good education.

With the 20,000 KES, Fatuma will be able to buy more clothing and increase the inventory in her store. She basically sells khangas (wraps of traditional cloth), and has done this for two years. She wishes to increase her inventory in order to sell more and be able to save. 

She dreams of her business growing and allowing her, in time, to save enough to have her own boutique.

Ama is a fish monger in Abura. She buys fresh fish to smoke and fry it for sale.  Ama has been in this business for 10 years now.  She is married to a fisherman and has one child. 

Ama uses her income to assist her husband to pay their utility bills.  She will use her loan to purchase a large quantity of fresh fish to smoke and fry for sale. 

With the new profit Ama wishes to expand her business

Efua is a fishmonger at Abura. She buys fresh fish and fries it for sale. Efua has been into this business for five years now. 

She is married and has four children. Efua uses her income to assist her husband to pay their utility bills.  

She will use her loan to purchase large quantities of fresh fish to fry for sale. With the new profit, Efua wishes to expand her business.

MAMADOU is 36 years old and lives with his children and his wives in the sub-prefecture of KOUROUBA, Region of KOULIKORO. He did not have the chance to go to school. Early on, he became interested in revenue-generating businesses, especially in the buying and selling of grains. 

Concerned about satisfying his clearly growing customer base, he decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After having correctly repaid the second loan, he is on this third individual loan, which will be used to purchase 4 tonnes of grains (corn, beans, millet, fonio) from peasant producers in and around DANGASSA. He will keep the grains for at least two months. Basically he makes his sales in bulk to a customer base composed of retailers from the big cities, such as Bamako or SANANKOROBA.

MAMADOU hopes to make an average monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan and reinvesting in business.

Victor, 61, grew up in a family of scarce economic resources so when he finished elementary school he started to help his parents working hard doing  heavy work.  Now, he’s married to Georgina, 72, and they’ve gone through obstacles together like the inability to have children since treatments were very costly.  However, they’ve gotten ahead and live in Latacunga, capital of Cotopaxi Province, one of the provinces that make up the Sierra Region of Ecuador and that in recent years has developed significantly  and is now considered one of the region’s most important thanks to the flower growing industry, mining, metallurgy, agroindustry, agriculture and animal husbandry.  In addition, there are businesses established here that generate important income transforming it into a commercial city with several opportunities for getting ahead.  Although there’s a high poverty index, the enterprising spirit of its residents has made the city stand out.  Families can be found both in the rural and urban sectors that stand out because of their skills in taking off with an idea that can generate profits for them in order to obtain daily sustenance.

Victor learned from his parents how to manufacture concrete blocks and thanks to his enterprising spirit has been doing this work for the last 32 years.  He works every day for between 10 and 12 hours and even this is not enough to meet customer demand mainly because production is time consuming and requires much care.  

Victor is asking Fundación Alternativa for a loan to buy materials and to pay a person to help him with production so that he can offer a larger number of bricks and attract more customers and increase his profits that he’ll use to support him and his wife for a stable future with good health and also to pay some pending tax debts.  Victor is thankful for Kiva’s involvement in being part of this step towards growth both in his work and in his family life.

Nana Ama is a baker. She bakes meat pies and popcorn for sale at Abura. She is married to a driver and has two children. Nana has been baking for eight years now. She uses her income to help her husband feed and clothe their children. She will use her loan to purchase bags of maize, flour, sugar and cooking oil for her bakery. With her profits, she hopes to expand her business.

Bushra is a married woman who lives with her family. She is housewife and does family caretaking activities. 

Her husband is a cycle mechanic. He has his own kiosk for cycle maintenance in his village. He has been carrying out this work for many years. Now he is going to add sales of new cycles to his business so that he can earn more profit. This facility will provide easy access to the buyers in his locality. 
. 
Bushra has applied for a loan from Asasah, KIVA's field partner in Pakistan, to purchase new cycles for their shop. She and her husband are buoyant that this facility will add profit to their business venture.

Lucy is a widow who is 45 years old and a mother of three children. She sells clothes in the Narok area and has been running the business for seven years earning a monthly income of KES 20,000.

She has borrowed her first loan of KES 15,000 from KADET LTD to purchase more clothing and put up a stall for the business. 

The anticipated profit will be used to pay school fees for her children. Her dreams are to improve her living standards and own a residential plot

Amima is a petty trader. She operates a grocery shop. The items in her grocery shop are milk, Milo, sugar, soups, different kinds of soft drinks, tin tomatoes, tin fish, biscuits, toffees, and powdered milk. She has been doing this for two years now   Amima is married with two children. She uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of their home  Amima needs this loan to purchase a variety of groceries to satisfy her customers. With the new profit, Amima wishes to expand her business.

Mary is a 47-year-old married woman. She has three children between 10 and 24 years old. She describes herself to be a God-fearing woman. She operates a dairy farm where she sells milk. She has been involved in this business for nine years. Her business is located near estates and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to pay for the renovation of her cow shed. Her business goal is to run a ranch within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will build rental houses, which will increase her business income. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

Mwanamisi is a very devoted woman who very much loves her work and has the urge to move forward. She has had a food stall for several years, which she is still into. She is thankful for the previous loan, which enabled her to increase production. 

Mwanamisi wants to make new investments, and she does not have enough funds to do so. For this reason, she is requesting another loan in the amount of KES 25,000 to buy more ingredients such as basic grains, sugar, cooking fat, meat, etc. 

Mwanamisi has a good repayment history, and she is sure that she will repay her loan just as she did with the previous loan, which will make her stand a better chance to be entrusted with more loans in the future.

Wesakulila Group consists of  22 women and 20 men.  They are farmers in Lugari District. The 2013 long rains season will be Edina’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She joined this year in order to grow enough food for her family and use her increased profits to send her children to school.

Edna thought last year's harvest was poor.  She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer she can have an excellent harvest. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, repairing her home, buying livestock, saving for the future, and perhaps investing in another business. For the 2013 long rains season, Edina's group members will take input loans of ½ acre each.  In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 21 acres of land.   

Edina is pictured on the right with her hand raised. The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

Nawab Begum has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her sewing and embroidery business. With the loan investment, she will buy a new sewing machine and also some embroidery material that will allow her to prepare better looking clothes and satisfy her clients.  This will also increase her orders and profits.\r\n\r\nShe has operated her business for many years, and is very confident that by purchasing these business items, she will be able to make her business a more profitable one.

The four members of the TERIYA group are married women who are 43 years old on average, and have an average of 5 children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Lafiabougou, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso.

They are on their fourth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their customers.

Aby, the first person from the right towards the left, sells food condiments and fabric in this TERIYA women's group. With this loan she plans to buy two rolls of fabric for men and women in Burkina Faso. She resells it at the market of Lafiabougou and in her family to a clientèle consisting of men and women, for cash. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 37,000 FCFA of which part is used for daily family expenses and the other is saved.

Herminia is a 61-year-old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She runs a blacksmith shop together with her husband for more than five years now. This is one of their sources of income. Her husband also works as a mechanic. \r\n\r\nHerminia is asking for a loan to buy metal and flat bars and other materials for their shop. With this they will be able to improve their living and income.

Sakina is the mother of 6 children: 4 sons and 2 daughters. She is a housewife and takes care of the family. Except for her elder son, all her kids are in different stages of school education. Her husband is rickshaw driver and has been driving it for many years.  He operates it more than 14 hours a daily to meet his family expenses.  Due to this hard driving, he has to bear the daily maintenance expenses of his vehicle because it requires proper maintenance of its engine and body, but he is unable to put up these expenses.\r\n\r\nSakina has applied loan from Asasah, KIVA's field partner in Pakistan, so that they can repair the rickshaw. She also comments that this facility will save the cost of daily maintenance and time spent on it as well.

Kabana is a group of 21 farmers in Lugari District, represented by Ruth.  The group has 14 women and 7 men. Ruth on in the right of the photo with her hand raised. The 2013 long rains season will be Ruth’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow enough food for the family.

Ruth described her harvest last year as poor.  She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer, she will be able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers who have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock, setting up a poultry project and perhaps investing in another business. 

Ruth’s group members will each receive input loans for ½ acre during the 2013 long rains season.  In total, they will receive inputs for 10.5 acres of maize and sorghum.

Prisila, 50, is in a common-law marriage and has 8 children. She lives in a community in the town of Msambweni.

Seven years ago, Prisila decided to start up a business selling fruits with the goal of earning income to support the household expenses.  At this time, she is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES. She's planning to use the loan to invest in fruit such as oranges, papayas, watermelons, and mangoes, etc.

With this loan, Prisila is hoping to increase her sales and thereby improve her standard of living.

In the photo are members of the “Trust and Pay I” group. They are small-scale business people based in Kenema, a city in Eastern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Fatmata.  Fatmata is 40 years old.  She was born in Makeni city in Northern Sierra Leone.  Today, she is residing in Kenema together with her husband and 5 children. Her husband is a trader and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. 

For many years now, Fatmata has been selling market food – onions, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, rice, etc. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy the above mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

Donika is an Egyptian grandmother of a nine-year-old granddaughter, Lisa, whom she raises all on her own.  Donika’s son, who is the child’s father, struggled financially and ended his life in a very tragic way. Then little Lisa was placed under the custody of Donika. They both live in a village in southern Albania.\r\n\r\nDonika did the seamstress job for a very long time and operated from her own home, but after she got the custody of her granddaughter, she stopped it because she had to look after Lisa.  Now, Donika is requesting a loan to cover medical expenses and she is almost begging lenders to help by financing her.

Nato is from a small village in the Vani district. She is 40 years old, married and lives with her family: her husband and two children (23 and 14 years old).  Her younger son goes to the local school. The main source of income for the family is the small monthly salaries of Nato’s husband and her elder son. Her husband works as a cook and her son is an artisan.  Nato runs a small agricultural business. In particular, she has two milk cows whose milk is used in cheese products. The family sells hens as well and piglets seasonally.  

Nato has requested loan from local financial institutions several times for her trading business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time because of low income and the lack of experience in the new business, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.  Her loan request with Credo was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative by Kiva and Credo.  This start-up loan program envisages provisioning credits with soft conditions for business start-up and re-startup to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

Nato will purchase clothes in Tbilisi for wholesale prices and resell them in her village for a profit. It will be hard work for Nato, but according to estimations, her business will be profitable and increase the income of her family. The increased profit will be reinvested in the clothing trading business to increase her stocks and sales volume. The family members will be able to increase their spending to satisfy their daily needs and improve their living conditions, and Nato will be able to finance the education of her child. She awaits your support.

Dilrabo is married to a kind man by the name of Ilhom and has 6 children.  Her husband is a driver and his income is not enough to provide the family with all necessary things. Dilrabo decided to start a new business in farming in order to generate  income with which she can contribute to her home’s finances.  She studied at the course of ‘To Get Ahead’ by an organization for women and got enough skills about business.  Her children will help her with the business. She will be very successful business woman as she is hardworking and smart. \r\n\r\nDilrabo is asking for a loan of 4000 Somonis to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers to start her new farming business. She will get through using the loan and her business will be another source of income so that her family can have a good quality of life and better financial opportunities to progress. She awaits your support.

Lydia has always been known as a hardworking person who has gotten her family ahead with a lot of effort. Despite not having had a chance to go to school, she has worked at different things, always leaving a good impression because of her commitment. 

Lydia is taking out a new loan to expand her clothes selling business. Thanks to having good sales and growth, Lydia is seeking a loan to buy more clothing and stock for her business to respond to her customers' orders.  She says that her previous loan was of great help since she was able to have ready stock to sell.

Lydia hopes to make more and more income to offer her family a better quality of life.

Luke, a 30-year-old married father of three children, two of whom are currently in school, lives in the town of Arua Hill in the Arua region of Uganda. For the past 15 years, Luke has been working hard to manage his small workshop business which makes beds, chairs and tables.

To help expand his business, Luke has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to buy more materials to make wooden beds. This will help him to generate greater profits and pay his children's school fees. He hopes to become a big and well-known local businessman in town in the future.

Luke is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Luke who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

Benanacio is 33 years old and lives with his companion Beatriz, age 30. Their cheerful family includes three young children: Edgar, Ruth, and María. Benancio and his family share a home made of wood, which he acquired at a very young age with the help of his parents.

He inherited a few plots of land from his grandparents, but he was able to expand his acreage by purchasing some additional plots that adjoined that property. Benancio has six years of experience in this line of work. He has several cacao trees since this area is well-suited for producing organic crops that are of high quality. In addition, farming is an activity that has been practiced by his family for many generations.

In order for the work to be done correctly, Benancio needs the help of workers who are reliable people from the area. They will be able to complete the outstanding tasks in a shorter period of time. This type of uniform and efficient maintenance is reflected in the final harvest.

For the next growing season, Benancio plans to hire outside help to maintain his cacao trees. He knows that cacao groves require weed removal three times throughout the season. The first removal is usually the most difficult and detailed. In addition, he wants to have organic compost and small tools available so that the outstanding work can be completed.

His goal for the future is to convert his business into a small-scale collection center of agricultural products. Benancio hopes that the large-scale distributors will want to work with him in the future, which will create an opportunity for him to improve his family’s financial condition. This is the second time he has requested a loan from MFP. Thanks to this loan, he will have everything he needs to invest in his farming business so that it will run smoothly. Benancio and his fellow Communal Bank members share the same motivation, so he is grateful to be part of a group that is responsible and demonstrates great camaraderie.

With this loan of 1,500 PEN, Benancio will hire workers for the first round of weed removal from his cacao grove. Any remaining funds will be used to buy sacks of organic compost, including bird droppings.

Jessie’s 32-years-old and has a 5-year-old son; she lives in the Tembladerani zone.  She works selling a variety of staple items in her grocery store located in the same neighborhood where she lives.  This loan is her first sequence in the institution and Jessie will use it to buy a variety of Christmas panettones and Christmas ring cakes to stock the store because the Christmas season is approaching and these products will be in high customer demand; she will also buy grocery items and soft-drinks to provide a variety of goods to her customers.  Her reason for requesting this loan is to continue improving her business.  Jessie will use profits to continue buying products and improving her income this way.  Her business wish is to have a warehouse to provide better customer service.  Jessie’s a very hardworking woman who feels happy about the opportunity granting the loan provides her with.

Juan, 53, attended elementary school.  He’s married to Carmen, 51, and they have two children who are 14 and 11 years old.  They live in Latacunga, capital of Cotopaxi Province one of the provinces that make up Ecuador’s Sierra Region.  Latacunga has developed significantly in recent years to such an extent that it’s considered to be one of the most important in the region thanks to its flower industry, mining, metallurgy, agroindustry, agriculture and animal husbandry.  Businesses that generate interesting income are also established here converting the city into a commercial center with several growth opportunities.  Many festivals occur in this city preserving the roots and purity of historical origins and ancestral traditions.  At every festival, traditional food, dances and artistic presentations are the center of attention for all inhabitants and tourists.  Some of the dishes that are served in this city are ‘hornado’ [roasted pig], guinea pigs, ‘chugchucaras’ [fried pork, 'mote'-boiled hominy, potatoes, fried plantains, turnovers, popcorn, and pork rinds; it is accompanied by aji, a spicy sauce made with hot peppers, tomatoes, cilantro, and onions], etc.

Juan has worked for a year raising animals for subsequent sale.  It was quite a challenge for him and his family to start something new but the experience his friends and neighbors shared with him helped him to feel confident about continuing forward and he’s done excellent work despite having worked for a long time manufacturing concrete blocks.  The little space he had available at home, however, made it impossible for him to continue with this so now he uses his free time to help out in nearby block factories.

Raising animals has now become his main source of employment and he spends between six and eight hours daily at it; his wife helps him and they work together even at dawn to tend to their animals and care for their health so that they will be in higher market demand.  Juan is prepared to take the next step for his business’ growth so wants to buy more animals to earn higher income that will help him improve his and his family’s quality of life.  To reach this goal, Juan has asked Fundación Alternativa for a loan he can use to make this purchase and also to obtain the training he needs to correctly manage his business and the resources that are being invested in it.

Marco, 47, is married and has two children; he lives in the municipality of Taulabe, Comayagua.  Marco has always been a merchant.  He used to just sell and repair watches and sell plastic items.  Ten years ago he acquired a stand at a local market where he sells vegetable and fruit like tomatoes, chilies, cabbage, potatoes, onions, beans, grapes and apples; he also sells movies on CDs and DVDs and repairs watches.  His wife helps him with the business.  He’s invested 7 loans into the business counting this current 12,000 Lempira loan that he’ll use to buy CDs, movies, vegetables, grapes and apples for the Christmas season aiming at increasing sales volume and income.  His plan is to separate the vegetable business for his wife to run and he’ll run the CD, movies and watch repair business himself.

Joseph is a 33-year-old farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya, where he lives with his three children who are all schooling. He has been practicing mixed farming for over 10 years, producing milk, maize, tea, and pork, which he sells at the market in his local area.

Joseph is requesting a 30,000 Kenya shilling (KES) loan from Juhudi kilimo to purchase pigs. He will sell the pork and earn extra income that will assist him in improving his livelihood and paying for his childrens' educations. He aspires to be the leading supplier of pork in his region. High costs of feeds is his major challenge in farming.

Joseph is grateful with the way Juhudi kilimo is processing loans.

Alberto is 61 years old, a friendly man and a dreamer.  He lives in his own home alongside his wife, Nora.  Nora is his business partner and also works as a cook in a restaurant.  They have one 8-year old son, who goes to school.  They intend to give him a decent quality of life. \r\nAlberto's work is selling general grocery items, like rice, sugar, flour, milk, eggs etc.  His store is located in his home.  He has been in this work for four years and has had a favorable increase in customers.  Alberto started this business because he needed a way to support his family and is unable to do heavy work due to an accident at his previous job.  Every morning Alberto and his wife go to the market.  They purchase the items they will need in order to offer their customers quality service.  Alberto says that his business is profitable because he has a lot of customers.  He is also in an accessible area, and his earnings are always increasing.  Before starting his business, Alberto had financial problems- he didn't have enough capital to open a business.  But he got a loan and decided to start the business that he currently runs.  He hopes to keep his store going, to get ahead, and to increase his sales.  This will be his fourth loan with MFP.  He plans to continue being a reliable member of his communal bank.   In addition, the members of his communal bank are responsible and offer each other mutual support.  With the requested sum of 1000 soles (USD $400), Alberto will purchase larger quantities of merchandise to stock up his store, like rice, sugar, eggs and other items.  If his store offers a variety of products, he will have a greater number of customers, which will increase his earnings.

Michael is 38 years old and married; he has two children, who attend school. He is a farmer from Kitale town (famous land of bull fighting), in western Kenya. He has been in the farming business for nine years and solely relies on the income from this business to meet his basic needs. However, he faces the challenges of diseases and lack of enough animal feed, which affect his production. His mixed farm is known for kienyeji (exotic) eggs and chicken, vegetables and milk, which are all sold locally.\r\n\r\nMichael has made a loan request of 62,400 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo, in order to buy and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help him meet the basic needs of his family. He is optimistic that with financial help and training from Juhudi Kilimo, he will be able to overcome the challenges.

Eusebia, 63, is married to Ezequiel, 57.  She's satisfied that her four children are grown and independent.  She has a house made of adobe, which endures over time.

Like any dedicated mother, she worked with Ezequiel producing cacao and coffee, this being a big help in supporting her household for 40 years.  The plots of land where she always worked are rented to other farmers now because she's aware that the energy she always applied is no longer the same, and she has thought about changing jobs.

Among her possibilities is selling chicken dishes on the weekend.  She considers this a job that requires less effort; also, she's a friendly person who's well known in her area.

She hopes to continue generating income to pay the expenses for one of her younger children's advanced studies.  She'll request 500 soles [PEN] to buy utensils and supplies to get started in her business selling chicken dishes in her community.

Adelia continues with her same job selling various staple items in a neighborhood store she has had for a long time.  She says the previous loan went well for her.  She used it to buy construction materials to remodel, putting the finishing touches on her apartment in her in-laws' house.\r\n\r\nNow she's requesting a loan to buy groceries such as rice and noodles, and also to buy a variety of products such as candy, soda, and panettone because her sales increase in this end-of-the-year season and she generates more income.

Martha is 47 years old, a happy woman and a dreamer.  She lives in her own home together with her second husband, who makes his living in multiple areas.  He is a construction worker and a taxi driver, etc.  They are raising their three children, who are 15, 6 and 3 years old.  All three go to school.  Martha's work is preparing and selling food, like fried chicken, hamburgers, fried rice, chicken stew etc.  She runs her business in front of her house.  Each day, at dusk, she takes out her utensils, like tables, chairs, plates, spoons, etc.  She started her business because she needed a way to support her children's education and also to have a job to help with the household expenses.  Martha and her husband do the shopping together very early every morning.  Her oldest son helps her to prepare the different food.  She thinks that her business is profitable because of the good flavor of her dishes.  She has more customers every day and her earnings reach 50% of what she invests.  Prior to starting her business, Martha had financial problems because she didn't have a steady job, which is why she decided to start her own business.  In the future, she hopes to build a restaurant in her home, to make a better living.  She is requesting a loan of 1,000 mil soles (USD $400), which she will use to purchase ingredients like rice, eggs, condiments, bread, potatoes, etc. to prepare different plates of food.  Martha is very happy to have financial backing for her business.

Silas is a 47-year-old farmer from Nkubu county in Kenya where he lives with his wife. He has been practicing mixed farming for over 20 years, producing tea, peas, milk, beans and maize, which he sells at the local market in his local area.

He is requesting a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry birds. The proceeds from the products he will sell will be used to improve his poultry business and his livelihood. He aspires to buy another one-acre piece of land in the next five years.

The high cost of feed and the poor market for his products are his main challenges in farming.

Silas is happy with the way Juhudi Kilimo is processing loans.

Emardin is a very responsible, hardworking person who would like to improve her quality of life and that of her family in order to triumph in life. She is 46 years old, is widowed, and lives with her six children in the rural area of Samburu, Kinango district.

Emardin works along with her children in agriculture. They grow a variety of crops like sugarcane, bananas, and vegetables, and also keep livestock.  They also need to invest in the purchase of seeds, pesticides, and fertilizers.

She dreams of having a ready market for her produce and of improving the quality of life of her children.

The four members of the group FAÏDA are married women averaging 37 years of age and three children each. The women live in polygamous families in NOUMOUSSO, a working-class district in Kadiolo City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on their third loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. The past loans were correctly paid back.
 
MARIAM, who is sitting first from the right in the photo, sells Wax and Real 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa). She gets her supplies from Cote d'Ivoire from wholesalers and often from the big market in town on market days. She sells them retail for cash to a customer base composed of men and women at the market and at home.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 32,750 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used for repaying the loan and the interest on it, and the other part is for her savings.

The four members of the group SINDIYA are married women averaging 37 years of age and three children each. The women live in polygamous families in NOUMOUSSO, a working-class district in Kadiolo City. They are on their third loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. The past loans were correctly paid back.
 
DJENEBA, who is sitting first from the left in the photo, buys and sells condiments, as well as Wax and Real 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa) in this group of women. She intends to use her loan to purchase 5 packs of condiments. She gets her supplies from the villages neighboring Kadiolo City and from wholesalers at the big market of Sikasso City on market days. Accepting cash and credit, she sells them retail to a mixed customer base at the Kadiolo City market and at home.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 20,750 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used for repaying the loan and the interest on it, and the other part is for her savings.

Sophia is 36 years old and lives with her seven children and husband. She sells dried fish in the town market. She has had this business for many years and has a lot of sales experience. She has acquired a lot of customers because she always has what people are looking for and she offers the best quality products at low prices. \r\n\r\nSophia is a hard-working woman who strives to get ahead. She wants to succeed in the short-term, which gives her a lot of motivation and strength in her work. She is asking for a loan to buy more sacks of dried fish to sell. She is a responsible person with a spotless moral character, and she is sure that she will be able to successfully repay the loan. She hopes to provide economic security for her household.

Susan is a 48-year-old farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and their five children, two of whom are still schooling. She has been farming for the past 15 years, producing milk, beans, and maize that she sells at the local market in her area.

She is requesting a 40,000 Kenya shilling (KES) loan from Juhudi kilimo to purchase irrigation equipment that will help her water her crops and have more produce despite the bad climatic conditions. The increased income will help her improve her living standards and be able to pay for her childrens' educations.

Poor infrastructure, pests and diseases are some of her major challenges in farming.

Susan says that Juhudi kilimo has very affordable interest rates for repaying the loans.

Elgiz is 28 years old. He is a single person. Egiz lives in the Fizuli region with his family, but he was an IDP (internally displaced person) person from Fizuli city. \r\n\r\nNow he needs 1,000 AZN (Azerbaijani New Manat) to buy new wheels and other spare parts for his car. He loves his work. Elgiz has been in this taxi business for 2 years. He wants to increase his monthly income to help his family.

Nahason is aged thirty-eight and is a farmer in Nyamira county in Kenya, where he lives with his wife and four children, who are all in school. He has been in farming for the past seventeen years, producing milk and vegetables. He sells second-hand clothes as an additional source of income.

He is requesting a loan of 60,000 KES to buy a dairy cow, which will give him more milk and more income. This will enable him to uplift his livelihood and pay for his children's school fees. 

He aspires to buy two more dairy cows in the next five years.

High transport costs, pests, and diseases are his major challenges in farming.

Nahason is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for giving him the loan.

This young woman is starting a business of selling clothing (khangas). She wants to have a new start and to be more responsible, which is one of the best and biggest decisions that she has made. Her family is ready to give her support. She currently sells fried fish, a business she has run for the last three years. 

Mlongo is an active woman. She is enterprising, dedicated to her work, and a fighter with many goals that she wants to achieve. She is working hard to reach a more prosperous future and is very happy with the business. 

Mlongo anticipates a good return on this investment because she wants to take advantage of the approaching December festive season. She plans to sell door-to-door in the neighborhood. However, she does not plan to quit her fish selling business since she mostly sells during the afternoon hours. 

With the loan, Mlongo will buy bales of khangas to sell.

Valya lives in Gyumri town with her family. She is a teacher and works at local school. Her daughter, Sona, studies at the Armenian State Economic University in the faculty of Public Finance.

It is very difficult for Valya to sustain the family of five. Valya's salary allows her to cover family's basic costs, but is not enough to save for Sona's education. 

With the requested amount, Valya will pay for her daughter’s annual tuition fee and will be able to ensure a better future for her family.

This group is called Al-Khir. It consists of 6 ladies who live in Taiz, Yemen. \r\n\r\nEyman is 23 years old. She is a single woman who lives in Taiz, Yemen. She owns a house and she applied for a youth loan of 30000 YER from AMB to buy water tank for her house.

Juan is a farmer.  He is 40 years old, single and lives in Sololá. 
Juan makes his living growing potatoes, onions, carrots and green beans on a plot of land that he rents with other farmers.  It is located a few kilometers from his home.  Juan learned to farm from his father, but before growing his own crop, he worked with others.  That helped him to perfect his work and to gain more experience farming. 
Juan has now been growing his own crops for fifteen years.  He saw that he would have a getter income working on his own.  He is requesting a loan of Q 4,000.00 (USD $525) so that he can purchase potato seed and fertilizer to later plant and harvest.  This will improve his income and his family's quality of life. 
With his earnings, Juan dreams of purchasing a plot of land and expanding his plantings.  He also wants to build a better dwelling for his family.

Marciana is a mother and a grandmother; she’s a very hardworking woman.  Despite her age of 52, she is full of life and proud to see her children now productive, independent adults who are forging good futures.  She owns a house built of substantial materials that she managed to build little by little.  Up until a short time ago, she worked in agriculture and animal husbandry but then looked for a business alternative like the sale of fish and vegetables at wholesale.  She’s been doing this for a year and she’s met new customers who are now her friends.  She heads out by herself with help from transportation providers who cover her routes taking her products preferably on the weekend.

She likes her activity very much because she must rise at dawn often and cover several points in her location contacting many people who value her work very much and establish good friendships with her; it must be clear, however, that she ends her day exhausted after returning home where she stores her goods.

At the exact first year anniversary of her business, she plans to buy merchandise to supply more annexes and needs more capital to do so since one of her goals it to reach all the points in her location.  This will be her first MFP loan and she feels very happy with the opportunity being provided and is committed make her payments responsibly.  She hopes to retain the harmony and motivation she found since first becoming part of her communal bank; she considers it to be a great team.  She will use the 1,000 new soles to add to her capital earmarked to buy merchandise consisting of frozen fish and basic staple vegetables that are in high demand by her retailer customers.

Ahmad is a 24-year-old, Lebanese man. He got engaged few years ago, waiting the perfect time to get married and have his own family. Meanwhile, he’s living with his parents and four siblings. His father is their main income provider. Ahmad is really ambitious, he seeks to grow very fast in his domain and better support his family. He opened his own pharmacy in 2009 and has his own, loyal customers. \r\n\r\nToday, he needs to borrow a youth loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase the required quantity of medicines and renovate his pharmacy as well. He notes that this will allow him to respond to his clients rapidly. He plans to enlarge his pharmacy and open other braches, in the near future.

Tamara is a 35-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and four children. Two of her children are still attending school. In 2009, in order to supplement the family’s income, she decided to start her own home business. She’s a bread baker. She prepares bread and delivers it to her neighbors in town and the surrounding areas. Her husband, who works on his own, represents the main income source of the family. \r\n\r\nToday, she is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase ingredients for the bread and better improve her business. She states that the loan will certainly help her increase her business productivity by a large percentage, which will earn her higher profits. In the future, she plans to diversify her products and, therefore, attract additional clients.

Hussein is a 59-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and two children who are attending school. He has been working for a local company since 2008. He is the only source of income for his family. His wife is taking care of the house and the children as well. But Hussein’s income is not covering all their needs, especially his children’s educational fees. This is the reason he’s requesting a loan from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l. In this way, he will be able to pay his children's school fees. His only goal is to insure a good education for his children until graduation and avoid facing financial problems for the family. One of his greatest dreams is to see his children achieve good positions.

George is 34 years old and a farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya where he lives with his child who is in school. He has been in farming for over 10 years producing tea and milk, which he sells to the people in his local area.

He is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase materials to construct a greenhouse, which will help him get more produce and hence more income to boost his livelihood and pay for his child's education.

Unpredictable weather conditions and lack of a readily available market are his major challenges in farming.

George is grateful for the sincerity of Juhudi Kilimo's staff.

Mbeyu is 53 years old and very much wants to get ahead and improve her life. She lives with her family in her house, the same place where she has her business. She has a shop selling essentials like bread, drinks, frozen and canned products, dairy products, sweets, and more.\r\n\r\nUntil her sales have become stable, which she wants to considerably improve, Mbeyu is asking for a loan from Yehu, with which she can have the necessary money to be able to buy bigger quantities of foodstuffs, detergents, basic grains, paraffin, and other instant products.  This will benefit her shop by making it stronger so that people prefer her shop and it is the first choice for buying what they need for their home.

Norah is a fifty-year-old farmer in Nyamira county in Kenya where she lives with her husband and two children who are both in school. She has been in farming for the past twenty years producing tea, milk, coffee and bananas which she sells at the local market in her area. She also runs a butchery as an additional source of income.

She is requesting for 50,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. She will earn extra money from selling the the milk and this will help her to improve her living standards and to be able to pay for her children's school fees. Norah aspires to expand her tea plantation to two acres of land.

Poor markets and irregular weather patterns are her major challenges in farming.

Norah is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for giving her the loan.

Patience learned how to sew at a young age and has dedicated most of her life to this activity. This has enabled her to acquire a great deal of experience, which has resulted in a reputation for offering products that are of the highest quality and above all, unequaled services. With a sewing workshop at the town center, Patience is able to generate income, contribute financially to her household, and provide her family with a better quality of life. She does repairs and sewing of new clothing at the same time.\r\n\r\nShe received a few orders some time ago, but has not been able to fulfill them due to a lack of capital to buy the materials that she needs. For this reason, she seeks to overcome this difficulty by requesting a loan in order to buy raw materials and sewing supplies that will allow her to complete her customers’ orders. Patience dreams of continuing to develop her business and gradually improving her business revenues. This will enable her to improve the facilities in her home and to have a better quality of life.

Zulfiya is a very successful woman in her village. She is respected and known as a fair and purposeful woman. She is 41 years old. She is divorced and is raising three children. In her personal life she is not lucky, as her husband left her with three children, and does not even provide them with the necessary resources for living. It is difficult for Zulfiya to provide for the children. However her parents help her, even if she does not want help. 

In order to improve their living conditions, Zulfiya decided to set up her own business for the good of the family. With this aim she attended the course "Bring It On", organized by the Association of Business Women and she received a certificate. Now she may organize her business and become successful in this area. 

Zulfiya would like to set up a business of growing agricultural crops, as she has experience in this type of business. From the income received she plans to provide her children with a good education and proper food. She requests a loan in the amount of 1,500 somoni for the purchase of mineral fertilizers and seeds, in order to set up the new business. She awaits your kindness.

Surayyo is a resident of the Gissar region. She is 36 years old and married. She has two children. Surayyo works from home, sewing national dresses. She is a seamstress. She has been working with this type of activity for 7 years. \r\n\r\nSurayyo takes a loan to repair the house and to purchase a new sewing machine, in order to provide quality services.

Difficult living conditions force a person to focus all their efforts and make use of all existing resources. Mahfurat is one of these individuals who try to improve living conditions and boost the economic condition of the family. She is a widow and is raising a child. When her husband died, she was left with no food and she had to cope with the costs herself. 

Mahfurat decided to set up her own business for the good of the family. With this aim she attended the course "Bring It On", organized by the Association of Business Women, and she received a certificate. Currently she can set up her own business and become successful in this area. She would like to set up a business of buying and selling food products. From the income received, she plans to improve her living conditions. 

Mahfurat requests a loan in the amount of 2,000 somoni for the purchase of products, in order to set up the new business. She awaits your kindness.

Lyudmila lives in Gyumri town with her husband and 3 children. She works at local school as a teacher and her husband Artur is a taxi driver. Lyudmila’s elder daughter studies at Armenian-Russian Slavonic University in the department of Finance and Credit. \r\nTogether with her husband, Lyudmila works hard to sustain her family’s living. Unfortunately this family’s current income doesn’t allow them to pay for their daughter’s tuition. So Lyudmila has applied for this loan of 230,000 AMD, to pay for her daughter’s tuition fee for the first semester.

Umasi is grateful for the support she got from the previous loan. She says that her business is doing well and that she can now count on good results from her previous investments. She has been able to improve her standard of living. Umasi wants to make some improvements to her house, which is why she is asking for a loan to buy iron sheets for roofing. She will also buy assorted nails, timbers, etc. She thanks Kiva lenders and Yehu for entrusting her with loans.

Josephine, 39, is a farmer in Nyamira County in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and seven children. Only three are still in school. She has been in farming for the past eight years, producing tea, sorghum, maize, wheat and milk, which she sells at the local market. She operates a wholesale cereals shop as an additional source of income.

She is requesting a 60,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow that will help her increase her milk production and thus bring in more income to help her improve her living standards and pay for her children's education. She aspires to be the leading supplier of milk in her area in the next five years.

Unpredictable weather conditions are her major challenge in farming.

Josephine is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for its support to clients.

Rodah is from the town of Samburu. She is married and has five grown children. She is the proprietor of a mini-store, where she sells drinks, flour, basic grains, and other household items. She began with a small business and later, little by little, grew to where she is today, thanks to her self-sacrifice.

Rodah comments that, thanks to this work, she can keep up her home and cover the expenses that arise in her home on a daily basis. She says that she would like to be able to continue with this business, as she has good sales, and the business generates a good income for her.

Rodah is requesting a loan for the purchase of drinks, flour, sugar, rice, and other things, with which she will be able to stock up her business. In this way, she will have everything in her store for any customer, whatever they need.

Rabih is a 31-year-old Lebanese man. He’s married to Najla, a beautiful young woman. They have only two children, who are still studying. Rabih is a great man who loves his family and really cares to offer them a respectable life. He works non-stop, on his own, to be able to cover their expenses. He has been working as a plumber since 2000. He is also specialized in installing solar systems. He’s an honest man and above all punctual, which makes his customers loyal to him. Today, he’s asking for a loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l to renew his plumbing tools. This Kiva loan will facilitate his business operations and allow him start his new project properly. This is how Rabih works to collect higher revenues and help his family live a very comfortable life away from struggle.

Sona is 26-year-old proactive student. She lives in Baghramyan village in the Ararat region with her family. Sona studies at the Armenian State University, in the faculty of Philosophy and Psychology. She is in her fourth course. \r\nSona’s parents are involved in agriculture, which is the main source of income for her family. It is very difficult for the family to cover their daily costs and save money for Sona’s education. This is why Sona has applied for this loan to pay for tuition fees for the first semester.

This group is called Aziah, and it consists of seven ladies who live in Taiz, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 210000 YER from AMB.\r\nAziah raises sheep. She has been in this line of work for many years. She is 23 years old and single and lives in Taiz, Yemen. She is asking for a youth loan of 30000 YER from AMB to buy sheep for resale. This loan enables her to sell the sheep as well to generate even more income. She hopes to provide a better life to her family. She promises to pay on time and is very grateful to all Kiva lenders.

Adrian is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in silver and gemstone jewelry.  He would like to invest in the purchase of gemstones and raw silver to continue production.  Adrian has been selling through NOVICA since 2010.  This is his story:

"In jewelry, I've found a medium of bodily expression.  In the School of Fine Arts, I learned to express my ideas with a brush and oils.  I can also do so through silver, gold and precious stones.  I live in Peru doing what I love most, and I am passionate about jewelry.  For me, each piece of jewelry is a work of art, and I'm a perfectionist as I create them.  I hope you enjoy the quality and design of my art."

"I wish to thank everyone involved in this microcredit, because with it I'll be able to increase my production.  I will also be able to work on new designs for all the wonderful women that enjoy wearing my jewelry."

Use the link below to view Adrian's silver and gemstone jewelry on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/7520

Mrs. Aldarmaa is a 35-year-old woman who lives with her husband and two children in Ger in the Govi-Altai province of Mongolia. Her husband Davaatseren has been working as an assistant worker in a wooden furniture manufacturing company for years. Her daughter Angarmaa, who is 14, and her son Purev-Ochir, who is 11, are secondary school students. She has been running a butcher shop since 2003 in a rental counter of a local market. She and her husband are planning to start a new business of furniture manufacturing in their area. She has already built a strong relationship with local suppliers and customers and it will be easier for them to start their new wooden furniture manufacturing business. She is now requesting 3,800,000 MNT to purchase starting inventory for starting their wooden furniture manufacturing business. She and her husband are honest, responsible and hardworking people.

Mrs. Amarjargal is 37 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in the Sukhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband, Soronzonbold, is 35 years old and is an interior designer who works in a private construction company. Her daughter, Dolgoonmorongua, goes to kindergarten. She has been working as an assistant worker at a local market for years, and she also works part-time at the construction company her husband works at. She and her husband are planning on starting their own interior design business for local customers. She is asking for a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase starting inventory for her new interior design business. She and her husband are hardworking, honest, and responsible people.

Abel is a Peruvian artisan that specializes in tooled leather furniture and decor accents.  He would like to invest in the purchase of fine leather, wood and various fixtures to continue production.  Abel has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story:

"I have been crafting leather items since I was 16.  My older brother, Hector, taught me.  When I was 23, I opened my own workshop in my house.  I cut and tool fine leather with a distinct style and skill that you won't find in many workshops.  I design many beautiful Inca and colonial motifs, and emboss those upon the leather.  I am especially happy and proud that my products are being sold all over the world through the Internet."

"I would like to thank you for offering me your support through this microcredit.  It will allow me and my team to continue crafting items.  This is a traditional art form that has allowed us to provide our children with an education, and pass down a beautiful art."

Use the link below to view Abel's tooled leather furniture and decor accents on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/951

Diego is an artisan in Guatemala who specializes in hand-carved wood art.  He would like to invest in the purchase of cedar, mahogany and granadillo woods, as well as in replacing some tools in his workshop.  Diego has been selling through NOVICA since 2011.  This is his story:

"What I enjoy the most about my work is also my biggest challenge, creating new designs.  Wood is a noble element, totally transformable, that gives you a lot if you know how to work it, treat it and take care of it.  I remember with much gratefulness a companion in the first workshop where I worked.  He took a lot of time to teach me things I never imagined possible to do with my hands.  Now I spend some of my time teaching the young people who work with me."

"I thank you for supporting our type of work and our art; without it, we wouldn’t be able to promote our work and provide properly for our families.  I appreciate your support by way of this microcredit so that we may get ahead in our work.  Being able to purchase the materials and tools we need means the artisans at the workshop can continue their work and we can develop our creativity.  May God bless you all!"

Use the link below to view Diego's hand-carved wood art on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/8047

Julie, 47, is a widow and a mother of six children. Her children are all grown up and independent, and they are between the ages of 19 and 26. Julie lives in the Paynesville South community, called Kpelle town. For the past ten years, she has been selling pepper, vita, salt, onions, and rice at the community market. She loves to do this business because she feels self-reliant.  She received help from her sister to start in this  business. She will use the loan given to her to purchase more vita, salt, onions, and palm oil to increase her sales. Her plan for the future is to become a big business woman.

Suwitra, from Bali, specializes in traditional batik and hand-painted apparel. He would like to invest in the purchase of larger amounts of fabric to expand production.

Suwitra has been selling through NOVICA since 2007. This is his story:

Suwitra designs and creates elegant wearable art through his unique ability to capture nature's beauty in clothing apparel. He masters batik and silk screening techniques as well as hand-painted motifs, which he transforms into colorful sarongs, scarves and stylish clothing.

"I am glad to have the possibility to receive this microcredit. I'll be able to buy the materials I need to build up my stock. Thanks to your support, I have an opportunity to develop my business. I hope this will also lead to more people that will really like my designs. Thank you so very much."

Use the link below to view Suwitra's batik and hand-painted apparel on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/6227

Jameo is a 40-year-old married woman who has been excited ever since she got to know about the UGAFODE micro-mortgage loan program. It is cost effective and affordable especially to the low income earners. She is convinced that with this program her dream of a decent house is going to be a reality and she and her children and grandchildren will be well accommodated, unlike in her current structure. She is dedicated to paying her loan installments on time and to building a good relationship with the institution.

Jarwolay is 35 years old.  She is married and the mother of three children between the ages of three and 21 years.  She lives in a community called Peace Island in Jacob Town and all three of her children attend school.

She works very hard in her cook shop, or restaurant, where she sells food.  She works five days a week from 7 AM to 6 PM each day.  Jarwolay prepares cassava, potatoes, grains and palava sauce (a type of stew) to meet customer demand.  Because of the good service she provides to her customers, she makes a profit everyday.  With the profit, she buys more goods and attends to the needs of her children.  

She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more ingredients for her business.  Her plan for the future is to give her children a better education.

Emmanuel is an artisan who specializes in African masks and sculptures. He would like to invest in the purchase of raw materials such as wood, aluminum plates and paints.

Emmanuel has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story:

"After completing a course in auto mechanics, getting a job was difficult and neither my parents nor I could afford the high cost of the machinery I would need to set up on my own. I struggled while doing odd jobs, but I managed to save what I could until I had enough money to buy a small piece of land and put up a wooden store, but I didn't know what to sell.
