I started buying finished carvings, and in the evenings I learned to carve these beautiful items. My background in auto mechanics became very useful at this point because of my knowledge in cutting and designing of metals, as well as the skill I learned from my father who was a blacksmith. With constant practice, I entered the world of art. My inspiration comes through dreams, so when I wake up I immediately put the design on paper in order not to lose the idea."

"This new microcredit will go a long way to help build up my stock and grow my business. Thank you so much for your help."

Use the link below to view Emmanuel's African masks and carvings on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/1536

Evelyn is an artisan who specializes in traditional West African masks. She would like to invest in a bulk purchase of raw materials such as wood, metal plates and paints.

Evelyn has been selling through NOVICA since 2008. This is her story:

"My greatest inspiration is to preserve our rich cultural heritage. Initially, I wasn't using a lot of different materials, but now I use recycled glass and glass beads, aluminum, brass and more. I sit and draw a mask creatively, and come up with the colors that will make it stand out."

"I believe that this microcredit will help me create a bigger stock of products and increase sales. My sincere gratitude to all of you for participating in the funding of this microcredit."

Use the link below to view Evelyn's African masks on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/6750

Noé and his family's primary source of income is their dairy farm. Constantly looking to reduce his costs while hedging himself against an unpredictable market, he is investing in a 40 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester to reduce his natural gas and agrochemical fertilizer expenses. Using the processed waste from his dairy cows, Noé will fertilize the alfalfa and maize used in their feed. Additionally, his family will benefit from the biogas generated in the kitchen and in the bathroom, reducing their dependence on fossil fuels and their associated costs. This loan represents 43% of the total cost of Noé's Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

At 47-years-old, Maria is a native of Santa Rosa. She decided to lead an independent life with only her four children by her side, two of whom are young and still require her support and attention. She is the owner of a wooden house where she performs her duties as a mother. 

Maria produces agricultural products, among which is her preferred product, organic cacao, because it is a fruit in high demand in her region and it is easily grown in the area considering everything required. She carries out her agricultural activities on parcels of land she acquired with the help of her ex-partner 20 years ago. In order to obtain the quality of fruits that she wants, she must rely on additional help from laborers on site to carry out distinct complicated tasks. 

She likes to work in the fields because it reminds her of times when she was a child together with her parents doing the same activities. However, by the time the cacao is ready there is a certain decrease in the final price offered by stockpilers. She is hoping to improve the situation for the next season.

Finding herself at the start of the season whose harvest is projected for next year, she needs to have capital in order to continue to expand her plantations and to replace old cacao trees respectively. For this reason she needs seedlings, and manure compost from Guano Island. It is also necessary to add the cost of manual labor, whose payment is made in advance. 

Now she is asking for 1000 soles to buy seedlings and bags of compost. The remaining money will be used to supplement the capital to pay the laborers to develop scheduled tasks.

María del Carmen is a dairy farmer, following the family tradition. Focused on reducing costs while improving her dairy production, she will save money and help the environment with her 20 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester. Using the waste from her dairy cows, the biodigester will produce biogas to heat the water used to clean her milking parlor. This will reduce disease in her cows, improve milk quality and save her money. She will also fertilize her cow feed using the potent organic fertilizer produced by the system. Her loan represents 44% of the total cost of her system.

Ignacio (pictured with his mother and wife), a dairy farmer, will use his 10 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester to reduce costs and improve yields on his farm. He will process his cow waste to produce fuel for cooking and heating bathwater and for use as fertilizer for the cow feed: alfalfa and maize. This loan represents 43% of the total cost of his Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

Benjamín represents the future of farming in Mexico.  He is continuing the family tradition but wants to do so while reducing costs and decreasing the environmental impact caused by his animal waste.  Currently, the waste from his six cows is seen as just that - waste.  However, with his eight cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester, this waste will generate fuel and fertilizer, allowing him to lower costs, maintain or improve yields, and reduce the odors and flies associated with manure piles. This loan represents 43% of the cost of his Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

María Teresa's entire village smells like cow manure.  As a hub of dairy production in the region, the large quantities of cow waste cause multiple problems: odor, flies and water contamination. 

María Teresa is doing her part to combat these problems by acquiring a 25 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.  The purchase is not entirely altruistic as, by using the system, she will use the manure produced on her farm to generate high quality fertilizer and biogas, reducing both her fuel and fertilizer costs.  

This loan represents 44% of the total cost of her Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

Marie is a single woman who lives in a neighborhood in the capital. She has been running a restaurant for two years, where she serves diverse dishes. Due to her high energy, she has built a clientele she’d like to continue to satisfy. In order to do this, she is seeking a loan to increase her stock of food and beverages. The profits from this loan will allow her to ensure the longevity of her business while meeting the needs of her brothers.

Edma is the coordinator of her group, Lamentation de Geremy. She lives in the Trou-du-Nord region in Haiti, where electricity is rare and water is very limited. She has been running her charcoal-selling business for the last four years.\r\n\r\nShe would like to use this loan to invest in charcoal; she has bought wood for the charcoal. Some other members of the group need a loan for businesses such as selling food products, cosmetics, clothing, shoes, and charcoal. Edma says that her main challenge is to be able to sell more during the economic crisis in Haiti, where there isn’t a lot of money.

Flor, 18, shares her married life with Renán, also 18.  They decided to start together from a young age, driven by love and the special trust between them.  As a fruit of their relationship they have a precious little girl named Asulda, age 1, to whom they direct their future goals.  They live temporarily in an adobe house, which they rent.

For two years she has made a living with Renán in agricultural work on some plots of land her parents gave her because they're a young couple with a great desire to improve themselves.  Their main crop is organic cacao because it's very stable in the area.  As in any beginning they had certain problems trying to achieve financial stability for the future family.

What's encouraging is that, in spite of starting out with little capital, they've managed to cover all the basic family expenses, considering that they already have the responsibility of their little girl.  Nevertheless, working together has been a great tool for unity because understanding and family harmony prevail in their family environment.

A little while ago she received a proposal from a merchant in the area who offered to rent her his store for a long time because he plans to take a trip for a variety of reasons.  She considers it a good opportunity and plans to take it.  So she hopes to contribute to the family finances along with the field work with her husband in charge.

She has many desires for the future, including studying pharmacy at the advanced level because she feels she's capable of doing that in the near future.

This is her first loan with MFP.  She's very grateful for this opportunity, which she considers the motivation she needs right now to realize her commercial objectives more fluidly.  She's grateful to her colleagues in her communal bank for the great opportunity they're giving her and for their welcome, and she's committing herself to complying with all the stipulated agreements.

With the 500 nuevos soles [PEN] she'll supplement the capital she has dedicated to paying the first month's rent on a small grocery store that she'll manage from now on.

Victoria is 56 years old and lives in the Philippines.  She is married and has four children. 

Victoria has a sari-sari or general store that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, household products and beverages.  She has had this business for seven years.  She has requested a loan of 11,000 PHP in order to buy and stock canned goods, snacks and beverages. 

Victoria has been a member of HSPFI since 2009.  In the future, Victoria hopes to improve her business in order to be able to educate her grandchildren.

Born around 1975 in Sikasso, Ms. Mariam is a widow and the mother of three children. She resides in her deceased husband's home with her children in a nuclear family located in Wayerma, in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After several unsuccessful businesses, Ms. Mariam was introduced to small-scale commerce over ten years ago and particularly in the buying and selling of clothing, handbags, embroidered cloth, 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa), etc.  She purchases her merchandise in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) and then resells it from her spot at the big market of Sikasso where her merchandise is much in demand by her customers (composed essentially of housekeepers retailers at the market) for its quality. 

Concerned about further satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her first loan. Thus, she is requesting this loan to increase her business capital for buying: 30 lengths of Wax 'pagne' cloth, 20 sets of embroidered fabrics, and 20 handbags. 

She envisions making a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and pay the loan interest. And the rest will be invested in her business.

Ms. Assata was born around 1977 in Sikasso. She is married and the mother of five children. She lives with her husband in a large traditional extended family in Sanoubougou II, the downtown of Sikasso City. Ms. Assata is a teacher by training. Instead of practicing this profession, she became familiar with the buying and selling of fresh milk, curdled milk, and yoghurt ten years ago. She operates in a kiosk located in her district in Sikasso and by going door to door. 

Concerned about further satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso about a year ago. She in on her first loan. She is requesting this individual loan with the goal of increasing her business capital, so as to purchase 100 liters of fresh milk for processing into curds and yoghurt. This is to do better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base.

With this loan, she envisions making a monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and pay the loan interest. And the rest will invested in her business.

Born around 1969 in Sikasso, Ms. Maminata is marred and the mother of four children. She lives at her husband's place with her children in a nuclear family located in Wayerma, in Sikasso City. After several unsuccessful businesses, Ms. Maminata was introduced to this revenue-generating business over five years ago. She enjoys a great reputation locally buying and selling condiments at the house and at the Lafiabougou market, where she has a spot. 

Concerned about further satisfying her ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her first individual loan. This loan will be used to purchase: 5 pails of peanut butter, 3 boxes of Magie [bouillon cubes], 2 boxes of tomato paste, 2 sacks of onions, and 5 boxes of mustard, in Sikasso. 

Accepting cash or credit, Ms. Maminata makes her sales to customers from all walks of life. With this loan, she envisions making a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and pay the loan interest. And the rest will be invested in her business.

Born around 1963 in the N’Kourala prefecture of Sikasso, Mrs. Mariam is a widowed mother of four children who lives in Médine-Sikasso. After having lost her husband, Mrs. Mariam started selling food condiments. She sells at the Médine market, where she has a store, and where she is heavily sought after by her clientele for the quality of her products. In order to satisfy her growing clientele, she decided to join microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. She has already benefited from three loans, which have all been successfully repaid. In the goal of continuing to improve her business, she is seeking a fourth loan, which will allow her to increase her business funds to be able to buy 15 sacks of fresh tomatoes, 15 sacks of onions, different grains, and a stock of condiments. Her products are bought on the spot by farmers coming from neighboring villages and brought back to sell in the weekly markets in Yorosso and Kouri near the Mali-Burkina Faso border, for retail and wholesale for credit on fair days to a clientele composed essentially of fairground people. She envisions earning with this loan a monthly profit of 110,000 FCFA, which will be used to contribute to family expenses, pay interest on her loan, and reinvest in her business.

Ritaflor is 27 years old.  She is single and lives in the Philippines.  

Ritaflor has a sari-sari, or general, store that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, household products and beverages.  She has had this business for six years.  She has requested a loan of 11,000 PHP in order to buy and stock canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Ritaflor has been a member of HSPFI since 2011.  In the future, Ritaflor hopes to improve her business.

Elsa is 41 years old.  She is single and lives in the Philippines.

Elsa is making and selling snacks like biko (a type of rice cake) and juices.  She has had this business for nine years.  She has requested a loan of 8,000 PHP in order to buy raw ingredients like sticky rice, cheese, flour and sugar, which she uses to make snacks.

Elsa is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Elsa hopes to improve her business.

Eduard is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines.  He is married and has two children. 

Eduard provides motorela, or motorcycle, transportation services.  He has had this business for six years.  He has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP in order to pay for maintenance.

Eduard has been a member of HSPFI since 2012.  In the future, Eduard hopes to improve his services.

Melanie is 25 years old, single and lives in the Philippines.

Melanie has a store that sells snacks like banana-que. She has had this business for six years. She requested a loan for 7,000 Philippines pesos to buy raw ingredients used in making banana-que, like yellow bananas, cooking oil, sugar and margarine.

Melanie is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Melanie hopes to improve her business.

Rigo is 37 years old, single and lives in the Philippines.

Rigo has a shop that sells different kinds of beverages, like soft drinks and wines. He has had this business for nine years. He requested a loan for 8,000 Philippines pesos to buy stock of beverages to resell.

Rigo is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Rigo hopes to improve his business.

Camalia is 28 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Camalia has a food/retail shop (or sari-sari store) that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. \r\n\r\nShe has had this business for seven years. She requested a loan for 8,000 Philippines pesos to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages. Camalia has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Camalia hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

Marilou is 47 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children.

Marilou has a pump boat to use for fishing. She has had this business for 23 years. She requested a loan of 8,000 Philippines pesos to pay for the maintenance of the pump boat.

Marilou has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Marilou hopes to improve her business.

Melecia is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Melecia has a food/retail shop (or sari-sari store) that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She had this business for 16 years. 

She requested a loan for 30,000 Philippines pesos to buy stock of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Melecia has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, Melecia hopes to improve her business for the education of her grandchildren.

Roselyn is 33 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has five children. Roselyn has a sari-sari (conveninece) store, where she sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She has had this business for six years. \r\n\r\nRoselyn requested a loan of PHP 11,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.  She has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. Roselyn hopes to improve her business in the future, for the education of her children.

Gemma is 24 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has one child. Gemma has a sari-sari (convenience) store, where she sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She has had this business for four years. \r\n\r\nGemma requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages. She joined HSPFI in 2012. Gemma hopes to improve her business in the future, for the education of her child.

Genevieve is from Campo 1, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She's married and has two children. To earn a living, she raises pigs for sale. Every month, she earns about PHP 19,974. \r\n\r\nIn 2011, she joined GDMPC. She has applied for a loan of PHP 40,000 from the cooperative. She will use the loan to purchase livestock feed and other supplies for raising pigs. She plans to buy more piglets to raise and eventually sell, to make good cash income.

I Dream of Johnny was established in June of 2000 by owner JCM. The business manufactures and distributes customized and personalized apparel and accessories for babies. The company exhibits its products in showrooms in Los Angeles, New York, Chicago and Texas. Clients range from wholesalers to retail stores across the USA, with 20% of annual sales coming from exports to Canada. There is growing demand for I Dream of Johnny products due to quick order turnaround time.\r\n\r\nI Dream of Johnny was recently approved to manufacture apparel using licensed logos from various universities. I Dream of Johnny has received orders from Barnes and Noble bookstores at Boston University and from the Harvard University Trademark Program for these licensed logo products. This microloan will be used to fill these two large orders helping I Dream of Johnny maintain its quick order turnaround time and preserve its competitive advantage in a highly competitive retail market.

Erdenekhuyag is 38 years old and lives with his family in their wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital. His house is located in the boundary area of the city with no water, minimal roads and spotty electricity. Erdenekhuyag‘s family consists of four people: himself, his wife and two children who are students. In 2008 they bought the land and built a 60-square-meter wooden house. \r\nSince 2003, Erdenekhuyag has had a micro bus with 14 seats and with his wife runs a transportation business between Ulaanbaatar and a province 800 km away. He runs three times minimum in a month to Zavkhan province. \r\nAs his children grow the house is feeling smaller. Therefore Erdenekhuyag is planning to expand his house by building a new floor with wood and laying bricks on the outer side of the walls in order to stop the heat loss through the walls. By doing this Erdenekhuyag’s family can improve their living condition and will have a spacious house that will serve them the rest of their life.

Melvin is married with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Melvin is 41 years old and all of her children are in school.

She has a business selling native bags in the Philippines. Melvin requested a 11,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase more native bags to sell to customers.

She has been in this business for six years. In the future, Melvin would like to save enough money so she continue to send her children to college.

This time, for her eighth cycle loan, Carolina is applying for a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy fruits, vegetables and charcoals to sell at her stall.  \r\nThe charcoal retail business that she previously funded through Kiva partners and NWTF continues and provides for Carolina and her family with income that is improving their standard of living.

As the married mother of four children, Juliet works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from fattening pigs. Juliet is borrowing 20,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy fishing net and other equipment for her fishing business.\r\n\r\nJuliet has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business and continuing to send her children to school.

This is Leonora, 52, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband,manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leonora operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Leonora hopes to expand her business and dreams to give her children a good and quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

Jeshty is a 32 year old married woman and a mother of two young children ages eight and four. She earns a living through her store. She sells various goods and commodities like pants, shirts, belts, shoes and other fashion accessories. This is the source of her income. \r\nJeshty works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family especially for the schooling of her children. As of now, Jeshty is in need of additional capital for the expansion of her business. She is asking for a loan to buy more products to sell such as pants, shirts, shoes and other fashion accessories. With this, she will be able to increase her stocks and attract more customers and buyers into her store, thus augmenting her sales and income.

Henrylin is 35 years old and married with four children. Three of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Henrylin has a fishing business in the Philippines. She requested a 12,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy fishing net, bamboo, binder and other fishing equipment.\r\n\r\nHenrylin has been in this business for seven years. In the future, Henrylin would like to build and expand her business.

Luisita is a 57-year-old married woman and a mother of four grown up children from Ubay, Bohol. Her husband is a habal-habal, or motorcycle transport, driver. Luisita has been engaged in a hog-raising business for several years now. 

Luisita is asking for a loan to buy a new tire for the motorcycle and feed for her pigs.

In the future, Luisita dreams of making her business a success.

Issifou was born around 1969 in Gningoni.  He is the father of five children and he lives in a nuclear family in Kadiolo (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

He has been selling grains for the past four years.  Thanks to his experience in this field, he enjoys a good reputation as a seller and he receives orders for grains, particularly maize.  In order to have the necessary resources to satisfy his customers' needs, Issifou decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  This is his fifth loan, and all previous loans have been duly repaid.

This loan will help him to buy two tonnes of maize and one tonne of millet.  He buys grains from villages around Kadiolo and stores his merchandise before reselling it for cash.  His customer base consists of men and women who come from major cities such as Sikasso, Bamako and Koutiala.

Thanks to this loan, Issifou is expecting average monthly profits to reach 90,000 CFA francs.  He will use these profits to pay his loan's interest, and will invest the rest of the money in his business.

As a married mother of six children, Lourdes works hard to support her family.

She has a selling firewood business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from farming vegetables. Lourdes is borrowing PHP 13000 through NWTF to purchase more firewood to sell.

Lourdes has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

Judith is 34 years old, married and has three children who all attend school. She is a small-scale farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where she has been farming for 10 years now. Her mixed farm produces maize, milk, vegetables and beans which are all sold locally. She is also a teacher at a local school in the same town. Judith, pictured at her sukuma wiki (vegetable) farm, has always been passionate about farming and has no regrets at all in investing in this type of business.\r\n\r\nShe has made her first loan request of 41,600 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help improve the livelihood of her family. She is planning to expand her dairy farm by acquiring at least six quality dairy cows able to produce at least 20 litres of milk daily. Her primary challenge has been poor market prices for her farm produce.

Caren is a small-scale farmer from Mabonde location, Kitale town in western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last three years and has solely relied on the income from her farm to cater to the needs of her family. Her mixed farm produces maize and milk which are all sold to the local market. 

Caren is 27 years old and married with one child, 3 years old.

She has requested a loan of 41,600 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help her expand her business and secure a great future for her child. Her biggest challenge has been competition and poor market prices for her farm produce.

She is grateful for the financial support and appreciates Juhudi for its efficiency in providing financial services.

Cleophas is 24 years old and married. He is a small-scale farmer from Kitale county in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for five years now and has one employee. He sells his farm produce, which includes milk and eggs, to the local market. He solely depends on the income from his farm to meet his basic needs. He faces the challenge of diseases which affects his poultry farm and lowers his egg production.\r\n\r\nCleophas has made a loan request of 31,200 KES ( Kenyan shillings) to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help him improve the livelihood of his young family. He hopes to expand his dairy farm by acquiring additional dairy cows in the near future.

John is 30 years old and married with two children. He is a horticultural farmer and has been in this business for the last three years, earning a monthly income of KES 30,000. 

He is servicing his first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET LTD and this will help him purchase farming inputs, such as fertilizer and pesticides.
He hopes to use anticipated profits to expand his farm and reinvest. 

His dream is to improve his family's living standards and to educate his children

Lourgen is 47 years old. She is married with three dependents. They live in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Lourgen cultivates bananas to sell. She has been in this work for 15 years. She gets a monthly income of 5,000 PHP. In 2011, she became a member of GDMPC. She has applied for a loan of 10,500 PHP from the cooperative to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Lourgen is planning to set aside a portion of the income generated from this loan to buy a new freezer for the store.

Dinah, age 52 and single, is from Sinusa, Ozamis City. Dinah has been in the gardening business for 10 years, and she earns 5,000 PHP a month. Dinah joined GDMPC in 2011. Dinah is requesting a loan of 7,500 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

This is Marissa, 41, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Urbano, a company driver, and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
Marissa has a dishwashing liquid business. She buys the ingredients and mixes them to make a dishwashing liquid. She then puts it into bottles, retails it and distributes the product to some variety stores. She also sells them to her neighbors and in the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 6,000 in weekly sales.
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy bottles and ingredients to make her dishwashing liquid. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
Marissa hopes to give her children a good quality education and dreams to expand her business through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

Galina lives in the Novaya Kahovka. She is in the business of selling underwear, socks, stockings and other small items on one of the town markets. Galina's merchandise is popular and she has a group of regular customers.\r\n\r\nGalina hopes to use the loan in the amount of 15,000 hryvnia to stock up on the assortment of underwear, socks and stockings for which there's additional demand.

Olga has used Kiva's loan services several times. Thanks to the previous loan Olga was able to buy used arches for the greenhouse and complete the building of two large greenhouses as well as significantly increase revenue from the garden and buy a tractor for cultivation of land. Moreover the family could afford to buy an inexpensive vehicle of local make.\r\n\r\nThis time Olga needs a loan in the amount of 20,000 hryvnia to install heating in the greenhouse: to buy a boiler for 10,000 hryvnia and hoses for installation costing 10,000 hryvnia. This will give her the opportunity to sell early vegetables at a higher price. At this time one of the major current issues for Olga is the long distance from the road and the market which makes it difficult to export products. Sometimes she has to ask some of the neighbors to transport the produce. Over time Olga hopes to purchase a vehicle for business to solve this urgent problem.

Nikolai lives in Kamenka. He is a greenhouse farmer and uses his own plot of land to cultivate early vegetables and flowers for sale. Nikolai and his wife have been engaged in this business for the past 30 years.

Using the additional funds of 24,000 hryvnia, Nikolai would like to build a new greenhouse. The most expensive part of the project will be the greenhouse framework, which will cost roughly the entire amount of this loan.

Nikolai is planning to continue developing his business and, in time, build additional greenhouses. He also plans to open a small flower shop at the bus station, thereby replacing the stall he currently operates there.

Galina is a farmer and cultivates early vegetables for sale. Together with her husband, she has been in this business for over 20 years. The business brings them additional income and is gradually expanding.\r\n\r\nGalina plans to invest the 10,000 hryvnia from Kiva into repairs of a greenhouse in advance of the new season. She also hopes to purchase a gas boiler to finalize the construction of the greenhouse heating system, and to buy manure for use as fertilizer. Galina and her husband dream that in time they will be able to carry out repairs in their home and buy an air conditioner for their family.

Stella, a 32-year-old married woman, has 5 children and operates a small retail shop in one of the busy trading centers on the outskirts of Lyantonde town. She works 7 days a week so that she can maximize profits. Her main challenge is limited capital and competition from the neighboring retail traders. Often, her customers ask her for goods she does not have, apparently because she cannot afford them. With the previous loan, she was able to stock some of them, like cooking utensils and other household items. Her honesty and good customer service have helped her to have an edge over some of her competitors. She is confident that with this loan she will be able to make enough profits, since she will have more items--especially with the festive season at hand. She is sure she will make her repayments well. In the picture is Stella (right) with the Ugafode staff.

This is Analiza, She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase raw ingredients for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan that will allow her to buy raw ingredients like sugar, flour, butter and other ingredients. Her profits from her business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and pay for her children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Analiza hopes her business will grow and dreams of being able to give her children a good future and high-quality education through all her hard work with her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week. It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

This is Susan, 51, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Jaime, a driver and the father to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Susan operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands.

Susan hopes to expand her business and dreams of having a good life through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

Marilou is a 42-year-old married woman and a mother of seven children from Ubay, Bohol. She has owned a 'habal-habal' or motorcycle transport business for more than 8 years now.\r\n\r\nMarilou is asking for a loan to buy new tires, nuts and bolts and gasoline. With this, she will be able to maintain the good working condition of the motorcycle thus allowing her husband to use it to earn their living.

This is Kristine.  She previously accessed a 40,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise and different products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another loan of 50,000 PHP to buy more merchandise like electric fans, rice cookers, flat irons, bags and other products needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help to cover her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Kristine hopes to grow her business and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

Saverino is a forty-eight-year-old married man with eight children living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in agriculture for eleven years and works ten hours a day. After realizing that the only lucrative business is agriculture, he decided to buy land and venture into working it and has since reaped tangible benefits. Like most farmers he has challenges of unpredictable seasonal weather changes and has recently been affected by the banana wilt disease devastating his plantation.\r\n\r\nHis dreams are to educate his children and rehabilitate his banana plantation by cutting down the affected plants and planting new banana stems. Saverino intends to use the loan facility to rehabilitate his banana plantation.

Marina is 52 years old. She is a widow and lives alone in Sighnaghi District. The only source of income for Marina is her small monthly salary, working as a servant-maid in a family. 

As her income is not enough for everyday expenses and food, Marina decided to start a new business. She has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for the business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was always rejected, due to lack of experience in a new business and her low income. Experience is usually demanded by local credit providers. 

Her loan request was approved under a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions providing business start-up and re-startup credits with easier conditions for the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products and are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Marina will purchase used clothing and sell it from her house among her neighbors. She will begin her entrepreneurial activity with a wide assortment of merchandise and high sales volume. This will increase her income. She wants to develop her business further and reinvest the increased income in her business. The new business initiative financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve her living conditions. She is grateful in advance for your support.

Jophes is a 30-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. This father to two children is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He was inspired to the teaching profession by his urge to serve the nation and he feels there is no better way but to teach the children of his nation. He does farming to supplement the low pay from his salary. Jophes intends to use the loan to buy cement and sand for building a residential house.

Rosemary, 58, is a small-scale farmer from the fertile land of bananas: Nkubu town in Mt. Kenya Region. She has been farming for the last twenty years, producing maize, beans and horticultural crops which she sells locally. She also operates a retail shop in the same town. She says that farming has always been her hobby and this has made it more successful than she ever imagined. She, like any other farmer, faces the challenges of lack of enough water for her crops and lack of enough capital for expansion.

She has made her first loan request through Juhudi Kilimo for a loan of 40,000 KES in order to purchase irrigation equipment, including water pipes and a pump. This loan will enable her install irrigation equipment at her farm which she can use during the dry season. She says that this will ensure constant production throughout all seasons. The increased production will increase her income and improve her living standards.

Rosemary would like to acquire a pick-up truck in the near future to help transport her produce to the market

Agnes is a 26-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. A mother to two children, she is married and lives in Kagadi,  Uganda. She was inspired to join the teaching profession by her desire to inspire young people. She also operates a boutique to supplement her meager salary. Agnes is requesting for a loan to pay her children's school fees.

This is Emelia. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and they also helped with her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Emelia hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving her children a high-quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

Juliet is a 46-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. A mother of five children, she is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. 

She became a teacher at her parents' urging as she originally wanted to be a secretary. Nonetheless, she has now come to love and appreciate her profession over time.

Juliet sells juice at school to supplement her salary. Her dreams are to see her children attain degrees and to set up a school canteen. Juliet is requesting a loan to pay the school fees for her children.

Martina earns a living by selling dried fish to the local people at the market. She lives with her husband in Ubay, Bohol, Philippines. She has been in business for more than 30 years now. Her husband works as a fisherman.

Martina is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets for her husband. She also wants to buy additional fish to dry and sell.

In the future, Martina hopes to expand her business and make it a success.

Pamela, 32, is a small-scale farmer from the outskirts of Nkubu town in Mt. Kenya Region. She is married with two children aged six years and 8 months old. She has been practicing mixed farming for fifteen years now, producing beans and bananas, which she sells to the local market. She also operates a retail shop in the same town. 

Pamela has made a loan request for 45,000 KES to buy chickens and chicken feed for her poultry farm. This is the first time she is venturing into poultry farming. Her love for chicken and the need to diversify in her farming business have inspired her to expand into poultry farming. She says that the proceeds from the sale of eggs and chicken will help improve the livelihood of her family.  

Lack of enough capital, competition and poor market prices for her farm produce have been her primary challenges.

Felista, 41, is a single mother to three children aged between 8 and 16 years. She owns a boutique where she sells clothes and shoes. A resident of Kagadi, Uganda, she has been in this business for 14 years, and she supplements her earnings with rental income from her house. As a divorced mother, she plans to invest in real estate to secure her children’s future. Inadequate capital is a major challenge to her business. Felista intends to use this loan to buy clothes to sell.

This is Narlina. She previously accessed an 8,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities of different supplies and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in paying for her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

Narlina would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy more quantities of supplies such as a dust pan, mirror, hanger, pliers and other products for her business. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profits, which will help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s educational expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Narlina hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years and dreams of giving her children a good and quality education. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

William is a 39-year-old, hardworking married man with five children. He and his family live in Kagadi, Uganda. He is a government employee who works as a primary school teacher. He has been in this profession for 20 years. He was inspired to join the teaching profession by his desire to teach.

To supplement his meager salary, William has decided to venture into the produce business. He has found it to be very lucrative. Inadequate capital and poor transportation systems are his major challenges. His business plan is to own a food store where he can supply his customers all year round.

William is requesting a loan to buy agricultural produce such as maize and beans to sell.

Jean Chrysostome is married and an employee of AEE Rwanda. He is 39 years old and has 2 children, the eldest of whom is 2 and the youngest, 1. Neither of his children go to school (they have not yet reached school age) and he is responsible for no other people. He was born in Rwanda and has a university (A0) level education in public health.

He opened his account with ACB Ltd in 2008 and is currently on his 3rd loan cycle. The previous loans have been properly repaid. The loan granted to him will be used to buy 4 bags of cement, 12 kilos of nails and 16 sheets of triple ply-board which he will use to finish off his house that he will then rent out. The only difficulty that Jean Chrysostome expects is the non-payment of his salary by his employer. His strategy is to keep decorating the house so that renters are attracted to it and prepared to pay a high rent. 

He has the following ambitions: concerning work, he will be punctual and avoid irregularities, and concerning his family, he will make sure his children get an education and will develop his house so that he can live in a beautiful home.

John is a 31-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. A father of three children, he is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He has been in the teaching profession for six years. He was inspired to the teaching profession by his desire to associate with young people.

To supplement his meager salary, John has ventured into the produce business. With the proceeds, he has been able to buy land and pay the school fees for his children.

John is requesting a loan to buy agricultural produce such as rice and beans to sell.

Judas, 32, is a married man with five children aged between 1 and 15. He lives in Kagadi, Uganda. Due to his passion to change his and his children's future, he started a produce business ten years ago. He has been able to build rental houses to supplement his produce business income and has also continued to do farming. He dreams of educating his children up to university level and opening up another outlet. Weather changes and bad roads affect his business. Judas intends to use this loan to buy beans and maize to sell.

Fidèle, a rice farmer, is married and 38 years old. He is a member of the solidarity group Dushyirehamwe/sngnr (join together/sngnr) which is engaged in rice farming. He has 3 children, the eldest of whom is 9 years old and the youngest, 6. Two of his children go to school and he is not responsible for any other people. He was born in Rwanda and has 6 years of primary education.\r\n\r\nHe started working with ACB Ltd in 2011 and his current loan is his third one with ACB Ltd. The 2 previous loans were properly repaid. He will use this loan to buy chemical fertilizer and to pay the labourers. He is not expecting any difficulty in reimbursing this loan. In order to increase his farming operation, he intends to increase the area under cultivation. He aims to buy a modern cultivation machine to help him with his farming business. As regards his family, he plans to educate his children.

Sophie is a 47-year-old woman, the single mother of 3 children aged between 18 and 27, two of whom go to school. Despite her hearing problems, her eldest child is still following a course in sewing. The latter's mother, our customer Sophie, has been selling fresh food at a market in town for 10 years already. She enjoys a good experience in this line of work, which has allowed her to build up a considerable portfolio of clients.\r\n\r\nShe would like to use this loan to buy 10 melons, a net of oranges, a net of grapefruit, 10 bunches of plantains, 50 heads of pineapple and a box of tomatoes with which to reinforce her stock, so that she can better meet demand. The additional profits will enable her to better meet her family's needs.

Frola is 37 years old and married with three school-aged children. She lives together with her family in Nkubu town in the Mt. Kenya region. 

She is a hardworking farmer who not only practices farming as a business, but also as one of her hobbies. She has been farming for over 15 years now, producing beans and horticultural crops which she sells to the local market. She faces the challenge of poor prices for her farm produce and lack of enough capital for expansion.

Frola has made a loan request of 15,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to buy a water tank. She says that with this water tank, she will be able to catch rainwater and use it during the dry seasons for her crops. This will enable her to have constant and improved production in all seasons. The proceeds from the sale of these crops will help pay school fees for her children and improve the livelihood of her family.

She is grateful to Juhudi for the financial support and commends it for its efficiency in loan processing.

Amon lives in rural western Uganda and is a farmer. He grows coffee, Irish potatoes and sugarcane. He does all this to earn income to sustain his large family and pay school fees. 

He wants the money to buy materials to complete his house, which is inhabitable at the moment. With the loan, his family will have better shelter and enough space to house all his six children, who have had to share beds at the moment.

He is confident he will be a rich man with time. Weather changes and limited capital are his major setbacks.

Mario, a 24-year-old-single Roma man, lives in a major city in central Albania. He’s got future plans and works hard to achieve them. Mario wants to get married, have children and a house of his own, he said with a smile. 

He was in his early 20s when he started buying and selling used clothes at the Roma Market in his city. With the income he has been generating from this activity, he has been able to make a living and help his parents and siblings also.

Now, Mario wants to stock up on more inventories of used items to resell. It will be the first time for him to request a loan through Kiva, but not the first time requesting a loan from VisionFund Albania. He has successfully repaid all previous loans and has gained so much respect from the VFA institution for his responsible nature.

Fatuma is a 26-year-old married woman with two children living in Masindi, Uganda. She makes a variety of dishes, and with the proceeds she has been able to pay her children's school fees and renovate her house. She has been in business for twelve years, despite the challenge of inadequate capital. Her dreams are to educate children and set up a modern bakery. Fatuma intends to use the loan to buy cooking ingredients such as flour and cooking oil.

This is Emily, 56, a resident of Payatas, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Onofreg and a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Emily operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also has a thrift store. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Php (Philippines pesos) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Emily hopes to expand her business and dreams to have their own house and lot through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

Twenty-seven-year old Josephat is a married father of an 18-month-old baby. He is a resident at a Makimsony location in Litein town in South Rift, Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for 10 years now, producing vegetables and milk, which he sells to the local market. Farming has been his only source of income. \r\n\r\nJosephat has made a loan request of 40,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) in order to buy a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire an additional dairy cow that will increase his milk production and earn him more income. The proceeds from this business will help improve the livelihood of his family. He faces the challenge of insufficient animal feeds, especially during the dry season. He plans to acquire additional dairy cows to expand his dairy farming.

Halima, 29, is married with four children. She lives in Masindi, Uganda. Twelve years ago, she decided to venture into making food to sell in schools and churches, and she has been able to secure a number of loyal customers. The high cost of ingredients and lack of permanent premises are her major challenges, while her dreams are to own a bakery and pay her children's school fees. Halima intends to use this loan to buy baking ingredients such as flour and cooking oil.

Orgit is 28 and married with two children, ages one and two. He and his family are Egyptians. Until four years ago, Orgit lived in Greece and worked in construction. He has since he has returned to his homeland, which is a major city in central Albania. Orgit continues to work in construction yet it is not a steady job; it’s kind of on-call because of the economic situation. To increase his income, he started buying and selling used clothes in the market. Orgit is sole financial provider for his family.\r\n\r\nOrgit is requesting a 100,000 ALL loan from Kiva lenders to buy more used clothing to sell. This will be his first loan, and Orgit assures everyone that, based on his responsible character, he will repay his loan on time.

Philip is 42 years old and married with four children, all of whom attend school. He is from Litein town in the south rift in Kenya. For the past 16 years, Philip has been a small-scale farmer, producing tea and milk which he sells at the local market. He also operates a food kiosk in the same town. Philip's business challenges include diseases and insufficient dairy fodder which affect his production. \r\n\r\nPhilip is requesting a 55,000 KES loan to construct a green house. His loan will improve his production and increase his income to meet his basic needs. Philip also plans to expand his farming business by acquiring quality dairy cows to increase his milk production and earn him more income.

Joseph is a 35-year-old married man from Samburu, Kenya. He is the father of two young children. Joseph works buying fruits and vegetables to sell at the market and he works hard to increase his earnings. \r\n\r\nJoseph is requesting a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables such as onions, bananas, tomatoes, and potatoes to sell at the market. He will use his loan to increase his sales and then his profit.

This is Milagros. She previously accessed a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase hogs and feed needed for her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a new 14,000 PHP loan to buy additional hogs and feeds needed for her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Milagros hopes that her business will expand, and that she will have more workers that she will manage. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

Maryliza is a 46-year-old married woman and a mother of a 21-year-old son from Ubay, Bohol. She has run a sari-sari (or variety store) business for more than 12 years now. She sells various goods to the people in her community.

Maryliza is asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell in her store, such as canned goods, noodles, chips and biscuits, soda and toiletries. With this, she will be able to attract and cater to more buyers and customers in her store, thus augmenting her sales and profit.

In the future, Maryliza has hopes of expanding her business in order to generate more revenue necessary for the needs of the family.

Sarah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells shoes. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 700000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fashionable shoes to sell, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and pay for her basic needs, like food. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

Aidah is 22 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Aidah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fast foods. 

To help expand her business, Aidah has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cassava, Irish potatoes and cooking oil that will be fried for resale and will help Aidah to generate greater profits and pay for food and school fees for her child. 

Aidah hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Aidah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

Aminah is 20 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. 

For the past three years, Aminah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells sugarcane. 

To help expand her business, Aminah has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugarcane for resale and will help Aminah to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. 

Aminah hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her capital and become a rich business woman. 

Aminah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

This is Marilou, 37, a resident of Payatas, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Onofreg and mother to her children. Together with her husband, Marilou manages her household while operating a variety store. She works hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5-PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Marilou buys supplies at wholesale prices and sells by the piece. Her regular customers are neighbors and local community members and she earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

Marilou is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory and help continue her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands. Marilou dreams of giving her children a good and quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

This is Nida. She previously received a 16,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase materials for her scrap metal business. The earnings generated with her loan were a big help for her children's education and in her family's personal, household, and business expenditures. 

Nida is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan to incorporate into her revolving fund and purchase more scrap materials. The profit from her loan will definitely help to provide for her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. Nida looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and she dreams of being able to provide her children with a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work. Nida faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

Christine runs a store selling basic necessities such as rice, beans, detergents, flour, etc. She lives with her husband and three children in a house they rent. She has had the business for two months and it is growing little by little.

She is seeking a loan to buy products such as rice, sugar, beans, cleaning products, flour, oil, etc., for the store. The loan will enable her to have more money available to buy stock.

Christine's hope is that her children will be good students and that she will be able to help them with income from the store.

Narcisa is a 65-year-old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. 

She has been engaged in a sewing and dressmaking business for more than five years now. This is the source of her income.

Narcisa is asking for a loan to buy more cloth, thread, needles and other materials for sewing. Through this, she will be able to accept more requests from her customers and clients.

Narcisa dreams of making her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for reinvestment in the same business and savings for future use.

Prossy's group is composed of six hard working women. Prossy is 22 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past four years, Prossy has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells juice. 

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice. It will help Prossy to generate greater profits and buy basic needs for home like food. 

Prossy hopes that in the future she will be able to own a big store that sells sugarcane and to become a big supplier in town. 

Prossy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

David, 46, is married with nine children. Six of the children are currently attending school. He is a small-scale farmer from Kitale county in western Kenya, where he has been farming for fifteen years now. His mixed farm produces maize, vegetables and sugarcane, all of which are sold in the local market. He solely depends on the income from farming to cater to the needs of his family. However, he faces the challenge of diseases that are too expensive to treat and a poor transport network that affects his income.\r\n\r\nDavid has made a loan request of 62,400 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will enable him improve the livelihood of his family. He hopes that in the near future he will have expanded his farm to five acres and acquired six dairy cows.

Rosalia is a 36-year-old married woman and mother of three young children from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in her mat weaving business for more than seven years now. This is the source of her income.

Rosalia works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family, especially for the schooling of her children. Rosalia is asking for a loan to buy coloring and romblon--a tropical plant--and other materials for mat weaving. Through this, she will be able to weave more mats, thus giving her more to sell in the market.

In the future, Rosalia hopes to expand her business so that it will continue to generate more revenue necessary for the needs of her family.

Boushra is from Iraq. She is 49 years old, married and has four children. Her husband and one of her children are employed.

Boushra is a hairdresser who specializes in preparing brides. She has owned a beauty salon since 2005 and now she has two employees. She has a good reputation and she is well known in the surrounding areas.

She is requesting a $3,000 loan to add an extra chair with all its accessories to the shop. She is aiming to grow this business and increase her profits so she will be able to provide her family better life conditions.

Norah is a merchant from the rural part of Samburu, Kenya. She earns a living through her retail shop that she operates from her home, serving the community. She has been in this business for the last one year.

Norah is asking for a loan to buy additional stock to sell such as detergents, flour, cooking fat, basic medicines, snacks, drinks, etc. With this loan, she will be able to enhance her stocks, thus allowing her to attract and cater to more customers and buyers in her store. 

In the future, Norah hopes to expand her business and save money for future use and expenses.

Nihad is from Iraq. He is 37 years old, married and has two children. He is the only provider for the family.

Nihad owns a small shop selling vegetables and fruits. He established his business in 2009. He has a good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a $1,500 loan to renovate the shop. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

Lucia is 46 years old and a dairy farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. She is married and has five school-age children who all attend school. 

She has been in the farming business for eight years now and solely relies on the income from her farm to meet the needs of her family. She sells her milk to the local market. She faces the challenges of diseases and high cost of dairy feeds, which affect her production.

She has made a loan request of 52,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help her pay school fees for her children and improve the livelihood of her family. 

She plans to increase her milk production by acquiring hybrid dairy cows and also by venturing into poultry farming in the near future.

Teofila is a 50-year-old married woman and a mother of two children from Bohol, Philippines. 

She earns a living through her variety store, selling various goods and commodities to the people in her community.

Teofila is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell such as rice, canned goods, snack foods and chips, soda, soap and toiletries. Through this loan, she will be able to attract more buyers and customers to her store, thus allowing her to augment her sales and profit.

Tareq is a 20-year-old single young man who lives with his family. They live in a quiet area and his father's salary is not enough to cover the family's needs. For the past two years, Tareq has run a small store where he sells clothes. His business has been profitable and he has been able to increase his family's income. Tareq lacks enough capital to cover his costs.\r\n\r\nTareq is requesting a FATEN youth loan to purchase a new collection of clothing to sell. His loan will allow him to provide a greater variety of clothing for his customers to choose and buy. Tareq believes his loan will increase his sales and income. He is photographed inside his store.

Stella's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Stella is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past three years, Stella has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells a variety of goods such as beans, cabbage, nuts and shoes. 

To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more beans, cabbage, nuts and shoes for resale, and it will help Stella to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Stella hopes that in the future, she will be able to see her business expand into a big shop. 

Stella is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

56-year old Gloria del Carme is married and has a son. She lives in Chinandega which is located in the western part of the country. It's known as a productive business area. Gloria earns her living selling soft drinks, popsicles, chocolate-covered bananas etc. She also sells pigs, pork, and fried snacks. Known as a hardworking woman with a desire to get ahead, Gloria has run her business from her home for ten years. \r\n\r\nShe has worked with the Foundation in the past and demonstrated responsibility with the loan repayments. The money she needs now is for working capital to buy stock for her store: sugar, fruit, pickling spices, pigs to butcher, meat pasties, fried snacks, lard etc. Gloria is grateful for the help Kiva donors provide to poor people and poor countries like Nicaragua so that people can have work.

María Inés is 59 and lives in Chinandega department, located in the eastern part of the country. She is married and has six adult offspring. For the past two years, María Inés has sold pigs. She is hardworking, responsible, and seeks to get ahead. Her business, which is located on her property, comprises buying pigs in lots to fatten and resell to meat merchants. \r\n\r\nShe has worked with the institution and has a good credit history. Her objective for this loan is to purchase a lot of pigs and take advantage of the Christmas season when meat sales are strong for year-end events, graduations, and so forth. María Inés thanks the Kiva lenders for their support of low-income people in poor countries such as Nicaragua that allows them to have decent work.

Barbra is 22 years old and lives in Seeta town in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her shoe-selling business. She is a member of a two-person loan group comprised of hardworking women. 

Barbra is requesting a 400,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more fashionable shoes to sell. Her loan will help her generate greater profits to improve her family's standard of living. Barbra hopes that in the future she will be able to own a better shop that sells good shoes.
