Barbra is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Agnes is 34 years old and works as a small-scale farmer. She is from Kitale town in western Kenya. Agnes is from the Abaluhya community which is well known for poultry farming and bull fighting. For the past 10 years, she has been running a mixed farm in the Kapenguria division where she produces maize, milk, eggs, and chickens that she sells at the local market. She also operates a retail shop and kiosk where she sells vegetables. \r\n\r\nAgnes is requesting a 31,200 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She believes that by acquiring a dairy cow her milk production will increase and she will be able to make enough money for her children's upkeep. In the future, Agnes plans to apply for a bigger loan to set up a posho mill.

Besik is 47 years old. He lives in Martvili District with his wife, son, daughter-in-law and grandchild. The family runs a small dairy farm of two milk cows, whose milk is used in cheese products. The cheese is sold at the local open market. 

Besides dairy farming, Besik serves the local people as a taxi driver with his own car. His wife is involved in a flower-trading business. She purchases flowers locally and sells them in the nearby district for a higher price. 

All of the family members work hard, but the income is not enough for covering the everyday expenses. So, Besik decided to start up a new business. He has requested loans from his local financial institutions several times without any success. His loan requests were rejected every time because of low income and the lack of experience in the new job, which is usually demanded by local credit providers. His loan request was approved under a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo.

The start-up loan program provides startup and re-startup credits with soft conditions for country, rural poor who do not have access to credit products since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the loan, Besik will build a greenhouse. He will purchase building materials and construct it. Besik will plant different kinds of flowers, which will be sold by his wife at a good price. This will increase his income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva startup loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family. Besik awaits your support.

Flavia's group is comprised of 2 hard-working women. Flavia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Flavia has been working hard to manage her piggery.

To help expand her business, Flavia has requested a loan from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more pigs to be raised for resale, and will help Flavia to generate greater profits and expand on the rooms for the piggery. Flavia hopes that in the future she will be able to see her business expand into a big farm and become a big supplayer in town.

Flavia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Immaculate is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her small business where she sells cooked food.

Immaculate is requesting a 600,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to purchase ingredients such as cassava and Irish potatoes. Her loan will help her to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young siblings. Immaculate hopes that in the future she will be able to improve on her business and become a well-known businesswoman in town. 

Immaculate is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Mariam is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past two years, she has been working hard to manage her small business where she sells cooked food. 

Mariam is requesting a 400,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to purchase different types of raw food such as cassava, Irish potatoes, and matooke to cook and sell. Her loan will help her generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her children such as food. Mariam hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Dinora is 32 years old. She is married and has three children ages 14, 12, and 10. She is a native of the municipality of Achuapa, which is located in the northern part of the country. Dinora runs her own business, a small pulpería, which she runs from her home. A pulpería is a small grocery store where food products are sold in small quantities, such as: individual cigarettes, rice, oil in ¼, beans, bread, milk, eggs, and packets of coffee and shampoo. \r\n\r\nDinora has shown responsibility by repaying her previous loans. She will use this loan to invest in working capital and to stock her grocery store by buying products of daily consumption for the home in order to increase her sales and improve her income. Dinora is thankful for the help Kiva lenders provide to low income families and poor countries such as Nicaragua so that they too can have decent work.

Analisa is 21 years old and the mother a six-month-old child who lives in Ubay, Bohol. She owns a sari-sari or variety store which she has run for more than two years. She is requesting a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell in her store such as canned goods, snacks, soap and toiletries as well as piglets to raise. In the future, Analisa wants to expand her business and save money to pay for the future schooling of her daughter.

Betty leads a loan group which is made up of two hardworking women. She is 22 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and the mother of two children, both of whom attend school. For the last three years, she has earned a living by selling food. To help expand her business, she is requesting a loan for 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more ingredients such as potatoes, and hopes that increased sales will help her pay for the education of her children. Her goal for the future is to buy a plot of land. Betty is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

The solidarity group Los Coquitos is comprised of two members, Paz Catalina and Ery. Paz Catalina is the coordinator of the solidarity group and is in charge of the smooth operation for the group. She is originally from Somotillo, a place located in the northern part of the country. Paz Catalina's job for the last two years has been the service of video games, located in her home. Paz is a responsible, hardworking woman who wants to excel. The loan is to invest in fixed assets, such as the purchase of three TVs to give better service to their clients and thereby earn a better income. Paz appreciates the assistance the Kiva investors give to people with limited resources and in poor countries such as Nicaragua, to have a decent work environment.

Jackline is 22 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her restaurant, where she earns a living by selling cooked food. To help expand her business, she is requesting a loan for 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more food, including plantain, rice and beans as well as chairs and some tables. She hopes that these items will help her earn a larger income, which will allow her to pay for her child's education. Her goal for the future is to expand her business into a big hotel. Jackline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to making microfinance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

Gorret is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past year, Gorret has been working hard to manage her small clothing business. 

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more new fashionable clothes for resale, and will help Gorret to generate greater profits and add to the business so it can expand. Gorret hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand her business into a big shop. 

Gorret is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Beatrice is a member of Mwangaza Group in Lugari District. She is pictured with 20 One Acre Fund farmers, 13 women and seven men. Beatrice is standing on the right with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Beatrice’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, take advantage of the best input prices and be assured of reliable input delivery.

Beatrice described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies and buy a dairy cow. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Beatrice’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 9.5 acres of land.   

Irene dropped from the program after the photo of her group was taken.

Awa is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She has been active in the clothing trade for over five years. Her business is in clothing sales. The income Awa earns from her clothing sales enables her to expand her business, and to pay for the daily needs of her family.\r\n\r\nShe is requesting a loan of 150,000 XOF which she will use to purchase the clothing she will then resell. Her aim is to increase the income she earns, and she hopes to someday acquire a department store where she can sell her clothing.

Racheal is 21 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Racheal has been working hard to manage her shop that sells medicine. 

To help expand her business, Racheal has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock different medicines and other items for the clinic, and will help Racheal generate greater profits and register her drug shop with the authorities. Racheal hopes that in the future she will be able to save her money to open up a clinic. 

Racheal is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Zawadi is a group of 20 farmers in Lugari District represented by Lily.  The group has 16 women and four men. Lilly is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Lilly is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for her family.\r\n\r\nLilly thought her harvest last year was poor. She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer she can have an excellent harvest. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest to repair her home, buy livestock, save for the future, increase her land acreage and perhaps invest in another business. Lilly’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season.  In total they will receive inputs for 10 acres of maize and sorghum.

Verónica is 38 years old, married, and has four minor children, ages 13, 10, 8 and 3, who are all in school. She is from the town of Malpaisillo, located in the western part of the country. Her work is renting Nintendo games and preparing Nicaraguan fast food.

The business came about because of her need to have a source of work and help with the household expenses. Veronica has shown herself to be responsible, by paying back the previous loans in a timely manner.

She needs loan in order to have working capital and to maintain her equipment. Veronica is thankful for the help that the Kiva investors offer to low-income people and to poor countries such as Nicaragua, so that people can have decent livelihoods.

Pedro is from the county Asedades, on the outskirts of Teustepe.  He is married with two adult children. Pedro has been selling watches, belts, purses for 8 years.  He previously worked as an electrician in the market, and he was always saving. But upon being unemployed he didn't know what to do, so a very close friend suggested that they go together to sell merchandise to another city.  His money gradually increased. Currently, one of his children helps him tend to the business.\r\n\r\nToday, Pedro is requesting this loan to buy watches, belts, wallets and calculators to sell.  He also wants to further strengthen the business to increase his income in order to improve the infrastructure of his home.

Yannick is a young Cameroonian of 25 years old. He runs a business selling clothes and hats in a district of the city, where he has been working for the past year. He buys his merchandise in Douala at retail from sellers there.\r\n\r\nYannick wants to use this loan to buy a bundle of jeans. This will not only expand his stock of goods, but will also increase his client portfolio as retailers will be able to buy their supplies from him. Yannick's ambition is to open his own shop selling ready to wear clothing.

Sarah's group has 19 farmers and is located in Lugari District.  Sarah is pictured on the right of the Tumaini Group with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Sarah’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.\r\nSarah described her harvest last year as good, but she hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies and perhaps invest in business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive half an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Sarah's group will receive 9.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

Raed is a 38-year-old single man. He is employed in a local company and gets a low salary, which is not enough to cover his needs. For the past two years, Raed has had a grocery store selling different types of groceries. It has been a profitable project, but more financial support is needed to cover the costs.\r\nRaed is requesting a USD 1,500 loan from FATEN to help him cover the costs of purchasing needed stock of basic groceries that customers often request such as rice, sugar, and dairy products. This will increase sales and increase Raed's income.\r\nRaed is photographed inside his store.

Emmanuel is a rice farmer. He belongs to the joint-liability association called Twitezimbere Bahinzi /kzr Group. He is married and is 35 years old. Emmanuel has four children, the eldest of whom is 12 years old and the youngest of whom is nine. Two of his children currently attend school. He has no additional dependents other than his four children. He was born in Rwanda and has had five years of primary education.\r\n\r\nEmmanuel began working with ACB Ltd in 2012 and is on his second loan cycle. His first loan has been fully repaid. With his present loan, Emmanuel plans to purchase 80 kilos of chemical fertilizers, and to pay for the labor required to work his rice field. As he does not expect to have any problems with repayment, Emmanuel's planning strategy is to cultivate in a timely manner, and to use good quality seeds. This will maximize his agricultural yields. His ambition is to become the largest rice grower in the region. For his family, Emmanuel plans to educate his children to the university level.

Madona is 36 years old, married and lives in Batumi city with her husband and two children (12 and 15 years old). The children go to the local school and her husband is an armament officer who earns a monthly salary. Madona’s economic activity is a newly started small grocery store. She also rents out a room in her house to earn additional monthly income. Madona requested a loan from local financial institutions for the business expansion, but without success. Her loan request was rejected because of low income and insufficient experience in her business.
Her loan request was approved through a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. They do not have access to traditional credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

Madona requested a loan to equip the store with an additional refrigerator. She will keep perishable products there and will be able to sell meat which is in high demand. The existing refrigerators are inadequate to store all the inventory. When Madona has an additional refrigerator, she will be able to increase her inventories as well as the turnover in the store. This will raise the income of the family, which will be used to improve the family’s living conditions. She awaits your support.

Eva is 22 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Eva has been working hard to manage her salon, which does hair styling. 

To help expand her business, Eva has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hair styling products and equipment, including a big dryer. This will help Eva generate greater profits and save some money for her child's school fees. Eva hopes that in the future she will be able to develop her business more. 

Eva is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

Rosa, 57, went to elementary school, and then married young. She recently separated from her husband, which has been a very difficult situation for her, but she decided to keep moving forward with more determination and strength of will. She lives in the canton of Pastaza, in the provine of the same name, which is part of the Amazonian region of Ecuador. The capital of the canton is the city of Puyo, which is located in the middle of the Amazon rainforest, just west of the province of Pastaza at 924 metres above sea level. Demographically it’s a small area, but it has a variety of sites that attract national and international tourists, especially ecological endeavours and extreme sports.
It’s a city that grows economically every day because of commerce, livestock breeding, agriculture and tourism; for this reason, financial and commercial businesses have opened branches here to take advantage of the economic activity maintining the city. Competition between companies is strong, but each has promoted its own added value to gain preference with clients. 
After her separation, Rosa found herself insecure about her future; there in Pastaza she felt that she had no alternatives because of her advanced years. However, those limitations didn’t last long when she put into practise the knowledge she gained from her parents, concering the undertaking of a business and selling spices.
After the sun comes out, Rosa opens the doors to her business, which is located in a small space in the local market. She started her business 10 years ago with the help and support of her daughter. Rosa has become a determined woman and thinks one can always accomplish more and it’s never too late to dream. With the 10 hours that she invests in her work every day, she knows her business can grow in some way. That’s why she decided to request a loan to buy spices and herbs in order to increase her sales. “Fundación Alternativa” communal bank has offered Rosa the training and advice to correctly administrate her tangible and intangible resources. Rosa is grateful to the Kiva lenders for contributing their grain of sand to the accomplishment of her dream of being a successful small business.

Adama is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She has had over seven years of experience as a merchant, and runs her business selling jewelry. The income she earns from her business allow her to support her five children, aged between four and 19 years old.\r\n\r\nAdama is seeking a 100,000 XOF loan from the local UIMCEC office where she is a member. She plans to use this loan to expand her business. Adama will use her loan to purchase a supply of jewelry that she will resell to her customers. Her hope to someday become a major jewelry retailer.

Jiinue Group is located in Lugari District. It is a group of 14 women and 7 men led by Agatha, pictured on the right with her hand raised. Agatha is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.\r\nAgatha thought her harvest last year was poor.  She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer she can have an excellent harvest. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock, and perhaps investing in another business. Agatha’s group members will each receive input loans of a half acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 10.5 acres of maize and sorghum.

Cissy is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past two years, Cissy has been working hard to manage her small business selling vegetables. \r\nTo help expand her business, Cissy has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more vegetables, such as green cabbage, for resale, and it will help Cissy to generate greater profits and add in the business to expand. Cissy hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. \r\nCissy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

Aba is married and has five children. Her husband is a fisherman. Aba sells Fante kenkey at Ankwanda near Elmina, which she has done for three years. Aba uses her income to assist her husband in taking care of the home. Aba will use the loan to purchase maize in bulk to produce kenkey for distribution. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to reinvest back into her business.

Jansughi is 49 years old and lives with his wife and two children (15 and 18 years old) in Zestaponi district. The only source of income for the family is the small income, earned by Jansughi, who is involved in book trading. He has been running the business during five years and the project was profitable, but now it needs financial support. Several times, he has asked for loans from local financial institutions to develop his business with no success. His loan requests were rejected each time because of his low income.\r\nJansughi’s loan request was approved as part of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-ups and re-startups with credit, with soft conditions to the rural poor who do not have access to credit products, since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. With the received credit, Jansughi will cover the costs of purchasing needed stock of books that customers often request. He plans to increase the turnover in his trade business gradually. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the income of the family. Jansughi will work hard, and he will be able to improve the living conditions for his family. With this loan, the family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, in the event it is needed.

Comfort is a petty trader. She sells dresses and underwear for ladies and children at Amkwamda near Elmina. She has been in this business for the past two years now. Comfort is married. She uses her income to help her husband pay the utility and accommodation bills.  She needs this loan to enable her  to purchase more underwear and ladies' and children's dresses to sell. With the new profit, she plans to acquire a shop for the sale of her dresses.

Titus still practices mixed farming, which he has done for the past four years and the business has improved very much. He used his previous loan to buy farm inputs and potato seedlings and he got a very good harvest.


Now he has applied for his second loan from KADET LTD, to enable him pay labor costs and to buy fertilizer and potato seeds for planting. He will plow the anticipated profit back into his business, to grow crops and buy more dairy cows for milk production.

He hopes to improve his standards of living and provide for his family all the basic needs in the near future.

Annah is a 36-year-old married woman. She has a child who is 13 years old. She describes herself to be honest woman. 

She operates a grocery store where she sells vegetables and fruits. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located within a productive area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business.

She will use the loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to buy vegetables and fruits to sell. Her business goal is to improve her business within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

Christoper is a 36-year-old married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself as a determined man. 

Christoper operates a retail store where he sells clothes. He has been involved in this business for 7 years. His business is located in a suitable business environment and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving the business. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy clothes to sell during the December holiday. His business goal is to improve his business within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will educate his children with the profits generated. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

Nancy is a 25-year-old married woman. She has 4 children with ages ranging from 2 years to 10 years. She describes herself as a polite woman. She operates a retail stall where she sells cereals. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located within a busy market, and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving her business. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy cereals to sell. Her business goal is to improve her business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will diversify her business into a rental house/accommodation business.

Efua cooks banku for sale. She serves it with fried fish, pepper, and tomato sauce at Abura. She is married and has four dependents. Efua has been in this business for four years now. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their children. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale. She hopes to use the new profit from her expanded business to mount a better stall for the sale of her banku.

Maura is known to her family as being the happiest and most optimistic person.  She’s 30 years old and her family includes her husband and two children.  Thanks to her many years of hard work she was able to build the first floor of her house out of concrete and brick.  She has been developing and maintaining her cacao plantation for the past 8 years, thanks to some parcels of farmland that she inherited from her parents.  The need to support her son created this opportunity and she has been able to become a great cacao producer in her area.

She can always count on external personnel or helpers for her normal activities, since her parcel of land is large and requires outside help.

She likes her job very much because she considers the work in the fields the healthiest there is, even though cultivating the plants takes a lot of time and effort.  Despite that, she considers her production to be very profitable because she is located in a zone where the cacao is of a unique quality.

She wants to begin the cacao campaign in a different way.  She plans to replace the old trees and use the leftover stems to graft, so she needs to buy new plants, fertilizer, tools and hire trained people in order to get an optimal result and get the maximum benefit from her parcels.  In this way she hopes to increase her income by the end of the campaign.

In the future she wants so start her own parallel business by adding a grocery store that she can run whenever she does not have to work the fields during the rainy season.  This will be her third loan thorough MFP and she is very grateful for the opportunity given because it allows her to develop her productive activities with complete fluidity and confidence.  She feels very confident and motivated by how the members of her communal bank feel responsible for making their loan payments. 

She will use the 1,000 PEN to supplement her working capital to use toward her immediate purchase of nursery plants for grafting, compost, and to pay for necessary laborers who will do the work.

Rufina, 46, is married to her life companion, Máximo, and to add to their family joy they have four children: Vanesa, Frank, Romario and Luis.  She has worked growing cocoa beans, ‘barbasco’ [an evergreen bush] and corn for 25 years.  With the vast experience she’s gained throughout her life and with the firm support she’s always had from Máximo, she’s managed to provide her minor children with everything necessary to forge a profitable future for them.

Barbasco is one of the products that can take up a large portion of her parcel because it’s used later in an industrial process as a natural insecticide which is why it has a high market price in the foreign markets and why she spends a great part of her time caring for the plants that grow from roots.  Even though, she still has to make a considerable investment in manpower.

Five months after the last harvest, she wants to once again plant and to do so needs to hire on average ten day laborers who will do the hard work of clearing the fields to ready them for planting as well as planting the roots.  In addition to this, proper maintenance and weeding of the cocoa bean plants must also be done in order to have additional economic support.  Because of this she’d like to request 1,000 new soles to hire day laborers to clear the field earmarked for future barbasco production and to provide cocoa bean crop maintenance.

Cynthia, 46, is a university graduate. She lives in the community of Congo Town called Chugbor. She is a widow, and the mother of two children who are between the ages of 9 and 15, and are currently in school. She started with the initial capital of 8,000 Liberia dollars, which she received from her brother. She has sold salt, pepper, onion, palm oil, vita, rice and black pepper for the past fifteen years. She likes this type of business because she makes a profit. With the profit she buys more goods and attends to the needs of her children.\n\nShe has requested this loan to purchase more rice, vita, onion, pepper and cooking oil for the business. Her plan is to become an international business woman.

Esi sells beads and jewelry at Ankwanda near Elmina. 

Esi has been through senior high school.  She is married with five children.  She has been in this trade for five years. She assists her husband in the upkeep of their home. 

Her loan will be used to buy additional beads and jewelry to sell. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

Rafaela Emilia is 28 years old. She is a single mother to a 10-year-old son. She is from the municipality of Malpaisillo, located in the northern part of the country.
Rafaela's business is the selling of merchandise such as men's and children's clothing, trousers, skirts, dresses, blouses, underwear and shoes. 
The business is a street trade that originated with the goal of having an income source to help with the household expenses.
The aim of this loan is to invest in working capital and supply her business with shirts, skirts, dresses, underwear and trousers. Rafaela Emilia is grateful for the help Kiva lenders provide to low income people from poor countries such as Nicaragua that allows them to get a decent work.

Silvio lives in the Las Banderas district of Teustepe.  He's married and the father of three children, only one of whom is in his care.  He makes a living buying and selling quarry stone.  He does his job with a truck that a friend financed for him four years ago.  He repaid the debt little by little, and now the truck belongs to him.  He says that every afternoon he visits his evangelical church, thanking the Lord for all his progress thus far.  With his truck he gives work to two people who help him carry and sell the quarry stone.

Silvio is requesting this loan to buy more quarry stone to store and to sell to various communities.  This type of stone is used to build houses.  He'll have it in stock because demand for his product increases in the Christmas season.

His next goal is to be able to pay back this loan and request another one to buy another used truck so his son can work.

Mohamed is a 47-year-old married man. He has six children with ages ranging from 1 year to 12 years. He describes himself as an honest man. 

He operates a food stall where he sells fish and water to customers. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located within a busy and viable community and his primary customers are local residents. 

He describes his biggest business challenge as high prices of fish. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy fish to sell. His business goal is to start a new business of a grocery store within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will improve the living standard of people by supplying water to them.

This is his second loan with SMEP DTM after taking a loan of KES 20,000, which he managed to repay successfully.

James is a 27-year-old farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya, where he lives with his wife and two children, one of whom is schooling. He he has been in farming for over 10 years, producing horticultural crops and selling them at the local market in his area. He also has a retail business as an additional source of income.

He is requesting a loan of 60,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi kilimo to purchase irrigation equipment, which will help him better his production and earn more income. This will help him uplift his livelihood and be able to pay for his children's schooling. He aspires to buy a pickup in the next 5 years to assist him in transporting his products.

Lack of capital and poor market are his major challenges in farming.

James is thankful to Juhudi kilimo for giving him the loan.

Rokhaya is a married woman who lives in Sénégal. For more than 10 years she has been developing her catering service. She also sells ice cream and local juice. She has 10 years experience in her business. The profits that she makes allow her to help her 3 children aged from 7 to 13 years old in their daily needs. \r\n\r\nWith the increase in her income she envisions diversifying the products and services that she offers to her clientèle. She is a member of one of the branches of the UIMCEC and is requesting a loan of 300,000f with which she plans to increase her working capital. This will allow her to take care of the new expenses as she wants to start the same business and sell at night. Her future project is to have a large restaurant in the neighborhood where she lives.

Ali is from Iraq. A youth client, he is 26 years old and single and lives with four family members. He is the only provider for the family.

Ali owns a car accessories shop. He specializes in customizing cars. He established his business in 2003, and now he has an employee. He has built good experience in this field, and he is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a youth loan of $3,000 to renovate his shop and increase his stock of accessories. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide better living conditions for his family.

Aba is a fishmonger at Ankwanda, near Elmina. She is married to a mason, and they have four dependents. She has been a fishmonger for the past five years now. Aba assists her husband in the upkeep of their children. She will use her loan to purchase more fish to smoke and then sell. Aba will expand her business with her increased profits.

Efua sells waakye (rice and beans cooked together) at Ankwanda, near Elmina. This dish is normally served with eggs, macaroni, salad, hot black pepper sauce and tomato sauce. She is divorced and has six children. Her business is five years old. Her loan will be used to buy rice and beans to sell. She plans to reinvest the new profit.

Joyce is into gari production.  Gari is made out of cassava.  

Joyce sells the gari at Ankwanda, Elmina, and has done this for some years now. She is married with one child. She uses her income to support her husband to pay their accommodation and utility bills.  

Joyce will use her loan to purchase cassava to produce her gari to sell. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

Nana fries doughnuts for sale at Ankwanda near Elmina. She lives together with her husband and three children. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their family. \r\n\r\nHer loan will be used to buy flour, sugar, oil and other ingredients that will enable her to fry doughnuts in larger quantity for sale. She hopes to build a snack bar with the new profits.

This group is called Al-Ahsan. It consists of four ladies. All of them are friends and live in Taiz, Yemen. They have primarily worked different businesses for several years. The entire group took a loan of 200,000 YER. 

Asrar is a 28-year-old who lives in Taiz, Yemen. She is a hairdresser who works at home. She has developed a good reputation in her community for her customer dealings and good quality services. She is very experienced in her business and has been operating it for many years. 

Asrar has applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB for her business. With this loan, she will purchase cosmetics, which will allow her to fulfill her client orders on time and earn higher profits. She is confident of her business' success after investing the loan. She hopes to have a cosmetics shop in the future, in order to increase her profits.

Ekua buys fresh fish from the market and smokes them, for sale at Ankwanda, near Elmina. Ekua is married and has five children. She uses her income to assist her husband to pay their children’s school fees. A loan will help Ekua to buy more fresh fish to smoke and sell. This will result in an increase in her income, so she will save towards the university education of her children.

Hussein is a 28-year-old man. He’s Lebanese, single, and is living with his parents and two working siblings. He is a great support to his father, their main income provider, especially after finding it hard to cover the usual family expenses on his own. 

Hussein has owned cattle since 2009, from which he obtained dairy products such as milk. He has been involved in this occupation since many years ago; he knows very well how to manage his work in a good way. He’s really good in his domain and looks forward to developing his business as much as he possibly can. 

For this reason, he wanted to take a youth loan form Kiva Partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase a milk machine. He will be utilizing this machine to facilitate the milk production process.  

In his opinion, this step will allow him to increase his productivity and therefore his earnings, and thus his whole way of living. This is how Hussein works every day to improve his way of living.

Ekua sells rice, sugar and gari (cassava flakes) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Ekua is single and has three children. 

She has been selling rice, sugar and gari for the past ten years. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees, as well as all other household expenses. 

Her loan will be used to buy bags of rice, sugar and gari for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to support herself and her family.

Lucy is 32 years old, married and has a 5-year-old child. She does farming to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years.  She mainly grows tomatoes, spinach and cabbages on her farm.  She has employed two people in her business.

Lucy also earns extra income from her rental houses.  Her desire is to practice large-scale farming in the future.  

She has requested 7,300 KES to buy a water tank for storage of water on her farm.

Jawad is from Iraq. He is 37 years old, married and has two children. His wife works and helps with the family income.

Jawad is a photographer and owns a studio. He specializes in producing video taped films. He established his business in 2008 and now he has an employee. He built a good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a loan of $2,400 to expand his shop. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better living conditions.

Maria is 47 years old and lives her life at the side of Manuel, who is 54. The one thing that completes her happiness is her little Antony, 13. Together they form a family where love and work are their reasons for being.

Thanks to all their years of work and effort they have managed to finish building a home made from good quality materials. She farms the parcels of land that she and Manuel have acquired. For 20 years they have been managing to establish cacao plantings, which over time have achieved an enviable quality.

During all this time she has had various life experiences, both good and bad, but always at the side of her partner. He in turn is her faithful work companion, not to forget the day laborers that she hires to help with the necessary work.

In beginning next year's cacao season, she has carried out the reconditioning of a part of her land to render it more productive, and ready for the planting of the seedlings or young cacao, for which she must acquire these plants and also buy sacks of organic fertilizer. 

Another of the her requirements for optimizing her output is to bring in day laborers for the planting of temporary shade trees which are very necessary so that the sun doesn't directly affect the plantings.

This is how she carries on with quite a bit of motivation, since one of her long-term objectives is to acquire a home in the region's capital. This is so that  in the future she can send her son to a fine university for his post-secondary studies 

This is her first loan with MFP. She is very happy and promises to be punctual in making her installment payments. She sees her fellow communal bank members as a good team; responsible and supportive, and this makes her feel very confident.

With the 1000 nuevos soles she has been granted, she will buy cacao seedlings, as well as sacks of organic fertilizer. The remaining money will help pay for the day laborers for the tree-planting.

Omar is married and has one child. He started to work when he was 15 years old but he is not working right now due to the increase of unemployment in our country (Nicaragua). \r\nHis biggest wish is to get ahead which is why he is studying for a law degree with the help of his wife, who pays for tuition fees. Omar is asking for a loan to pay the final fees to register his degree, so he can find a good job, help his family and make use of his knowledge.

With this loan of 50,000 KES, Mwanamisi will buy merchandise to restock her store where she sells fuel (diesel and petroleum) and charcoal. Her store is located at her home.

Mwanamisi is a married mother and has 8 children, three of whom are in school. Her hope is to see her business flourish and have a prosperous life in the future. 

Mwanamisi wants to have the ability to produce enough income to provide for her family. With this loan, she will buy more gallons of fuel and sacks of charcoal for sale. By doing this she is sure to have increased income.

Johnson is a 29-year-old married man. He has two children, ages one year and three years. He describes himself to be an honest and intelligent man. He operates a grocery stall where he sells vegetables and fruits such as cabbages, mangoes, onions, tomatoes etc. His business is located at a densely populated slum and his primary customers are residents from the slum. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds from improving the business. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy vegetables and fruits to sell. His business goal is to be a wholesaler of vegetables and fruits within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will have had expanded his business and improved the living standard of his family. This is  his first loan with SMEP DTM.

Sylver, a rice farmer and a member of the group TUBANIRANE-MABUYE-NYKBY, is married and is 35 years old. He has three children of whom the oldest is 5 years old and the youngest is 6 months old. Neither of his children go to school and he has no other dependents. He was born in Rwanda and his level of education is 6 years of primary school.

Having joined the services of ACB Ltd. in 2012, he is on his first loan cycle. This loan will allow him to buy 50 kgs of chemical fertilizers and will pay for the manual labor with the remainder of the loan. Not expecting to have any difficulty repaying the loan, Sylver will use the strategy of asking for other loans with the aim of growing his agricultural business. His ambition is to become the great rice farmer in his region. For his family, he plans to build a house.

Other than his farming business (financed), Sylver also breeds animals.

Hawa is a widowed woman who lives in Sénégal. She sells fabric and has been working in this field for more than 5 years. 

She is requesting a loan of 200,000 frs which will be used to buy fabric to resell. She wishes to strengthen her working capital even more. 

The income that her business generates for her allows her to support part of the responsibilities of her family of 7 children. Her goal consists in beginning to run her own boutique selling clothing for children. Her future intentions are also to acquire a large store to sell fabric.

George is 36 years old. He lives in Gori District with his wife and mother. George requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the monthly pension of George’s mother. It makes a total of 150 Laris per month. It is hardly enough for food for a three-member family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

George requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. His loan request was approved in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions the provision of business start up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit George will rent space and start an auto repair business. George plans to purchase essential auto repair installations such as a tire changer and trim controller in order to respond rapidly to his clients' problems. He believes that acting properly is really essential to attracting more customers. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

Yaa is married and has seven children. She sells kenkey (fermented maize dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for the past eight years. Her husband is a farmer. Yaa uses her income to pay her children's school fees. Yaa will use the loan to purchase bags of maize for her kenkey production. With the new profits from her expanded business, Yaa plans to continue to support her children.

Florence, a single mother of three children, resides in one of the city's suburbs. She earns her income from small rooms that she lets out at affordable prices to low income earners. Florence educates her children and supports her needy relatives with the income from the rentals. She will use this loan to construct an underground water tank and also renovate the small rooms to make them more habitable for her tenants.

\r\n\r\nFlorence is very shrewd and dreams of owning an estate of rental units. She says, "All things are possible as long as you believe," and is committed to pursuing her dreams until she gets a breakthrough. In the picture is Florence with the Ugafode credit officer in front of the house where she wants to put the tank.

Zakaria is 64 years old, married and has three children. To earn a living, he has been farming for two years, and his desire is to practice large-scale farming in the future.

\r\n\r\nThrough Faulu Kenya, Zakaria has been able to purchase some farm inputs, and he is now requesting this loan for 53,156 KES to buy seeds and fertilizers. This will help him educate his children until university level.

Rosmeri is 24 years old and has a partner, Edwin, who is 32 years old. Both lead a harmonious coexistence and have, as the fruit of their love, their son Edwin, who is 6 years old. She has managed and worked together with her partner in their carpentry business for the last four years. The business started because the young couple was looking for a fixed income to support the family, because then Edwin was only working as a helper in other workshops. They decided later to become independent thanks to loans from MFP and their savings thereafter. 

They consider their work an activity of family union. Rosmeri helps with the minor activities in the pair while Edwin is in charge of the main, required work. Working together in this way they have succeeded in converting their business in to their primary family income. However, sometimes delays in the arrival of their wooden blocks causes them to have to cancel certain orders. 

In order to continue completing orders, they wish to continue investing in the purchase of blocks of wood for the fabrication of tables, chairs, beds, and more. In the future, Rosemeri wants to expand and open a grocery store parallel to the family business in order to grow economically; all of this is in thinking ahead for her son's future. This is her sixth loan with MFP. She considers the loans she receives to be an important work tool that must be treated with great responsibility. These 500 soles will complement her capital to buy blocks of wood and primary materials necessary to complete orders from her clients.

Ali is a 58-year-old, widowed man from Lebanon, who lives with his nephews. Twenty years ago, he started to work in a lingerie shop, and after gaining the needed experience, he was able to open his own shop in 2009. His store is located in a strategic point; he has a fair number of loyal customers to whom he offers a wide variety of lingerie. \r\n\r\nAli and his nephews are cooperating together for a better standard of living. And today, he is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l, to expand his store’s inventory of new lingerie collections. He’s sure and certain that the loan will help him diversify his merchandise selection. In the future, he is hoping to sell women's clothes, in addition to lingerie.

Majdoline is a 38-year-old woman. She lives with her husband, Samir, and their three children at their house, which is located in one of the beautiful Lebanese villages. Despite everything, Majdoline is obliged to work continually as she is responsible for supporting her husband with their family expenses. Her husband works in floor covering and has more than fifteen years of experience. 

Majdoline started to sell clothes from her home to avoid rent expenses. She provides her customers with good quality products at fair prices. She is satisfied with what she has attained so far, even though she wishes to enhance her family’s way of living the most. 

That’s the reason why she is asking today for a loan from Kiva Partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase a new winter collection. She notes that her sales will increase after these purchases, especially because of the holidays. 

In the near future, she wishes to open her own clothing shop and maybe hire new employees to help her achieve the work tasks and therefore earn a higher income.

Esi is single and has two children. She sells kenkey (fermented maize dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. She has done this for the past seven years. 

Esi uses her income to take care of herself, paying all household and other expenses. She is 70 years old. 

Esi will use the loan to purchase maize for the production of kenkey. With the new profits, she plans to expand her business.

Jaafar is a 31-year-old married man living with his wife and two children. He is from Lebanon. Since his marriage, Jaafar became the one responsible for his family and he had to work non-stop to support them properly financially. In 2008, he opened his own shop where he sells car accessories. His supplies are used in different types of cars. Today, he is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional car accessories in order to satisfy his customers' demands and provide them with top-quality services. Jaafar is very optimistic, ambitious, and always seeks the best; and this is the reason why he is doing a great effort in his professional career to progress and improve his finances.

Wilson, a 30-year-old married father of a three-year-old, has been operating a retail shop for a period of two years, earning an income of KES.10,000.  He is requesting his first loan of KES.10,000 from KADET LTD to purchase sugar, cooking fat, washing bar soaps, and powder. Wilson will reinvest the profits into his business, and hopes to own an expanded hardware shop in the future.

Mayyada is a 38-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and three siblings. All members of the family cooperate to maintain their respectable standard of living. Mayyada has owned a beauty salon since 2004, where she provides customers with beauty services such as hairdressing, make up, etc. Mayyada also has another job in order to supplement her income. Today, she is requesting to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase more beauty products and supplies. She intends to enhance her work operations by offering her clients high-quality services in order to satisfy their demands and keep them loyal to her shop. In the future, she plans to expand her business into other areas.

Married with no children, Ekua, who was educated through junior high, has been selling kenkey (fermented maize dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, for the past three years. Ekua is responsible for helping her husband, a farmer, in paying for household expenses. Whatever she has left, she saves for the future and reinvests in the business.

\r\n\r\nHer loan will be used to buy more maize for the production of kenkey. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

Single with one grown child, Ama has been a fish monger for three years now. She buys fresh fish from the market and fries it for sale in Esissamkrom, near Cape Coast. Ama is responsible for paying household/living expenses and helping pay her grandchildren's school fees.

\r\n\r\nWith this loan she will buy fresh fish to fry for sale. She hopes to use the resulting new profits to continue to support herself.

Ama  sells  footwear, sanitary towels, sauce pans and other cooking utensils in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Ama has gone to school through junior high school.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a carpenter. Ama has been in this business for 4 years. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy footwear, diapers, pots, pans, and cooking utensils to sell. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

Leon is a 28-year-old man from Lebanon. He’s single and lives with his parents and one working sibling. His father is the one responsible for their needs and covering the house expenditures. One of Leon’s greatest dreams is to be able to take some responsibilities off of his father by earning a good income. He has been working independently. He sells electrical generators upon clients’ requests. Through his job, he will be able to enhance his family’s life and get married as he has always dreamed of. To help him achieve his goals, he is requesting a youth loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase the needed spare parts for the generators he owns. With this opportunity, he will improve his business and therefore boost his revenues.

Fredrick is 37 years old and married with four children aged between 1 and 10 years old. He is a small-scale farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for ten years now, producing maize, tomatoes, beans and milk, which are all sold locally. He also operates a phone and battery charging business in the same town.

Fredrick has made a loan request of 62,400 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help him improve the livelihood of his family. He faces the challenges of diseases and lack of enough animal feed. 

He hopes to expand his dairy farming by acquiring additional dairy cows in the near future.

Efua is married and has six children. She sells banku and accra kenkey, food staples eaten with many dishes in Ghana, in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. She has been doing this for the past five years. Her husband is a farmer. Efua uses her income to pay for her children's school fees. Efua will use the loan to purchase maize and cassava, which is what kenkey and banku are made from. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to continue to support her children's education.

Farak is from Iraq. He is 41 years old, married and has five children, three of whom are employed. 

Farak is a farmer and owns a farm. He established his business in 1995 and now he has 3 employees. He built a good experience in this field and he is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

Farak is requesting a sum of $2,400 loan to install a fence around his farm and to buy fodder for his cattle. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

Efua is married and has three children. She operates a provisions store in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for six years. Her husband is a farmer.  Efua uses her income to pay her children’s school fees.  Efua will use the loan to purchase canned fish, canned tomatoes, cooking oil, and other items for her provisions store. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua  plans to invest in her children's education.

Mirva is a 33-year-old married woman from Lebanon, a place known for its friendly and welcoming people. She’s living with her husband and two children. Mirva and her husband cooperate together to bring added income and enhance their way of living. Her husband is serving in the Lebanese army. As for Mirva, this ambitious young woman started her own home business in 2009. Her job consists of restoring computers and installing software as well. She works with high professionalism and always seeks to better improve her knowledge. This is why she looks today to borrow a loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a laptop for her business. Definitely, this will boost her work and facilitate her business operations. Her future dreams are to be able to take bigger projects, and grow little by little.

Abena is a widow and has eight children. She sells limes and yams in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for twenty-two years. \r\n\r\nAbena uses her income to pay for all household expenses and pay for her children's school fees.  She will use this loan to purchase yams and limes to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Abena plans to help her children succeed in life.

Esi operates a provisions store in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Esi has received an Education Completed status.  She is married and has four children. Her husband is a sprayer for a local farm. \r\n\r\nEsi has owned her provisions store for four years now. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy foodstuff in bulk for sale. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

Kennedy is asking for a new loan to buy additional merchandise to sell such as bread, biscuits, soap, shampoo, and flour.  Thanks to his efforts where  he has successfully operated a motorcycle service, this has allowed him to have enough saving to open a retail shop. He says that he is still in his motorcycle business.\r\n\r\nKennedy is optimistic that if the loan is granted, he will be able to improve his store and attract more customers and buyers, which will improve his sales and profit. Since the previous loan, his living standards have greatly improved.

Aba is single and has two children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Aba sells sugar cane in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for two years. Aba uses her income for paying her children's school fees and other household/living expenses. Aba will use this loan to purchase more sugarcane to sell.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to support herself and her family.

Sarah  is married and has six children. She sells cosmetics, footwear, and sanitary towels in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has done for the past eight years. Her husband is a farmer. Sarah uses her income to pay for her children's school fees. Sarah will use the loan to purchase cosmetics, sanitary towels and footwear to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sarah plans to invest in her children's education.

Esi sells kenkey (fermented maize dough) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Esi has received a junior high school education.  She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a carpenter. \r\n\r\nEsi has been selling kenkey for the past three years. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for household expenses. Whatever she has left, she saves for the future and reinvests in the business. Her loan will be used to buy maize for the production of kenkey. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

Esi produces kenkey (fermented maize dough) for sale in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Esi has received a junior high school education.  She is married and has 7 children.  Her husband is a farmer. \r\n\r\nEsi has been selling kenkey for the past three years. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for household expenses. Whatever she has left, she saves for the future and reinvests in the business. Her loan will be used to buy maize for the production of kenkey. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

Jean Paul, rice farmer and member of the solidarity group RAMBANIBIKORWA, is married and 28 years old. He has only one child who is 2 years old. This child hasn't yet reached the age to go to school. He has no other dependents. He was born in Rwanda and his level of education is 6 years of primary school. He started collaborating with ACB Ltd. in 2012 and is on his first loan cycle.\r\n\r\nThe loan granted him will allow him to buy 85 kg of chemical fertilizers and to pay for manual labor. He doesn't expect any difficulty repaying this loan. His strategy to grow his farming is to request other loans in the future. For his farming business, he has the ambition of being the great rice farmer in his region. For his family, he is going to build a house and buy a cow.

Martine is a woman who lives in a neighborhood of the capital. A mother, she has been managing a call-box in a corner of the square for 2 years. Thanks to her dynamism and her audacity, she has acquired a large clientèle whose satisfaction she would like to continue to ensure. For this she is requesting a loan to acquire a larger quantity of communication credits and additional lines (SE, Camtel, etc.). The profits generated from this loan will allow her to increase her capital and to improve her living conditions.

Parfait Yves is a young Cameroonian of 27 years old. He has been running his business selling food from stall in his town's market for the past two years. Despite not having much experience, he has an extensive customer base.\r\n\r\nParfait Yves wants to use this loan to buy rice, cartons of tomatoes, soap, and spaghetti to increase his stock of merchandise. This will allow him to be better able to meet his customers' demand. His ambition is to open a large shop so that he can earn more income and better provide for his family.

María Gladys is 53 years old, married and has three adult children. She is from the city of León, a place located in the western area of the country. María Gladys' work is the sale of general merchandise, a business which consists of the purchase and sale of clothing such as pants, shirts, skirts, underwear, sleepwear and shoes. María Gladys has had this business for 17 years, and it is located in a permanent location in the city.

In her previous loans, she showed herself to be responsible by paying in a timely way. The purpose of the loan is to invest in working capital and stock her store with a variety of clothing articles. 

She is grateful for the help that the Kiva investors provide to low-income people, and to poor countries such as Nicaragua, so that people can have a decent livelihood.

Julito is a 38-year-old married man and a father three children from Talibon, Bohol. He has been engaged in the fishing business for more than five years now. Julito also runs a sari-sari or variety store business.\r\n\r\nJulito is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets and additional merchandise to sell in his store such as canned goods, snack foods, chips, soaps and toiletries. With this, he will be able to improve his daily earnings.  Julito hopes of making his business a success.

Janet is 20, single, and a mother of  a son who is 1 year of  age.  She stopped her education in the 10th grade. Janet lives in Jacob Town in a community called Amagashic.  Janet has a table at the community market where she sells flour, sugar, sardines, butter, eggs, and milk for the past seven years.  She is very proud of her business because with the profits she buys more goods and attends to her son needs. She received help from her father to start in this business, and learned to sell from her friend. She is requesting a loan to purchase more flour, eggs, sugar, sardines, and milk to increase her  sales, since she is the only source of income for her child. Her plan for the future is to further her education.

Ekua is married and has seven children.  She sells limes, salted fish, and cooking ingredients in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has been doing for three years. Her husband is a mason.  Ekua is responsible for paying school fees. \r\n\r\nEkua is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy bags of limes, fresh fish, and cooking ingredients in bulk. She hopes to use the profits to expand her business.

Ekua owns a chop bar (a small restaurant on the side of the road) in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. Ekua has received no formal education. She is divorced and has four children. Ekua has owned her chop bar for quite a few years now. She is responsible for taking care of her children (feeding, clothing, paying their school fees, etc.) as well as taking care of herself. She also pays for other household expenses such as utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients in bulk for the dishes she makes at her chop bar. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to continue to care for herself and her children.

Adwowa Suzzy is married and has three children. She has received no formal education. She sells second-hand clothing, kenkey (fermented corn and cassava dough that is wrapped in corn or banana leaves) and fish in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast, which she has been doing for two years. Her husband is a farmer. Adwowa Suzzy uses her income to pay her children's school fees. \r\n\r\nAdwowa Suzzy is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase bags of maize to produce kenkey and second-hand clothing to sell. With the  profits, Adwowa Suzzy  plans to expand her business.

Ma. Lifamy is a 27-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol, and a mother of a five year old daughter.  She and her husband have been engaged in the fishing business for almost three years now. This has been the source of their daily income.

Ma. Lifamy is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, hooks and buckets. With this, her husband will be able to catch more fish to sell in the market. 

In the future, Ma. Lifamy hopes of expanding their business and save money for reinvestment in their business.

Georges is a man who lives in a neighborhood of the capital. A father, he has been selling secondhand clothing in a market of the square for 8 years. Serious and dynamic, he has acquired for himself a large clientèle whom he would like to continue satisfying. For this he is requesting this loan to buy bundles of secondhand clothing. The profits that he generates from this loan will allow him to increase his capital and to cover the expenses to school his younger brother.

Daouda is a married man. He tends a store selling charcoal beside the market of his locale. He manages to generate income that allows him to meet some of the needs of his wife and three children. In order to strengthen his business, he is requesting a loan of 400,000f to buy 200 bags of charcoal.

Sarah, 45, is a mother of five children between the ages of 18 and 28. Four of her children live outside of her home and are independent. Only one of them stays with her at home, and is currently attending the university. Sarah stopped her education in the ninth grade. She resides with her husband at Jacob Town community. For the past ten years she has been selling coal, soft drinks, washing soap, bath soap, and many other items. One difficulty she faces is low sales during the rainy season. She makes a profit when she sells because her soft drinks are always cool and quench her customers' thirst. She also has what her customers need. She is requesting a loan to purchase more coal, soft drinks, and bath soap for the business. Her dream is to have a big store.

Maguatte is a married man, father to 5 children. He has been selling fabric for more than 20 years at the central market of his locale. With the help of his oldest son, he takes care of his family with the income generated by his business. He is requesting a loan of 350,000f to buy fabric in order to strengthen his business.

Maximiliana, age 34, has a beautiful marriage with Adrián, age 44.  The main additions to her family happiness are her two little daughters, Loida and Raquel.  It is for them that she devotes all of her work and effort.  They share their housing with relatives in a house made from adobe blocks.

Together with her life partner she engages in one of the most productive business activities in the area, the upkeep of organic cacao crops.  She is lucky to have some land that is very productive.  The quality of the soil contributes considerably to the final income that she gets.  Even so, in order to carry out good maintenance, she needs to follow a series of steps that she got from an institution in the field of cacao production.

A little while ago she reconditioned a large part of her crops in order to increase her land’s productivity.  She did this in the hope of getting greater profitability during the next season.

She plans to divide her land into two parts.  One part will be for pure, organic cacao.  It is for this part that she wishes to get cacao plants or seedlings and sacks of organic fertilizer.  She also needs to hire ten day workers to help with the planting and maintenance work.

She wishes to continue working with the same motivation as always.  This is because her objective is to increase, even more, the dimensions of her land buy purchasing other adjoining land that her neighbors plan to sell in the future.

Therefore, she needs to request 2,000 soles to buy seedlings, organic fertilizer, and to hire day workers to do the maintenance work on her cacao trees.

Luvuno, 48, lives with her family: husband and six children, and runs a store where she sells essential items such as basic grains, beverages, snacks and other products. The store is located in her home and is very well-known because she is a good salesperson and sells quality products at low prices. Luvuno is very dedicated to her work and is always looking for ways to prosper. She wants to stay ahead of the competition and invest in her business, but she is in need of capital. Therefore, she has requested a loan from Yehu to buy basic grains, instant products, sweets, bread, beverages, detergents, etc.\r\n\r\nLuvuno is able to make payments on her loan and has a good credit record. She is happy to receive the support and is confident she can pay back the loan on time, while giving her family the more fulfilling life that they deserve.

Eugenie is a 24-year-old woman from San Jose, Talibon, Bohol. She has been making a living through her sari-sari, or variety store, business for more than two years now. \r\n\r\nEugenie is asking for a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell in the market, such as canned goods, noodles, soap, toiletries, snack foods and chips. With this, she will be able to cater to more buyers and customers in her store, thus increasing her sales and income.

Analou is 37 years old and the mother of two young children who lives in Talibon, Bohol. She has earned a living for the last three years by running a sari-sari (or variety) store. She works hard to help her husband meet the needs of their family, and is asking for a loan to buy additional items to sell to her customers, including noodles, biscuits and other snack foods, candies, soda, soap and toiletries. This loan will allow her to attract  more customers into her store. In the future, Analou dreams of expanding her business and saving money to pay for the schooling of her children.

Belen is 52 years old, married and lives in Talibon, Bohol. She earns a living by selling drinks and other refreshments to people who live in her area. She has been in this business for almost 30 years and is applying for a loan to renovate her house. She will use the loan to buy cement, galvanized iron and nails. She will also use a portion of the loan to expand her business. Her goal is to earn enough money to meet her family's needs.

Maricela is a 20-year-old young woman.  She finished secondary school.  She's single and has a child, age 3.  It has been very hard for her to raise her child alone, but he has become an inspiration every day for her to get ahead in her job.

They live in Pastaza, a canton located in the province of the same name, in the Amazon region of the Republic of Ecuador.  The canton seat is the city of Puyo, located in the middle of the Amazon jungle in the west of Pastaza Province at 924 meters above sea level.  Demographically it's small, but there's a wide variety of sites preferred by Ecuadorian and international tourists, especially for ecological and extreme sports activities.

It's a city that grows economically every day because of commerce, livestock, agriculture, and tourism.  For this reason branches of banks and businesses have been established to make the most of the economic activity here.  In every business there are people who, faced with the lack of jobs, have not given up but rather have undertaken ideas for businesses to have a decent life and make their dreams come true.

Maricela started selling fruits and vegetables on foot when she was pregnant, about four years ago.  The possibility of continuing to study had disappeared, first because of her scarce financial resources and then because of the arrival of her child.  Nevertheless, in spite of the obstacles, she has gotten ahead with her life.  She works ten hours every day.  Her job consists of sorting, cleaning, and selling fruits and vegetables.  When she goes out to sell she stays in strategic locations in neighborhoods where housewives shop.  She learned this business from her parents and now manages it very well.  

In this season, tropical fruits such as plums and mangos appear in the market and are in high demand among her customers.  This is why Maricela needs a loan to stock her business with a quantity of these fruits and earn more income to give her son decent lifestyle.  She  also wants to maintain savings she can use in the future for her son's education, to give him a profession, which she herself didn't have the opportunity to have.
