Maricela is grateful to Fundación Alternativa, which adroitly and trustingly gave her the loan and the counseling to manage and carry out her business well.

Rosalina, 55, is a single mother of five children, who are independent, in the city of León. León is in the west of the country. Rosalind sells flip-flops for women, children and men, and shoes made of fabric. She’s been running this business for 19 years. The idea for this business came about as a result of needing a source of income to help out with expenses at home. Rosalind has shown herself to be responsible in repaying previous loans. The objective of this loan is to invest in business capital and stock her business with flip-flops for women, children and men, and shoes made of fabric. Rosalind is grateful for the help Kiva investors offer those of few resources -- and poor countries like Nicaragua -- so that they can have a dignified work environment.

Abdul is a Ghanaian artisan who makes hand-carved wood masks and sculptures. Abdul would like to invest in the purchase of wood and other materials that he uses to create his authentic African masks.

Abdul has been selling through NOVICA since 2010. This is his story:

"I always knew I wanted to paint but wasn't sure I could make a living out of it, so I looked into other fields too. I observed master carver Musa at his workshop for a period of time, then I picked up a log of wood and started carving out a mask as I had observed him doing. This surprised Musa, and he was willing to help me perfect the skill. I developed a love for this new art, and that's how I eventually became a master carver too! I am now able to share this skill with others who I teach to carve."  

"Thanks to the first micro-credit you granted me, I was able to bring in other wood carvers to assist me. Now, I'd like to stock up on materials to continue creating my masks. I thank you very much for your assistance with this micro-loan!"

Use the link below to view Abdul's hand-carved wood masks and sculptures on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/7253

Scovia is 25 years old. She has one child. 

She earns her income through farming. She grows maize, beans, coffee, cassava, sweet potatoes, and pineapples. She also keeps sheep, chickens and pigs. 

Scovia looks forward to becoming a community knowledge worker (CKW). As a CKW she will use the materials in her business-in-a-box (smartphone, solar charging set, and weighing scale) to disseminate vital agricultural information to the other members of her village, helping them to improve their crop yields and increase their incomes.  She needs to buy the business-in-a-box.

With the additional money that she will earn as a CKW, Scovia will invest in her farming business. She dreams of improving her standard of living.

Jesús, 41 years old, is a happy, idealistic and enterprising woman. She is separated from her partner and lives in the home of her parents together with her 8 year old child to whom she would like to give a good education and a better quality of life.

Jesús' work consists in the sale of fizzy drinks like beer of different brands and soda of various flavors. In the same way she sells sweets such as cookies, chocolates, caramels and fruit ice cream such as strawberry. coconut and pineapple, among other flavors. She sells her products in a locale inside the home of her parents. She has been running this business for 3 years. She comments that she started this business because of the lack of jobs and decided to generate her own income, to settle the expenses of the home. She counts on the help of her parents to prepare the various ice creams and for the purchase of the fizzy drinks. She considers her business profitable because her locale is located in a place that is much traveled by people from the whole city who consume the products that she sells. She comments that before starting this business she did not have the capital to start her own business. Thus she made the decision to take a loan and count on the capital help.

She hopes in the future to increase the production of her ice creams so that her business continues to grow. So this will be her loan number 3 with the MFP institution. She wants to continue being punctual with her payments, because things are going very well for her. As well her group motivates her so that she gets ahead with her business. With the amount requested, 1000 soles, she will invest in the purchase of fizzy drinks such as beer of different brands and sodas of various flavors. She will also buy sweets such as cookies, chocolates, caramels, etc. and will acquire fruits such as strawberries, coconuts and pineapples, among others.

Andrey is a vendor selling automotive spare parts for Russian-made cars, such as VAZ, Moskvitch and Volga at the automotive market. He is trustworthy, polite, responsible and hard-working. He regularly makes trips to buy merchandise for his stock. He has already taken out several loans, which allows him to maintain his business at a good level. This time he needs a loan in order to buy spare parts for VAZ cars: wires, spark plugs, lights, mats, fresheners, grills, etc.

Luz, 45, is a hardworking, enterprising woman.  She lives in her own house with her son who is attending school in Lima but is on vacation now. Luz’s work consists in selling cakes in various flavors like banana, chocolate, milk and orange.  She heads out to the Yarinacocha District market to sell her products every morning.  In the afternoons, she buys the various ingredients needed to make her delicious cakes.  She’s been in this business two years and is doing very well.  

Being alone and caring for her son’s wellbeing is what led her to start this activity and it’s become profitable because of the large number of customers she has.  She’s recommended for the good flavor and she also makes birthday cakes.  Prior to starting this activity, she used to sell groceries but didn’t do too well because of the location of her store which is why she decided to change her line of work.  She hopes in future to have a locale of her own that has a suitable environment for comfortable customer service.

Therefore, this will be her 3rd MFP loan and she is very grateful to the institution for letting her be part of this group that supports each other and also because she now has back-up capital for her business.  She will use the requested 1,200 to buy an electric oven to quicken production.  She will also stock up on flour, eggs and milk, among others.  This will make it possible for her to increase her income.

Rosalía, 37, is married and has no children.  She’s from León Department, a place located in the western part of the country.  León is noted for being a place with welcoming, helpful, hardworking people.  Rosalía’s economic activity is selling fruit and vegetables; she’s been in this business for 15 years.  Her daily routine is to work 8 hours going from place to place with a basket on her head selling her fruit and vegetables.\r\n\r\nShe has worked with the Fundación previously and has been responsible and made her payments as required.  The objective of this loan is to invest in working capital and stock her business with vegetables and fruit like oranges, tomatoes, peppers, papayas, pineapples, passion fruit, squash and chayote to be ready for the Christmas season this way.  Rosalía is grateful for the help Kiva lenders provide people of scarce resources and to poor countries like Nicaragua so that ways of earning a living with dignity are possible.

Xochilt, 30, is married and has two children who are 7 and 3 years of age and attend a local school.  She’s from the municipality of Nagarote, a place located in the western part of the country.  Xochilt’s economic activity is a hardware store located in a specific place in town; it consists in selling building materials and supplies like screws, pc tubing, wires, hinges, hammers, saws, wrenches, padlocks, pliers, shovels, wheelbarrows, etc.  She’s been in business 7 years and has been responsible with payments making them as scheduled.  The objective of the loan is to invest in working capital and tock her business to acquire more customers and higher income.  Xochilt is grateful for the help Kiva lenders provide people of scarce resources and to poor countries like Nicaragua so that ways of earning a living with dignity are possible.

María Mercedes is 44 years old and is a single mother of two children, ages 22 and 15. She is a native of León, Nicaragua, which is located in the western part of the country. She has made a living selling a variety of clothing, such as pants, suits and dresses, skirts, baby clothes and cosmetics, for 13 years. She works 10 hours a day, going from place to place with some 20 kilograms (44 pounds) of products to offer her regular and soon-to-be customers. She already has worked with this institution and has demonstrated responsibility making her payments on time. Her goal for this loan is to increase her working capital and to stock up on supplies to satisfy her customers' demands and take advantage of Christmastime, when sales increase. María Mercedes is grateful for the help Kiva lenders have provided to people with few resources in poor countries like Nicaragua so they have a means to dignified work.

Irma is 32 years old and the single mother of three children, ages 14, 10, and 6.  Irma is originally from Sauce, a place located in the northern area of the country.  Irma has been raising and selling pigs out of her home for six years.  She started this business because she needed a source of income to be able to help with the household expenses.\r\n\r\nIrma has proven her responsibility to repay her previous loans on time.  Her objective for this loan is to invest in her business by buying land and pigs to rise and sell.  Irma is grateful to the Kiva investors who help people with limited resources in poor countries like Nicaragua so that they will have sources of dignified work.

Ricarda is a hardworking woman.  She’s 44-year-old and a widow.  She’s a member of the “Los Encinos Ganadería” group.  She says they gave it this name because where they live oak trees are common and the ‘ganadería’ part is because most of the members work raising pigs, cattle and sheep.  She says that at her husband’s death, she’s had to take on her children’s care all by herself.  Back then, the three of them were students but now two of her daughters work in Mexico City as domestic employees and they help her support her son who is attending high-school with much sacrifice.

She’s been growing avocadoes for more than four years.  She says: “My husband left me a business that requires much hard work to care for but thanks to it I’m able to move my son, who is studying, forward since I was unable to study due to the lack of resources.  I have to devote myself to the land my late husband left me and thanks to the three loans I’ve gotten I’ve been able to move it forward even though I did neglect it somewhat when my husband died but now it’s in good condition.”  She says she’s asking for this loan to buy organic manure, fertilizer and insecticide to protect against the chilling frosts and hail storms that are common in winter.  

She says that she now has about 200 trees and hopes to continue planting more since her field is large; it’s almost two hectares and she wants to cover it entirely with this type of fruit.  She relates that when it’s harvest time she heads to the wholesale food market to sell them by the kilo since it’s more profitable to sell them that way.  She says the last few harvests have been good since her yields were quite large.  

Her greatest hope is that her youngest son will have a career so he will not have to suffer working in the fields and that her daughters can restart their schooling because she does not like their being so far from her.  She also wants to continue to buy avocado plants to continue growing them and leave a good business for her children.

The other group members’ names are Eulalia, María del Carmen, María Luisa, María, Alicia, María Angélica, Lorena, Rosario and Sandra and they will use their loans to buy fertilizer, organic manure for avocado farming, will buy feed and vaccines for pigs, fertilizer and manure for tomato crops and will buy merchandise to stock a grocery store.

Florencio is 48 years old and a native of a community called Valle Verde that is full of lush vegetation and where the majority of the inhabitants make a living in commerce. Florencio has worked with VisionFund for less than a year and the loans have helped his business go very well, so he is very content because he can make headway for his family. He belongs to a group called "Aves de Paraíso" ("Birds of Paradise"), which gave itself this name because their meeting place has a thicket of flowers of the same name that aren't very common in the region and are very beautiful. Florencio makes a living making ice creams and sorbets, with flavors like strawberry, coconut, vanilla, lemon, chocolate, apple, cheese, and many others, but these are the ones most requested by his customers, who are mostly children and youths since he sells outside of a elementary and high school in his community. He says that he is requesting the loan to purchase supplies to make his sorbets, such as milk, food dyes, fruits, ice, rock salt, sugar, cones and napkins. He says that he gets up very early to make his sorbets because they need to be ready by the time the children leave school. First he grounds the fruit or adds vanilla to the milk. The trick is with the ice cream. He says that he puts ice and rock salt inside a big pot so it doesn't melt too quickly, and then he puts another metal canister inside with the ingredients and slowly churns it as the ice cream freezes. He says he does this every day so he can take his delicious and rich ice creams to the school. He says that he started this job because he could not find stable work and a friend told him how to make ice cream, so he decided to take up the work. He says, "I enjoy what I do because I already have my customers, and I'm my own boss and have time to be with my family." He has four children who are in elementary and high school, and for this reason he works very hard to provide them with the best and so they don't lack anything in regards to their education. His goal is to purchase a newer moto-tricycle, because the one he has is deteriorating and every time he punctures a tire he has to change it for a new one and pay for it in small payments. The other nine members are Isela, María Remedios, Cirenia, Socorro, Yaquelin, Marcela, María Llasmin, Sandra and Maribel. They invested their loans in ingredients to make tortillas; in the purchase of items for their grocery store; construction materials that they sell; sweets and different savories that they sell; sweets and fritters to sell; seasonal fruit and vegetables; chicken to raise and later sell, etc.

Mateo, 70, is a farmer. He is married and lives in Sololá. He has seven children. Four of his six sons are married, and his daughter is married too. They work independently.Two of his sons still live with him and help him in the fields. He works in agriculture, growing potatoes, onions, carrots, and green beans on some parcels of land that he has a few kilometers from his home. He learned this trade from his father, because he did not have the chance to study in school.\r\n\r\nBefore he had his own crop, he worked with his sister, where he perfected and gained more experience in his work. Now he has had his own crop for 25 years, and he has had acceptable earnings. This is why is applying for a loan of Q 4,000.00 so that he can buy potato seeds and fertilizer. He will plant it and harvest it and improve his earnings and his family's quality of life. With his earnings, he dreams of buying another parcel and being able to expand his crop and earn more money in the future.

María is 62 years old. She grew up in a poor family, so she only managed to get through elementary school. She separated from her husband a number of years ago, which was something very painful in her life and represented an obstacle in pursuing her business. María raises her 13-year-old grandson because of some problems the boy's mother has with her work schedule. They live in Quinindé, a hamlet in the province of Esmeraldas that provides a number of cities in Ecuador with bananas, cacao, coffee, palm and forest products, and the majority of the inhabitants make a living in commerce. That has become even more the case since the roads into town were expanded, allowing a lot of commercial movement, especially on the weekends when merchants of all kinds go out to offer their products at the area flea markets. Tourism is another important industry because the natural ecosystem offers a wide variety of places to see waterfalls, rivers and forests full of flowers and animals. Every family works hard and looks for new ways to improve their quality of life, so one could call this an enterprising place. María started her seamstress shop a number of years ago. She learned from experience and little by little improved her craft, and now she is an expert and spends between eight and 10 hours a day making clothing for all occasions, according to the demands of her customers. She is requesting the loan to purchase distinct fabrics and in this way she can offer a wider variety of styles. She hopes this will increase her income, since her goal is to have a big seamstress shop making clothes to sell all over the country, and with that she will be able to pay for her grandson's education until he becomes a professional. María has joined with friends who also need to expand their businesses, as is the case with Jofre, who makes a living raising and selling pigs. Juilo raises pigs and sells fish, while Cruz sells pigs and chickens. Another María raises and sells chickens. Teresa, Verónica and another María sell clothing via catalog, same as Sonia, who despite a physical disability also sells jewelry. Patricio and Angela have grocery stores.

Dulamsuren is 52 years old and lives with her son in their four-room house in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.  She has been working as an education manager for 6 years in a special training school for children with dysphasia.  Her eldest son works in Korea as a contract worker.  Her younger one is a journalist, working in television as a sports commentator.  Dulamsuren rents two of her rooms to students from the countryside.  \r\n\r\nIn the future, once she is retired, Dulamsuren wants to establish her own school for children with dysphasia.  So she initially planned and built her house to meet standards in order to bring this dream to life.  Due to the lack of money, she is approaching her goal little by little and doing certain things each year.  This time Dulamsuren is planning to solve the heating problem of the house.  Her loan will be used to insulate the house walls on both sides and to install an electric heating system that emits less carbon dioxide into atmosphere.  By doing this she can reduce heating expenses and, at the same time, save the environment.

Raymond is a 43-year-old man who has been selling basic supplies at a local market, in town, for just one year.  Although it has not been long since he got involved in this business, Raymond has already built a very large customer base.  This is why he often has a hard time meeting all of his customers' demand. 

He would like to use his loan to buy flashlights, locks and rechargeable lamps, which will help him to strengthen his inventory.

His ambition is to save enough money to build some rooms that he intends to rent.

Editha is 59 years old and widowed with 13 children.  She is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines, and has been doing so for 18 years.  She has borrowed from NWTF 17 times in the past to sustain this business.  \r\n\r\nEditha requested a loan of 12,000 (PHP) to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.  In the future, Editha would like to save enough money to improve the financial stability of her family.

Elena works as a market vendor and sells women's clothing such as slacks, pants,  sweaters, jackets, etc.  Her retail outlet is ideally located, which is good for business.  Elena is a responsible, honest and punctual client who has always repaid her loans on time.  She currently needs a loan to buy women's clothing in bulk quantities.

Remelyn is 28 years old and married with three children. Two of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Remelyn has a tricycle transport business in the Philippines. Remelyn requested a 20000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy spare parts for her tricycle transport.

Remelyn has been in this business for three years. In the future, Remelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

Apec Al Ouma GE 3 Tivaouane Diaksao is a credit group made up of seven women who all stick together as members of the same association, live in the same area, and are evolving in the same business sector running their own businesses.  They are represented by a woman named Oumou, who is pictured seated to the left dressed in yellow.  She is a married woman who sells fabrics, ready-to-wear items, linens, and incense.  She has 11 years of experience running her business.  

The profits that she takes from her business enable her to contribute to the day-to-day expenditures of her household. She always begins her workday at 8:00am and finishes at 1:00pm. She has joined with a UIMCEC [field partner] office, where she has come to ask for a loan to bolster her current account.  

Her goal is to increase her profits so that she can be prepared to cover the cost of school fees for her children, as well as improve the quality of food for her family.  She hopes to one day acquire her own store, and to travel to countries with stronger commercial backbones so she can import goods.

Merlita, age 49, is married with six children. She is from Taguitic, Kapatagan, Lanao Del Norte. To make a living, Merlita raises hogs for sale. Merlita has been engaged in her business for six years and earns 6,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) a month. Merlita joined GDMPC in 2008. \r\n\r\nMerlita is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase feeding supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Ana started her business a year ago with her own working capital. Now she is applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business by buying beer, oil, coffee, sugar and petrol to sell.

She has three children, and her husband is very helpful in doing business because he is also a businessman.
 
Her business place is very crowded and many people come to buy. She is making a good income. She lives in her simple house made of palm branches and zinc for the roof. She wants to make her kiosk into a big store in the future. None of her children are in the school; they are all underage.

Sarah is a 30-year-old single mother living in Masindi, Uganda. Sarah sells vegetables, and with the proceeds she has been able to provide basics for her child. She started her business 12 years ago. Like most good mothers she hopes of her child being educated to attain a degree.\r\n\r\nSarah faces a challenge of the perishable nature of her goods, and her dream is to buy a refrigerator and diversify her business to include general merchandise. Sarah is requesting a loan to buy general merchandise, such as soap and salt, to sell.

Nino is 43 years old. She lives in the Chkhorotsku District with her husband and two children. 

Nino had requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected every time because of her low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from their agricultural business. In particular, they have 0.5 hectare of land, where 150 nut trees and 5 persimmon trees are grown. It brings hardly enough for food to a four-member family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Nino has requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. 

The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits, with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” due to their low incomes. 

With the received credit, Nino will begin trading with clothing. Nino plans to purchase clothing from wholesalers and resell it among her villagers. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will increase the income and will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

Leonard is a twenty-four-year-old farmer in Litein county in Kenya where he has been practicing mixed farmeing for the past three years, producing milk and vegetables which he sells at the market in his local area. He has a motor bike which he uses to offer transport services as an additional source of income.

He is requesting a 60,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a chaff cutter that will help him to harvest more feed for his dairy cows and hence more milk production and more income that will boost his livelihood. He aspires to buy another motor bike to expand his business in the next five years.

High competition is his major challenge in farming.

Grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for the support it offers to farmers.

Teresita, 48, is married with 4 children, living in Poblacion, Aurora. In order to add income in the family, she manages a retail business which started 3 years ago. She usually gets 3,000 PHP per month. With the help of GDMPC microcredit, Teresita is able to procure more bottles of drinks to sell because of the amount of 7,000 PHP rendered to her. She joined GDMPC in 2011. Someday, she’s hoping for much greater revenue for business expansion.

Claire Leonce Martine is a young Cameroonian woman.  At 26 years old, she is engaged as well as the mother of four children, all of whom attend school.  For two years now, she has been doing business sewing at home.  She sews to-order and then delivers in bulk to retailers.  She works alone and has only one machine at her disposal. With this loan she would like to buy two sewing machines and rolls of fabric, since she aspires not only to settle in the city, but also to begin training for her sewing.

Faridah is aged 28, a single mother of two children living in Masindi, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after them solely rests on her since her former husband got another family and her desire is to educate her children up to the University. She has a food production business and works 10 hours a day. She started the business 13 years ago after dropping out of school due to lack of school fees. She is a market vendor and is challenged by high transport costs and the rainy season while her business desire is to rent business premises and diversify her business to include a retail shop. Faridah is requesting a loan to buy food items such as beans and maize to sell.

Oleg sells bicycles and spare parts at the market "1000 Trifles". He also sells wheelbarrows, sleds, shovels and other items. This time, Oleg needs a loan to stock up on spare parts for bicycles: spokes, tires, wheel hubs, saddles etc.\r\n\r\nOleg is responsible and disciplined, and pays back his loans on time. His retail spot is located advantageously. He has a number of established, tested, and reliable suppliers, and stocks quality merchandise, which serves well to attract regular customers.

The Houenoussou 3 Group is made up of 28 people who live in the same area.  This is the first time that the group has asked for a loan via ALIDé, which they are doing in order to raise the levels of their businesses.  The representative of the group, named Faissathou, is pictured with his hand raised.  Faissouthou is 64 years old and lives in Bénin.  He is married to Christian.  The couple has five children, all in school, of whom two are still dependents.  The couple work togther to provide for the various household expenses.  Faissathou did not go to school.\r\n\r\nFor thirty years, Faissathou has been selling jewelry in his region.  He buys his stock at a market in Bénin.  In pursuit of customer satisfaction and to grow his turnover and profit, Faissathou is asking for his first loan through ALIDé along with his group.

José, age 47, is a determined and kind man. He lives in his own home with his common-law partner Ameli, who manages a beauty salon and has been doing very well. They have three children (ages 22, 15, and 4) and want to provide them a good education.

José’s work involves selling spare parts for motorized vehicles such as spark plugs, chains, bearings, and other items. He also performs vehicle repairs and is able to fix engines, bearings, electrical systems, and many other things. José performs his work in a shop located inside of his home. He started in this line of work at the age of 12 by helping out at his uncle’s repair shop. At that point, he knew that this would be the career he wanted to pursue. José has been doing this type of work for 35 years and now he has the help of his son, who works as his assistant and is also practicing the trade at an institute. He says that his business is profitable because he only had to make an initial investment – the purchase of the necessary tools for repairing vehicles. Prior to pursuing this profession full-time, José thought he would start a business of buying and selling timber. However, he did not know anything about this trade, so he ended up getting swindled and losing all of his capital. After that, he made the decision to return to his previous skillset of repairing vehicles since that is what he knows best. In addition, he would have the opportunity to work at home and be with his family. He hopes to improve his shop in the future by acquiring a lathe and a grinder.

José is requesting a loan of 2,500 PEN so that he can buy spare parts such as spark plugs, chains, bearings, and other items. He will buy these items wholesale in the city of Lima, which will help him increase his earnings.

Alma is from Lantungan, Aurora. She is 50 years old. She is married and has 2 kids. To make a living, she makes and sells snack food. She has been engaged in her business for 3 years and earns about 3,000 PHP a month from this business. In 2011, she joined GDMPC. Alma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP. This loan will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

Candida has been involved in business activities since 2007. She started with her own working capital of $ 200. She is aged 25, and has two children, one of whom is in school. Her husband is a business man. She has a kiosk in front of her house. She is taking a loan from Tuba Rai Metin to buy additional supplies to sell including cigarettes, candles, oil, books, pens and rice. She hopes to live a better life and give her children a good education.

Rogelio, single, is 26 years old and lives in Solinog, Calamba. Rogelio is operating a general store, selling a variety of products to local community members to earn a living. He has been doing this for two years and every month he earns PHP 3,000 from this work. \r\n\r\nHe has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase new items such as candies, milo (brand of malted milk), shampoo, soaps etc. Recently, Rogelio joined GDMPC. Rogelio hopes to improve the general living conditions of his family.

Tengiz is 39 years old. He lives in a small village of Tetritskaro District with his wife and two children. Tengiz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from the dairy business. In particular, they have two milk cows, whose milk is used in dairy products. Tengizi’s wife produces cheese and yogurt and sells it at a good price with milk. It is hardly enough income for food for a four-member family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence-poor category. 

Tengiz requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit Tengiz will purchase a minibus. After purchasing a minibus, Tengiz plans to go to the capital city with his minibus and sell milk, yogurt and cheese there. He will be able to transport more dairy products with the minibus and this will significantly increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

Susana lives in Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. Aged 45, she is a widow and has three children. For the last seven years, she has made a living through raising corn for sale. She earns about 3,000 PHP a month. \r\n\r\nIn 2009, Susana joined GDMPC. She is applying for a loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue she earns as a result of this loan to continue improving her business.

Epripras is a widow who has four children. She is 62 years old, and lives in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Epripras owns and operates a coco plantation, harvesting and selling coconuts to earn a living. She has been doing this for six years. She makes PHP 8,500 a month from her business. \r\n\r\nShe has requested a loan of PHP 33,000 to pay for the cost of farm maintenance. Epripras joined GDMPC in 2010. Epripras wants to save the revenue generated from the business as a reserve for future emergencies.

Olivia's group is composed of two hardworking women. Olivia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Olivia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, in which she sells flour, sugar, soap, and cooking oil.

To help expand her business, Olivia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities like soda, sugar, Splash brand juice, and cooking oil for resale. This will help Olivia to generate greater profits and pay for her medical bills and her child. Olivia hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. She makes sure that she works hard to see that she educates her child.

Olivia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Prudence's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Prudence is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kamwenge in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Prudence has been working hard to manage her small business selling clothes. 

To help expand her business, Prudence has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to resell and will help Prudence to generate greater profits and pay for her medical bills and her children. Prudence hopes that, in the future, she will be able to educate her children up to the university level and also buy a plot of land. 

Prudence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Parsiano is 34 years old and lives in the town of Lyantonde in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children, with 3 of them currently in school. In the past 12 years, Parsiano has been working hard to manage his bar and restaurant, which sells variety of different drinks such as lemonade and beer . 

To help expand his business, Parsiano has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to obtain more stock of drinks such as lemonade for resale, and will help Parsiano to generate greater and increased profits to live a better life. Parsiano hopes that in the future he will be able to raise funds to make a bigger bar . 

Parsiano is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Parsiano who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Herbert is 47 years old and lives in the town of Lyantonde in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 20 years, Herbert has been working hard to manage his farming, which trades in milk products like ghee, milk and skins. 

To help expand his business, Herbert has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to get more animals for the business and will help Herbert to generate greater profits, sell milk products and buy all the necessities for the family. Herbert hopes that in the future he will be able to have a bigger farm. 

Herbert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Herbert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Enock is 48 years old and lives in the town of Mbarara in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 6 years, Enock has been working hard to manage his grocery store, which trades in groceries. 

To help expand his business, Enock has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to procure more items for the store such us sugar, salt and bread to be sold and will help Enock to generate greater profits and increase on business sales. Enock hopes that in the future he will be able to become self-reliant. 

Enock is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Enock who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Hadiya is 42 years old and lives in the town of Mbarara in the Mbarara region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 6 years, Hadiya has been working hard to manage her grocery store, which sells sugar, rice, posho (maize flour)	and fish. 

To help expand her business, Hadiya has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities such as rice and maize flour for the store and will help Hadiya to generate greater profits and help the borrower increase sales from the stock, hence improving living standards. Hadiya hopes that in the future she will be able to own her own supermarket. 

Hadiya is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hadiya who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Mastulla is 49 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is widowed and has two children.  For the past 4 years, Mastulla has been working hard to manage her salon, which works on women and men's hair with a video library that rents out video tapes and cds. 

To help expand her business into a big unisex salon, Mastulla has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a dryer,a steamer and video tapes for renting out to her customers and will help Mastulla to generate greater profits and increase her daily sales.  Mastulla hopes that in the future she will be able to own a unisex salon. 

Mastulla is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mastulla who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Christine's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Christine is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mukono, in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, and 1 of them is currently in school. For the past 2 years, Christine has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fast foods. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 400000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cassava, Irish potatoes and cooking oil that will be fried for resale, and will help Christine to generate greater profits and expand the business. Christine hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a big hotel. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Emmanuel Ratisbonne is a 40 year old man, engaged to be married, and father of two children, both of whom attend school. He has a stand in a neighborhood of the city from which he has been selling candy, cookies, crackers and cigarettes for the past year. He also offers his customers long-distance phone call services and sells communication credits. He manages his business well thanks to the accounting and business skills he acquired in school. He is asking for a loan in order to purchase more merchandise to sell (candy, cookies, motor oil and cooking oil) but also to purchase additional communication credits so he can increase his volume of sales. He hopes to save his profits not only to spend on the wedding, but also to open a real store.

A married man and the father of four children, Ababacar lives in a small village in Senegal. For the past six years his commercial activity has been increasing. He owns a motorized vehicle that serves as a method of shared transportation for passengers, providing him with regular income that he spends on taking care of his family's needs in addition to the maintenace of this vehicle. He is a member of the UIMCEC branch near his home. He is asking for a loan of 400,000 FCFA (approximately 800 USD) that he will spend on the maintenance of his vehicle. This loan will help him increase his revenues and allow him to continue to cover the costs of his family, a responsiblity which he bears, as head of the household. He hopes to someday own a taxi company that would have 3 or 4 vehicles.

Marie Michelle is a young 26 year old Camerounian woman, married and the mother of three children aged between 2 and 6 years old, two of whom attend school. For the past two years, she has been making and selling clothes from her home. She sews based on orders and then delivers bulk quantities to wholesale retaliers. She works on her own and owns only one machine. She is asking for a loan in order to purchase an additional sewing machine, more cloth, and other sewing materials so she can make clothes and pillows to be sold at a later date, rather than always relying on customer orders. She hopes to one day open a sewing workshop.

Julieta is a 64-year-old resident of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga. Julieta supported her two children's needs from the little amount of 5,000 PHP she earns monthly from her gardening business for 20 years. However in 2010 she became a member of GDMPC, and she applied for a loan at GDMPC micro finance of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Julieta wants to expand her business one day.

Rosita is 33 years old. She is married and she has eight children; three of them are in school. She has a kiosk in front of her house. To improve her kiosk, she is requesting a loan to buy more stock to keep in her kiosk. She has been doing business for the past three years. She lives in her simple house with her family. She hopes to build a good house and make her business bigger in the future.

Habibullo lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. He is 41 years old, divorced, and has two children. Habibullo has been engaged in retail activity for the past ten years. Presently, he operates his own grocery store, and has plans to develop and expand his business. He is taking this loan to purchase necessary food products and gifts in order to increase his sales volume and expand the assortment of his merchandise prior to New Year.

Altansukh is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in their house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. 

Altansukh is a Buddhist monk, and since 1991, he has been helping people who are in need of support in spiritual or psychological matters. His wife helps him and manages his back issues. His daughter studies at a university, and the other two attend a secondary school. 

Altansukh has principles, and helping people is his main goal. He never charges anyone; that is strictly established. His family lives on endowment that people give. 

Altansukh is asking a 2,000,000 MNT loan to pay for his daughter’s tuition.

Estephanie Jane of Sinian, Baliangao helps support her family through her charcoal-making business. She’s 22 years old and married with one child and she tries her best to earn on her own. For two years, she has managed this business and earns about 3,500 PHP per month. Now, she’s needs to pay for the labor cost in charcoal making. She joined recently and thanks GDMPC micro finance for the loan of 7,000 PHP they provided to her. \r\n\r\nEstephanie Jane desires to improve her business in the future.

Tamila is 29 years old. She lives with her husband in Kutaisi District, West Georgia. Tamila requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the small income earned by Tamila’s husband, working as cook locally. That makes in total 250 Laris per month. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Tamila requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Tamila will sell clothing and bed-clothes. She plans to purchase clothing and bed-clothes from wholesalers and resell the goods locally. That will increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

Inga is 46 years old and lives with her daughter and son-in-law in the Kutaisi district of West Georgia. She has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times in order to start up a family business, but without any success. Her loan requests were rejected every time because of the family's low income and poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is Inga's work as a local cook. She makes a total of 250 laris per month, which is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo's assessment, the family belongs to the "subsistence poor" category. 

Inga has requested a loan from Credo for a family business start-up. Her loan request was approved under the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides credit for business start-ups, offering favorable loan conditions to poor rural people who do not have access to credit because they are regarded as “high risk borrowers”. Using the loan, Inga will set up a new business trading in clothing and bed-clothes. She plans to purchase clothing from wholesalers and resell it locally. This new business initiative will significantly improve the income and living conditions of the family.

Gregoria, 53, resident of Dinas, Sinacaban. Gregoria supports her 4 children with the small amount of 4,000 PHP.  She makes this amount monthly from her gardening business of 5 years. This year she joined GDMPC and she has applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Gregoria wants to expand her business one day.

Ahmad is from Iraq. He is a youthful client only 19 years old. He is single and lives with 4 family members. He and his father are the only providers for the family.

Ahmad owns a store that rents kitchenware. He established his business in 2009 and now he has one employee. He has built good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.
He is requesting a sum of $2,400 to rent a warehouse. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide better life conditions for his family.

Rodel is married with 2 children. Rodel is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. Rodel manages a gardening business to earn a living. He has been doing this for 3 years. Every month he earn 4,500 php from this work. He has requested a loan of 10,000 php to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizer. Rodel joined GDMPC this year. Rodel hopes to double his income from the business.

Elizabeth sells ground pepper, spices, and shrimp at Elmina market which she has done for some years now. She is married with 4 children.  She uses her income to assist her husband in paying their children’s school fees.  Elizabeth will use her loan to purchase ground pepper, spices, and  shrimp. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

Joeniel is 24 years old and is a married entrepreneur of San Roque, Panaon. He has 2 children and earns a living from his transport service business. He began this business almost 3 years ago and he earns 4,000 PHP a month. To improve his business, he has asked to borrow 8,000 PHP from GDMPC Micro Credit which he joined in 2011.  The loan is to obtain accessories and tires. He’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding his business.

Rosalina is 28 years old and married. She sells secondhand clothes. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy more clothes to sell. She has been operating this business for the past year.\r\n\r\nShe earns a good income. She lives in the city next to a garden, and many people come to buy things from her kiosk.

Grace sells groundnut charcoal at the Elmina market, which she has done for some years now. She is married with three children. She uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of their home.  \r\n\r\nGrace will use her loan to purchase bags of groundnuts to make charcoal for sale. With the new profits she earns, she will expand her business.

Regina sells gari (tapioca), rice, sugar, canned tomatoes and canned fish in Emissa Krom, near Cape Coast. She has gone to school through junior high school. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a mason.  \r\n\r\nRegina has been selling canned fish, canned tomatoes, gari (tapioca), rice and sugar for three years. She is responsible for caring for her young children and saving money to pay for their eventual schooling. Her loan will be used to buy boxes of canned fish and tomatoes, bags of rice, sugar and gari. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

Lonah is a member of the Upendo Group in the Lugari district. She is pictured with 20 One Acre Fund farmers, including 15 women and five men. Lonah is standing on the right with her hand raised. Lonah is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 long rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizers, and to grow enough food for the family.

Last year, Lonah harvested eight bags of maize on a 3/4-acre of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 long rains season. She hopes that her profits can be used to buy livestock as an investment for the future. 

Lonah's group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 long rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 10 acres of maize and sorghum.

Pascal is 52 years old and married with five children between 2 and 17 years old. He sells various foods such as beans, potatoes, rice, sorghum, etc. His business is well-organized and he works from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. every day of the week except on Saturday. 

Pascal is the leader of the group called "ABADATENGUHA C12063" in the local language. In the photo, he is raising his hand. Pascal has five years of experience in this work. Some members of the group sell boutique items while others sell food. The leader of the group also sells food. 

Pascal has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy various goods such as beans, potatoes, rice, sorghum, etc. for resale in his store. With the profits he earns, he plans to save enough money for his future and to reinvest in his business.

Susan is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a dried fish business in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 15 years.  She earns additional income from a general store. \r\n\r\nSusan is requesting a loan from NWTF for 28,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional fish for her making dried fish.  She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. In the future, she hopes to save money to expand her business.

Jabbar is 41 years old, married, and has five children, one of whom is employed.  He is from Iraq. Jabbar owns a store selling tools and supplies, which he has been doing since 2009. He has one employee. He has good experience in the field and is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.\r\n\r\nJabbar is requesting a loan for $3,000, which he will use to make new shelves and a new roof for his store. He hope to expand his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

Hafisa is a 43 year old, married, and has four children.  She lives in Masindi, Uganda.  Hafisa bakes bread, which she has been doing for twelve years. With the proceeds, she has been able to buy land and pay school fees for her children.\r\n\r\nHafisa is requesting a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat and cooking oil. She has a challenge of the high cost of raw materials. She hopes to educate her children up to the university level and open another outlet.

Salama is a group of 20 farmers in Lugari District. The group has nine women and 11 men.    The 2013 long rains season will be Geoffrey’s first season with One Acre Fund.  He joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed, fertilizer, the best input prices, and reliable input delivery. He hopes to grow enough food for his family and use his increased profits to send his children to school.

Geofrey described his harvest last year as good, but hopes he can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer.  He plans to spend the money that he earns from his next harvest on sending his children to school, repairing his home, buying livestock, and perhaps investing in another business. 

During the 2013 long rains season, each group member will receive ½ acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Geofrey’s group will receive 10 acres worth of inputs on credit. Geoffrey is on the right of the photo with his hand raised.

Margalita is from the Chokhatauri district. She is 34 years old, married and lives with her family: her husband and parents-in-law. Her husband works as a police officer and her mother-in-law is a doctor locally. Both of family members get monthly salaries. Besides, Margalita’s father-in-law is provided with a retirement pension. 

Margalita has requested loan from local financial institutions several times for a business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time because of lack of experience in new business, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.

Her loan request was approved in the frames of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the requested loan, Margalita will start up a dental clinic locally. She will purchase dental equipment and operative supplies to satisfy the professional needs of the dentists that will be working at her clinic. Margalita hopes her business will be profitable because of the price range and well qualified dentists. This will increase her income and the family members will be able to increase their spending to satisfy their daily needs, in order to improve their living conditions.

Mary Cris is 22 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 11,500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, spices, etc.

Mary Cris has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from selling coconut shells.

Mary Cris aspires to save money to expand her business.

Since she received her Kiva loan, Luz has improved in her work and in her family life.  She has been able to offer a diverse set of designs, better finishing touches to her home, and a much larger and more open patio where she can share time with her family. 

At present, she is applying for a new Kiva loan that she will use to buy raw materials and sewing supplies in large volume.  She is preparing for the New Year season, a time when her number of customers grows; everyone wants to see themselves looking elegant and well-dressed in their clothing.

This is what she will do with her loan if her application is successful.  Her message to Kiva is the following: "gratitude to all of the financial backers because little by little, I have improved, as much in my business as in my home."

Jacklyne is pictured on the right with her hand raised among her New-Hope Group members. The 20 of them, 11 women and 9 men, are farmers in the Lugari District. Jacklyne is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 long rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer.

Jacklyne described her harvest last year as poor. She hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer she will be able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. 

Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies, buy a motorbike and invest in business. 

For the 2013 long rains season, Jacklyne’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

Wema Group is located in the Lugari District. It is a group of 16 women and four men led by Janex, pictured on the right with her hand raised. Janex is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 long rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, access the best input prices and assurance of reliable input delivery. She hopes to grow enough food for the family and to use increased profits to send her children to school.\r\n\r\nJanex described her harvest last year as good, but she hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, repairing her home, buying livestock and perhaps investing in another business. During the 2013 long rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Janex's group will receive 10 acres worth of inputs on credit.

Jane is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Jane has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice that will be sold. This will help Jane to generate greater profits and buy basic needs at home like food. Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business. 

Jane is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

Eva is 47 years old. She lives with her husband and two children in Khelvachauri District, West Georgia. Her husband works as an artisan locally and gets a monthly income. Her economic activity is a newly started business. In particular, a grocery store. 

Eva requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for further developing her business, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of lack of experience in her business, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.
  
Her loan request was approved within the frames of new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Eva will cover the costs of purchasing her stock of basic groceries for starting a grocery store. She plans to work hard and increase the turnover in her business gradually. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family. 

With this loan, her family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, in the event they need it.

Kosay is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and has one child. Kosay is the only provider of the family.

Kosay owns a small restaurant/café. He established his business in 2003 and now he has two employees. He has built a good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a loan of $2,000 to paint his restaurant/café and to install a new floor. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

Jamiila is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Jamiila has been working hard to manage her small food stall, which sells raw food. 

To help expand her business, Jamiila has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food such as matooke (steamed green bananas) and sweet potatoes for resale. It will help Jamiila to generate greater profits and take care of herself and buy basic needs for the family. Jamiila hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business than what she has now. 

Jamiila is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

Allen's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Allen is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past two years, Allen has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Allen has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale, and will help Allen to generate greater profits, which will be used to buy food at home. Allen hopes that in the future she will be able to earn more, which will help take care of her family. 

Allen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

Nadia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Nadia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Nadia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap. This will help Nadia to generate greater profits and expand her business into a bigger shop and to buy more items for the shop, which will increase her capital. Nadia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Nadia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Ismaeil is from Iraq. He is 46 years old, married and has four children. Ismaeil is the only provider of the family. He owns a small grocery store selling soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents and snacks. He established his business in 2006. He is well known in the surrounding area and has an excellent reputation.\r\n\r\nHe is requesting an $1,800 loan to install a new floor in his mini-market and to increase his inventory. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

Hadijja is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past year, Hadijja has been working hard to manage her small food stall, which sells fruits. 

To help expand her business, Hadijja has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits like tomatoes and will help Hadijja to generate greater profits and buy basic needs at home like food. Hadijja hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a bigger food stall. 

Hadijja is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Aby is a married woman who lives in a town in Senegal. She has nine children.

Aby shifted into the retail sector over six years ago. She sells fabric and bags. She is a member of a branch of the UIMCEC, and she is seeking a 300,000 frs loan in order to buy fabric and bags to resell. She also wants to diversify the products that she sells by incorporating other feminine items.

Her objective is to increase her profits so that she can better care for her family and cover her own personal needs. Her dream is to have a big store where she can sell fabric, scarfs, and bags.

Fulgence, a member of the Duterimbere Nymgn solidarity group, is 32 years old and married. He is a rice farmer and the father of two children, the eldest of whom is eight and the youngest three. One of his children is in school. He has no other people to take care of.

Fulgence was born in Rwanda, and completed six years of primary school. This is his third loan cycle since joining ACB S.A. The two previous loans have been repaid in full.

Fulgence will use this loan to buy 70kgs of chemical fertilizer, and the remainder will be used to pay his labourers. He does not foresee any difficulty with repaying this loan. His strategy to ensure the growth of his farming business is to work as hard as possible. His ambition is to purchase a cultivator, and he would also like to build a house for his family.

Philemon is a member of the Dusangirimirimo solidarity group. His main business is rice farming, and this is the business for which he is seeking finance. He is also a small-scale trader.

Philemon is 46 years old, married and the father of six. His eldest child is 20, and the youngest three. Five of his children are in school, and he has no one else to look after. He was born in Rwanda and completed eight years of primary school.

Philemon started working with ACB S.A. in 2011 and is currently on his third loan cycle. The previous two loans were correctly repaid.

With the loan requested, he will purchase 40 kilograms of chemical fertilizer. The remainder will be used to pay his labourers. He does not foresee any difficulties repaying this loan, and will work as hard as possible to expand his agricultural business. 

Philemon's ambition is to become the region’s largest rice grower. At home, is aims are to educate his children and ensure they are well looked after.

Andrés is 32 years old and married. He is a member of the Twitezimbere Kmn solidarity group, made up of rice farmers. He has two children: the eldest is four and the youngest one. Neither of his children attend school, as they are not yet old enough. He has no other dependents.

Andrés was born in Rwanda, and completed six years of primary school. He started working with ACB S.A. in 2012 and is currently on his first loan cycle.

The loan requested will enable Andrés to buy chemical fertilizers and pay his labourers. He does not foresee any difficulties repaying the loan. His strategy will be to cultivate the rice at the right time, which will ensure that his farming business is able to grow. 

Andrés' ambition is to purchase a cow, which will provide milk for the family. He will also pay medical fees and buy food for his family.

Athanase is a rice farmer and a member of the Abesamihigo D solidarity group. He is 42 years old and married. He has seven children, the eldest of whom is 30 and the youngest nine. Six of his children are in school, and he has no other dependents. He was born in Rwanda, and completed six years of primary school.

He began working with ACB S.A. in 2011, and this is his third loan cycle. The previous two loans were correctly repaid.

With this loan, Athanase will purchase 60 kilograms of chemical fertilizer. He will use the rest of the loan to pay his labourers. He does not foresee any repayment difficulties.

Athanase's growth strategy is to increase the area of land he can cultivate. His ambition is to purchase a cultivator. In terms of his family, he would like to educate his children and pay for the family’s medical needs.

Gina is 32 years old and married with one child.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Gina has been raising livestock for two years and also earns additional income from buying and selling coconut wine.

Gina is borrowing PHP 11,500 through NWTF to buy additional livestock to raise. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

Mercy is single and lives in a neighbourhood of the capital. She has one child. \r\n\r\nMercy manages a hairdressing salon that she owns. Thanks to her excellent business skills and dynamism, she has built up a large clientele, which she would like to continue to serve well. In order to do this, she has requested this loan to purchase beauty products. The profits made using this loan will enable her to increase her capital and meet the needs of her family.

Angel is a 24-year-old single mother of a child living in Masindi, Uganda.

After separating from her fiance, who left her pregnant, her only resolution was to start a business to support herself. She sells second-hand clothes and with the proceeds she is able to pay rent and pay school fees for her young sister. 

The seasonal nature of the business is her challenge while her dream is to diversify her business and practice farming.

Angel intends to use the loan to buy clothes ahead of the Christmas season when demand is high.

Irene's group is composed of three hardworking women. Irene is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past four years, Irene has been working hard to manage her small restaurant business, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food that will be cooked for resale. This will help Irene to generate greater profits and increase her capital to buy needed items for the restaurant. Irene hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

Doreen is a 33-year-old married woman with two children living in Masindi, Uganda. She has been operating a retail shop, and with the proceeds she has been able to pay her children's school fees and buy land. Like most retail owners, she endures the challenges of price fluctuation and high license fees. Her dreams are to educate her children up to University and have a wholesale shop. Doreen intends to use this loan to buy general merchandise to sell, such as soap and salt.

Joan is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, 1 of whom is currently in school. For the past 4 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her small hotel that sells cooked food.

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 800000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more fresh food for cooking and reselling, and will help Joan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to to become a rich business woman. 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Joan is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 500000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food for cooking and reselling. It will also help Joan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a bigger restaurant. 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

Delys bought several beauty products and renovated her salon with her previous Kiva loan. She's currently applying for a new loan because December is approaching with a lot of orders and her working capital is not enough to purchase beauty products. She'll use them to offer beauty enhancement services at her beauty salon, and also for selling. That's the reason why she seeks a new Kiva loan, which she'll use to purchase shampoo, hair products, cosmetics, lotions, etc.

Jerome is a rice farmer and member of the solidarity group Twiteganyirize. He is 42 years old, and married. He has five children, the eldest of whom is 12 and the youngest four. Three of his children are in school, and he has no other dependants. Jerome was born in Rwanda, and completed four years of primary school.

Jerome will use this loan to buy 60kgs of chemical fertilizer, and the rest of the loan will be used to pay his labourers. He does not foresee any difficulties repaying the loan. 

Jerome’s strategy to expand his farming business is to request other loans in the future. This will allow him to increase the size of his business.

Jerome's ambition is to produce large quantities of rice, which will allow him to become the main rice farmer in the region. At home, he would like to educate his children and look after his family.

Innocent is 34 years old and married. He has four children, the eldest of whom is 8 and the youngest one. Two of his children are in school, and he has two other dependants. He was born in Rwanda and completed six years of primary education.

Innocent began working with ACB S.A. in 2011, and this is his fourth loan cycle. The three previous loans have been repaid in full.

With this loan, Innocent will purchase chemical fertilizers and pay his workforce. He does not foresee any repayment difficulties.

In order to expand his farming business, Innocent will secure other loans, which he will use to strengthen the business.

Innocent is a rice farmer and a member of the Abunzubumwe A solidarity group. His ambition is to be able to use a cultivator in his farming business, and he would also like to build a house for his family.

George is 22 years old and lives in the Telavi district with his wife and child. He earns an income as a taxi driver and provides services to local people. George's income is not enough to provide food for a three-person family and, according to Credo estimates, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. George has decided to start a new business to supplement his income but his loan requests have been rejected several times by local financial institutions. He lacks experience with new business start-ups and does not qualify under income requirements. \r\n\r\nGeorge is requesting a loan under the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This loan program envisions providing start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the rural poor, who do not have access to many credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.
