George will use his loan to start a car wash.  He will purchase essential equipment and a vacuum cleaner. George will provide services to local community members and hopes to increase the monthly income of the family. His new business initiative will significantly improve the living conditions of his family.

Ahmad is a 26-year-old youth client who is single and lives with six family members, three of whom are employed. He is from Iraq. Since 2010, Ahmad has owned a small grocery store where he sells soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents, and snacks. He has two employees. Ahmad has good experience in his field and is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.\r\n\r\nAhmad is requesting a 2,400 USD youth loan to renovate his grocery store. In the future, he hopes to grow his business and increase his profits to provide his family with better living conditions.

Maureen is a 28-year-old married woman with three children. She lives in Masindi, Uganda. Maureen operates a beauty salon and has been able to buy land and pay school fees for her children with the income she has earned. She does not have adequate capital to purchase modern equipment to attract more customers.\r\n\r\nMaureen is requesting a loan to buy synthetic hair and cosmetics for her salon. In the future, her dream is to modernize her salon and diversify her business to include farming.

Innocent is a 54-year-old married man with four children. He lives in Kasese, Uganda. For the past 26 years, Innocent has been a teacher. He was inspired to become a teacher by his love of associating with young people. Innocent's major financial challenge is his low salary as he is unable to fully meet his daily expenses.\r\n\r\nInnocent is requesting a loan to pay school fees for his children. In the future, he plans to venture into business to supplement his salary.

Inga is 39 years old, married and lives in Kobuleti district with her husband and three children (14, 18 and 21 years old). Her husband works as a salesman and gets a monthly salary. Inga’s economic activity is a newly started small grocery store, where she sells different kinds of groceries. Inga requested a loan from local financial institutions for the business expansion, but without success. Her loan request was rejected because of her low income and insufficient experience in her business. \r\n\r\nHowever, her loan request was approved through a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. They do not have access to traditional credit products, being regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. Inga requested a loan to purchase basic groceries that customers often request. She plans to increase the turnover in her trade business gradually. This will raise the income of the family, which will be used to improve the family’s living conditions. She awaits your support.

Elizabeth is a 42-year-old hardworking woman living in Masindi, Uganda. She sells food; she started this business to support her growing family. With the proceeds, she has been able to buy land for farming and pay her children's school fees. Two of them have now graduated. The business is usually good during festive seasons such as Easter, Christmas and when students break for their holidays. She dreams of educating her children to attain degrees, at least. She also wants to own a food store. To help reach these goals, Elizabeth is requesting a loan to buy food to sell.

Eddy is a fifty-two-year-old married woman with seven children living in Kasese, Uganda. She has been operating a retail business for twenty-two years and she has been able to buy land for farming with the proceeds. She began her business to be economically empowered. Inadequate capital and price fluctuations are her major challenges, while her dreams are to have a wholesale shop and venture into commercial farming. Eddy intends to use this loan to purchase soap and palm oil to sell. She is a member of the above-mentioned group, in which each member guarantees the other in accessing a loan.

Nana is 42 years old, married and lives in Tbilisi with her husband and three children (11,17 and 21 years old). The younger children go to the local school. Nana’s economic activity is a newly started small store, where she sells different kinds of fruits and vegetables. Nana requested a loan from local financial institutions to expand her business, but without success. Her loan request was rejected because of her low income and insufficient experience in her business. \r\n\r\nHowever, her loan request was approved through a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. These people do not have access to traditional credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. Nana requested a loan purchase coffee grinder and coffee. She will sell coffee and offer grinding services to her clients. Nana plans to increase the turnover in her trade business gradually. This will raise the income of the family, which she will use to improve the family’s living conditions and finance the education of her child. She awaits your support.

Leyne, who is from San Juan Nepomuceno, is applying for her first loan with Kiva to be ready for the year-end events that usually generate the highest sales of the year for businesses. Her working capital, though, is tied up in accounts receivable. She is seeking her first Kiva loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to buy clothing, underwear, and casual shoes. She is certain this investment will be successful because she will be meeting the needs of her regular customers, who live in the neighborhood where she has operated her business for two years. \r\n\r\nAt age 20, she started selling a variety of merchandise to earn income, and the business funds her daily needs and her dreams for the future. There is a small display case in the doorway of her house to attract customers to buy her merchandise. Mostly, Leyne sells clothing and shoes that she buys in the coastal city of  Barranquilla, which is three hours from her native San Juan Nepomuceno, and in Bogotá, the capital of Colombia. Her customers usually pay on credit; sometimes they pay in cash for cheaper items such as underwear. Right now she wants to increase her sales, but her goal is to continue her education so that one day she can achieve her dream to have a prestigious career.

Reyna, 32, is from Santa Rosa District.  Her partner is Zacarías, the father of their three minor children she shares many life experiences with and who all live together in a cozy house made of Wood.  For many years she worked growing organic cocoa beans but when the crops were attacked by a seasonal pest infestation she had go into a new business: raising barnyard fowl.

She’s been in this line of work for a year and after selling her first batch of animals she feels motivated because the birds attained good growth.  She likes this activity very much because she feels she has a unique understanding of the birds and it’s somewhat easier than the hard field work she used to do and she also does not have to hire additional staff so her profits are good.

She wants to start raising a new group for the second season and needs to buy baby chicks and sacks of natural feed to provide them with the all the care necessary and repeat her initial good results.  She feels that her calling is raising animals which is why in future she wants to go into raising cows and others.

This is her first MFP loan and she’s very grateful and commits to faithfully make her payments so that she can access a larger loan in future.  She will use the 1,000 new soles to buy barnyard fowl chicks and also set aside some of the money to buy grains of corn for the constant feeding of the fowl.

Reyna is 42 years old and is a kind and enterprising woman. She lives in her mother’s house with her three children aged 23, 20, and 15, who are all studying to have a better future. Reyna makes and sells fruit ice creams using fruits like aguaje, coconut, and camu camu among others. She also sells different flavored sodas and different types of beer. She runs her business from a part of her mother’s house. She started this business because she did not have enough income to be able to cover her children’s study expenses. Her mother helps her to buy the drinks, and her children help her to make the ice creams.

She comments that her business is profitable due to the fact that her city is very hot, meaning that every day she gets more and more customers and her sales increase. Before she started her business, she had money problems because she could not afford to pay for her children’s studies, and this worried her a lot. But her family decided to support her financially so that she could start a small business. She hopes to keep the business going because it makes good profits and allows her to cover her expenses.

This will be her third loan from MFP, and she is very grateful to the institution for giving her the opportunity to be a part of such a supportive group. This motivates her to continue making her repayments on time.

With the requested amount of 500 soles, she will buy fruits like aguaje, camu camu, coconut etc. to make more ice creams, and she will also buy sodas at wholesale so that she can increase her profits.

Yudaya is a hardworking woman living in Masindi, Uganda. She sells second-hand clothes and decided to start her business to meet her daily expenses which were very high. Yudaya's business challenges include inadequate capital and the high cost of transport.\r\n\r\nYudaya is requesting a loan to buy clothing to sell before the Christmas season. In the future, her business plan is to set up a modern boutique and buy land for farming.

Mzevinar is 40 years old. She lives with her husband and 2 children in Batumi, West Georgia. Mzevinar is a cleaner and her daughter is a waitress in hotel; they both get monthly income. Mzevinar requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected every time because of her low income and family’s poor living conditions. According to Credo's estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. \r\n\r\nBecause of her failure to get a traditional loan, Mzevinar requested a loan from Credo to start-up her family business. Her loan request was approved due to a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. This start-up loan program provides business start-up and restart-up credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. These borrowers do not have access to credit products, for they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With her loan, Mzevinar will renovate a flat, which she has bought to rent out. Because of tourism development in Batumi, Mzevinar believes that renovating this flat will help her earn income. This new business initiative, financed with a start-up loan from Kiva, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

Amjad is a 26-year-old youth client who is single and lives with five family members, two of whom are employed. He is from Iraq. Since 2011, Amjad has owned a small grocery store where he sells soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents, and snacks. He has one employee. Amjad has developed a lot of good experience in his field and is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.\r\n\r\nAmjad is requesting a 1,200 USD youth loan to design a new display window and to increase his inventory. In the future, he hopes to grow his business and increase his profits to provide his family with better living conditions.

Denis lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past 3 years, Denis has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, posho, flour, and other items. 

To help expand his business, Denis has requested a loan of 3000000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. He will use this loan to increase his inventory of sugar, all types of flour and salt. This increased inventory will help Denis generate greater profits and improve his standard of living. Denis hopes that in the future he will be able to start a mini-supermarket. 

Denis is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). This program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Denis who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Matia is a 43-year-old, married man with eight children living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the charcoal and firewood business for six years and also does farming as an additional income source. He says that if he had enough capital, he would deal in solar and bio gas since his current business is affecting the environment. He only does it to support his big family. Like most good fathers, he has dreams of educating his children to attain degrees as minimum qualification. Matia intends to use the loan facility to buy charcoal and firewood to sell. He is a member of the above-mentioned group where each member guarantees the other in accessing a loan.

Patricio is a young artisan from Ibarra who lives with his wife and his two children. He defines himself as a successful and unassuming person. Patricio belives that with faith and hard work, everything will go very well and he'll pave the way towards accomplishing his goals.\r\nThe loan that Patricio has requested from Fodemi will be used to purchase supplies such as iron, metal brackets, a welding rod and steel. He'll use them to make industrial kitchens, since his work is becoming very well-known in his town and it's in increasingly high demand.\r\nPatricio's dream is to own a large industrial machine shop where he can manufacture all kinds of metal artifacts and create jobs for young people who wish to learn this trade.

Rodrigo is 27, has an Internet café in his native city of San Jacinto, and also sells a variety of merchandise. He offers classes in Internet applications, hardware, and software and supports students who successfully complete the training. This business idea was an alternative way to earn income and to benefit from his knowledge and use it to serve his community. His first customers were students, teenagers, and homemakers. His goal is to better organize his business and increase his customer base, and he works very hard to achieve this dream. \r\n\r\nHe is applying for his first Kiva loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to buy an Internet server and a variety of merchandise to meet his customers' orders. Rodrigo wants to make his Kiva loan a success by taking advantage of the high demand and offering desirable merchandise during the Christmas and New Year's season.

Zakaria is 48 years old and married to his wife, Liana. They live in Tbilisi, the capital city of Georgia. Liana works as a cleaner in a shop to earn a monthly income and Zakaria is currently unemployed. The family lives in poverty. According to Credo estimates, they belong to the vulnerable poor category. Zakaria decided to start a new business as their existing income isn’t enough for the family and their living conditions are poor. \r\n\r\nZakaria is requesting a loan under the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This loan program envisions providing start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the rural poor, who do not have access to many credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. Zakaria will use his loan to purchase a car and start a local taxi service. He hopes his loan will increase his family's income and enable them to improve their living conditions. Zakaria's family will also have enough income to access regular credit products available in the country’s capital market.

Robinah is married with three children, two of whom are currently in school. She lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. Robinah works hard to manage her shop where she sells soft drinks and mik. 

Robinah is reqeusting a 2,500,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to increase her stock and buy more goods such as salt and milk to sell. Her loan will help to generate greater profits which will allow her to improve her living standard and buy basic necessities. In the future, Robinah hopes to start up a dairy. 

Robinah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robinah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Mohammad is from Iraq. He is a youth client, 24 years old, single and lives with four family members, of whom two are employed.

Mohammad owns a car spare parts shop. He has been in this field since 2007. He has sufficient experience in this field, a deep understanding of local customers, and knows about their demands. He is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a 2,400 USD youth loan to pay the annual rent of the shop. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

Tamaz is 62 years old. He lives in Senaki District with his wife and 9-year-old son who goes to the local school. Tamaz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for agricultural business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. The only source of income for the family is the monthly salary of Tamaz working locally as an artisan. The monthly income of the family is 500 Laris. It is hardly enough to feed a three-member family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the vulnerable poor category.\r\n\r\nTamaz requested a loan from Credo to start up a dairy farm. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provisions of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit, Tamaz will purchase a milk cow. He will place it in an old empty farm building located in their yard. Tamaz will work hard on the farm. He will produce cheese and sell it in the village. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the income of the family. Their income will double and the family members will be able to improve their living conditions.

Jennifer  is 49 years old and is married with six children, two of whom are currently in school. She lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past eight years, Jennifer has been working hard to manage her boutique where she sells men's and children's clothing. 

Jennifer is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more clothes to stock her shop. Her loan will help to generate greater profits, boost her business, and increase her family's income. In the future, Jennifer hopes that she will be able to live a good life that is free from poverty. 

Jennifer is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jennifer who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Meslem, 22, is from Iraq. He is a youth client. Single, he lives with two family members. He is the only provider in the family.

Meslem owns small cafeteria. He established his business in 2011, and now he has one employee. He has earned good experience in this field, and he has an excellent reputation in the surrounding area.

He is requesting a $2,400 youth loan to renovate his cafeteria and install new ceramics on the cafeteria’s floor and walls. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he can provide his family a better standard of living.

Harriet is 29 years old and is single with two children, one of whom is currently in school. She lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past five years, Harriet  has been working hard to manage her boutique where she sells clothing. 

Harriet is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more clothes to increase her stock. Her loan will help to generate greater profits and increase her family's income level. In the future,  Harriet hopes that she will be able to live a good life. 

Harriet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Harriet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Neyl is 42 years old and lives in the municipality of San Jacinto where he makes a living selling coffee and coffee products in a kiosk that he has had since 2011. However, he has 11 years of experience in this work when he worked in SENA--National Learning Service, and was able to take advantage of the education provided. He organized business initiatives, selling coffee, milk shakes, iced coffee, and other products derived from coffee. \r\n\r\nHis clientele has now grown and he needs a greater infrastructure, which is why he now needs a Kiva loan, his first loan that he is taking out with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With the loan he will buy a coffee grinder, two tables, chairs and will pay for the repairs needed for his kiosk. He is very satisfied because he manages his business directly and uses organic coffee that he grinds himself and with the support of his wife. He buys directly from farmers located in Montes de María and he sells directly to the consumer. He has a dream to have a kiosk in Mexico and in New York in the future. However, his greatest challenge is to grow enough because he can only obtain the resources little by little. He is working gradually to accomplish this.

Christopher has been a member of the communal bank La Cascada II for four years. He is proud to belong to Vision Fund because it has helped his transport business very much. He is 34 and married to Brenda, who is a high school teacher. They have two small children: one is in preschool, and the other is seven months old. Christopher was born in San Felipe de los Alzati, a beautiful place where a winter season flower called Nochebuena is grown every year. It is also a tourist destination close to the Zirahuato and Santuario de la Mariposa Monarca archeological sites. 

He has taken classes in electronics, computer technology, carpentry, and cutting and sewing, but none in his current profession. As a youngster, he helped his mother meet the household expenses, since she was a widow and he was responsible for his family from an early age. With their combined efforts, they bought a van that he has used to offer public transport service for 13 years. His route begins in Zitácuaro and passes through different towns until it ends in Dongu; he has two other routes as well. 

He is applying for a loan to do maintenance on the three vans and also to buy spare parts and tires. This loan will let him repair his transport vans and will be of great help in supporting his family and his brothers, who have regular work driving two of the vans. His goal for the business is to save money to buy a new transport van and increase his profits.

The four other group members are Tomasa, Irma, Estela G., and Estela M. They will use their loans to buy merchandise for a grocery store; to buy catalog perfumes and cosmetics for resale; and to buy seasonal fruits and vegetables for resale.

Raquel, 36, is a joyful and friendly woman. She lives in her mother-in-law's home with her partner, Jack, who works on civil construction projects. They have four children, ages 16,14,13, and 5, to whom they want to give a good quality of life. Rachel sells second-hand clothing for women, men, and children. She does this in a market called "Hoyada" about a kilometer from her mother-in-law's house. She has been in this business for three years. She got started because she needed to earn money, because she did not have a job, there were debts to pay, and her partner's income was not enough to cover household expenses. Her oldest son helps her with sales when he gets out of school. She has a friend in Lima to whom she sends money every month so that she can buy her merchandise wholesale.\r\n\r\nShe believes her business is profitable because many people from different communities come to where she works and they buy her merchandise everyday. She says that at first she didn't have a place to make sell her products. Because of this, her customers couldn't find her and this situation was hurting her more and more. Her mother gave her a space in the market, and since then she has been set up in that place. She hopes to move forward, progress and be able to buy varied merchandise, in order to earn a good income. This will be her third loan with MFP. She is very excited about the kind of people who make up her group, because they are joyful, friendly, respectful, and above all, they make their payments on time. She the amount she is applying (1,200), she will buy merchandise. She will send the money to her friend in Lima, so that she can buy the merchandise wholesale. Then she will have more earnings.

Abdón lives in the Santa Rosa community.  At thirty-seven years old, he shares his life with his partner Ruth, who is thirty-three years old.  Together, with their effort and work pushing them forward, they have provided a good education with values and morals to their four children.  He has a home constructed of wood.  

He has worked as an organic cacao farmer since he was a young boy, since his parents and grandparents were also faithful producers of various crops.  He has been an independent producer for thirty years, thanks to some land he acquired from owners who auctioned it off.

He feels very proud to be a great producer in this area.  Thanks to the permanent support of Ruth in their different activities, they have managed to avoid hiring day laborers for various tasks.  With all of their experience in the countryside, they are very capable in farming tasks, like planting, weeding, and pruning the cacao trees.  They obtain good profits and make a great team effort that revitalizes them as a couple.

As part of a plan to replace the old cacao trees, he wishes to bring in plot grafts to take the maximum advantage possible from their crops.  This requires him to count on urgent capital to buy seedling trays, an organic fertilizer made of sea bird dung from the Peruvian Islands, and to purchase the tools needed for the hard work ahead.

In general, the cacao plantations require a type of shade when they initially begin to grow.  For this reason, he finds himself planting timber trees for shade.  In the future, he hopes to sell them as blocks of wood.  He already thinks this is a good business that he would like to get into.  

He is requesting 1000 "soles" to buy seedling trays to use in grafting process for the cacao plants.  He will also buy organic fertilizer, which is very essential for a quality yield.

Mildred, 50, lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children. For the past 19 years, Mildred  has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells breakfast, lunch and supper. 

To help expand her business, Mildred has requested a loan of 2500000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to improve to improve her kitchen and stock food to cook and resell. This will help Mildred to generate greater profits, boosting the business and increasing her family's income. Mildred  hopes that in the future she will be able to be self-reliant and productive. 

Mildred  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mildred who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Edwin is married and has three children.  He is a community leader in Mukuru kwa Ruben, an informal settlement in Nairobi, Kenya. He gives counselling services as well as spiritual guidance to people in his community. He believes in reaping where one sows, a value he has instilled in his children. 

Edwin is also a businessman who always seeks to invest his money in profitable opportunities that create win-win outcomes for himself and his community. As such, he wants to invest in Fresh Life Toilets to give people in his neighborhood accessible sanitation that is currently lacking, and generate income at the same time. He is requesting a loan, which he will use to purchase and run two Fresh Life Toilets.

Edwin hopes to positively impact the sanitation of his neighborhood and earn enough additional income from this venture to eventually purchase more Fresh Life toilets. Having educated all his children, Edwin's dream is to see them prosper. Finally, he would like to expand his investments.

María Lourdes is 42 years old and originally from the town of Zitácuaro. She has worked with VisionFund for four years although before she was part of a group called Barandillas. She decided to leave and ask for an individual loan with which she is very excited since she has faith in that her business will grow because of the new loan. For more than 21 years, she has had a couture shop in her home. She says that it all began because in high school she would go to the cutting and sewing workshop, and when she left high school creating clothing caught her attention. Therefore, she decided to enroll in a special school to perfect her techniques for the production of clothing. She says that she makes blouses, suits, pants, skirts, trousers, sheets, bedspreads, pajamas, etc. In the season in which the children and youths begin school, she goes to the schools to sell uniforms, and sometimes that same school will ask her to make daily and full-dress uniforms. Also, she makes suits for dances, costumes, fifteenth-birthday dresses, wedding dresses, and evening gowns.

She says that the loan that she is requesting is to buy material like cloth of different textures and colors, thread, zippers, buttons, needles, and many more things needed to make her clothing. She is very happy because she says that thanks to her new loan her business will improve a lot. Apart from this, she wants to buy a variety of cloths and materials because she wants to make bathroom, living room, and dining room sets, like Christmas table cloths since these are sold at a good price.

She comments that she will go to Mexico City and de Toluca where she will buy her material since one of her siblings will take her there to place the orders that afterwards they will bring to her house since she will buy wholesale. 

She is the single mother of one daughter, and she says that she is making her want very much to come out ahead because she wants to improve her quality of life and to save money for her studies when she is older. She says that her recommendation letter is from the same people who recommend her to others since her products are very pretty and delicately made.

Othman is a 45-year-old married man. He lives with his wife and five children. Othman owns a small farm of olive trees which gives the family a seasonal income. He also drives a taxi. These two sources of income do not bring in enough money for the family's needs. One of Othman's sons is at university studying business administration.

Othman took out a loan from FATEN to pay his son's university fees. This loan helps the family by paying the studying expenses and ensuring Othman's son's bright future. 

Othman appears in the picture next to his taxi.

Wael is a 26 years old, married, works as a teacher in the public sector and supplements his low income by raising cattle. His livestock help him and his wife pay for necessities. He previously took out a youth loan from FATEN to buy additional cows and expand his farm, and successfully completed both projects. He is requesting a new loan to buy more cows. His goal is to raise his income and improve his family's living standards.

Mohammad is a 24-year-old single man. He is a worker who has a small income. This income is not enough to cover his needs. Mohammad wants to finish building his house. He needs to buy more constructions supplies like cement, wood and other supplies. This loan will help Mohammad buy all the supplies he needs to complete his house. Mohammad requests a USD youth loan from FATEN to purchase all the constructions supplies. Mohammad is photographed in the location of his house.

Joyce is 32 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married  and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past four years, Joyce has been working hard to manage her retail shop, selling salt, sugar and other items. 

To help expand her business, Joyce has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock like sugar, cooking oil, and soap to be re-sold; it will help Joyce generate greater profits, increase the store's stock, and help the business to grow. Joyce hopes that in the future she will be able to have a big business. 

Joyce is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joyce who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Annet is 30 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She has one child who is currently in school. For the past three years, Annet has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, rice and flour. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy and stock goods such as sugar, salt and soap for resell, and will help Annet to generate greater profits and improve her standard of living. Annet hopes that in the future, she will be able to have a big business. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Annet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Enid is 40 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two currently in school. For the past five years, Enid has been working hard to manage her business,  which sells soft drinks and alcohol. 

To help expand her business, Enid has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a refrigerator and more soft drinks to sell, and will help Enid generate greater profits to improve her standard of living. Enid hopes that in the future, she will be able to be a good entrepreneur. 

Enid is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Enid who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Ariunaa is 42 years old lives with her mother and two children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her mother is a little bit sick and stays home. Her son Semjaan, 19, is a university student and her daughter Semjid,16, attends secondary school. She has been operating a business selling clothing supplies for years and stopped her business because she started working in a private company. Now, she is restarting her clothing supplies business in the local market. It will be easier this time because she has years of experience. She is having problems with cash and is now requesting 1'500'000 MNT to pay her son's university tuition fee and accommodations in the capital city. She is a hardworking and friendly person.

Nanuli is 55 years old. She lives in the Kutaisi District with her husband, son, daughter, daughter-in-law and an infant granddaughter. Nanuli requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for an agricultural business start-up, without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time due to low income and the family’s poor living conditions. The only source of income for the family is the monthly salary of Nanuli’s husband, working as a local artisan. The family has pigs, and sells piglets seasonally.

The monthly income of the family is 400 Laris. It is hardly enough to feed a six-member family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs in the vulnerable poor category.
 
Nanuli requested a loan from Credo to start up a dairy farm. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides for a business start-up, and re-startups.  It has credits for soft conditions for the country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products because they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit, Nanuli will purchase a milk cow. She will place it in an old empty farm building located in their yard. Nanuli will work hard on the farm. She will produce cheese, and sell it in the village. 

The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the income of the family. Their income will double, and the family members will be able to improve their living conditions.

Christine is 32 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has two children, one currently in school. For the past four years, Christine has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, rice and flour. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 12,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy soft drinks, rice and bedding, and will help Christine to generate greater profits to improve her way of living. Christine hopes that in the future, she will be able to be a good entrepreneur. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Christine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Aminah is 43 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Aminah has been working hard to manage her kiosk, which sells raw matooke (Ugandan bananas). 

To help expand her business, Aminah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more matooke, and will help Aminah to generate greater profits to improve her way of living. Aminah hopes that in the future, she will be able to be a good entrepreneur.. 

Aminah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aminah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Maka is 36 years old and lives in the Khobi District with her husband and 3-year-old son.  Maka requested a loan from the local financial institutions several times for an agricultural start-up without success.  Her loan request was rejected each time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions.  The only source of income for the family is the agricultural business, which is a plot of land where maize, laurel leaves, and citrus are grown.  In addition, the family runs a small dairy farm of 3 milk cows, whose milk is used in cheese products.  The monthly income of the family is hardly enough to feed three people.  

According to Credo estimates, the family belongs to the vulnerable poor category.  Maka requested a loan from Credo to start a dairy farm.  Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo.  The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the rural poor who do not have access to credit due to low income (which labels them as “high risk borrowers”).
With the requested loan, Maka will purchase a car which will be used to take the cheese to nearby villages for sale.  This will significantly decrease their transportation costs and allow additional savings for home renovation.  Maka awaits your support.

Cecile is 29 years old and married to a businessman. She earns a living by selling beer in a store that she has been running for three years. She is requesting a loan to buy more beer to sell, and will use the profits made possible by this loan to set aside money as savings.

Nutty is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children who are all currently in school. For the past 20 years, Nutty has been working hard to manage his leather business, which sells shoes. 

To help expand his business, Nutty has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more good leather shoes to sell. By increasing his inventory, Nutty will be able to generate greater profits and expand his business by buying more goods. Nutty hopes that in the future he will be able to to produce quality goods. 

Nutty is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Nutty who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Agnes is married with three children aged between one month and five years old. She sells animals. With this loan, she will buy more goats and hens to sell. She will use the profits from her business to buy a cow so that she can provide milk for her family.

Jafred's group is made up of eight farmers and is located in the Lugari District. Jafred is pictured on the right of the Weyeta Group with his hand raised. He is new to farming and excited by the approach of the 2013 rainy season. He joined a group called the One Acre Fund to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, to access the best prices for supplies and secure their timely delivery, to grow enough food for his family and use the additional profits he earns to send his children to school.\r\n\r\nJafred described his harvest last year as poor. He hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer he will be able to double his harvest in his first year as a member. His biggest concern is sending his children to school. He plans to use his profits to pay for their education, buy livestock and expand his farming efforts. For the 2013 rainy season, Jafred’s group members will each get half an acre of land. Our field officer, Lazarus, is seen on the left with a yellow shirt.

Osee is married to a businesswoman and they have eight children. Osee is 52 years old. He owns a pharmacy and has been running the business for the past 10 years. With this loan, he wants to buy more medicine to sell in the pharmacy. The profits will be used to reinvest in the business.

Mary is a 42 year old woman who deals in poultry farming; she began this business because she wanted to raise money to pay school fees for her children. She has 5 children and all of them go to school. Her main challenges include price fluctuations, high prices of the poultry feed and high competition at her village. She would like to improve the quality of her poultry in the future to boost her business and improve the standards of living of her family. She is a very hard working woman.

Jacqueline is buying materials to make bags in her dressmaking shop, and also, she wants to buy a new sewing machine in order to augment her productive process and offer her clientele a better quality of products.  

At present, Jacqueline is applying for a Kiva loan so that she can purchase fine thread to make the many bags demanded in other regions of the country. Her Kiva loan will produce success, as evidenced by the customer requests that are, little by little, materializing. Jacqueline is encouraged and she is disposed to turn these into permanent orders.

Jacqueline wishes to say 'many thanks' to her financial supporters and she asks for their ongoing assistance so that she can continue working with these resources.

Satou is 49 years old, and a widow. She has three children aged between 18 and 30, only one of whom is still in school. Satou has one other dependant. 

For 11 years, Satou has run a business selling traditional cloth pagnes, jewellery and perfumes from home. She has good experience in this area. 

Satou would like to use this loan to purchase cloth, jewellery, bags and perfumes to boost her stock so that she can meet her customers' needs. The income generated from this will help her to better meet the needs of her family, which have been a heavy burden since the loss of her husband. Her ambition is to open a shop.

Dative is 43 years old. She owns a boutique that she has been running for the past 5 years. \r\n\r\nWith this loan, she wants to add more merchandise to the boutique. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest in the same business.

José Francisco, a dairy farmer in Mexico State, processes much of his milk into cheese and yogurt because he can sell them at higher and more stable prices than milk. However, production is energy intensive and requires multiple tanks of non-renewable and expensive LP gas per month. That is why he is requesting a loan to buy a 16-cubic-meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester that will convert the abundant cow manure on his farm into renewable fuel, and give him a cleaner, more environmentally-friendly and cheaper energy source. The system will also generate hundreds of liters of fertilizer per day for use on the maize and alfalfa he uses as animal feed. This loan represents almost half of the total cost of the Sistema Biobolsa biodigester he plans to buy.

Annonciata is 35, and she is married with five children. She sells sodas and beers. She has been in this business for 10 years. \r\n\r\nShe would like to get the loan to buy more sodas. She will use the profits from her business to renovate her house.

Ana has a sewing business and is very grateful for her previous Kiva loan because she got the opportunity of participating in the Kiva program in the Fundación and was able to increase the volume of her purchases of fabric, embroidery and sewing supplies.  Her business has now improved and she’s managed to produce much more thus increasing her income.  Her goal for later on is to hire employees and expand her productive process and with it the infrastructure of her customer base.  She’s currently preparing to receive Christmas and New Year’s with a significant increase in dressmaking orders and this is why she’s calling on Kiva once again because she’ll use her loan to buy more raw materials and supplies to make elegant gowns to respond to market demand because that’s what her loan’s success is based on.

Anastasie is 37 years old. She owns a bar and has been running the bar for the past 5 years.\r\n\r\nWith the loan, she would like to add more beer for resale. She will use the profits from the business to make savings.

Bhawani is 48 years old, married and two children.  In 2000, she established  her milk selling business.  Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she suppoorts her family.  

Bhawani is requesting her fifth loan from Patan BPW, which she will use to buy a young milk-producing cow.  In the future, Bhawani plans to improve the economic condition of her family.  

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal.  Cows are never raised for beef, but for milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made.  Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking.  On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about $0.50.  In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction and as fuel for fires and can be captured in methane storage tanks.  The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

Luis, 50, lives in the beautiful capital of Colombia: Bogotá.  He starts his fique [fiber made from agave leaves] crafts-making process very early.  It consists in washing, dying, sifting, sewing and selling his main product: place mats in various designs.  Luis makes his purchases in crafts centers where supplies are sold that make it possible for him to reach the best results with his pieces and his sales are daily and are cash.  His 30 years’ experience is very well-known and this is why crafts stores prefer him.  His goal is to double his current production because he has orders pending and needs to buy raw materials in larger amounts which is precisely what motivates him to seek a Kiva loan, his first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that he’ll use to buy fique, wool, thread, sisal rope, reeds, plastic bags, etc.  With his Kiva loan he will put into practice his particular commercial strength because it’s a challenge “to attain great market drive,” as he, himself says.

Nory used her Kiva loan to buy fine thread in larger amount and made hammocks that she sold.  She also used part of the loan to enroll her son in the university in Cartagena and this made her very happy for which she’s very grateful to Kiva and is asking Kiva lenders to continue supporting Kiva’s work in order to continue receiving the benefits of that money.  She’s currently applying for a new Kiva loan to buy fine thread in larger amounts to make new hammocks to sell to order in the city of Cartagena.  Her investment’s success is based on that because she succeeds in selling her products responding to market demand which grows much more every day.

Eusebio’s married and has six children two of whom are independent.  He lives in his own, one-bedroom house with adobe walls and dirt floor located in the city of La Paz’s Las Lomas zone.  Eusebio works as a baker in two places for more than 8 hours daily.  His income is to support his family, to pay basic utilities like electricity, water, sewage and also to pay for food.  He needs the loan to buy building materials (bricks, cement and sand) to add a room to his house.  Eusebio’s dream is to finish building his house and to improve his family’s quality of life.  This is the second time he’s worked with IMPRO and first with KIVA.

Indira is 27 years old.  She is married and has a nine-year-old child. In 2003, she established her cow milk selling business. Working four hours a day and seven days a week, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buy a young dairy cow. In the future, Indira plans to raise the economic condition of her family. She is grateful for everyone's support.\r\n\r\nDairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for their meat but are used for their milk. Curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made from dairy cows. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about $0.50 USD. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung used in home construction, as fuel for fires and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

Benjamin is a 43-year-old married man and a father of six school-aged children from Talibon, Bohol. He is a fisherman and has been in the business for more than 15 years. Benjamin is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, hooks, buckets and ingredients, such as meat and seasonings, for his food vending business. Benjamin hopes that this loan will help him to improve his earnings thus allowing him to support the needs of his family and send his children to school.

Jyanti is 35 years old, married, and has two children.  In 2000, she established  her vegetable farming business.  Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she suppoorts her family.  

Jyanti is requesting her eighth loan from Patan BPW, which she will use to buy seeds and fertilizers.  In the future, Jyanti plans to improve the economic condition of her family.   

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land.  Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seeds and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market.  Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

Gulipa is a 51-year-old married woman. As her family's main income provider, Gulipa has been working in animal husbandry and crop farming since 1995. She began her business with 10,000 som. 

Thanks to persistent work, Gulipa now has two cows  on her farm. Every year she cultivates 1.25 hectares of land, where she plants potatoes and barley. Her monthly income is about 12,000 som. 

With long term business development in mind, Gulipa turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 40,000 som to purchase young cattle for fattening and subsequent sale. She plans to invest her profit in future cattle purchase and to renovate her home in the near future.

Paula’s married and has three children who are all independent.  Paula only attended elementary school.  She lives as a caretaker in a relative’s house occupying a single room with adobe walls and a dirt floor located in the city of El Alto’s Villa Ingenio zone.  Paula sells gloves she knits herself in various street markets in different parts of the city of El Alto and with the little she earns is able to cover her food and basic utility costs.  She needs the loan to buy more yarn and increase her capital to have a wider variety of gloves to offer her buyers.  Paula’s dream is to improve her income and above all to improve her family’s quality of life.  This is 7th IMPRO loan request and 4th with KIVA.

MIrly works making and selling crafts like backpacks, purses, cases and accessories.  She started her enterprising alternative when still very young because it’s tradition among women in her native San Jacinto and with it she’s managed to support and school her children who are now 14, 17 and 21 years of age.  She sells her products by traveling to Sincelejo, a city in the northeast of the country, on the Colombian Caribbean coast.  She also sells from home where she lives with her spouse and children.  Her goal is to expand her customer base and to sell other crafts too make in various parts of the country and to expand her productive capacity.  She’s currently applying for a Kiva loan, her first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to buy yarn to make backpacks and purses she has on order; her presales are what guarantee effective sales thus insuring her Kiva loan’s success.

Hosea is a 38-year-old married man with seven children living in Kasese, Uganda. He is involved in a number of businesses, such as cosmetics, motorcycle transport, and farming. He started these businesses in order to support his growing family, and his desire is to see his children finish school and graduate. Inadequate capital to meet the different tastes and preferences of his customers is his major challenge, while he dreams of owning a fashion school and opening another outlet. Hosea intends to use the loan facility to buy cosmetics, oil and hair weaves to sell.

Elsa is 44, married and lives with her husband and 3 children in their own home.  The house is situated in the small village of Guaraguaos Alto in Tambogrande District.  The area where Elsa lives is rural, but she does have electricity.  Elsa's business involves selling beer from her own home, where she prefers to serve her customers on Saturdays and Sundays. 

She has built up a stable customer base in the area and has more than 5 years' experience in the business.  Her husband is a farmer who has his own parcel of land, on which he grows mangoes and lemons.  Both of their incomes covers their household expenses.  

When Elsa realised that her good service had boosted customer numbers and that she could not serve them all as she would like, she thought it appropriate to renovate her premises, as well as buying more beer.   She has, therefore, applied to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles to allow her to achieve her goal.

Julia is 50 years old and married with two dependent children.  She lives in her own home with her husband and children.  Her house is located in the rural community of Nueva Esperanza Hualtaco III, in the Tambogrande District.  She doesn't have basic services.

Julia's primary activity is raising sheep and poultry, and she already has 15 heads of sheep.  She also spends her time on the lemon harvest on a 1 hectare inherited plot.  This activity is divided between spouses, who mutually support each other.  

Her husband makes his living doing agricultural work.  They both work day after day so that their home will be better off.  

Julia wishes to buy animals to sell and vaccinations to keep them healthy, as well as to fix up and improve her corrals.  This is why she thought it prudent to get a loan of 2000 nuevos soles to achieve her goal.

Aslibegim lives in the city of Dushanbe. She is 64 years old and divorced. She has worked as a teacher in a school for 30 years. \r\n\r\nAslibegim has one child, a son, who works as a taxi driver, and she would like to help him. Hence, she is requesting this loan to renovate his car and purchase winter tires so that he can continue his business and offer safe service.

Monday is a 27-year-old married man with two children living in Kasese. To supplement his agricultural income, he sells beans and has been in business for 13 years. He mainly supplies the beans to schools, which buy in bulk. Like most good fathers, Monday's desire is to see his children graduate with degrees. He would also like to build a permanent house as the family currently lives in a mud-wattled dwelling. \r\n\r\nPrice fluctuations and unpredictable weather changes are Monday's major challenges. His dream is to own a food store and venture into commercialized agriculture. He intends to use this loan to buy beans to sell.

Thanks to her previous Kiva loan, Carmen bought men’s, women’s and children’s clothes that she sold and earned a bit more money.  Her dream is to have a shop in a large shopping center and to finally finish furnishing her house.  She sends the following message: “Immense gratitude to Kiva lenders for the commitment they’ve made with us; may they continue supporting us.”  She’s currently applying for a new loan that she’ll use to buy outfits for men, women and children that are apt for the entire family so that during Christmas and New Year’s her customers will feel very happy welcoming these holidays gathered together as families.

Leyla, 47, lives in the city of Cartagena de Indias with her spouse and three children whose ages range from 5 to 21 years.  She has a beauty shop there where she offers image enhancing services to all the surrounding families.  Her business started when she took an evening barber course at the age of 16 while working days because the teacher hired her when she saw her enthusiasm and capacity for applying the skills she was learning.  She gained vast experience this way and sometime later capitalized her business and has it to this day.  

She started out buying her work tools with her own income and continued taking refresher beauty courses and gradually expanded her growth possibilities; she purchased furnishings to organize her sales point.  Her drive for advancement led to her opening an academy and she taught courses.  Later on she became still better-known and she got a job that required her to travel frequently so she changed her business for a good job.  Five years after that, though, she returned to her original idea of having her own business.  She’s done very well with this one and she simultaneously generates income by selling merchandise, especially those associated with beauty.  She’s a beauty consultant and sells cosmetics and hair products at the same time and this is what her customers like best.

She’s currently applying for a Kiva loan, her first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that she’ll use to buy hair treatments and cosmetics as well as a display case to keep her inventory well-organized.  Her Kiva loan’s success rests on her vast experience and her managing to lower costs by being able to pay cash for larger amounts which is precisely what Leyla is pursuing.

Nasridin is a 41-year-old resident of the Rudaki region. He is the father of two children. \r\n\r\nNasridin has been working as a baker for ten years. He has his own bakery, where he employs two people and bakes bread for sale. Nasridin is requesting this loan to renovate his bakery and purchase flour and yeast.

Burulcha is 40 years old. She is a mother and has raised 3 children, all of whom currently live with her. Her oldest son helps his mother run the household. Burulcha has secondary education. She got married after graduating from high school. She is a very active and hard-working person.

Burulcha has been an entrepreneur for a long time, nearly 15 years. She started her business with 5,000 KGS. Today, the family continues farming and raising livestock: they keep 2 cows, 1 calf, 1 horse, and 5 sheep. As an additional source of income, Burulcha sells milk from her home. The family's monthly income is roughly 17,000 KGS.

Burulcha has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 100,000 som (KGS) to purchase livestock. She plans to buy calves and sheep. In the future, Burulcha plans to further increase the size of her herd, as well as improve her family's financial situation and carry out repairs in their home.

Sandy, 23, is a kind woman with dreams.  She lives in her mother-in-law’s house with her spouse, Jorge, who works for a gas company.  They have a two-year-old son they plan to give a good education.  Sandy’s work consists in selling carbonated soft-drinks in assorted flavors and various brands of beer; she also sells snacks like chewing gum, candy, cookies, etc.  She does this work in a space located in her mother-in-law’s house.  

She’s had the business for two years, a dream she made reality at the age of 20 since she sold soft-drinks with her mother and that’s where she got the idea for her own business.  Her spouse helps make the purchases to stock her economic activity and her mother-in-law helps with customer service.  She comments that her activity is profitable because every afternoon many neighbors gather in front of her house to play bingo and they consume large quantities of the products she has for sale.  

She comments that before starting this business she did not have a space of her own and had to go from place to place but then her mother-in-law offered her house so she could start her business.  In future, she wants to finish building and furnishing her locale to provide better customer service and increase her profits which is why she’s asking for a 1,200 sol loan to buy larger amounts of soft-drinks in assorted flavors and beer of various brands as well as to buy snacks like chewing gum, candy, cookies, etc.

Digna, 39, is an enterprising woman who very much wants to get ahead.  She’s married to Rubén and they have three children together who are 24, 21, and 11 years of age respectively; she lives with her entire family in a house of her own.  Digna’s work consists in selling at retail basic staple items among which are rice, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, oil, vegetables and more.  She has this business located at home and she tends to it full-time, every day.  She’s been in this line of work for just a year.  At the beginning, she had her husband’s help but now she herself tends to her customers full-time.  She complements her store with the sale of clothing, shoes and cosmetics.

What she likes about her work is that she has time to do other occasional chores especially her household chores.  Fortunately, she does very well because they always have customer due to the variety of products she stocks and also because hers is the only grocery store in the neighborhood so she expects to be able to continue surging forward and to make her business grow too.

This is MFP loan #20 and she thanks all those who provide her with the opportunity of accessing this loan that insures her being able to stay in business.  On the other hand, she commits once again to make her payments punctually because she does not want to leave a negative impression with her fellow group members who have been noted for the punctuality and responsibility of their payments.  She will use the requested 1,300 soles to buy stock merchandise like snacks, rice, sugar, bread, eggs, milk, oil, vegetables and others for her store.

Vicente Ramón is 47 years old, married, and from the town of Leon. His work is making clay bricks. The business is located in his home, and he has been in this business for 22 years. It came about because of his need to have a source of work, in order to improve his family's income. 

Vicente Ramón has already had credit with the Foundation, and has shown his responsibility by making payments in a timely manner. The purpose of the loan is to invest in raw materials such as earth, sand and clay for making clay bricks. 

Vicente Ramón is grateful for the help that the Kiva investors offer to low-income people and to poor countries such as Nicaragua, so that people can have a decent livelihood.

Toktobubu is a 56-year-old married mother of seven. She is a super mom. Since 1976 she has been working in animal husbandry and providing the main source of income for her family. She started her business with 1,000 som. Thanks to hard work and persistence, she now has a total of three dairy cows, 20 sheep, and 12 horses. Her monthly profit from the sale of cattle and dairy products is between 15,000 and 20,000 som. \r\n\r\nWith long term business development in mind, Toktobubu turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 45,000 som to purchase fodder for her cattle to feed them through winter. When she sells the cattle next fall, she plans to complete the construction of her home in the village.

Nurjamal is a 56-year-old widow and mother of three. After the fall of the Soviet Union, Nurjamal was given part of her land. Since 1991 she has worked in animal husbandry and crop farming, providing the main source of income for her family. She started her business with 1,000 som and thanks to hard work and persistence she now has a total of one cow, five sheep, and two horses, which provide her with a monthly income of 20,000 - 30,000 som. Additionally, she plants clover and barley on 3.6 hectares of land annually. \r\n\r\nWith long term business development in mind, Nurjamal turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 50,000 som to purchase cattle. When she sells her cattle next fall, she plans to build a large shed.

Nidia bought groceries with which she stocked her store. With this, sales have increased and also her income. Her shop now has better infrastructure. Her dream for the future is to add a floor to her home so that she can locate her store on the first floor and her family on the second. She sends her thanks to Kiva because she says that, "Without these loans I would be at a standstill, and wouldn't be able to keep moving forward."\r\n\r\nNow she is applying for new credikiva loan, with which she will buy groceries, snacks, soft drinks and alcoholic beverages. She knows by experience that getting ready for the Christmas and end-of-year holidays will make her credikiva loan the best investment.

Pilar, 40, has a partner and one daughter in her care. She lives in her own home located in the Nueva Arica district, Chiclayo province, capital of Lambayeque department. Pilar has worked selling groceries for more that 15 years in a small store in the front part of her house. During this time, she has gained a lot of new customers, who prefer her for her good manner and disposition to help them and serve them. At the same time, she receives retirement income, with which she maintains her family. \r\n\r\nPilar needs to buy a greater quantity of groceries and beer to later sell it. This is why she has applied for a loan of 1500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to reach her goal. With this investment, she will be able to improve her and her family's quality of life as well as improve her business. Pilar has good personal references.

Santos is 53 years old and lives with his partner in their own home, located in the rural settlement of Lagartera, in Mórrope,  a rural area which is part of the province of Lambayeque, and is located approximately one hour from the city of Chiclayo.

Santos has been buying and selling smaller animals for 15 years. He fattens them, and when they reach their ideal size and weight, sells them in the local market to merchants who visit his area. As well, he works as a day laborer on farms, makes adobe bricks, and builds houses from local materials.

Santos wishes to buy food for his animals, and also to install a floor in a room in his home. This is why he has felt it necessary to apply to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 4000 nuevos soles.

Santos has enough livestock to meet the demand in this Christmas season.

Silvia is pursuing a law degree at San Franciso Xavier University. She is studying law because she believes that it is a field that will help her country progress and one that will allow her to help herself and her family live a better life. Without access to this student loan, she would need to focus less on her studies and direct her attention towards finding someone to help pay her tuition or risk having to drop out of school. For Silvia, a degree is an opportunity to earn a professional position and a professional paycheck. Putting school on hold would prolong her current financial situation, something she desperately wants to change. 

Without the loan, Silvia thinks that she would need to ask her parents or other family members but worries that this may not be possible because her father is the only income generator in their family. He works as a carpenter while her mother tends to the house and family. Both her parents were only able to complete their primary education before they needed to enter the workforce. This loan will help Silvia to focus on finishing her law degree and become the professional that she aspires to be.

Silvia has two brothers and one sister, but she will be the first student in her family to earn her college degree. She hopes to be an example for her siblings. With multiple college-educated people in the family, Silvia feels hopefully that together her siblings can change her family’s status and provide a comfortable life for each other. She currently earns $350 per year, but she hopes to earn over $6,000 annually after she graduates. Silvia wants her lenders to know that Sucre, the city where her university is located in, has many students and that this youngsters are very important to the vitality of the city.

This loan is administered by Vittana's partner Banco Fie.

Ciro is studying law at San Fransisco Xavier University in Sucre, Bolivia. He chose law because he finds the discipline very interesting and he has always enjoyed reading. As Bolivia continues to develop, Ciro hopes that a degree in law will prepare him for the challenges ahead and help bring him financial success that he and his family desperately need. Ciro’s mother is retired and his father works as a auditor. With a limited family income, affording school has always been a challenge. Ciro’s younger brother has hopes of earning a university degree as well, and with the promise of success, Ciro hopes to be able to help him afford his own education.

With the money from his student loan Ciro plans to budget it to help pay for his school materials that will help him finish his thesis and the many fees associated with the school’s administration and titles. 

In Bolivia it is common to pay tuition at the end of the semester in form of a exam fee and at the end a four-year degree, in the form of a thesis fee and title fee. Despite having completed all the required work, Ciro fears that if he cannot afford the fees he will be unable to receive his degree. He hopes to not have to postpone his studies. School takes up much of his time and currently Ciro is unable to find a job that is flexible with his school schedule. 

With a degree in law, however, he expects to earn $5208 a year, a salary that would allow him to help support his brothers’ education and his parents’ well-being into the future. Ciro wishes to share that his city of Sucre, is very beautiful with great historical colonial architecture and many lovely museums.

This loan is administered by Vittana's partner Banco Fie.

Juan dreams of becoming a commercial engineer. He is currently enrolled in a degree program at the San Fransisco Xavier University but with his currently financial status he is unable to purchase the materials he needs, which is crippling his performance in school. Juan shares with us that without a computer it is difficult to learn and practice the practical component of his degree and it is inconvenient and even challenging to complete his thesis without consistent access to a computer and the internet. Much of engineering is computer based and without one, he feels that he is falling behind. 

Although Juan is the youngest of two, his household supports eight people in total. While both his parents are college educated, their family finances are very tight. With the aid of a student loan Juan plans to buy a laptop and the books and materials that will help him succeed. He chose commercial engineering because the field interested him and because he perceived a need for it in the job market. He hopes to be able to use his salary to help his family’s finances.

In addition to his classes and study sessions, Juan holds a part time job. Currently he makes around $8,600 a year but with a degree in engineering he hopes to be able to double his salary, maybe even more. The prospect of a secure salary and in turn, a secure future for himself and his family is worth the sacrifice and extra work now. With the security of loan, Juan can be confident that he can afford his full education and be able to help move his life and his family forward.

This loan is administered by Vittana's partner Banco Fie.

Esperanza is 41 years old, live with her partner, and has two minor children. She lives in her own house in the rural settlement of Eureka, which is part of the rural area of Lambayeque District. This is a small community with approximately 200 families.

The work Esperanza does is raising and selling animals. She has been doing this work for 20 years, in which time she has acquired quite a bit of experience and clientele. The business is located in her home. She learned this work from her parents, so she knows this line of work to perfection. 

The income she earns from this work helps to cover her personal expenses and those of her family.

Esperanza has applied to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles, which will help her invest in doing finishing work on her pens, and putting a gate on her home. This business has competition, but also has a wide market to sell into.

Mr. Ndiaga Laye is a young single man living in Senegal. For over four years he has been working as a fisherman. He is a member of his local UIMCEC branch. He is seeking a loan of 300,000 West African Francs in order to finance his wedding. His wish is to have many canoes and  motor boats  in order to increase his earnings from fishing.

Felícita is 26 years old. She lives with her family in their own house located in the Mórrope district. They live in a rural zone in the Province of Lambayeque.

For the last 15 years, Felícita has made a living raising and selling small animals. She runs this business from her home, where she keeps the animals  in air-conditioned pens. Felícita also works on other farms occasionally and receives day wages. Her husband makes a living as a fisherman in the port of Chimbote. Together they are working to help their family. 

Felícita wants to buy animal feed for her animals. This will help them grow bigger so they will be better fit for consumption. That is why she is requesting this loan of 3000 soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

Eduardo is 47 and a man who has always liked to face up to the circumstances that have arisen. This is how he was able to move forward in life, together with his wife Doris, with whom he has three children, ages 24, 23 and 19. They live in their own home, where he continues to work very hard, as he wishes to provide his family with a better quality of life. 

Each day, Eduardo heads to the sawmills located on the outskirts of the city, to obtain good-quality wood and at lower prices, so that he can put it up for sale in the same place where he buys it. He has customers who always ask for his merchandise, and when he doesn't have something, he doesn't hesitate to go to another place to obtain what his customer is requesting. 

He has been in this business for 20 years, and everything is going extremely well. He performs these tasks every day, generally in the mornings, from Monday to Friday.

He is grateful that things are going very well, as he has good customers who seek him out each day because of the quality of the wood he sells. He hopes to continue working this way, and in the future set up a small sawmill. 

This is his third loan with MFP, and he is very happy knowing that he has financial support, which will provide him the assurance of continuing to work with great peace of mind. For his part, he promises to continue being on time paying his installments, as he was with previous loans he had. As well, he feels comfortable belonging to his communal bank, as all its members are very responsible and supportive. 

With the amount applied for of 1200 soles, he will buy a greater quantity of shiplap cladding, which is used in house construction.

Elen is 28 years old and a very hardworking and enterprising woman who is sure of herself.  She is married to Segundo, the father of her two children, ages 13 and 14, and lives with her husband and children who are her motivation to search for a better quality of life.  They live in a home of their own which she was able to build with her husband, thanks to lots of effort.

Elen sells lumber and has a workshop in a large space on her land.  She works there with her husband’s help and cuts lumber for fences or for building homes.
