She has been doing this for 15 years because it provides a good income and she likes it because she can stay at home to raise her children and to housework.  She also likes the income that she uses to help her husband pay the household expenses.  She wants so set up a shop so she can increase her production and also wants to buy some carpentry equipment.

This will be her 11th loan through MFP and is grateful to those who make this loan possible.  She feels more comfortable about being able to move ahead with her work and promises to make her payments on time.  She feels comfortable and supported by the other members of her communal bank.

She will use the 1,500 PEN from this loan to buy lumber, chisels, sandpaper, and other things she uses in her work.

As a married parent of two children, Alicia works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from tailoring. Alicia is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF, to buy additional items to resell in her store, like shampoo, sugar, noodles and canned goods.

Alicia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 11 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

Alicia is 38 years old, married, and has four children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a food production and vending business in the Philippines, and she has requested a PHP 27,000 loan through NWTF, to buy ingredients for her food business.\r\n\r\nAlicia has borrowed and repaid 24 loans from NWTF, before this loan. She has been running the food business for 18 years and also earns an income from raising pigs. Alicia aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

As a married parent of five children, Berning works hard to support her family.

She has a business, buying and selling crabs and shrimp in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from farming rice and selling dried coconut meat. Berning is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase more crabs and shrimp to resell.

Berning has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

As a married parent of four children, Creninda works hard to support her family.

She has a business of buying and selling bananas in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling dried coconut meat. Creninda is borrowing 11,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy more bananas to sell for her buying and selling bananas business.

Creninda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

Edelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has had a mobile fish selling business in the Philippines for 12 years. She also earns some income from raising chickens and ducks.

She is borrowing 27,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell.

Edelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. 

She dreams of saving up enough money to send her children to college.

As a married parent of three children, Edelyn works hard to support her family.

She has a tailoring business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from food vending. Edelyn is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks for her tailoring business, like linens, pins, tailoring chalk, etc. 

Edelyn has sustained her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF. 

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her chidlren to college.

Edna is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell

Edna has been in this business for three years.  She earns other income from farming rice.

Edna has sustained her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough so she can afford to send her children to college.

Braulio is 40 years old, married, and has four children whom he is responsible for. He has been living with his family in their own home for more than five years. Their home is located in the city of Tambogrande, and they live in the urban part of this district. They do not have basic services.

Braulio's main work is raising sheep and poultry. He also sells fruit, as a secondary activity, on a parcel of land he inherited. He has been doing these activities for more than three years, and also has his partner's support in all the work that he does. His children support him in his livelihood by shepherding the sheep and goats, and this is a great help to the family business.

Braulio wishes to buy balanced feed for fattening livestock, so that he can sell them for a better price. He also wishes to buy fruit merchandise, so that his business can continue to grow, which will allow him to improve their quality of life. This is why he has applied to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles for achieving his objective.

Elena is 49 years old and married with seven children.

Elena works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 22000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell, like canned goods, spices, noodles, etc.

Elena has borrowed and paid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 8 years and also earns an income from raising livestock and restaurant.

Elena aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

Erlinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her general store business, like canned goods, coffee, soap, etc.

Erlinda has been in this business for 2 years. Erlinda earns more income from mat making and selling flowers.

Erlinda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

Krishna is 37 years old. She is married and has three children aged 18, 16 and 14. In 2003, she established her grocery store business. Working seven days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid four loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy grocery goods for her business. In the future, Krishna plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.  \r\n\r\nIn the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a pasal, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk and staples such as rice, lentils and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While typical pasals might be no more than 100 square feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce and shrewd businesswomen.

Anastasia is 24 years old and she is married. She runs a business just nearby the main road and very close to a garden where many people come to visit the garden and buy her things from the kiosk. Anastasia is earning a good income. Now she is applying for a loan from TRM (Tuba Rai Mentin) to improve her business. She will purchase some additional supplies for resale with the loan, including soft drinks, hard drinks, oil, biscuits, slippers, and rice.\r\n\r\nShe hopes to make her business bigger and she wants to live in a better life.

Alphonse is currently on his third loan cycle. His ambition for his farm business is to use machines for cultivation. For his family, he is going to build a nice house. The other information remains the same as the previous cycle.

Heberardo is 22 years old. He lives with his partner and has two children. He lives in his own home with his partner and their two minor children. The home is located in the Caserío, Platillos en the Tambogrande district. He lives in the rural part of the district, but they have electricity. 

Heberardo makes a living in agriculture, given that he inherited 10 hectare from his father, for which he has proof of possession from the Lieutenant Governor of the village. On this land he plants corn two times per year. Additionally, he works raising livestock, which when are the right weight and size are ideal to sell in the local market. With the income, he is able to cover his and his family's expenses. 

Heberardo wants to buy fertilizer and agricultural chemicals for his crops and also wants to hire laborers for their corn crop. This is why he has requested a loan of 2500 soles in order to achieve his goal.

Among the challenges all Ecuadoreans face to overcome the threat of poverty day to day is Sandra, a 42-year-old woman with many stories to tell but what’s now of concern is her present and her and her daughters’ future who even though they are now adults Sandra still hopes to see them reach their dreams since for her it was difficult to complete her schooling for lack of economic resources and because she took on the role of father and mother for her siblings since they were orphaned at a young age.  She’s currently divorced living with her youngest daughter, Diana, in the southern part of Quito, Ecuador’s capital city, specifically in Chillogallo.  Until a short time ago, the southern section of Quito wasn’t much of a strong economic sector in the capital of the Republic of Ecuador.  Now, it’s considered to be an economic strong point in the city’s economy.  Enterprising families are found here that have struggled to stand out.  It’s been a meeting point for natives and migrants from other cities and countries and for people from several provinces; it’s been rebuilt with broad streets.

Sandra started a fruit and vegetable business 12 years ago and one of the biggest obstacles she’s faced and one that meant a significant expenditure of money was when her oldest daughter was diagnosed with cancer which was treated and she’s now in stable health.  

Sandra learned this activity from her aunt who taught her since she was a young girl about suppliers, accounts, etc.  Sandra developed it for her siblings so that she could move them forward and later she did it for her children.  It’s very hard work that requires physical effort to lift the boxes of fruit to sort them and even the schedule requires much willpower because Sandra invests at least 12 hours daily from the moment she starts at one a.m. and goes until one p.m. or even later.

Sandra is asking for help to get a loan to buy seasonal fruit that has high customer demand at wholesale.  Extra income generated will be invested in her business’ growth and in her youngest daughter’s higher education.  Sandra says that she hopes to leave a print on her daughters so that when they are completely fulfilled they’ll be sure to realize that their mother contributed to their getting there; this is why she’s even planning on getting training where she was trusted enough to be lent the money at Fundación Alternativa which is a Kiva intermediary that trains and strengthens entrepreneurs’ businesses aiming at lessening poverty in the country.

Mame Coumba is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She works in the services sector. A hairdresser, she has over ten years of experience in this business. She is an associate of one of the U-IMCEC branch offices in the town where she lives. She has already prepaid a previous loan and is requesting a loan of 300,000 for fixing up her hair salon. The revenues her business brings in enable her to support her three children in addition to covering the rent for her salon, where she does business. This financing will help her to draw in more customers, increase her revenues, and cope better with her day-to-day expenses. Her greatest dream is to have a larger hair salon in the area.

Ms. Nogaye is married and lives in Senegal. She has been working in the commercial sector for over seven years. She devotes all her time to selling cloth and perfumes. She is the mother of three children from 3 to 15 years old. She is requesting a loan of 200,000 francs for bolstering her working capital. Part of the financing will be used to purchase cloth and perfumes to resell. And the other part will enable her to develop her new business selling breakfasts. Her end goal includes boosting her profits to cope better with her expenses. In addition, intending to diversify the products and services offered to her customers, she would like a roof for her family in the future.

Lidia, 37, lives with her husband and two minor children who are in her care in her own house located in Caserío Malingas Grande that belongs to Tambogrande District.  Lidia lives in the rural part of the district and her house is made from insubstantial materials; it has electricity.

The activity Lidia carries out is raising small farm animals and barnyard fowl for subsequent sale.  She sells them at home and in adjacent zones.  She tends permanently and has an established clientele.  She also has one hectare of farmland she inherited where she grows lemons and mangoes.  Lidia has more than 4 years’ experience in agriculture and animal husbandry businesses.  In addition, her husband owns a hectare of land he inherited in the San Martín zone.

Lidia wants to buy nutritionally balanced animal feed for her livestock and this is why she’s asked Edpyme Alternativa for a 2,000 new sol loan to reach her objective.

Graciela, 20, is a very kind, good, hardworking young woman.  She’s single but has a little one-year-old son.  She lives with her mother and brother in their own house and they all share the struggle to get ahead.  

Graciela’s work consists in buying and selling lumber.  She buys chunks of wood from various sawmills located near her house and she takes them to her workshop to process into simple pieces, either slats or boards.  She then places everything she makes in her warehouse and then sells them from there individually.  She does all this process between the sawmills and the sales point at home.  

She’s been working this way for a year and is doing very well.  She’s very happy that she’s doing well because her profit margin is good since she uses up all her product.  Now that she’s doing this work, she does not have to wait for the money her ex husband earns since now she too can contribute to her home’s economy.  She has her ex husband’s unconditional support and they work together to provide all the best for their family which is why she’s asking for a 2,500 sol loan to buy lumber to start the process of turning it into slats and boards again.

Gredel, 42, is a good, kind, cheerful woman married to Kelin; they have two children who are 23 and 21 years old.  She lives in her own house where she shares her days with her two children and her husband with whom she worked much to improve their quality of life and so that they would have no unmet needs.

Gredel’s work consists in selling various products.  Among the things she sells are beauty products, perfume, cosmetics and more; she also sells seasonal clothes that she brings from other cities to sell to her girlfriends, neighbors, family members and coworkers on credit.  She’s been doing this for more than 20 years and is doing very well.  In addition to this work, she’s also employed as a teacher at a local school which gives her potential customers and while doing her job she’s able to sell more.

She started this activity when she needed to pay for her schooling since back then she was still a student and needed a source of income.  She gradually made progress until she graduated and was able to also work in her profession.  But even so, she continued with her commercial work because it produces good profits.  She has many future plans and hopes to continue working and generating income for her home.

This is MFP loan #3 and she’s grateful to the people who are making this financing possible that she needs to be able to reach her objectives.  She will use the requested 2,500 soles to buy beauty products, cosmetics and perfume to sell and she’ll also buy some articles of clothing to offer her customers.

Juan, 52, lives in the city of Chincha that’s noted for its warm, welcoming climate as well as for the cheerfulness of its inhabitants.  Juan’s a very hardworking man above all because he’s the father of two marvelous children and together with his wife they focus all their efforts into giving their family a life with dignity.  

Juan works day to day in agriculture, especially growing cotton.  He’s been doing this for 15 years and spends about nine hours daily at work.  He’s always watchful of his crops and this is why he believes he does well in his business, because of his dedication to it and his desire to get ahead.

Juan is very grateful to Kiva lenders because thanks to the help they’ve given him he’ll be able to buy manure and fertilizer, among others, to improve his crops and have a good harvest; he will continue striving towards making his greatest dream reality: to build his house out of substantial materials because it’s currently adobe and to give his children a good education.

Julissa, 29, is a member of the “Clavel” (Carnation) communal bank; she’s married and her husband is a merchant.  They are a hardworking, responsible family.  She started her business selling snacks and juices and then decided to sell food and the business had good results so she still is selling grilled meat and snacks.  She’s open to the public from 4pm until 10pm.  The loan Julissa is requesting is to buy products like meat, beans, lard, vegetables and cheese to make the food she offers her customers.  With support from the loan she will be able to offer more products to her clientele.  The only inconvenience Julissa faces is competition since there’s another place nearby that sells snacks which is why she tries to sell top quality products so her sales won’t be affected.  Her goal is to open a restaurant to better care for her customers and offer more products that will satisfy their wishes.  This is Julissa’s first loan request to FAMA and she expects to make her installment payments punctually.

Delfina is taking a loan of $1,000 from TRM (Tuba Rai Metin) to improve her business. Delfina has eight children and a husband. She is a very hardworking woman. \r\nDelfina will use the loan to buy doughnuts, cigarettes, rice, fish canes and other stock to keep in her kiosk. \r\nShe hopes that she will make more income in order to support her family and send her children for a good education.

Lidia is a 35-year-old Ecuadorian woman. She married young, but she was able to finish high school. She’s currently separated and raising her children on her own – they’re 13, 9 and 6 years old. Although the separation was a difficult time for her children and herself, together they have since become an exemplar family. They live in the Chimbacalle neighborhood that’s located in the south of the city of Quito, which is the capital of the Republic of Ecuador. Up until the last few years, the southern part of Quito was not considered as playing a major part in the economy of the city, but now it’s considered one of the city’s economical strengths. In this area you’ll find determined families who have fought to get ahead. From natives to migrants from other cities and countries, this area has been the meeting point of people from various provinces and has been reconstructed with extensive streets. Chimbacalle, where Lidia resides, is a very commercial neighborhood that is constantly growing and lends itself to the economic growth of the city. There are parks with big green spaces where families meet on the weekends. There is access to a great number of services and the people in this area, with determination, use every opportunity that presents itself to establish new businesses. In this area, you will see street vendors, working children and families in need.\r\nLidia is a street vendor and she's been selling casual clothing for 5 years. This undertaking was very important for her, as it was the only livelihood she had for her herself and her children since the separation. Previous to the separation, she worked as a street vendor and brought in some extra money, but it was more of a hobby; afterwards it became her fulltime job and the income now provides the education and wellbeing of her children. In the beginning, she sold only cosmetics, but there was demand for clothing, so she now dedicates about 6 hours or more each day to taking down orders from her clients, classifying the new clothing she has, delivering the orders to each address and collecting outstanding accounts. All of that work, while still attending to her children; helping them with homework, going over lessons and studying.\r\nLidia is requesting a loan to buy wholesale merchandise in order to get more discounts on her final bill. This will help increase her earnings so that one day she can accomplish her dream: owning her own clothing store that will help sustain her family and provide her children the opportunity to earn professional degrees that will take them further in life. Lidia is grateful that Fundación Alternativa believed in her enough to provide her with a loan and the training needed to visualize and project her business into the future.

Elizabeth is 42 years old, married and has three dependent children. She owns her home, nevertheless she is living with her mother in Sector La Campiña in Cayalti, located one hour from Chiclayo, the capital of the department of Lambayeque.

Elizabeth has been selling beauty products for four years. She also raises and sells farmyard animals. She feeds them until they reach an ideal size and weight. She supports her family with her earnings.

Elizabeth needs to purchase more beauty products to sell and also more animals to fatten  for sale. Consequently she is requesting a loan of S/. 2,000 from Edpyme Alternativa.

Santos, 26, is single and has no direct dependents.  He lives in his own house located in Caserío Sialupe Huamantanga belonging to Lambayeque.  Santos lives in the rural part of Lambayeque District and has running water and electricity; the place is small community of about 50 families.

The activity Santos carries out is raising and selling animals.  He’s been in this business for ten years.  The business is located at home.  He learned it from his parents, that is to say, he knows it to perfection.  This business has competition but it also has a large market to develop in.  He earns extra income in activities related to agriculture.

Santos wants to buy pigs and turkeys to sell for Christmas and increase his sales this way which is why he’s asked Edpyme Alternativa for a 1,000 new sol loan to reach his objective.

Oscar is a 46-year-old father living with his family in Cayaltí District, a zone with quite a bit of commercial activity located in Lambayeque Province an hour from the city of Chiclayo.  He’s had a home-based grocery store for the last 8 years.  He offers his customers a variety of basic staples there like groceries, vegetables and other perishables.  His customers prefer his store because it always has quality products and good service.  His business allows him to help his wife support the family.  He also works raising barnyard animals and earns daily wages working as a laborer.\r\n\r\nOscar wants to buy more groceries to expand the store and stratify demand so he’s deemed it advisable to request a 3.000 new sol loan from Edpyme Alternativa that will help him reach his goal.  He will also buy medicine for his mother who is in poor health.

Norma, 45, has a spouse and two children in her care.  She lives in her own house made of substantial materials with her husband and children.  The house is located in Caserío La Pala belonging to Tambogrande District.  She lives in the rural part of the district but does have electricity. 

Norma’s economic activity is raising and selling cattle, producing milk to sell fresh in the zone.  She works permanently and has an established clientele.  She also raises small farm animals like pigs, sheep and barnyard fowl.  Norma has more than 6 years’ experience in animal husbandry businesses.  Her husband works in agriculture on inherited land.  With the income they both earn they contribute towards moving their home forward.

Norma would like day to day to tend to more customers with respect to the milk sales and this is why she wants to buy much more milk to resell later.  On the other hand, she’d like to plant grass to feed her cattle to also increase milk production.  With this, she intends to increase her sales and as a result her income too.  This is why she’s thought it advisable to request a 1,500 new sol loan from Edpyme Alternativa.

Carmen, 58, is in a common-law relationship and lives with his family in his own house. They live in the hamlet of Quemazon in the district of Morrope, which is about 60 minutes by motorcycle from the city of Lambayeque.
Generally the name "Carmen" is given to someone of the female gender, but in his case, his parents decided to give him that name.

Carmen is a livestock farmer, something he's been doing for more than 10 years. In that time, he's acquired many clients and much experience. He breeds animals, fattens them up and when they reach an appropriate weight, he sells them to buyers who come by his place and in the local market.

Carmen wants to invest in buying animals and balanced animal feed, in order to continue growing his business. To accomplish this objective, he's soliciting a loan of 1500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

Mabel is 33 years old. She is a member of the Camarones Communal Bank. She is married and has one child. Her husband works in the metal industry. They live in the Quebrada de Arena community in Tocoa, Colon. 

Mabel started her business selling clothes three years ago. Her work schedule if from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. and she is a street seller. She needs the loan she is requesting to purchase different styles of clothing that will appeal to her customers so that she will be able to stock her business. The greatest difficulty she faces is related to the weather for when it is raining, her sales drop because she cannot do business on the street when it is raining and she does not own a vehicle to transport her goods.  

Mabel’s goal is to stabilize her business and to own a shop where she has a variety of garments to sell. This is her first loan from FAMA and she expects to make all of her payments on time.

Lusmila is 54 years old. She is single and lives with her parents and a brother in Saltur, a community dedicated to trade, agriculture and cattle raising.

She has been selling basic necessities and other groceries in a small store installed in her house for the past 15 years. Her main customers are her neighbors in the area. She offers various products that are used daily, so that her business is well patronized. Always trying to provide good customer service, Luismila tries to stock high quality merchandise and wait on her customers in a friendly manner. 

Lusmila wants to expand her business by buying more products so that she can increase his sales and profits. Consequently she is requesting her first loan for S/. 2,000 from Edpyme Alternativa.

She is well known in her community as a hardworking woman who is always ready to help when asked. Her greatest wish is to continue growing as a business woman in order to provide her family with a better quality of life.

Leodan, 34, lives with his parents and is without a family of his own. His house is in the Cayaltí district, located one hour away from the city of Chiclayo, which is the capital of the province of Lambayeque. 

Leodan is known in the area because he provides mototaxi service. He takes passengers short distances in the La Curva area. He's been running this business for 3 years and has a clientele that trusts him. Leodan has good personal and work references. His family is united and so he puts his earnings toward the family expenses.

Leodan would like to by spare parts for his mototaxi and provide its maintenance and that way improve his service. To accomplish this objective, he is requesting a loan of 1000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

With this investment he'll be able to provide his services to more clients and generate additional income for his family.

Pablo is a 48 year old farmer who is married and lives in Sololá. He has two sons. They study in a school in the community and help out in the field in their free time. 

He makes a living in agriculture, growing onions, potatoes, carrots, cabbage, radish and flowers in plots of land just a few meters from his home. He learned this from his father when he was only in primary school as he also supported his father in the field of agriculture. 

He has now been doing his own cultivation for 15 years making good money watching the vegetables grow. He requests a loan of Q 9,000.00 so that he can buy potato seeds and fertilizer to later grow and harvest, improving their income and living conditions and expanding their farming.

In the future, he wants to have a tree nursery and reforest an area that is supporting the environment of the community.

Alex is 21 years old, in a common law marriage, and lives in a home of his own located in the Huaca Quemada settlement in the Mórrope district.  This settlement is about 80 minutes from Lambayeque by motorcycle.

Alex raises livestock and has been doing this since he was a child.  His parents taught him this and he knows a lot about this business and he is able to cover his family expenses with this income.

Alex wants to buy animals to resell and also balanced feed for them.  He has requested a loan of 3,000 PEN through Edpyme Alternativa.  This will allow him to continue growing his business.

Mateo is a married, 34-year-old farmer who lives in Sololá.  He has seven children, of which there are three boys and four girls.  Four of them study in a local school and in their free time they help him in the field.  

	He works in agriculture, growing onions, potatoes, carrots, green beans, and broccoli.  He grows these on plots of land which are a few kilometers from his home.

	He learned this trade while working alongside others who needed help in the fields. He has been working since he was a young boy without having the opportunity to study at his local school.  He has been growing his own crops for six years now. Seeing that he is making good profits from growing these vegetables, he is requesting a loan of 4,000 Quetzales so that he will be able to buy fertilizer and potato seeds to later grow and harvest.  This will increase his family's income. He wants to expand his crops onto more plots of land.  

        His biggest dream is to be able to provide his children with an education so that together they can prosper.

Jikaze Group is located in Lugari District. It is a group of 15 women and 7 men led by Joan, who is pictured on the right with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Joan’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer. With her increased profits,she will send her children to school.\r\n\r\nJoan described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school, save for the future and perhaps invest in another business. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Joan’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 11 acres of land.

Elizabeth is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Sitololwe Group members. The 20 of them, 16 women and 4 men, are farmers in Lugari District. Elizabeth is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, and to grow enough food for the family. \r\n\r\nElizabeth described her harvest last year as poor. She hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer she is able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, repairing her home, buying livestock and saving for the future. Elizabeth’s group members will each receive input loans of a half acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 10 acres of maize and sorghum.

Ibrahim used the previous loan to buy maize and beans to sell. He is a 37-year-old married man with five children living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been selling beans and maize for six years. His hardships are price fluctuation, inflation, inadequate capital to purchase stock, and seasonal weather. His personal goals are educating his children, building a permanent home, and buying a car. His business goals are buying land to grow crops, expanding his business into new markets, and hiring employees to help expand his business. Ibrahim is requesting a new loan to buy beans and maize to sell.

Kanymjan is 56 years old, a widow, and has 4 children. She has been raising livestock since 1982, having started her business with an initial investment of 25,000 som. Thanks to her hard work, Kanymjan's herd currently includes 1 dairy cow, 27 sheep and 1 horse, while her monthly business profits total roughly 5,000 som (KGS).\r\n\r\nIn order to continue developing her business, Kanymjan has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 100,000 som (KGS) to purchase 1 cow with a calf and 4 young horses. She plans to invest her profits from this loan into further expansion of her business.

Nazgul is 27 years old, married, and has a wonderful son. As the main source of income, Nazgul raises livestock. After starting this business with a sum of 20,000 som (KGS), through hard work Nazgul has developed it to the point where it currently earns 10,000 som (KGS) per month. Presently, Nazgul's herd includes 4 cows, 4 horses and 10 sheep. She sells their milk and dairy products from her home. Thanks to her business profits, Nazgul can pay for her family's main expenses.\r\n\r\nIn order to continue developing her business, Nazgul has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 100,000 som (KGS) to purchase additional livestock. This will allow her to increase production of milk and, concomitantly, her family income. Nazgul plans to invest her profits from this loan into further expansion of her business. In the future, she hopes to realize one of her long-time dreams and buy a car.

Bidii Group is located in the Lugari District. It is a group of 12 women and seven men led by Pamela, pictured on the left, sitting with the green purse. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Pamela’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, and to grow enough food for the family.

Pamela described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have and even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to buy livestock as an investment for the future. Then she can send her children to school and expand her cash, and horticultural farm.

During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Pamela's group will receive 9.5 acres worth of inputs on credit. Irine, a former member of Bidii Group, dropped from the program after the photo was taken.

Lincy is a member of Jitahidi Group in Lugari District. She is pictured with 28 One Acre Fund farmers, 20 women and 8 men. Lincy is standing on the right with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Lincy's first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Lincy described her harvest last year as poor. She hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer she is able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock and perhaps investing in another business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Lincy group will receive 14 acres worth of inputs on credit.

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

Everlyne is pictured on the right in the yellow shirt amongst her Tumaini Group members. The 19 of them (13 women and 6 men) are farmers in the Lugari District. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Everlyne’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She joined this year in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.\nEverlyne described her harvest last year as good, but she hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies and perhaps invest in business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive half an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Everlyne’s group will receive 9.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

Jisaidie Group is located in Lugari District. It is a group of 16 women and 6 men led by Dinah, who is pictured on the right with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Dinah’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to grow enough food for the family and plans to use increased profits to send her children to school.\r\n\r\nDinah thought her harvest last year was poor. She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer she can have an excellent harvest. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Dinah’s group members will take input loans for a half acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 11 acres of land.

Lena is a 54-year-old married mother of two sons. She works as a medical assistant in the local hospital. Her salary is 9,221 som. However, as Lena is the main income provider for her family, she also works in animal husbandry. She started her business with 5,000 som 33 years ago. Thanks to persistent work, she has been able to develop her farm so that milk sales provide her with a monthly profit of 6,000 som. Today she has one cow and three steer on her farm. \r\n\r\nWith long term development of her farm in mind, Lena turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 120,000 som to purchase four cows, which would allow her to increase her milk production and as a result her family's income. Lena plans to invest this new income to develop her farm and eventually to buy a home for her son.

Naarkul is a 58-year-old married woman. She did not complete her college education, but she has worked in farming for many years and has a wealth of experience. She started her business with 7,500 som in 1992. Thanks to persistent work, Naarkul was able to develop her farm and it now brings her a monthly profit of 5,000 som. Naarkul's husband and daughter actively help her run the business. They organize milk sales. Today she has two cows, one steer, and five sheep on her farm. \r\n\r\nWith long term development of her farm in mind, Naarkul turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 30,000 som to purchase a cow. A new cow will allow her to increase milk production to meet demand. She plans to invest the extra income in future development of her farm and to renovate her furniture.

Margret is a forty-year-old married woman with four children living in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling clothes for fifteen years. With the proceeds she has been able to build rentals and farm for additional income. Her business is usually at peak during festive seasons and when students are on holiday. She hopes to have a bigger business despite high taxes and clients who do not pay on time. Margret is requesting for a loan to buy clothes to sell.

Fotimakhon is a 28-year-old married mother of three. Her children are nine, seven, and four years old. Her husband is a migrant worker in the Russian Federation, but his income is not enough to support all the family's needs. Hence, Fotimakhon has to deal with the family's family's daily expenses on her own. It is very difficult for Fotimakhon to support three children. She decided to start her own business in order to create an income for herself since her husband rarely sends them money. \r\n\r\nWith this goal in mind, she took the course "Bring It On", organized by the Association of Business Women. She received a certificate from the program. Now that she is fully capable of successfully starting her own business, she wants to open a wedding salon in her home. She plans to use the extra income to make sure her children have a good education and healthy diet. She is requesting a loan of 800 som to purchase some technological devices needed to start her business. She is waiting on your kindness!

Jean Pierre is a member of the TWITEZIMBERE ZONE 2 solidarity group.  He is 42 years old, married, and has 4 children.  His eldest is 25 years old and his youngest is 17.  All of his children attend school and he doesn't have any other dependents.  He was born in Rwanda and completed six years of elementary school.

Jean Pierre started working with ACT Ltd in 2011 and he is currently on his fourth loan cycle.  He repaid his previous loans in full and on time.

Jean Pierre will use his current loan to buy 65 kilos of chemical fertilizers and any money remaining will be used to pay workers.  He does not anticipate any difficulties in repaying his loan.  He envisages taking out further loans in the future in order to grow his farming business.

Jean Pierre grows rice and his business goal is to become the best rice grower in his region.  As regards his family, he aims to educate, care for and feed his children.

Patrick is a member of the TWITEKUMURIMO GTMB solidarity group.  He is a rice farmer.  He is 45 years old, married, and doesn't have any children.  He does not have any further dependents.  He was born in Rwanda and completed 6 years of elementary school.

Patrick joined ACB Ltd in 2012.  This is his first loan cycle.

Patrick will use this loan to buy 100 kilos of chemical fertilizers and to pay workers.  He does not foresee any difficulties in repaying his loan.  He plans to  request further loans in the future in order to grow his farming business.  His business goal is to become the best rice grower in the country and his personal goal is to build a brick house.

The 'Takku Liggey Jeubeut Garab' loan group consists of one woman and four men who all live in the same village.  The group is led by Oulèye who works in agriculture.  More exactly, she is a market gardener.  She has been in this business for 15 years.  Oulèye is married and a mother.  She is requesting a loan for 800,000 CFA to buy potato seeds, onion seeds, fertilizers and manure for her agricultural business.  Oulèye helps cover her family's daily expenses.  With this loan, she will be able to start saving so that she can better meet her children's needs.  She hopes, with an increase in capital, to be able to start working in other areas.

Serigne Abdou Khadre lives in Senegal.  He is single and has been working in commerce for more than 10 years.  He runs a grocery store in his town.  The income he makes from his business allows him to cover his personal needs and to pay the rent on both the room that he lives in and the store where he runs his business.  He is a member of the UIMCEC office in his town.  He is requesting a loan for 500,000 francs.  Part of the loan will be used to buy more of the foodstuffs he currently sells.  The rest will be used to buy cereals so that he can diversify his product offerings.  His goal is to increase his profits so that he can better develop his business.

Gulbahor is a resident of the Gissar region. She is a 53-year-old married mother of six. She has been selling pistachios for seven years now. She would like this loan to purchase pistachios and walnuts.

Marhabo is a 39-year-old married mother of four. Her children are 20, 17, 15, and 10 years old. Their living conditions are very difficult. Her husband is a simple worker and is not in a position to support the family. The children are grown and demand more and more economic resources. Marhabo urgently needs to find a source of income. So, she decided to start her own cattle breeding business. \r\n\r\nWith that goal in mind, she took the course "Bring It On", organized by the Association of Business Women. She received a certificate for this course. She is now fully capable of successfully starting her own business. She plans to use the extra income to provide her children with a good education and healthy diet. She is requesting a loan of 1,000 som to purchase cattle to start her new business. She is waiting on your kindness!

Mulika Group is located in Lugari District. It is a group of 16 women and 4 men led by Janet pictured on the right with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Janet’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for the family.\r\n\r\nJanet described her harvest last year as poor.  She hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer she is able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock and perhaps investing in another business. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Janet’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each.  In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

Cheikh has been farming for more than 20 years.  He starts his workday at 8.00am and finishes at 5.00pm.  He is married and a father.  He needs 100,000 francs to buy onions, bell peppers and farming supplies.  Cheikh is a father who is solely responsible for covering his household's daily expenses.  The loan has impacted his life as as it has allowed him to save and also to improve the food he feeds his children.  In the future, he would like to fence off one of his fields which is near the village.

Josephat is a fifty two year old married man with eight children living in Kasese,Uganda. He has been running a pharmacy business for twelve years and also earns a salary as a health worker in a government hospital. His dream is to educate his children up to the University level while his business plan is to own his own pharmacy despite challenges of inadequate capital. Josephat is requesting a loan to buy medicine to sell.

Kibaya used his previous loan to buy general merchandise to sell. He is a 37-year-old married man with eight children living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been running a retail shop for five years. He acquired capital by selling coffee worth 700,000 shillings and now has 4,000,000 shillings as working capital. His hardships are customers not paying on time, inadequate capital to purchase stock and high taxes. His business goals are to expand his business into new markets and move the business to a more permanent location.  His personal goals are to educate his children and build a permanent house. Kibaya intends to use the money to buy clothes, sugar  and cooking oil to sell.

Paul is a fifty-eight-year-old married man with six children, all of whom attend school. He sells timber in an urban area and rents our property; he does farming for additional income. His major customers are builders, carpenters and schools. \r\n\r\nHis dreams are to educate his children, build a permanent house to live in, and own a furniture workshop, despite the challenges of poor roads. Paul is requesting a loan to buy timber to sell.

Mamadou lives in Senegal and works as a tailor.  He has more than 5 years experience in his business.  He is a widower and doesn't have any dependents.  He is a member of one of UIMCEC's offices and is requesting a loan for 200,000 francs to buy a bedroom set.  His aim is to equip himself so that he can improve his social life.  His wish is to own a large business which produces sports clothing.

Nason is a thirty-four-year-old married man with one child living in Kasese, Uganda. He is a renowned farmer who grows bananas and coffee. With the proceeds from this work, he has been able to build rental houses and buy land. Unpredictable seasonal weather changes affect his profit predictions. His dream is to buy more land and expand his farming activities. Nason intends to use the money to buy land to farm.

Rosset is a forty-year-old single mother of three children living in Kasese, Uganda. She operates a restaurant, a business she has been running for eight years. She says she started it through the savings obtained from selling secondhand clothes. Though the capital amount that started the restaurant was small, she says it has grown, and she feels happy about it. Her hardships are price fluctuations, inflation and inadequate capital. Her personal goals are educating her children and building a permanent house for her family. She dreams of expanding into new markets so as to have increased sources of income. Rosset used her previous loan to buy customer chairs for her restaurant, and she intends to use this new loan to buy food to sell,

Rozet is a twenty-six-year-old married woman with two children living in Kasese, Uganda. She works with the town council and has been in service for three years. She has dreams of educating her children up to university and upgrading her own studies. She says that her salary alone does not allow her to meet the basics of her family. Her desire is to venture into agriculture. Rozet intends to use this loan to buy land for farming.

Eva is a 55-year-old woman who operates a cosmetic shop in Jjandira village; she began this business because she wanted to raise money to pay school fees for her children. She has seven children, and two of them are in school. 

Her main challenges include bad debtors, price fluctuations, high rent, and competition in her village. She would like to expand her business to get more income to support her grandchildren, and meet their school fees requirements.

The loan will help her buy body jelly, hair oil and other products to sell. These products will be on high demand now, since it's near the festive season and people want to look good during Christmas. She is sure she will have big sales!

Mjeni is a devoted woman who has the urge to move forward. She has been selling firewood for several years with good results. Mjeni says that she was able to start a charcoal selling business alongside her firewood business. She narrates that the previous loan she had taken was of great help to her. This current loan will enable her to buy sacks of charcoal to increase the stock she has in her store. This way she is sure to increase sales and profits. Her goal is to see her businesses flourish.

Selina is an active and enterprising woman who is dedicated to her work. She is a fighter with many goals that she wants to achieve. She is working hard to reach a more prosperous future and is very happy with her business. She has been engaged in food vending for some time. She has been able to save money to expand her line of operation. She currently operates a kiosk, which is still in its initial stages of growth. However, she is optimistic that it will grow to a bigger retail shop.\r\n\r\nSelina wants to stock her kiosk with basic grains, foodstuffs, cleaning products, etc. She is asking for a new loan to invest in the purchase of this merchandise. She has good pay references and is responsible. She promises to settle the debt and at the same time has hope that she will bring home financial security and a better quality of life for everyone.

Eunice's group has 20 farmers and is located in Lugari District. Eunice is pictured on the right of the Mathumuni Group with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Eunice’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer that will allow her to grow enough food for her family.\r\n\r\nEunice described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, saving for the future and perhaps investing in another business. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Eunice’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

Maculada is 39 years old and married. She has seven children; six of them are in school. 

She is now applying for a loan from TRM (Tuba Rai Metin).  She will use the loan to buy some additional supplies/stock to keep in her kiosk and resell.

Maculada is living in a town which is about 1 Km from the city. Beside running a kiosk, she also buys firewood from a place where people sell firewood at a very low price. 

In the future, she wants to make her business bigger.

Joan lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children who are currently in school.  For the past 15 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her poultry business, selling eggs and chicken. 

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy poultry feed for the chicks, to get better eggs.  This will help Joan generate greater profits, increase the stock, and grow the business.  

Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to have a big business . 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Joan, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

George is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married  and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past three years, George has been working hard to manage his spare parts store where he sells motor spare parts. 

To help expand his business, George has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more spare parts to sell and will help George to generate greater profits and buy more spare parts. George hopes that in the future he will be able to supply a greater variety of spare parts to his customers. 

George is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like George who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but who have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

Mwanalima lives in the town of Samburu in the province of Coast. She is 24 years old and a married mother of two children who are currently in school. \r\n\r\nMwanalima decided to start a meat goat business three years ago. She says that it has been a profitable project. She is requesting this loan in the amount of KES 30,000 to buy more goats for sale. Mwanalima says that it is a job that needs a lot of dedication since it has many challenges.

Richard is 42 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married  and has five children who are all currently in school. For the past 12 years, Richard  has been working hard to manage his health clinic. 

To help expand his business, Richard has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medicine and machines that are used for examining patients. The loan will help Richard to generate greater profits. Richard hopes that in the future he will be able to produce more quality products. 

Richard  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Richard who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but who have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

Emmanuel is taking out another loan to expand his existing business. He wants to buy some pigs. With the previous loan, he was able to earn more  sales revenue, which improved his family's living standards. He is very sure that this loan will also have a positive impact on his business. Emmanuel would like to thank Kiva lenders for their support.

Nasif is from Iraq. He is 31 years old, married and has three children. Nasif is the only provider in his family.

Nasif is a barber who owns barber shop. He established his business in 2003 and now he has one employee. He has earned good experience in this field, and he has an excellent reputation in the surrounding area.

He is requesting a sum of $3,000 loan to pay the annual rent on his shop. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to improve his family's standard of living.

Godfrey is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Godfrey has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand his business, Godfrey has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, soap, salt and other commodities to resell. This inventory boost will help Godfrey generate greater profits and produce quality products. Godfrey hopes that in the future he will be able to produce more quality products. 

Godfrey is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). This program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Godfrey who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Semu is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has two children who are both currently in school. 

For the past three years, Semu has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells flour, sugar, rice, etc. 

To help expand his business, Semu has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more products such as flour, sugar and rice for resale and will help Semu to generate greater profits and buy more goods. Semu hopes that in the future he will be able to produce more quality products. 

Semu is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Semu who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Hamza is 25 years old and is a very hardworking man. He is a native of Samburu and lives with his wife and their two children. 

Hamza has a grocery store in his home. He started with a few items and began to increase with the help of his own savings and the loans he got through Yehu. He says that his work requires a lot of sacrifice because only he and his wife work out of the whole family. His dream is to set up a supermarket in his neighborhood.

He is asking for this loan in order to buy flour, noodles, breads, rice, cooking fat and other supplies that make up his greatest sales.

Dorcas is a member of Nandebe Group in Lugari District. She is pictured with 20 One Acre Fund farmers, 13 women and 7 men. Dorcas is standing on the right with her hand raised. Dorcas is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, receive the best input prices, ensure reliable input delivery, grow enough food for the family and use her increased profits to send her children to school.\r\n\r\nLast year, Dorcas harvested 4 bags of maize on 0.5 acres of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock, eradicating poverty in her family and saving for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Dorcas’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

This is 28-year-old David L. He is single and has one child, age 1 year 4 months. 

In 2005, David L. established his clothing business. He began his business because after he graduated from college, he was not fortunate to have a job and was advised by a friend who was a trader to join his business. 

Instead of sitting idling at home, he started with a small amount from his savings. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about SLL 506,000 every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 4,000,000. David L. requires a loan in order to purchase men's sport shorts - 1 bale @ SLL 2,000,000; children's wear - 1 bale @ SLL 1,000,000, and men's shirts - 1 bale @ SLL 1,000,000. 

Competition in his line of business is high and he requires enough capital to buy goods that are in great demand.

In the future, David L. plans to expand his business and open a store befitting his large stock. He is a hardworking business man. He thanks you for your support

This is 41-year-old Yorroh. She is married, and has five children, age 21, 18, 15, 8 and 2 years old. Four are school-going children. 

In 2007, Yorroh established her enamel pans and plastic business. She began her business because she did not have the opportunity to go to school because girl children's education was not important. After her marriage ceremony, her dowry was given to her, with which she set up her own business.  

Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about SLL 354,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Yorroh requires a loan in order to purchase pan sets - 20 sets @ SLL 30,000; hot pots - 20 set @ SLL 80,000; rubber buckets - 40 pieces @ SLL 100,000, enamel cups - 36 pieces @ SLL 5,000, and fruit plates - 22 pieces @ SLL 10,000. 

In the future, Yorroh plans to open a shop and help her children through school. The changes in the buying habits of customers are her problem. She hopes to acquire more loans so that she can improve her business. She thanks you for your support.

Jipange is a group of 11 farmers in Lugari District represented by Irine. The group has 6 women and 5 men. Irine is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Irine is a new One Acre Fund farmer, and she is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to get hybrid seed and fertilizer, access the best input prices, be sure of reliable input delivery, grow enough food for the family and use her increased profits to send her children to school.

Irine described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Irine’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5.5 acres of land.   

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo. Vincent dropped out of the group after the photo was taken.

Norica is a member of Angel Group in Lugari District. She is pictured with 20 One Acre Fund farmers, 14 women and 6 men. Norica is wearing a yellow shirt. Norica is a new One Acre Fund farmer, and she is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use the increased profits to send her children to school.

Last year, Norica harvested 2 bags of maize from 0.5 acres of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and buy livestock as an investment for the future. Norica’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season.  In total, they will receive inputs for 7 acres of maize and sorghum.

Agnes dropped out of the group after the photo was taken.

Qudratullo lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. He is 30 years old and has two small children. His wife takes care of the household. Qudratullo is an economist by profession, but does not work in this specialty. Instead, for the past 7 years he has been engaged in animal husbandry. He earns his living by raising cattle. Qudratullo is taking this loan to purchase two cows.

Zumratbi lives in the city of Dushanbe. She is 54 years old, married, and a mother of four children. Together with her sons, Zumratbi has been engaged in retail at a market for the past five years. She rents a stall where she sells women's footwear. Zumratbi is taking this loan to stock up on new merchandise.

Margaret, 28, lives with her husband and their four children.

She runs a store where she sells essential items such as basic grains, beverages, oils and other products. The store is located in her home and is very well known because she is a good salesperson and sells quality products at low prices. 

Margaret is very dedicated to her work and is always looking for ways to prosper. She wants to stay ahead of the competition and invest in her business, but she is in need of capital. Therefore she has requested a loan from Yehu to buy basic grains, instant products, sweets, bread, beverages, flour, etc.

Margaret is able to make payments on her loan and has a good credit record. She is happy to receive the support and is confident she can pay back the loan on time, while giving her family the more fulfilling life that they deserve.

Housein is from Iraq. He is a youth client, 23 years old and married, who lives with five family members, of whom two are employed.

Housein owns an aluminum workshop. He specializes in making doors and windows. He established his business in 2010, and now he has an employee. He has good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a youth loan of $2,400 to purchase equipment to work with construction grade PVC plastic and to increase his inventory. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

Jiendeleshe is a group of 20 farmers in the Lugari District represented by Linet. The group has 16 women and 4 men. Linet is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. The 2013 long rains season will be Linet’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, access the best input prices and assurance of reliable input delivery. She hopes to grow enough food for the family and use the increased profits to send her children to school.

Last year, Linet harvested seven bags of maize on 1 acre of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 long rains season. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to support her children’s studies. 

Linet’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 long rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 10 acres of maize and sorghum.

This is 39-year-old Aminata. She is widowed and has one child, age 6 years, who goes to school. She has one additional dependent who lives with her because she got him during the civil war.  

In 1997, Aminata established her business selling shoes, traveling bags, pan sets, flasks, women's dresses, etc. She began her business because she stopped school in class four. Her aunt did not allow her to further her schooling and she was attached to her aunt's shop.  When she fully matured, her elder sister sent money from abroad to start her business. 

Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,500,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Aminata requires a loan in order to purchase plastic shoes - 20 bundles @ SLL 144,000, and pan sets - 1 set @ SLL 70,000. The balance of SLLL 50,000 will be used for transport. 

In the future, Aminata plans to complete her house, acquire a shop and educate her child and dependent. The loan will help to increase stock and generate more income.  

Inadequate capital is her major challenge. She is hardworking and committed to her business  She thanks you for your support.

This is 32 year-old Mariama.  She is married and has two children, ages 14 and 11. 

In 2002, Mariama established her charcoal business. She began her business because she wanted to be of great help to her husband, and to adequately care for their children. 

Her business is located in  the city center, and her main customers are business people in food and catering, and households using charcoal.  Her business is open 7 days a week and 12 hours a day. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5000000. Mariama would use the loan to buy large quantities of charcoal, and to do little repairs in her store. 

In the future, Mariama plans to buy a big truck to transport the charcoal and do little repairs in her store. She thanks you for your support.

Enkhbaatar, 29, lives with his wife and two children in a rented house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital. Since 2010 Enkhbaatar has been managing a PC game center by renting a 40-square-meter house. His wife has worked as a packer in a private pharmaceutical company for 4 years. His boys go to kindergarten. His business is going well. 

Initially Enkhbaatar started the business with 6 PCs and now he has 20 PCs. Throughout the day Enkhbaatar stays on his business and night times he runs a taxi to gain extra income for his family. In 2006 his family bought a plot of land in an area of the city with no running water, minimal roads and spotty electricity. In the meantime, they have been building a house and it’s 80% complete. 

Enkhbaatar spent all the money he saved since he began his business to build a house. Now he is short on money and due to that, his building has to stop. Therefore, Enkhbaatar is a requesting a loan to complete his house. Using the loan, he will do interior decoration and install a low-pressure furnace, which emits less carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, and build a barn where the house door meets with outside.

Rose is 42 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is single and has four children with two of them currently in school. For the past 18 years, Rose  has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Rose  has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to increase the size of the business and have more space for her customers to sit, and will help Rose  to generate greater profits and purchase foods at a lower price and in higher quantity. Rose  hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business. 

Rose  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rose  who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Dennis is 30 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi  in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past two years, Dennis  has been working hard to manage his electronics store, which sells televisions and mobile phones. 

To help expand his business, Dennis  has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to procure more televisions and mobile phones for resale, and will help Dennis  to generate greater profits and improve his stock, hence more income and a higher standard of living. Dennis  hopes that in the future he will be able to make the business grow. 

Dennis  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Dennis  who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Having been a mere housewife who took care of the house for about five years, Josephine was introduced to selling beauty products out of her home by a friend and saw it as a way to supplement her income. Since beginning one year ago, she has greatly expanded not only her area of business, but has also taken on a managerial role with several other product sellers working under her. Josephine enjoys being her own boss and having the ability to work with different clients and other product sellers.

Due to lack of credit, she approached Yehu in order to find financing for her business and help provide financial support for her family.

This is Josephine’s first loan with Yehu. She wants to use it to buy more products in bulk in order to sell them at a better price and expand her business. She also wants to be able to continue growing her clients' confidence in her product. This loan will increase her abilities as a businesswoman and help her continue to enhance her position within the beauty product market.

Lameka is 49 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi  in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married  and has seven children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Lameka has been working hard to manage his poultry farm, which sells chickens. 

To help expand his business, Lameka has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to develop the business and build more space for the chicks to grow, and will help Lameka to generate greater profits to improve his standard of living and pay school fees for his children. Lameka hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the poultry farm. 

Lameka is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lameka who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Jane is 24 years old and is a married mother of one young child. Thanks to her efforts, her child has everything she needs. Jane has a vegetable stall located in a municipal market in her area. She has been doing this type of work for one year, and she has managed to build up a good reputation, which has enabled her to attract many regular customers.\r\n\r\nShe is seeking a loan from Yehu so that she will be able to buy fruit and vegetables in larger quantities. This gives her the advantage of buying at slightly lower prices so that she can make more profit, which is her main goal.

Zoyir works at a marked. He sells men's clothing (classical trousers). Zoyir has been in this business for six years. He is taking this loan to expand the assortment of his merchandise.\r\n\r\nZoyir is 49 years old, married, and has two children. His wife takes care of the household.

This is 40-year-old Rugiatu. She is married and has two children, 21 and 7 years old. They are both school-going children. She has one additional dependent.

In 1999, Rugiatu established her baby clothing and jewelry business. She began her business because her mother died when she was a child. Her father could not take good care of her, so he had to take her to a close friend who was a trader. She did not think it fit for her to attend school because she was not willing to pay her school fees. Instead, she was made into a house girl for several years. Later, he died and then her elder brother took her. They could barely feed her, let alone train her in school.  

She started trading with him in order to help in the running of the home. She has been a trader ever since she was a child and started her own business years later.  

Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 740,000 every month from this business. Rainy season is her major challenge for her business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. 

Rugiatu has already received and successfully repaid three loans, and now she requires a new loan in order to purchase women's underwear - 40 dozen @ Le 18,000; women's blouses - 20 dozen @ Le 150,000; baby wrappers - 3 dozen @ Le 216,000. The balance of Le 132,000 will be used as transport. 

In the future, Rugiatu plans to build a house and open a shop for her growing business. She wants her children to have a good education. The loan will help her as it is her only additional income. Her business is growing gradually and require enough capital to operate effectively, so she is looking forward to paying her loan in order to acquire subsequent loans. She thanks you for your support.

This is 48-year-old Saidu B. He is married and has three children, 20, 15 and 10 years old. All are school-going children. 

In 2010, Saidu B established his business, selling things like cigarettes, soap, batteries, paste, milk, sardines, toothbrushes, etc. He began his business because he was not privileged to attend school. He used to farm with his father and when he became mature, he farmed on his own and the proceeds were used to start a small business in the village.  

Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about Le 2,250,000 every month from this business. Inadequate capital is his major challenge.  He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. 

Saidu B. has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now he requires a new loan in order to buy cigarettes - 3 cartons @ Le 620,000; batteries - 5 cartons @ Le 171,000; sardines - 5 cartons @ Le 125,000; Peak milk - 4 cartons @ Le 260,000; drinks - 6 dozen @ Le 20,000. 

In the future, Saidu B. plans to open another outlet, provide quality education for his children, build a house and become a famous businessman.  This loan will help to achieve some of his future plans. He is a hardworking businessman. He thanks you for your support.

Oyuntuya is 23 years old, a single woman. She lives with her mother and her 2-year-old only son in their wooden house in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. Oyuntuya works as a waitress at a restaurant which is counted one of the biggest in her home town. She is active, open-minded and a hardworking woman.
