Her mother rents a grocery counter in the market and her son goes to kindergarten. \r\n\r\nOyuntuya said that soon she will be working as an administrator of the restaurant thanks to her service quality. Now Oyuntuya is asking for a 6,000,000 MNT loan to maintain a roof part of the house which drips water, because the winter is the exactly right time to do it. And she plans to make a sewer line for her house by using a well which is located on their land. If she makes these changes to her house there will be no need to use an outside toilet. By doing this her family can improve their sanitary and living conditions.

Hajara is 37 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi  in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has eight children. For the past five years, Hajara has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, where she looks after chicks, raising both layers and boilers. 

To help expand her business, Hajara has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to acquire more chicks, and will help Hajara to generate greater profits and buy chicken feed. Hajara hopes that in the future she will be able to construct a bore hole and start another farm of goats. 

Hajara is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hajara who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

Netri is a 32-year-old lady and is married to Oktaf, 35. They are blessed with two children who are five and one and a half years old. She is running a kiosk business to assist her husband in generating more income for her family. She selected the business for it is still rarely run by people in the village. She provides bath soap, detergent, stationery, cigarettes, candies, snacks etc. \r\n\r\nNetri was thinking to add more goods to her kiosk inventory (e.g., sugar, coffee, cooking oil and kitchen equipment) as demanded by the customers. Netri then requested a loan of IDR 7,000,000 from TLM. Netri believes that the loan assistance can help her to complete the stock in her kiosk.

Tami is a 28 year old married woman and mother of two children. Tami has been working as a hairdresser for three years.  In 2010, she started her own business to improve her family's living.

Tami is a hard worker.  Because she manages her business from her house, she can take good care of her family members at the same time.  She also works as a tutor to increase her income. 

Tami is applying for a youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to buy new furniture and tools to please her customers in a more relaxing atmosphere.  This is Tami's first experience as an Al Majmoua borrower. She is planning that with future experience, she will invest in moving her hairdressing business from her house to a special beauty salon in a very important region.

Ulsuluv lives in the Gissar region. She is a 57-year-old widow and has 5 children. She has a wealth of experience in selling nuts and pistachios, as she has been doing this for more than 7 years. Ulsuluv is seeking a loan to increase her turnover so she can expand her business.

Habillo lives in the Yavan region. He is 70 years old, married, and has 4 children. He is a philologist by profession, and has been working in that field for more than 20 years. He also has a small vineyard and has been growing grapes for the last 15 years. Habillo is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer.

Ilhomiddin lives in the Yavan region. He is 39 years old, married, and has 2 children. He is a winegrower, and has been doing this type of work for over 8 years. Ilhomiddin is seeking a loan to buy mineral fertilizer.

Marie Aline is a 42-year-old woman, married with five children between the ages of 9 and 25. All of her children are in school. She has a lot of experience in the business, which has allowed her to build a considerable client base. She would like to use this loan to buy bags of peanuts and pistachios, and some drums of oil to increase her stock of merchandise and satisfy her customers. Her income from this business will allow her to better ensure her children's education and health.

Mwanaisha, 26, a married mother of two children, lives with them in the municipality of Mombasa. She has had a business operating a rented food stall for six months.

\r\n\r\nMwanaisha is requesting her first loan from Yehu for 20,000 KES to purchase flour, meat, salt, rice, meat, vegetables, beans, and other supplies in order to meet customer demand. In the future, she plans to expand her business to provide better service.

Nimrod is a 36-year-old married man, blessed with two children: Rini, 10 years old, attends 4th grade of the elementary school and Nofri, 8 years old, attends 2nd grade.

\r\n\r\nHaving only a junior high school education prevented Nimrod from getting a permanent job, so two years ago he began to use his motorbike as a motor taxi to generate income for his family. Due to a little damage to his vehicle, currently Nimrod cannot operate the business and so has requested a loan of IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. The loan will help him to buy a spare part and a used motorbike to generate further income.

Mr. Meteda, is a devoted entrepreneur who lives in northern coastal plain of Papua, Indonesia. Papua is one if the poorest of Indonesia’s provinces and is plagued by social unrest. By selling Nazava Water Filters Meteda and his wife can acquire additional daily income. In just 3 months, Meteda sold 100 water filters and provided over 500 people with access to safe and affordable drinking water. 

Meteda sells water filters to both rich and poor because everybody is in need of ways to clean their drinking water. Compared to buying water, households save $132 USD per year using Nazava water filters, which enable them to purify rain, well or river water and make it safe to drink. 

The water filters that Nazava sells are assembled on the Indonesian Island of Java 3000 km from Mr. Meteda. Shipping them takes often more than 3 weeks. 

“Transport takes very long and I currently have the cash for just 12 filters, that’s why I often have to disappoint consumers because I quickly run out of stock“, says Mr, Meteda.

To fulfill the high need of Nazava water filters in his region, Meteda desires to buy a larger amount at reduced transport costs. 

With a 1100 USD loan, Mr Meteda can make safe drinking water available to 500 people in just 1 month. The loan allows him to purchase around 100 water filters at a reduced price and with reduced transportation costs. This will help more households in obtaining safe drinking water, augment their disposable income as well as the profit for Meteda’s family.

Gulbahor lives in the Gissar region. She is 28 years old, married, and has 2 children. She has a high school education and is a seamstress. For the past 2 years, she has been working from her home sewing traditional national dresses. Gulbahor is seeking a loan to buy a sewing machine.

Cleanta is the coordinator of her group, Paix de Jesus ("Peace of Jesus"), in the northern region of Haiti where electricity is scarce and water is very limited. She is unmarried and has two children. Cleanta has had her business selling diverse products for the last five years.\r\nBefore starting her business, Cleanta was a student. She would like to use this loan for selling diverse products. She hopes that this loan will allow her to make more sales. The other Paix de Jesus group members need a loan for businesses such as selling coal, clothing, and cosmetics. She says that her main challenge is having enough money to increase her sales.

This is 34-year-old Musa.  He is married and has 2 children, ages 10 and 8, both of whom are in school. 

In 1992, Musa established his second-hand clothing business. He began his business because he did not have the opportunity to go to school. Since his parents are traders, when was he was much older he decided to join them in business.  He helped his parents for years, until he decided to set up his own business. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about Le 521,000 every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. Musa wants to purchase sport shorts for men - 2 bales @ Le1,350,000 and T-shirts for men - 11/2 bales @ Le1,300,000. 

Since Musa was not fortunate enough to be educated, his future plans include the hope to support his children through school to whatever level they choose.  He hopes to expand his business, though competition is his main challenge.  

The loan will help him achieve his dream by requiring subsequent loans.  He will be able to buy more stock in order to be competitive.  He is a hardworking-business man.  He thanks you for your support.

Margret, a 32-year-old single mother of three children, all in school, lives in the town of Wobulenzi in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past five years, Margret has been working hard to manage her store, which sells clothing and bags.

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to obtain more stocks of clothes; this will help her to generate greater profits and live a more comfortable life. Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to build up the business.

Margret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

Mwanakombo is a person who has values, such as honesty, humility, respect and hard work, that were emphasized by her parents. These qualities have shaped who she is and have allowed her to set an example for her five children.

She is requesting a loan from Yehu so that she can buy more fish to stock her fish selling business. Mwanakombo sells at the market. Her work requires great sacrifice, yet she performs her duties with great care since she knows that she will be able put food on the table each day.

She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income. She is confident in the work she has achieved and will use her earnings to pay for the education of the five children who are still dependent on her.

Mishi has spent the past five years building a strong firewood business. While it may seem like a small, home-based business, it is really an effort to provide the neighbors with cooking materials they need. Her warm personality and the attention given to each of her clients has created a loyal client base. Mishi’s vision goes beyond the firewood – she sees the product as a way to build community and help women build confidence through a network of like-minded individuals.\r\n\r\nWith her loan from Yehu, Mishi will be purchasing more inventory to increase the services she provides to her clients. Furthermore, she is striving to achieve the goal of incorporating charcoal selling in her current business. Continuing to build her clients and her business will give her the leverage she needs to grow.

Nina is a 41-year-old married Lebanese woman living with her husband and three children. One of her children works, and the other two still attend school. In 2008, Nina started running her own business from home by selling makeup, accessories and perfumes. Her income is important to help with her household expenses and to pay her children's school fees. Nina's husband works at a local company, and they cooperate to meet the needs of life. Today, Nina is asking for a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to expand her inventory of perfumes, accessories and makeup. Her intention at this stage is to augment her sales so as to amplify her income. In the future, she is planning to open her own shop.

Ibrahim is from Iraq. He is 50 years old, married, has five children and is his family's sole provider. He owns a store where he sells tools and other hardware supplies. He established his business in 2011 and now has one employee. Ibrahim has acquired a lot of experience in this field, is well known in the surrounding area and has an excellent reputation. He is requesting a loan for $2,400 to install a display window and shutters in his store and to buy more items to sell to his customers. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so that he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

Grace, a member of Tuinuane Group in Lugari District, is pictured with 23 One Acre Fund farmers, which consists of 13 women and 10 men. Grace is standing on the right with her hand raised. A new One Acre Fund farmer and excited about the 2013 Long Rains season, she joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer.

\r\n\r\nGrace described her harvest last year as poor. She hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer that she will join the ranks of those who have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. Her biggest concern is sending her children to school, so she plans on using future profits from the harvest to support their studies. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Grace’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 12 acres of land.

Mary is a responsible and hardworking mother who works long days with one great dream of providing her family with the necessities of life. She has had a tailoring business for several years which has been growing since she received her previous loan.

Mary is requesting a new loan to invest in the purchase of used clothing which she sells from her tailoring workshop and also door to door. To make the most of her week, she visits a different neighborhood during the weekends to gain more customers.

She is happy to be entrusted with loans by Kiva and Yehu.

Umoja Group is located in Lugari District. It is a group of 9 women and 11 men led by Serah pictured on the right with her hand raised. Serah is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer\r\n\r\nSerah described her harvest last year as good but hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school and buying livestock. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Serah’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

Represented by Marbel, Kewa is a group of 20 farmers in the Lugari District. The group has 12 women and 8 men, and Marbel is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Marbel’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits for her children's education.

\r\n\r\nMarbel, who described her harvest as very good last year, believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, buying livestock, and perhaps investing in another business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Marbel’s group will receive 10 acres worth of inputs on credit.

Yassine is a 28-year-old Lebanese man who lives with his wife and child. Since their marriage, he has taken on responsibility for supporting his family by running an auto spare-parts shop. He opened this shop in 2006 and has all kinds of parts in stock so that he can fill customer orders. He is requesting a youth loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l, to increase his shop’s inventory of mechanical tools and supplies such as car mirrors. Yassine is really happy with how his shop is doing and the fact that he has earned a higher income by expanding it. In the future, he plans to open a new store at a new location.

Rose, 41 years old, is a hard-working woman. She lives in the coastal region of Kenya. She owns rental houses which she has managed for the last ten years. She is a married mother of three children who are all in school. She will use the loan she asks for to buy construction materials to repair her rental house. She hopes to offer a more conducive environment to her tenants. Rose hopes to have more rental houses in future.

Helen is 40 years old and lives with her life partner and their children in their own house. She handbags and shoes door to door, which are all made-to measure with quality materials and offered at excellent prices. Above all she gives very good customer service. In addition to this business, Helen owns a motorcycle taxi where she has hired a gentleman to operate it.\r\n\r\nHelen is an active woman and dedicated to her work with many dreams that she wants to fulfill. She wants to be successful and knows that the only way to achieve this is through perseverance and with a lot of motivation.She is asking for a loan to repair her motorcycle which developed technical problems the other day. Doing this, she will ensure safety of her customers and at the same time increase efficiency of the services hence increase her income.

Abbas is a 31 year old Lebanese man. He’s single, living with his parents and five siblings. Two of them are assisting with the family expenses in addition to the father their main source of income. As for Abbas, he has been working as a black smith many years ago. He learned this profession from his father who has the same occupation, and doing the best he can to better improve and develop himself. Despite his tough work tasks, and in order to better support his father, Abbas works really hard and nonstop. And as he wants to enlarge his business and grow his work as well, he decided to take a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase the needed metal supplies and carry on his work in a proper way.  He is very thankful for what god has given him and wishes to live a better and respectable life.

Eunice lives in the city of Mombasa in the province of Coast. She is married and has two children who are in school. She went into the business of selling snacks and vegetables as a way to make a contribution to her household and improve her and her family's life. She is requesting a loan to buy more snacks and vegetables to sell. Her goal is to have her own shop where she can sell all kinds of snack foods as well as distribute them to local high schools and elementary schools.

Gulbahor lives in the city of Dushanbe.  She is 41 years old, a widow, and she has five children.  Gulbahor is a dressmaker; she sews at her home.  She has been in this line of work for 15 years.  She is asking for a loan to buy a sewing machine to do her work together with her daughter.

Annie is a young woman from Cameroon, age 32. She has owned and operated a mobile call centre for over one year. She sells phone credit. Dynamic and welcoming, she feels that her stock of phone credit is not enough for her growing clientele. This loan will allow her to buy phone credit on a larger scale from the supplier (100 000 francs of time from Orange and 100 000 francs of time from MTN). The discount on this bulk purchase will allow her to increase her capital and have a mini kiosk, and to cover her family's costs.

Hasan is a 21 year old Lebanese single man. He lives with his parents and two siblings. He has worked as a private teacher since 2010. He tries his best to help learners get necessary education in a short period of time at low costs. Even though his father is responsible for all their expenses, Hasan wants to have his own business and future career. They are both cooperating to gather enough money and be able to cover their needs. Today, Hasan is applying for a youth loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a laptop for his business. In that way he will be able to do the necessary research for his students very easily and rapidly. He really wishes to receive more students with the coming school season and therefore increase his earnings.

Abir is a 39-year-old, married woman. She lives with her husband and three children. They are all attending school. She is obliged to work continually as she is responsible with her husband for covering the family expenses and responding to their children’s needs. She started her business in 2003 when she opened her own shoe shop. She provides her customers with good quality products at fair prices. She earns a barely fair income that is not sufficient to cover her costs; this is the reason of why she’s asking today for a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new collection of shoes. In the near future, she wishes to open other branches and maybe hire new employees to help her achieve the work tasks and therefore earn higher income.

Lenitus is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Pambazuko Group members. The 20 of them, 16 women and 4 men, are farmers in Lugari District. Lenitus is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer.\r\n\r\nLenitus thought her harvest last year was poor. She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer she can have an excellent harvest. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on investing in another business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Lenitus’s group will receive 10 acres worth of inputs on credit.

Martin, 39, is a responsible and hardworking father. He lives together with his wife (who helps him with his business) and with their two small children. Martin sells snacks on a main street. It is a busy street, which is good for him. He works everyday and has many regular customers.

He is requesting a loan with the intention to buy a larger amount of snacks for sale.

Martin is a hardworking person and is always trying to have a better life.

Marisol lives in a rental property with her mother and her four daughters. The house has three spaces, including a kitchen and a bathroom. It also has fine finishes and wooden floors. The house is located in the District of Alto San Pedro in the city of La Paz.

Marisol has a degree in Tourism and works for a private institution. She receives a salary that enables her to pay for expenses such as food, basic services, and the rent on her home. Marisol is requesting a loan so that she can pay for dental treatment. She has several teeth that are in danger of being extracted if they are not treated.

This is the fourth time she has worked with IMPRO and the third time with Kiva.

James is 42 years old, and he and his life partner have three children. He lives in a suburb of Likoni, Kenya and has for the last 10 years earned a living by selling fruits and vegetables, including tomatoes, potatoes, hot peppers, carrots, onions, lettuce, bananas and cabbage. He buys these vegetables wholesale from nearby producers and sells them in retail markets. His business is profitable because he is able to turn over his inventory each day. James is requesting a loan for 40,000 KES to buy more products to sell and to insure that he always has items to offer to his customers. His goal is to make his business grow and reach financial solvency.

Parviz lives in the city of Dushanbe.  He is 29 years old and is married with one child.  His wife is a homemaker.  Parviz has been working as a taxi driver for two years.  He mainly drives his fares around the city.  Parviz is asking for a loan to fix his taxi.

Tsiala is 47 years old and lives in Batumi city with her husband. She owns a two-story house in the city center and rents out the first floor. The rent and her husband's pension are their only sources of income. Tsiala wants to supplement her family's income by renovating a room on the second floor of her house so she can rent it out. Several people have already expressed an interest in living there, but she has been unable to get a loan to pay for renovations from several local financial institutions. That is why she is requesting a loan from Kiva and Credo, which help people who do not qualify for conventional loans. She will use the loan to buy the materials she needs to renovate her house. Tsiala hopes that renting out this room will be profitable and increase her income so that she and her family can improve their standard of living.

Vanessa lives at her mother’s house. At the moment, she is not able to find work as an accountant so she is operating a neighborhood store from her mother’s house. The house has one room, is made of brick, and has wooden floors. Her home is located in the District of Alto San Pedro in the city of La Paz.

Vanessa’s grocery store is her only source of income. The loan she is requesting will increase her capital so that she can restock her store. In other words, she will buy more sugar, rice, and sodas, as well as other items, such as stuffed animals and toys for the Christmas season.

Vanessa’s dream is to have a larger store so that she can grow her business and improve her earnings. This will enable her to support herself until she can find a job as an accountant.

This is the first time she has worked with IMPRO and Kiva.

Mwanakombo, 26, describes herself as a cheerful and friendly person, but someone who does not like things that are unfair. She lives with her husband and children in Likoni in the province of Coast.

Mwanakombo sells charcoal. In addition, she operates a green grocery selling a variety of fruits and vegetables. The business has allowed her to help her husband cover expenses related to their children's education and to the various household needs. This is her fourth experience with Yehu. She plans to use the loan to buy sacks of charcoal to continue with her sales business.

Her goal is for her children to finish their education.

Mwanatumu, 32, lives in her own house with her husband and four young children. She sells charcoal from her home. She is a very enterprising woman who works hard to help cover household expenses and earn a little money to cover some needs. She has struggled to keep her business afloat because competition is always there. She has been in business for six years, so she has many regular customers. Her customers prefer dealing with her because she’s a very charismatic, honest working woman.\r\n\r\nShe has decided to ask Yehu for a loan because she wants to buy sacks of charcoal to keep her business well-stocked. She states that she is very grateful to this institution because it provided her with help in the past when she most needed it. She hopes to have favorable results this time too.

Martin was able to buy clothes to resell during the previous cycle. He is grateful to the lenders for his loan through Ugafode. It is now approaching Christmas, and people are buying clothes for the festive season. He has therefore taken a loan of 1,500,000 UGX to buy more inventory before the prices go up. He will sell the inventory to his customers who are preparing for festivities and parties. He is confident he will make a big profit. He thanks Ugafode for the trust they have developed in him by giving him more. He is hard-working and honest.

Aziza is hard-working, calm and quiet. She is married and has 3 young children at home. Their living conditions are hard. Like all women living in 'kishlak' settlements, she works in the field to earn money to support her family, and she also raises cattle. In order to feed their children, Aziza's husband went to Russia to make money. Once he returned home, he again began to work in animal husbandry and growing crops. Aziza mainly grows barley, and also has an orchard where she grows apples and pears. She has been doing this business for over 10 years, and her husband helps her. She sells her produce to local residents at a lower price than they would pay at the bazaar, as there is no middle-man. She wants to earn more money so she can finish the house that she started building a few years ago. Aziza is seeking a loan of 3,000 Tajikistan Somoni to buy construction materials like cement, bricks, wood, and so on. She is waiting for your kind assistance.

Farogat is 20 years old.  She is not married and she lives with her parents.  She is a very focused and hard-working young woman.  Farogat did not have an opportunity to go to university and receive a higher specialization after she graduated from high school, so she decided to become an entrepreneur and to fulfill her plans that way.  With that goal in mind, she completed the "Get Ahead" course organized by the Association of Businesswomen and received a certificate.  Now she is fully capable of starting her business and becoming successful in that sphere.  Farogat wants to start a business buying and selling children's clothing.  She would like to use the income from her business to buy the necessary things for her dowry, such as clothing, items of gold, perfume, etc, as she plans to get married if she meets a good young man.  Farogat is asking for a loan of 3,000 somoni to buy the goods to start her business.  She is awaiting your kindness.

Transito is a woman who desires to do her very best for her family so that they can improve little by little and never be stagnant but rather keep striving for a better life. Transito lives with her husband, who works as a labourer alongside her, and their five children. The children are all minors but the oldest ones help with the work.\r\n\r\nThey sow beans and corn and then sell them in staple food stores and markets. In order to be able to count on extra income and grow their business, Transito requests a loan from INTEGRAL to buy cattle; with which they can produce dairy products to sell, at the same time as starting to buy and sell cattle.

Thirty-five-year-old Lady is a kind and cheerful woman.  She lives in her own home with her partner, Luis, who works for a business as a tractor driver.  She has three children who are 21, 14, and 4 years old for whom she works hard so she can give them a good education.  Lady's work consists of selling carbonated drinks, like different flavored soft drinks, and different kinds of beers.  As such, she has a refrigerator to keep her drinks cold.  Alongside that, she sells snacks, such as cookies, chocolates, and candy, among other things.  She carries out her work in a small space in her home.  She has had her business for three years and she started this work to help her partner out with the household expenses.  Today, it is very profitable because her shop is in a very convenient location for her customers.  She is thinking about renting a commercial space with a good location in the future where she can sell snacks wholesale.  This will be her third loan with MFP and she is very thankful to her group for giving her the opportunity to get capital to support her business.  With the requested 1,000 soles, she will buy carbonated drinks, such as different kinds of beer and different flavors of soft drinks.  She will also buy snacks, such as cookies, chocolates, candy, etc. and she will buy a display case so she can better exhibit her products.

Komiljon is 46 years old, married, and has four children. He tries to comfort his family with all the modern conveniences. With this aim, 12 years ago he began own business selling children’s clothes. Also, he has additional income from his food market. \r\n\r\nTo improve business, he is borrowing from Imon International organization in order to buy clothes for the new season.  He is hopeful of the possibility of expanding his business before long.

Tuychiboy lives in a village with his wife and six children. The family gathers their main income from farming; they cultivate onions. He has been busy with this business more than ten years. 

He has applied for this loan to purchase seeds and chemical fertilizers. Such expansion will significantly increase his profit from agriculture. 

Tuychiboy plans to use his profit for purchasing more seeds and chemicals and minerals in the future. He awaits your support.

Fifty-year-old Betty is an enterprising woman.  She lives in her own home by herself, as her children are independent.  Betty's work consists of sewing women's and little girls' clothing, such as blouses, polo shirts, and lingerie, among other things.  She carries out her business in a small space in her home.  She has been doing this work for six years; she started out with some friends who were sewing dresses for young ladies who were turning 15 and she saw that it was a profitable business.  Now her friends are her partners and together they sew clothing in bulk.  Her family gave her the financial support to buy her first sewing machine.  Currently, she hopes to form a small company along with her friends because she has more customers every day and she already has several orders.  As such, she is asking for 2,000 soles to buy supplies in bulk, such as fabric, thread, cotton, etc.  By buying wholesale she can get her merchandise and a lower price.  This will allow her to increase her income in the future.

Rocio is 28 years old and married. She lives with her children and her husband and they're her main priority. With her loan she intends to purchase a sewing machine, which will make it easier for her to manufacture clothing. That way she'll make good use of the knowledge she acquired in the trainings, and she'll be able to get an income in order to keep on investing in the purchase of fabric and other supplies. She'll do better finishing on the garments, and in addition she'll increase the quantity of pieces she makes. With this purchase she intends to manufacture more clothes and therefore meet the orders promptly. This is the first loan she has obtained from FUDECOSUR. She hadn't had any other loans from state-owned banks before. FUDECOSUR has provided the loan with better terms and a much lower interest rate.

Sixto, 53, is married living with his wife who is his greatest priority.  He intends to use his loan to buy fertilizer, fungicide and to pay labor costs to do tobacco crop maintenance in order to take advantage of the good fertility of the soil, the weather and other conditions that are favorable for tobacco growing.  With these improvements, he hopes to earn a bit of profits to improve his family’s living conditions and also to have some to invest more in the crops and to reach some goals.  This is his first Fudecosur loan.  He’s had no previous loans with state banks and Fudecosur offered the best terms and a much lower interest rate.

Emomali lives in the Rudaki region.  He is 30 years old.  He is married.  He has four children.  Emomali has been raising animals for four years.  He raises small horned livestock at his home.  Emomali is taking out a loan to purchase sheep and goats.

Parvina lives in Dushanbe.  She is 29 years old.  Parvina is married.  Parvina's husband is a baker.  He bakes flatbread for sale.  Parvina is a seamstress.  She sews traditional dresses.  Parvina has rich experience in this area.  Today she works at a tailoring studio.  Parvina would like to continue her activity after work at her home.  She is taking out a loan for the purchase of a sewing machine.

Mirzodavlyat lives in the city of Dushanbe.  He is 49 years old.  He is married.  He has two children.  His wife works in her profession.  Mirzodavlyat provides a service.  He is a taxi driver in the city, but most often he works on line number 3.  Mirzodavlyat has been working as a taxi driver for four years.  He is taking out a loan to purchase a new car.

A virtuoso seamstress needs your support. Rafoat is an experienced seamstress who excels at sewing traditional Tajik dresses.\r\nShe is 28 years old. She is divorced and raising a child. In order to support her family, she launched her own business two years ago. Thanks to her good service, she has acquired a large customer base. Her customers are women with a very demanding taste, but Rafoat easily manages to satisfy their whims. She needs a new range of  fabrics,   but her income is insufficient. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500 TJS in order to buy fabric. She is counting on you and your kindness.

Aniceth is a member of the solidarity group DUTERIMBERE KZH. He is married and is 38 years old. He has 4 children. The oldest is 11 years old and the youngest is 4 years old. Three of his children go to school and he has no other dependents.

He was born in Rwanda and his level of education is 8 years of primary school.

He started collaborating with ACB Ltd. in 2012. The current cycle is his first.

With this loan he is going to buy 65 kg of chemical fertilizers, and the rest will pay for manual labor.

He doesn't expect any difficulties repaying the loan.

As a rice farmer, Aniceth has the ambition to be the best rice farmer in the country. For his family, he is going to ensure his children's education as well as their medical care.

Vianney is a member of the solidarity group JYAMBERE--MUHINZI /MRR /BGRM. He is married and is 58 years old. He has 10 children. The oldest is 31 years old and the youngest is 7 years old. Three of his children go to school and he has no other dependents.

He was born in Rwanda and his level of education is 6 years of primary school.

He started collaborating with ACB Ltd. in 2012. The current cycle is his second.

With this loan he is going to buy chemical fertilizers, and the rest will pay for manual labor.

He doesn't expect any difficulties repaying the loan.

As a strategy, he is going to request other loans to grow his farming business. As a rice farmer, Vianny has the ambition to be the best rice farmer in his region. For his family, he is going to ensure his children's education as well as their medical care.

Boniface is a young Cameroonian who is 34 years ago. He has been managing a business selling clothing in a market of the city for 15 years already. He benefits from good experience in this field. With this loan he would like to buy bundles of clothing to strengthen his stock of merchandise in order to better satisfy his clientèle. The income generated will allow him to better meet the needs of his family. His ambition is to open a store.

Graciela, 38, is a cheerful, gracious woman.  She lives in her own house with her spouse, Antonio, who works in civil construction.  They have three children who are 14, 8 and 3 years old and who they want to provide with a good quality of life.  Graciela’s work consists in designing, sewing and selling women’s, men’s and children’s clothes.  She does this work in a space at home and has been doing it for four years.  She comments that she started this activity because she needed a job and a girlfriend taught her to design and dew so that she could go into this line of work.  She considers it to be profitable because firms request her services to make uniforms for their employees.  She also sells her creations in one of the city markets at wholesale.  She hopes in future to open a store in the city market to sell her creations.  She will request a 1,000 sol loan to buy merchandise like fabric, elastic, lace trim and thread to earn higher profits.

Mame Meissa is a married woman who has been progressing in the fishing sector for more than 20 years. She lives in a Senegalese locale and is a member of the branch of the UIMCEC in the same zone. The income that her dugout canoes bring in allows her to take care of her personal needs and also to participate in the management of daily expenses. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 frs for the purchase of another dugout canoe with the goal of growing her income even more. In the future she wishes to become a great promoter of fishing who buys and sells fishing machines and dugout canoes.

Matar lives in Sénégal. He has been employed for more than five years as a watchman in a local hotel. He is a member of one of the branches of the UIMCEC to which he has already reimbursed 4 previous loans. He is married and father to 5 children aged from 2 to 12 years old. He is requesting a loan of 150,000 frs to repair the terrace of his home. His goal is to renovate his home in order to improve the living conditions of his family. In addition he wishes to have a guarding agency in the future.

Osmin lives with his family.  He is a farmer, raises corn and beans, and has been doing this for a number of years.  He has lots of experience that allows him to have better harvests.  In order to pay the household expenses, he also sells fish and tamales when he is not farming.  His farmland is located in a highly agricultural location and he sells all around the community.  He has many customers who prefer to buy from him because of the good quality, prices, and service he offers.\r\n\r\nOsmin is a hardworking man dedicated to his work.  Each day he makes a great effort to get ahead because he knows that this is the way he will succeed the way he wants to.  He wants to take advantage of a new investment during this planting season but he needs capital, so he has requested a loan through INTEGRAL.  This will allow him to buy corn and bean seeds, fertilizer, insecticide, tools, fish, tamales, etc.  Osmin has a good payment history and knows that he can repay this loan and provide his family with a better quality of life.

Nito is 24 years old and in his third year studying animal science at the Instituto Superior Politecnica de Manica (ISPM), an agricultural training college near Chimoio in Mozambique.  His father died in war, his mother is disabled, and he has four brothers and one sister, so he must rely on himself to earn a living and help provide for his family.  Most of his brothers are in the army, but Nito always dreamed of working in agriculture.  \n\nWhen he was unable to get into his local university, Nito started working for the local municipality, but he did not see his life improving.  One day he saw an advertisement to study animal science at ISPM and applied for and was accepted to their three-year scholarship program.  With the loan, Nito will plant 3-5 hectares of maize, soya and cowpeas.  The loan will also pay for the mentorship of a local experienced farmer and weather insurance. He will use the profits to pay for his fourth and final year of university. Nito hopes to be a self-employed farmer and employ other people in the area to help the local economy.

Helder is 23 years old and a second-year student at the Instituto Superior Politecnica de Manica (ISPM), an agricultural training college near Chimoio in Mozambique.  His parents are subsistence farmers and have six sons and two daughters, so they cannot afford to pay for school.  Helder was able to get a scholarship to ISPM for the first two years, but he will need to pay for the final two years.\n\nWith the loan, Helder will plant 3-5 hectares of maize, soya and cowpeas. He hopes to use the profits he earns to pay for his remaining university fees and also to help his family. He sees farming as a good way to make a living and also to help the people in his community by providing them with food. One day, Helder would like to be a self-employed farmer who is known for his good farming skills.

Leonel is 20 years old and in his second year studying animal science at the Instituto Superior Politecnica de Manica (ISPM), an agricultural training college near Chimoio in Mozambique. Leonel is an orphan, has two brothers, and currently lives with his grandmother in Chimoio. He originally wanted to study civil engineering but didn’t have enough money to pay for the courses. He eventually got a scholarship to study agriculture and is now happy, as he enjoys his studies and appreciates the support of the lecturers.\n\nWith the loan, Leonel will plant 6-10 hectares of maize, soya and cowpeas. With the profits he earns, he hopes to pay for his fourth and final year of university, which is not covered by the scholarship, and to also help his grandmother by buying inputs for her small plot of land.  Leonel knows that a university education will help him to develop the skills he needs to be a successful producer. His ambition is to own his own farm and to rear animals.  Leonel dreams big – he wants to be the best producer in his area and to supply the whole country.

Ismael is 20 years old and a second-year student on scholarship at the Instituto Superior Politecnica de Manica (ISPM), an agricultural training college near Chimoio in Mozambique.  Since Ismael was little he grew carrots, cabbage, and fruits and always wanted to study agriculture and learn new techniques. His mother’s side of the family are all farmers, but they are encountering difficulties with aging equipment.\n\nWith the loan, Ismael will plant 6-10 hectares of maize, soya, and cowpeas on part of the university’s farm plot. He hopes to use the profits to pay for his fourth and final year of university, which is not part of the scholarship, and to also develop a small piece of land he currently owns. He wants to eventually have his own agricultural business where he can help people who do not have an education by training them in agriculture.

Mussa is 24 years old and a third-year student at the Instituto Superior Politecnica de Manica (ISPM), an agricultural training college near Chimoio in Mozambique.  Mussa’s widowed mother provides for his two brothers, two sisters, and him through subsistence farming, but she does not make enough money for school fees.  Mussa had always wanted to go to school and originally wanted to study Mathematics, but he was only offered a scholarship for the agriculture program.  He learned quickly, however, that he had talent at farming and could make a good living doing so.  He earned $100 through his first practical experience growing peppers on a small plot.\n\nWith this loan, Mussa will be able to plant 10 hectares of maize, soya, and cowpeas on part of the university’s farm plot.  He plans to use the profits he earns to pay for his fourth and final year of university, which is not covered under the scholarship, and to invest in increasing the area of land he cultivates next year. One day, Mussa hopes to own his own farm and equipment.

Margarita, 46, lives with Marcelino, and together they have 3 children aged 27, 24, and 17.  She lives in a rented home, located in a district of the central jungle.  Margarita is an enterprising woman.  She has had a business selling handicrafts for 20 years, particularly items made from wood, such as serving spoons, cutting boards, trivets, coasters, kitchen utensil holders, and other items made from wood that are used in the kitchen.  Most of the time she works on her own, but she has the support of her partner and children.

"This business is profitable if you sell in large quantities," she says.  Margarita gets her merchandise from a carpentry shop.  She sells her products on Fridays at the same location, and on Saturdays she travels 25 minutes to arrive at a market in another city.  On Sundays, she travels more than 2 hours to get to another community where she has a lot of customers.  She invests about 1,000 Peruvian soles every 15 days, and at this time she wants to invest a bit more so that she can go out to sell in other cities.

Margarita needs your support to invest in merchandise, because these are the months when sales are strong.  This is her second loan with MFP, and she is committed to making her payments on time.  She appreciates working with her communal bank "Rosas y Claveles."  With this loan, she will buy products such as kitchen utensils made of wood to sell in the various surrounding cities.

Dora Alicia, 34, lives with her partner and her children. She works growing corn, beans, and sorghum. She has been working in this sector for many years and this has given her a lot of experience which allows her to have better harvests. The land she works is located in a very agricultural area and very close to her home. She trades in the areas surrounding her community and she has a lot of steady customers who prefer her for the quality, good prices and excellent service.\r\n\r\nDora is an active and energetic woman who is dedicated to her work. She is always looking for alternatives that will open the door to success and she will not give up until she achieves it. In the last planting season, they had some losses and she wants to recover from that. That is why she is applying for a loan from INTEGRAL that will allow her to buy corn, bean, and sorghum seeds, as well as manure, insecticide, herbicide, etc. Dora Alicia has good payment references. She is sure she will be able to pay off the loan and she is also confident that it will give her family a better quality of life.

Retiña is 28 years old and a friendly woman with dreams for the future. She lives in her own house with her partner Miguel, who works driving tractors and  heavy equipment. They have two children, ages 11 and 2. They intend to give them a good education. 

Retiña's work is selling basic household necessities, such as rice, sugar, flour and eggs. She does this work in a shop located in her own home, but also sells her products in communities around the city.

She has been in this business for six years, but when she was 18 she helped her mother run her store, and from there she had the idea of having her own livelihood. Her partner helps her make the purchases for stocking her store and helps serve customers. She says that her work is profitable because she has many customers.

In addition, as she buys at wholesale, she gets good earnings. She says that before beginning this business, she didn't have her own shop, and had to move from place to place. Then she decided to rent an establishment on a very busy street.

In the future she wants to build a well-ordered and comfortable shop, so that she can give better service to her customers and increase her earnings. Therefore, she is applying for 3000 soles which she will use to buy merchandise, which she will do in the capital through her friend who lives there.

Gislaine is the coordinator of her group, Eben ezer 1, 2, 3 4 & 5. She lives in the Ouanaminthe region of Haiti, where electricity is rare and water is very limited. She is single and has no children.\r\n\r\nGislaine has been selling diverse products for the last six years. She would like to use this loan to invest in more products. Other members of the group need a loan to sell food products, charcoal, and cosmetic products. Gislaine says that her dream is to grow her business and have a prosperous business.

Ashobuddin is a resident of the city of Dushanbe.  He is 23 years old, married and has one child.  Ashobuddin lives with his mother and wife.  His wife is a homemaker, and mother is a seamstress.  Ashobuddin is a driver.  Today, he is involved in private transportation.  He provides a taxi service along the route #3 on the central city road.  He has been in this business for five years.  Ashobuddin is requesting this loan to repair his car, primarily to install equipment for natural gas.

Mr. Abdou has been a farmer for twelve years. He lives in a village located about 22 km from the main city. He specializes in truck farming and is seeking a loan to strengthen his business. He is going to buy farming products (diesel oil, fertilizer, manure) for the cultivation of his space. Abdou is married and contributes to the daily expenses. Abdou would like to cultivate other plots if he has the means with the help of IMCEC.

Yulissa is 25 years old and single mother. She has two children: a 3 year old, and a little one who is six months old. She lives in a rented house in a district in the central tropical forest.

Yulissa is an enterprising young woman. For 10 years she has bought and sold eggs, and distributed them to shops and grocery stores. For this, she has a motorcycle which she uses for these deliveries.

A little while ago she had problems carrying out her work as she had given birth to her youngest child. For this reason, her sisters help her with her work. Now that she has more strength, she is continuing with her work.

"The work is profitable. I buy each tray of eggs for 12 soles, and sell it for 16; and if the quantities are greater, the profit increases," she says.

She wishes not only to sell eggs, but also other products. But she needs money to acquire her merchandise. This month is important for egg sales, so she needs support, so as not to let this opportunity pass by. 

This is her third loan with MFP, and she feels happy for the support she has received all this time. In addition she says that her activities with the "Luz y Verdad" communal bank are rewarding because it is a responsible team.

With the money, she will be able to acquire more trays of eggs to deal with her orders, and supply more shops and grocery stores.

Haydar is a resident of the city of Isfara.  He is 41 years old, married and has three children.  Haydar and his wife provide a service.  He owns a bakery, where he bakes flatbread.  Haydar has been in this business for five years.  He is requesting this loan to purchase flour in order to stock up for the winter.

Mavluda is 36 years old, married and a mother of four children.  Currently, she is involved in selling women's clothing at the local Kara-Suu market.  She started her business with 50,000 KGS two years ago.  Mavluda's monthly income amounts to about 20,000-25,000 KGS.  Mavluda's husband works as a driver.  Mavluda has a secondary education and appears to be a very honest and goal-oriented person.  Today, she has a working capital of 150,000 KGS and was able to repair her house and build a temporary place during this time.  She achieved everything thanks to her love of hard work.  In order to further expand her business, she requested a loan in the amount of 120,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to increase goods turnover by purchasing a winter selection of warm clothing.  Mavluda plans to develop her business and increase her family's income in order to provide a normal future for her children.

Muhiddin is a resident of the city of Isfara.  He is 37 years old, married and has three children.  Muhiddin's wife works as a teacher at a university.  Muhiddin is involved in buying and selling dried fruits.  He has been in this business for eight years.  He is requesting this loan to purchase several types of dried fruits in order to get involved in wholesale sales.

Toliba lives in the Spitamen district.  She is 38 years old, married and has three children.  She is involved in animal husbandry.  Toliba has been in this business for fifteen years.  She is requesting this loan to buy bulls in order to increase cattle headcount.

Henri is a young, 28-year-old Cameroonian and a married father of two children, ages 1 – 5. It is worth mentioning that the eldest attends school. Henri is also responsible for two other children who attend school. For work, he has been managing a calling center called Call Box for four years. He is doing well in this domain, which has allowed him to build up a considerable and faithful clientele. He would like to use this loan to buy at wholesale communication credits to avoid breaks in order to be able to satisfy his clientele at any moment. The profits generated will allow him to better meet the needs of his family.

Anara is 50 years old, married and has one son.  To provide a source of income for her family, she became involved in animal husbandry and farming.  The business, started with 2,000 KGS in 1994, now yields about 5,000 som (KGS) per month from sales of milk and meat products and farming.  Today, her business contains six cows.  In order to further develop her business, Anara requested a loan in the amount of 80,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to buy cattle.  She plans to invest the earnings into a further expansion of her business by increasing the quantities of cattle.

Bahodir lives in the city of Khujand.  He is 43 years old, married and has three children.  Bahodir's wife is a seamstress, and his mother is a retiree.  Bahodir is involved in animal husbandry.  He earns a living by breeding cattle.  Bahodir has been in this business for fifteen years.  He is requesting this loan to buy cattle and livestock feed.

Bahridin is involved in animal husbandry.  He breeds cattle at home.  Bahridin primarily buys livestock for subsequent resale.  This time, he is requesting a loan to buy bulls in order to increase livestock headcount.

Mireille is the coordinator of her group, Maranatha de Samarie. She lives in the region of Samarie in Haiti, where electricity is rarely available and the water supply extremely limited. Mireille has been managing a business selling various products for the past seven years. She is married and has a son.\r\n\r\nMireille would like to use this loan to purchase various items such as shoes, cosmetics and cleaning products. Other members of the group need a loan to help with their businesses, in which they sell items such as food products, cosmetics, clothing, shoes and charcoal. Mireille says that her main challenge is to be able to sell more; since the economic crisis in Haiti, there has not been much money.

Cursina is 55 years old. She is single and lives in her daughter's house, located in the central jungle district.

She is a very hardworking woman. For the last 15 years, since her children became independent, Cursina has worked painstakingly in her carpentry workshop. She started out making furniture such as tables, chairs, and dressers. With years of experience, she was able to contract workers to help her to build truck bodies and other bigger pieces of furniture. 

"This business is profitable, even more so for furniture and coachwork, which earn a lot," says the proud owner of her accomplishments. Cursina is very happy to work alongside those she does because she believes they help her to accomplish her goals more easily. Her next goal is to expand her business, which she needs more raw materials to do. That is why she is requesting this loan. Cursina will invest this money to purchase wood from a variety of trees that she uses most often in her work: oak, cedar, walnut, and moena.

This is Cursina's second loan from MFP. She pledges to make her repayments punctually. She is very happy to have their support and the opportunity to belong to the tight-knit communal bank "Rosas y Claveles" (Roses and Carnations).

Fidras is a 27 year-old man who lives Hamadoni. He works in animal husbandry. Fidras mainly breeds cattle, and has been doing this type of work for almost a year. Fidras is requesting a loan to purchase some bulls and calves.

Dilnoza is hardworking and kind woman, because she grew up in a good family. Thanks to her parents, she received a high school education and a good upbringing. She is married and is raising one child. She has loved to sew ever since she was little, and so when she grew up, she became a dressmaker. Dilnoza runs her own business and knows how to sew her own designs. This outstanding dressmaker decided to take her trade into the commercial sphere and earn a living from it. With this goal in mind, she took a course organized by the Association of Businesswomen entitled "Achieve Success", and received a certificate. Now she is fully able to organize her own business and become successful. She wants to organize a dressmaking service, since she has experience in this area. She is going to open her own sewing shop near her home. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 5000 somonis to purchase a sewing machine to start the new business. If the business makes money, she will use it to improve her living conditions. She has big plans for the future, and it is certain that she will become a successful business woman. She awaits your kindness.

Verónica is a young person with great courage to face challenges.  She defines herself as a humble, honest and determined person who loves her only daughter who is 11 years old.  She works with her sister, a young girl, who appears in the snapshot.  Together they look for the way to get ahead and to improve their quality of life.

The loan requested from Fodemi will be employed in the upgrading of the restaurant and in the purchase of products like rice, potatoes and oil that are necessary for the preparation of breakfast, lunch and snacks that Verónica offers her customers.

Verónica’s dream is to have a much larger restaurant with industrial kitchens.  She is conscious that to fulfill her dream is possible but in order to do so she has to work day by day.  The motivation for fulfilling this dream is seeing her daughter grow up.

Djiby, who lives about 22 km from the main city, has been a farmer for more than 10 years. This is a very active young single man who lives off his business. He just opened an account to be able to benefit from a loan which will allow him to buy a ROC brand motor-pump in order to improve his market gardening business. With the income from his business he can support the responsibilities of the home and the daily expenses. His ambition is to buy other motor-pumps within the framework of always maximizing his profits.

Jean Claude is married and is 38 years old. He sells Christian books in a bookstore. He has 4 children. The oldest is 12 years old and the youngest is 4 years old. Three of his children go to school and he has no other dependents.

He was born in Rwanda and his level of education is 3 years of secondary school.

He started collaborating with ACB Ltd. in 2009. The current cycle is his tenth.

With this loan, he is going to increase the quantity that he sells by buying 500 Christian books of different types.

He doesn't expect any difficulties repaying the loan.

As a strategy, he is going to improve his collaboration with churches, which will allow him to sell his books through the churches.

His ambition is to see all the churches as well as their members buy books in his bookstore. For his family, he is going to ensure his children's education as well as their medical care.

Aside from his financed business, Jean Claude is an electrician. He also sells telephones and their accessories.

Tohirjon is married and has four children. He is a person who always tries to earn money in order to provide a better life to his children. Tohirjon began his own business dealing in animal husbandry seven years ago. He has requested a loan in the amount of 500 USD to increase the number of animals he has for sale. He hopes for Kiva's cooperation in this loan since it will be used to improve his family's income.

Manzura is one of the smart members of her family who lives happily but poorly. She is 49 years old and has a lovely husband who went to Russia to find a job. They are bringing up four children. Manzura tries to provide them with a high quality living condition. With this aim, eight years ago she began her own business with selling of ‘kuraga’. She has a garden full of apricot trees. There are more than 70 trees bearing apricots. She collects the apricots, dries them and sells as ‘kuraga’ to local people. \r\n\r\nThe developing side of her business is connected to her harvest. This season she had a small harvest, which is why she wants to buy additional ‘kuraga’ to make full her business assets and continue selling her goods. Her income is small and she can’t do it without additional capital. She is asking for a loan of 500 USD to buy ‘kuraga’ to develop her business. Each month she will make her payment on time. She will be happy for your support.

Muharam is 41 years old, married, and has 2 children. She owns a clothes store, which is based in the local market. Here she sells women's clothes and has a lot of customers as she renews her assortment every season. \r\n\r\nTo improve business, she is borrowing the amount from Imon International organization to buy women's clothes for the new winter season. She’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding her business before long.

Jamol is a hardworking man. He is married and has two children. In order to provide his family with all necessary things, eight years ago he began his own business dealing with farming. He grows onions, wheat and grapes. Also he is a builder and gets enough income. He wants to comfort his family with good living conditions. With this aim he is beginning to repair his house but he doesn't have money to buy paint and other building materials. He is asking for a loan of 400 USD to buy building materials to repair his house. He awaits your support.

Bineta is a single woman who has been doing business for 10 years.  She runs a boutique that sells food products, among other things.  She begins her workday at 7:00am and closes at 12:00am.  Thanks to the profits she earns from her business, she is able to satisfy her own needs and pay the rent for the shop where she does business.\r\n\r\nShe is a member of one of the UIMCEC branches, where she has already repaid six previous loans.  She is asking for a credit of 400,000frs in order to purchase products for resale in her boutique.  Additionally, she hopes to buy school supplies that she will resell since she intends to start diversifying the products that she offers to her clientele; the objective is to best develop her business and to bolster her income.  In the future, she hopes to travel for the purpose of importing merchandise for her business.

Allia is a 49-year-old married woman who has three family members and comes from Sahab, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 500 JD to pay for her home improvements. She wants to repaint her home and to do maintenance on the home. She hopes in the future to buy new furniture.

The Banc Villageois overseeing this group was created on November 19, 2004.  It is made up of 11 members who reside in the same locality and live in good harmony with each other.  They are primarily involved in retail business, in the preparation of meals, and in the fattening of livestock.

Marème is married and the mother of two boys.  She is 26 years old and standing on the right-hand side in the photo, raising her hand.  Her main activity is retail business.  She buys 15 boxes of soap and one bag of soap powder and then resells her goods for retail.  Additionally, she also prepares meals.  She has been involved in this type of activity since 2010.

After replenishing her stock of goods, she uses the rest of her money to strengthen her second business.  Her profits allow her to ensure her family's well-being (children's education, healthcare, food needs) and to increase her savings.

This Banc Villageois was created on November 19, 2004.  It is made up of 21 members who live in the same locality.  They support each other in a spirit of solidarity and they live in good harmony.  Their main activity is retail business, the fattening of livestock and the preparation of meals.

Nael, age 49, is standing on the right-hand side in the photo and raising her hand.  She is married and the mother of nine children (four boys and five girls).  Her main activity is the fattening of cattle.  She is using her loan to buy an ox which she will raise for six months and then resell at a weekly market.  Additionally, Nael prepares meals.  She has been involved in this activity for ten years.  After buying the ox, she will use the rest of her money to buy utensils for her food booth.

Her profits allow her to provide for her family, to contribute to her children's education, and to increase her savings.

Afaf is a 30-year-old married woman from Jarash, Jordan, who has three family members. She is requesting a loan of 400 JD to buy women's and children's clothes to sell to her friends and neighbors in the area. She wants to expand her business. She also wants to open a shop to increase her income.

Dua'a is a 22-year-old married woman from Nao'or, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 500 JD to buy materials for making  bread to sell in the same neighborhood. She wants to increase her products. She hopes in the future to expand her project. \nSince Dua'a is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

The 'banc villageois' that houses this group was created on December 28, 2009. It comprises 48 members who live in the same town. These members maintain good relationships and mutually support one another. 

Aminata, 34 years old, is standing at the right with her hand raised in the photo. She is a married mother of five children (2 boys and 3 girls). With this loan, she intends to bolster her shop. She is purchasing 10 bags of powdered milk and 2 bags of powdered sugar that she is going to sell retail. She is also purchasing a barrel of millet for 20,000 francs to make 'thiacri' which she is going to sell.

With the profits, she helps to care for the children and improve day-to-day family life. The profits will also enable her to pay the loan interest and to grow her savings.

This group was created the December 28, 2009. It is composed of members who all live in the same area. Solidarity and mutual support prevail in their neighborhood. 

Rockhaya, standing on the right side of the photo with her hand raised, is 55 years old and married. She is the mother of 5 children, 2 boys and 3 girls. 

Rockhaya is a tanner. With this loan, she hopes to buy sheep, goat, or cow skins (1,500 skins per month a 500 francs each) that she will tan and then sell to shoemakers. 

With the profits, she will improve the life of her family and pay for her children's schooling and their clothing. The profits will also allow her to pay the interest [on the loan] and increase her savings.

This group was created on December 21, 2009. It is composed of 33 women, who enjoy very good relations with one another.

Coudy, aged 51, is standing to the right and raising her hand in the picture. She is married and a mother of five children, three boys and two girls. Her main business is the retail of fritters. Her new loan will allow her to buy flower, oil and other ingredients to prepare fritters, which she resells in her village. 

Profits will allow her to improve her family’s living conditions and to send her children to school.

This group was created on December 21, 2009. The 48 members composing it live in the same district and get along very well together. 

Dieynaba, 39 years old, is standing at the right with her hand raised in the photo. She is a married mother of seven children. Her main work involves commerce. She sells bread, black-eyed peas, millet, and peanuts. She also has a parallel business, namely the fattening of sheep. She is purchasing two head of sheep to raise and then resell. 

With the profits earned, she envisions sending her children to middle school and supporting their well-being.

This group was created on December 21. 2009. The majority of its members live in the same district  and maintain good relations.

Dambo, 51 years old, is standing at the right with her hand raised in the photo. She is a married mother of seven children. Her main work involves fattening animals (cattle, sheep, and goats). She has been in this business for years. With her loan, she intends to purchase a steer that she will raise and then resell a few months from now. 

The profits earned will enable her to help out her husband to cover domestic expenses; and also, she plans on purchasing a mill or grinder.

This group, in existence since May 17, 1997, is composed of individuals living in the same village or nearby. They have a good rapport, maintaining friendly relations and supporting each others. Their main line of work is raising livestock and vending.

Amy, 38 years old (the one standing on the right raising her hand in the photo), is married and mother of six: four sons and two daughters. She also has one other child in her care. Her main line of work is raising sheep. She has completed three cycles already.

With this loan, she [will] buy one calf to raise and, once it reaches maturity, to sell at the weekly market. She will also buy a sheep to fatten and resale. She will use the remainder of the funds for her  work as a vendor, an additional business activity. After paying off her loan, she will have a profit allowing her to take care of her children, repair her house and contribute to everyday family expenses.

This group was created on December 28, 2009. The 27 members live for the most part in the same district, and they get along well. Most of them have small businesses.

Faty, 22 years old, is standing at the right with her hand raised in the photo. She is married and without children. Her main work involves commerce. With this loan, she intends to work in small-scale commerce.  She is buying some clothing accessories for men, women, and children that she resells. She gets her supplies  from the big cities where she can find a dozen dresses for children at 2,500 francs each and 8 pairs of shoes at 3,000 francs a pair.

With the profits, she plans to increase her capital, so as to prepare for her next loan.

This group was created on December 28, 2009. It is composed of members from the same district who maintain very good relations. Their main work involves commerce. 

Khady, 59 years old, is standing at the right with her hand raised in the photo. She is a married mother of one child, who is 20 years old. Khady's main work involves commerce. With this loan, she intends to purchase shoes for children and adults. She is purchasing 20 pairs of adult shoes at 1,500 francs a pair and 15 pairs of children's shoes at 900 francs a pair.

With the profits, she plans to increase her savings to fend off certain eventualities and also to meet the needs of her family.

This group was created on the 10th of October, 2012, with a membership of 35 women. They live in the same area and have good neighbourly relationships. Their main business is the retail of various products.

Adèle is the group's featured borrower. She is the one standing on the right of the picture with her hand raised. She is 57 years old, married and the mother of 2 boys. She also has an adopted daughter in her charge.

Adèle plans to buy a quantity of myrrh worth 45 000 francs (50 litres at 900 francs per litre) and pay 5 000 francs for the transportation to Dakar. She will resell it at 2 500 francs per litre. She plans to use the profits generated by her business to help her husband take care of the children's education, health and food expenses.

This Banc Villageois was created on December 3, 2007.  It is made up of 36 members who live in the same locality and get along well with each other.

The group's leader, Fatimata Ousmane, is a 64-year-old married woman.  She takes care of one of her children, as well as five other children.  

Fatimata Ousmane is involved in small retail business.  She sells groundnut, beans, millet etc..  She stocks up at the Guéoul market on Mondays and Thursdays.  In the photo, she is standing on the right-hand side, raising her left hand.

With her loan, she will buy various goods, which will help her to boost her profits.  She will also purchase a sheep for fattening up.

She uses her profits to support her husband in taking care of the family expenses.  Thanks to her profits, she also saves some money and hopes to reach financial autonomy.

This group was created on the 4th of December, 2007. It is made up of women who come from different parts of town but who are united by affinity, friendship and trust. Their businesses include retail, sewing services and livestock breeding. The PC group is made up of 17 women.

Emilie is 41 years old, married and the mother of 4 children (one boy and 3 girls). She sells second-hand clothing and shea butter, and benefits from several years of good experience. She is standing on the right of the picture.

Emilie's loan will enable her to satisfy her clientèle and to earn a large income. She uses the profits she makes to help her husband take care of the family's education and health. She also builds up her savings and covers her own small needs.

The Banc Villageois (Village Lending Group) that houses this group was started on November 19, 2004. It is made up of six members living in the same area who get along. Their principal activities are sales, livestock fattening, and food service.\r\nOumy, 37 years old, standing up at the right of the photo and raising her hand, is married and mother of 7 children (2 boys and 5 girls). She runs her store where she sells general grocery products. She has been in this business since 1996. The loan will allow her to replenish her store by buying new products. Concurrent with running this business, she practices pork fattening. With the remainder of the money, she will buy pigs which she will raise up to five months and resell them at the market.\r\nThe profits generated will be used for her children's education and the family's well-being.

This group was created on December 3, 2007. It is made up of women who live in the same village and its environs. As a business, they mainly sell clothing. Anta, 37 years old, is married and mother of six children (four boys and two girls). She is standing up in the photo and raising her left hand. WIth the loan, she counts on buying clothing that she will resell to customers in the nearby villages. She works selling cowpeas and beans and has been in this business for six years. The profits will allow her to take care of her family since her husband is in Italy.

The Banc Villageois (Village Lending Group) that houses this group was founded on September 28, 2012. It is made up of 27 women from the same area who work mainly in sales, agriculture and livestock fattening; the group PC 1 is made up of 27 women.
The featured borrower Madame Nafi is a 44 year old married woman. She is the mother of eight children, the youngest of whom is eight. She also has a granddaughter who is three years old. She is the house mother at the outpost health clinic in the village and she has several years of experience. She  practices sheep fattening concurrently. Standing up at the right of the photo, she is dressed in white and yellow flowers and is raising her left hand. 
With her loan, Nafi counts on buying two sheep for fattening and hopes to resell them four or five months later to prepare for her repayment.
She participates in the family spending (school fees, clothing, food, health) to support her husband.

The Sop Serigne Bara group was inaugurated on the 21st of September, 2012. It is made up of 50 women who come from the same area and whose main businesses include retail, restaurants, livestock breeding, sewing, crochet and embroidery services.\r\n\r\nKhoudia, the group leader, is 30 years old. She is married and the mother of 4 children (2 boys and 2 girls). She sells black-eyed peas and also works as a health advisor in the local health centre. She has a good experience in her line of work, which she has been doing for a long time. She is standing on the right of the picture with her left hand raised. Her loan will be used to buy black-eyed peas, a business which generates a lot of revenue for her. The profits she makes allow her to be self-sufficient and to build some savings with the banc villageois.

This group was inaugurated on the 28th of September, 2012. It brings together 35 women who are united by bonds of friendship and live in the same village. They have various businesses; retail, crafts and livestock breeding.\r\n\r\nMariama, the group leader, is 39 years old. She is married and the mother of 3 male children.
